From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon May  1 01:38:56 1995

Date: Mon, 1 May 1995 01:37:19 -0700
In-Reply-To: peterf@netcom.com (Peter Fogel)
        "Re: Public Newpaper Post, of Our SFR Calendar /Opinion" (Apr 30, 10:31am)
References: <199504301731.KAA11321@netcom2.netcom.com>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.0 06sep94)

Subject: Re: Public Newpaper Post, of Our SFR Calendar /Opinion
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

There needs to be a distinction between "media" and "public" distribution.
Public distribution of event information via sf-raves or otherwise means
increasingly broad availability -- and in general that's desirable,
whether it means people getting accounts on sf-raves or just the weekly
list, or seeing the list in some public place like on the counter at
Ameba, or on someone's refrigerator door.  That kind of public distribution
maintains the personal links that also provide the context for events
and to get to know this scene as something of a (fractured and disorganized)
community rather than just another commodity-offering operation the way
the commercial music business is.

Going to *media* based distribution means, inevitably, stripping out the
context and the personal connections in order to conform to the very 
narrow bandwidth limits and selection criteria used by the mass media.
Were we ecstatically happy when ambient music suddenly got a big spread
in the Chron recently, complete with nice photos and a listing of various
events?  Not entirely, I'd say.  Yet, the Gardening Club was not overrun
with the clueless hordes, because in fact most of this is still at the
myth stage for most people -- how many times do we hear from those who
clearly consider themselves well informed that raves are *only* about
taking drugs and loud poundy music?  Some people will see those public
listings and will be ready to jump in and try it out, and those people
*will* show up at the Gardening Club (to reiterate my example) and 
actually jump in fairly well.

As the Web becomes more of an everyday resource for things like event
listings, the distinction I'm making here between "public" and "media"
is gradually going to fade.  That could actually be a good development
since the linkage between the "resource" function that people rely on
from newspaper (media) listings would then re-merge with the cultural
connections we would like to make to those who are interested in
learning about and participating in what we're already involved with.

I can testify to the benefits of that approach, since the sf-raves
calendar has *always* fulfilled both functions for me.  

c u
phred

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon May  1 01:51:28 1995

Precedence: bulk

One bit more.  I think our scene *needs* new blood and fresh energy.
In some ways, we have a unique opportunity to help that happen.
It's always a risk going to a wider distribution of information.  For
good reasons we don't trust the mainstream media because at least with
regard to our scene(s) they have fundamentally violated the social
contract between journalism and the general public, which is to report
the truth.  Instead, they have as a whole selectively chosen a
deliberately provocative (and thus salable) interpretation of "rave"
by focusing on only the most superficial elements.  In some ways this
has provided a protective cocoon around a fragile developing new
cultural style, because a lot of the glory-seekers and trendmongers
have stayed away (not all of them, unfortunately).  On the other hand,
it's isolated us in a cultural bubble that we are beginning to become
quite frustrated with.  At least in my personal observation, subject
to the usual caveats about speculation being the inaccurate scaling-up
of casual observation!

So anyway, my point . . . The explosion of interest in the Web and the
Net offers an interesting opportunity to promote better events and a
better "subculture" for lack of a better term than we are currently
seeing.  Our own DIY events convince me of the value of that.  It's
not like *we* have to do all the cool events, nosirreebob, that's too
much dang work.  It's more like expressing our views about what we *do*
like and help inform and shape the expectations not only of those who
are already dialed in to the net-music thing, but those who haven't
yet made the connection but are leaping through all the new doorways
opening up onto the net.  It's a bit scary in a way because it will
change *us* too, so I will simply mention my own sense that PLUR can
be transmitted over TCP/IP :)

phred

        "RE:mix tapes(legality/morality)" (May  1,  2:49am)

X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.0 06sep94)

Precedence: bulk

I appreciated Lydia's post because it's clear she's had to deal with both
sides of the copyright issue.  In fact, I was just talking with some
friends of mine from Germany (they are called Station Rose, and will be
back in SF to perform this fall I hope).  They have a new CD-Plus
interactive CD-ROM coming out in a few weeks, so I asked them what they
thought of the prospect of people *easily* being able to sample both
the audio and video off their release.  "Basically, we don't mind,"
they said, although I think they would want some type of compensation
if someone used their material for seriously commercial purposes.
When you can not only easily copy an audiotape but an entire multimedia
presentation, using an ordinary home computer that now comes complete
with CD-ROM, multimedia card and speakers for $1500 or less, that is
a serious undermining of the way the copyright law has traditionally
worked.

My own take on it is that a radical rethinking of the situation is
needed.  People don't use ASCAP and BMI unless they have little choiced
(say if you are a public business like a bar where you pay ASCAP/BMI
fees for more than minimal use of copyrighted music).  But it is NOT
easy, convenient or cheap, even for them.  For the rest of us, it is
difficult, way expensive and prohibitively stupid.  

We need an online copyright collective that would provide direct payment
from consumers to creative producers, and cut out the middle-bullshit
that has grown huge and ugly stripping the value off of artistic
creation and lifting the wallets of people who would like to enjoy
music or art or writing or whatever.  Think of that next time you
wonder why CD prices are so damn high.  

For the first time in this century we have a chance to think about,
talk about and almost certainly eventually take part in moving
copyright questions into alignment with modern technology and
re-balancing the relationship between creators, distributors and
consumers of cultural work.  The only question is whether Hollywood
Babylon will reinvent itself on the net, developing institutional
relationships that cheat both the artist and the audience.

phred

All the comments made so far on this thread have struck me as valid, and the
positive possibilities of providing a more public presence (I didn't do that
on purpose, honest), are perhaps worth the risks.

It hasn't been mentioned that some people will probably request that their
parties not be mentioned if it is known that the calendar is going to be in
a newspaper. 

The issues surrounding cavalier use of audio and video samples, as well as
some other things, definitely create the need for real underground events.
On the other hand, such events don't have to be 'raves'.

I have mixed feelings about 'bootlegging' software, music and video.
In 'Dave's Perfect World' all distribution of the above would be done
through networks, any DJ or artist that used someone else's stuff would
send THE ARTIST, not the record company $0.50 or so for each use. The 
accounting would be done via software (your set list could add an entry
to a package that would let you send a check to every artist you appreciated
at the end of the year). No record companies. Party play would supplant air
play to promote new music (except for college radio, :) 

It is my perception that the main force driving the economics of house music
are DJ purchases of vinyl. Comments?

-Dave i.

became involved in the rave scene and it grew quickly -- in fact, many of
those on this list became involved then.

in the vibe rather than a drunken meat market.

for the first time has changed.

Any ideas on why this is so?  (or not so, if you demur)

You asked about what the rave scene could be like in 5 to 10 years? I think 
we will be full body electric- As 3D real time environments enter the net we 
should see online clubs/spaces blossom  all around us. At first the spaces 
will allow us to gather and listen to broadcasted soundtracks with text 
command interfaces. Then as they progress we should be able to take on 
virtual presence and even dance in these spaces.

Yeah, I think I know what your thinking, get out of the house buddy- But 
think of the possibilities The environments could always be changing and 
the people that visit them may even be global! The covert feeling that 
the 1920's clubs and Rave has given us will not perish it may just change 
it's sound and move further out digitally! 

Call me crazy-

What do I want the San Francisco rave scene to be like in 5 to 10 years?

That is a very difficult and easy question to answer.  Difficult in that 
the scene has changed alot since it began. It is always changing, it 
seems.  So many complain bitterly because "it ain't what it used to be."  
Well, change is the only constant - it's how you *deal* with the change 
that makes a difference.  Who knows what the scene will be like in 5 to 
10 years.  The music and attitude are a reflection of what is happening 
in the world at that time and what people *want* out of their scene.  
That could change drastically for all I know. We have no way of knowing.

The part that is easy to answer in what I want out of the scene in 5 to 
10 years is that I still want that incredible music, wonderful people and 
most of all - that Peace, Love, Unity, and Respect.  I still get that 
today, even if the rave scene is quite different than from when it 
began.  It is all what you (as in everybody involved) decide to make of 
it.  There is my 2 cents for the evening.:)

love,
Amy

Hello everybody,

Well I went to "stuwmpy stuwmp" (=)
and thought the music was really good.
The crowd could have been a little more energetic out there, but who cares
I was havin a great time dancing.  I went to "Diverse City Music for the
Future Generation" before Stompy stomp, and introduced my self to Ethan
while he was spinning a very good set.  The dance floor was basically empty
@ the time I went, which was early, but I wanted to hear Ethans set so I
went out and danced. A little later I went up stairs to listen to the dj up
there which was I believe "Ocean" I sat down for a while on the beanbags
with my eyes closed and enjoyed.  My friends I went with were getting a
little antsy So we left to go to Stompy stomp.  $12 the goon @ the door
says.  So I go in and pay and to my suprise there were alot of people there
and the music was wonderful I think it was Jeno.  As Willis Wong was saying
the visuals were "Whoa momma!".  I danced for so long that My friends
wanted to leave and I didn't.  I've got to remind myself to drive by my
self or find someone from the list to go with so I know I wont have to
leave any time soon when having so much fun.  The only thing bad about this
venue was the door thugs.  They were straight-up richards(DICKS).

ME:(To either Jason(Spun) or Jasons brother) "Is there ins and outs?"
Jasonorbro: "Ask the door men"
Me: "Is there ins and outs?"
Dick: "WAIT... I sad WAIT!"
Finally get my hand stamped with newly bought water bottle in hand....
Started to walk back in and,
DICK: Takes my water bottle out of my back pocket!
ME: "I just walked out my friends to there car right in front of you!"
DICK: "NOPE!"
ME: "BUT..."
DICK: "I fucking sayed NO!"
ME: "What ever, so can I drink my water out here?!"
DICK: "BEHIND THE RAIL"
ME: "Whatever...DICK!"
And walked back in to have 5 people ask me for a hand stamp.

Whats up with the goons at the door folks.  They could be a little more
gental.  Not everybody who walks through those doors is going to give them
throuble.  But other than that I had a BLAST.  Wish I could've met some
people from the list there.

Well that was my weekend, I'll be going out this coming weekend again
so if theres anybody out there that lives in San Jose and needs a ride or
wants to meet up and have dinner before a good night e-mail.

Hope everybody had a safe and wonderful weekend.

-=Siphon=-

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Sat, 29 Apr 1995 10:00:45 -0400
From: 3505mabd@vm1.ulaval.c
Subject: The Second Bomb of Oklahoma City

 An article by a middleastern journalist
-------------------------------------------
 The Second Bomb of Oklahoma City
 
 When I first heard the news about the Oklahoma City bombing and the
 children who were killed in the day care center, I couldn't help but to
 remember the children I used to work with when I worked at a day care
 center back when I was in college.  I remembered how innocent and pure
 were the children and how different they were from the society outside.
 The children at that day center, just like children all over the world,
 did not hate.  They were too young to understand the hatred, bigotry,
 sexism and racism of their parents, society and culture.  I took refuge
 in that day care center even when I didn't have to work.  That day care
 center became my shelter from the ugly world of grown ups outside of it.
 It also gave me hope for the future.  Hope that some of the children
 will keep their innocence and purity as they grow up.  For me that meant
 that there will always be hope as long as there are children out there.
 When I heard that someone out there killed that hope in Oklahoma City I
 was overwhelmed with grieve for the families who lost their loved ones
 and for all of us who witnessed another blow to humanity.
 
 My grief for the children, their families and for all of us was
 interrupted by waves and waves of hatred and racism that came through the
 media reports about the Bomb.  I spent Wednesday and Thursday listening to
 people saying that my mother, who gave birth to me and to my sister, does
 not "value life as we (Americans) do."  As for my father, who spend his
 time in hospitals trying to help people as a doctor, the "experts" were
 telling the American people that he is an "animal" who does not "deserve
 to live."  I heard politicians saying that my nieces Zaina (9 years old)
 and Alia (2 years old) "need to be punished severely."  Even my sadness
 was interpreted as "crocodile tears" and I was told that "people like me"
 are not worthy to grieve for "people like us (Americans)."  My only fault,
 and my family's only fault, was that we did not grow up watching baseball
 games and eating apple pies.  We are Arabs and that was enough reason for
 the media, the "experts," the politicians and the people of this country
 to blame us for the Oklahoma City bombing and then hate us for it!
 
 Well,
 
 surprise!!
 
 WE DID NOT DO IT.
 
 Sorry, said the media, the "experts," the politicians and the American people:
 We are sorry because we wanted to "ship you back to where you came from."
 We are sorry because we wanted to put you in concentration camps.
 We are sorry because we wanted to bomb your homeland.
 We are sorry because we doubted your humanity.
 
 Well,
 
 surprise!!
 
 THAT IS NOT GOOD ENOUGH.
 
 It is not enough because the feelings, the hatred and the racism,
 expressed in the media on Wednesday and on Thursday were not that different
 from the views of the people who the FBI believes are behind the
 bombing.  Yet, we are told by the media, the "experts" and the politicians
 that the Oklahoma City bombing is an "individual" and "crazy" act.  Even
 when the hatred expressed by these "individuals crazy" act is the same hatred
 we heard on Wednesday and on Thursday coming out from the media, the
 "experts," the politicians and the American people.  That is very
 alarming.  This country and all the people of this country need help.
 There is no need for more anti-terrorist's laws.  There is no need for
 more prisons and law enforcement agencies.  What this country and the
 people of this country need is a deep look inside a system that is built
 on hatred and racism.  What this country needs is an overhaul of the
 politicians, the media and the "experts" that spread hate all over.  It
 is not the Arabs and Muslims who need the apologies.  It is this country
 and the people of this country that need the apologies.  The media, the
 "experts" and the politicians need to apologize because they built a
 country full of hate and racism and the future for a country with so much
 hate and racism in it is bleak.  Take a look at Nazi Germany and learn.
 
 The Arabs and Muslims in this country and in the world need to be
 understood and respected, just like all the people and cultures of the
 world.  We all value life and the lives of our children.  If the media,
 the "experts" and the politicians are trying to monopolize humanity for
 "people like us," then they are wrong and must be stopped.  There is no
 difference between a mother in Rwanda who traveled 100s of miles on foot
 to find a safe place for her children and a mother in Oklahoma City
 spending extra time telling a bed time story to here kids.  The Iraqi
 parent who came out of a bombed shelter holding his dead son in his hands
 is not different from the fire fighter who carried the dead child out of
 the Oklahoma City federal building.  The tears that Lebanese mothers,
 Israeli mothers, Palestinians mothers, Bosnian mothers, Angolan mothers,
 Guatemalan mothers, Nicaraguan mothers, Sri Lankan mothers and mothers
 all over the world drop out of sadness and fear for their children are
 not different from the tears we are hearing from the mothers in Oklahoma
 City.  Let that be the lesson of Oklahoma City terrorist attack so we can
 put out the racist and hatred bomb that exploded afterwards.

On Mon, 1 May 1995 Stcavelti@aol.com wrote:

> Anyone interested can Email me privately and I can send them info that BMI
> sends me regularly). I believe that most nightclubs do pay this fee but

If you could, that would be cool...

> know. The first post regarding mix tapes mentioned the fact that song credits
> are rarely included. I feel this is a shame for two good reasons. The first

I totally agree.  When I look at DJ mixes, I would love to know the 
artists for that reason: so that I can go out and get their original 
stuff.  We all know that at this time any recording of a cd or record is 
going to lose its quality after repeated playing, but the original can 
last for a lot longer.

For this reason, I don't feel bad about making mixes and such, because 
the people that I make the mixes for either wouldn't get the music 
themselves anyway, or would want the original, and might well go out and 
buy it since I tell them the artist.  Of course, this is going on the 
assumption (a good one, of course) that they like the music I give them :).

When shopping for mixtapes, I usually look for the ones with song lists, 
and as most don't have them, I don't get tapes all that often.  It kinda 
sucks, and I bet a lot of people feel this way.

On Mon, 1 May 1995, Fred Heutte wrote:

> needed.  People don't use ASCAP and BMI unless they have little choiced
> (say if you are a public business like a bar where you pay ASCAP/BMI
> fees for more than minimal use of copyrighted music).  But it is NOT

I have a friend who works in a cafe that is just becoming more 
corporation-like (Spinelli's, if anyone's interested, a very cool and PC 
company), and unfortunately, in order to protect themselves from record 
companies or whoever from suing, they don't allow the employees to play 
their own music, which used to consist of dubbed tapes and originals.  IT 
sucks, because now they're stuck with this music service that gives them 
8 tapes a month, which are rarely completely loved by anyone.  They now 
feel like having music that they feel neutral about is better than no 
music.  And their feelings about working suffer, because they can't 
listen to exactly what they want.  I'm sure everyone out there has had 
the experience of being able to listen to your own music while you work a 
boring monotonous job vs. listening to crappy music or no music at all.  
It's a big difference.

I can almost understand why companies wouldn't want people giving their 
friends copies of their albums.  It makes sense.  But not allowing them 
to listen to music unless they pay royalties in a work place is 
preposterous.  It almost smacks of an infringement of the first 
amendment.  Owning information????  Geeze.  It touches a lot of topics.

JesusChrysler

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon May  1 19:29:52 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id TAA20843; Mon, 1 May 1995 19:29:52 -0700
Received: from coyote.rain.org by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id TAA20822; Mon, 1 May 1995 19:29:33 -0700
From: bliss@rain.org
Received: from 198.68.144.126 by coyote.rain.org(8.6.10/RAIN-1.0) with id TAA12527 SMTP
	  for <sfraves@hyperreal.com> on Mon, 1 May 1995 19:24:35 -0700
Date: Mon, 1 May 1995 19:24:35 -0700
Message-Id: <199505020224.TAA12527@coyote.rain.org>
Subject: some happy memories
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
X-Mailer: AIR Mail 3.X (SPRY, Inc.)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Love anais writes:
>We have the oportunity to introduce people that we meet in the "mainstream 
>world" to this community as others have, who may appreciate and promote our 
>values.  We have an opportunity and to some degree an obligation, to take 
>what we have out there and find a way to integrate it into our mainstream 
>lives.  those who understand, are interested, or relate, should be invited 
>to join us and they will in turn bring people who have responded to them in 
>the same manner.

>We are all wonderful people.  I would like to see us evolve in a manner that 
>promotes and rewards this.

I was thinking about this post that my girlfriend wrote and the positive 
responses that she received (thanks Bradley and Nomad) and I was touched by 
some very positive memories that I thought I'd share with any of you who don't 
mind reading a moderately long post.

As I was wondering aimlesly around the enormous warehouse at the first 
"Vision" :) :O ;), I encountered an astonishing number of friends from many 
tribes whose first words to me were "Bliss, meet [insert name here]. This is 
his/her first rave, and we want to show him/her what a truly beautiful and 
positve experience it is".  

Every one of these wonderful new people was nothing less than awe stricken by 
the freindliness and honesty of the people they had met (not to mention the 
awesome music, lazers, and visual experience).  They said things like "WOW!!! 
I didn't know there would be so many cool people" and "This isn't the shit you 
hear about in the news."

I'm sure I can honestly say that every one of these new faces had a smile on 
it at the end of the night and for many days afterward, and many of them went 
on to introduce their closest freinds to the profound enlightening experience 
that we all know and love.

I think that this is the best way for new people to enter our world.  No one 
needs to be taught how to "Rave" because that is something that is undefinable 
and simply comes naturaly, and differently I might add, to most anyone who 
joins us.  I do think that it is important though, for us to guide newcomers 
in such a way as to point out the positivity, honesty, sincerity, of the 
people involved in RC, and to help these newcomers have the most positive 
experience possible.  

It was at this same party that I was sitting off in a corner by myself, as I 
often do several times during the course of a good rave, watching the dancers, 
the lazers, taking in the music and the vibe, breathing :), enjoying the 
feeling of the e that I have taken, and reflecting on the beauty of it all.  
While I was doing this, I guy I did not know came up to me and introduce 
himself as Arty.  He asked me how I was in that "yes I really care" raver way, 
and asked if it was my first rave.  I explained to him that I had been raving 
for a couple of years and that this particular party was so good that it did 
indeed feel like the first time.  We had a fabulous conversation and in our 
excitement he suddenly said "let me introduce you to my FAMILY!!!"

Arty introduced me to Larry, Chelsea, Veronica, Dei, Dave, Steve, Joe, and 
Joe's mom Anne.  They were all from San Jose and are some of the finest people 
I have met raving.  I spent the rest of the night with my new freinds and at 
every rave I went to afterward I always sought out the San Jose Posee, and 
they were allways glad to see me and I them.

This to me is the true spirit of the Rave.  That selfless positivity that we 
bestow opon each other.  The warm smile given and returned.  The "How are 
You", asked and answered honestly.  The KNOWLEDGE, that PEOPLE really do CARE. 
 I will gladly share this world with all of you.

A rave is not a PLACE with MUSIC where people gather to dance.  A rave is a 
GATHERING of PEOPLE, dancing in a place with music.

Love you all
Bliss


          Mmmmmmmmmm Biddle Biddle Biddle Biddle...:):):) say it, it's fun

Dear All;

	The tone of this letter is happy, grateful, a little rightous, 
and with a tad of concern and should be read that way, thanks nuff said.

	A fantastic amount of good clear information, thanks. One of the
reasons I did this, was to make the promoters who are on this mailing list
more aware of what we want our scene to be and become. Unfortuately when
it comes down to whether raves become more commerial or not, we will be
the last thing the majority of the promoters consider, it will be more like
how much money can we make by doing this. But at least their on notice now
about what we would like to see and have happen. Please note, that I'm not 
saying that all of our promoters are like this. Ethan of F&F really cares 
about our scene, and works very hard at tring to make what we want 
happen, and I'm sure there are others as well, I just haven't met them yet.

	Raves cost money, there's insurance to buy, permits, halls to rent, 
sound system, security, and plus a lot of risk ...etc. People need to get 
paid for their services & time that are necessary for us to have a party.
Some of the biggest complaints I hear are things like not providing a 
clean, free water supply, first aid not being consitant, dirty venues 
..etc. I feel that if someone performs a service for you that they need 
to get compensated for it, whether it be a trade, cash, whatever. But I 
feel that sometimes excessive profits are made, at our risk and expense.

	I feel that we as a group of kind people need to make our desires 
known, to set boundries with our promoters. Like saying that we refuse to 
support a event thats not going to provide people with a free, clean 
source of water, and stick by our guns. The water issue is really an 
important one, becasue summer is not far away(YEAH)!!!, and I don't like 
having to do 1st aid on people with dehyration or heat prosration when it 
could have been avoided, and wasn't because of someones greed & selfishness.

	I just hope that the promoters on this list have heard what we 
have said, and will continue to say, and do something to make our(promoters 
included) vision happen. I hope these couple of posts brought some 
awareness into your lives :).

	    Peace, Love & Thanks From Across Cyberspace
		 a.k.a Brian Darkness, LMT/BSEE/CET
		(510)-547-5984 CT Active Voice & Fax
		   (510)-885-5387 CT Active Pager

		Internet:	brianv@liberty.com
		Alt. Internet:	brianvan@liberty.com

		  "Come see the world in my eyes"

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon May  1 20:54:00 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id UAA26050; Mon, 1 May 1995 20:54:00 -0700

Date: Mon, 1 May 1995 20:49:00 -0700
Message-Id: <199505020349.UAA24955@coyote.rain.org>
Subject: RE:mix tapes(legality/morality)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
X-Mailer: AIR Mail 3.X (SPRY, Inc.)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Lydia wrights:

>The first post regarding mix tapes mentioned the fact that song credits are 
>rarely included.  I feel this is a shame for two good reasons.  The first is 
>that if I lake an artist I hear on a mix tape I would lave to go out and buy 
>their CD therefore indirectly supporting the artist with publishing 
>royalties.  The second reason is that if there are no credits, the artist 
>doesn't even get any recognition for the affspring he worked so hard to 
>create and was so proud of.

I agree with Lydia that DJs should provide a track listing with their mix 
tapes.  I always wish that I could go out and purchase the music I hear on my 
favorite tapes.  I am a DJ myself and I create mix tapes.  When I do, I always 
include a track listing.  I do not sell my mix tapes (mostly because I am not 
a well known professional DJ), I give my mix tapes away to my people who 
appreciate them. Even though I do not make money from these tapes I still try 
to provide a track listing because I feel that the people who made the music 
deserve credit.

In effect a track listing provides advertisement to the artists.  Consider 
this:  If a DJ mixes a great tape that everybody loves and he provides a track 
listing, then other DJs will go out and buy the 12" vinyl, other listeners 
will go out and buy the CD, and the DJ who mixed the tape will have 
effectively helped the artist to sell his/her product.

I think that this advertisement is probably far more valuable to the artist 
than the collection of royalties from the mixed tape which probably doesn't 
sell enough copies to justify the administrative expense of collecting 
royalties anyway.  I could see the price of a mixed tape rising to $30 or $40 
just to cover the cost of the paperwork involved.  This may be my lack of 
experience speaking so I would be interested to hear others opinions on this.

Also, I can't tell you the number of hours I've spent in BPM and other stores 
listening to dozens of records only to find one or two that really move me, 
and every so often finding that one mythical 12" that i've been looking for 
for years.  If only the DJs had track listings with their tapes I might be 
able to find all of those records i've been looking for.  I would be happy at 
my turntables and the artists would have money in their pockets.  I would not 
be so boldly uncreative as to play the same mix as the DJ who mixed the tape 
from which I heard the records, so the DJ's creativity would not be 
compromised either.  

I don't think that true creativity is something you can steal.
Imitation is the sincerest form of flatery.

just a few thoughts.  :)
Bliss

Subject: copyright/royalty controversy
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

On 5/1 Jesus Chrysler wrote:
"I can almost understand why companies wouldn't want people giving their 
friends copies of their albums.  It makes sense.  But not allowing them 
to listen to music unless they pay royalties in a work place is 
preposterous.  It almost smacks of an infringement of the first 
amendment.  Owning information????  Geeze.  It touches a lot of topics."

I'm glad you're interested in finding out more about the copyright/royaty
issue. What I will send you might help you to understand why most songwriters
are against legislation which would take away their basic property rights.
There are two sides to the workplace issue. The employee would just like to
listen to music that he/she enjoys to help get through the day. On the other
hand alot of these businesses owe a certain amount of credit to the music
which helps create the ambience in an establishment (e.g. restaurants,
nightclubs, taverns, retail stores). Should they be allowed to use my
property for free? Is that stealing? Good question, and where do you draw the
line? As a published songwriter I'm not even sure where I stand yet on this
issue. 
I apologize if this is not completely rave related but I saw enough interest
to include one last post to the list and repeat my offer to send anyone
interested my BMI info as I am doing for Jesus Chrysler( Jesus Please email
me with a fax number or a snail mail address so I can pass on the info - and
that goes for any one else who wants it)

Love Lydia
(what is a rocker doing on this list anyway?!)

Happiness is only a smile away!

Hey you all.

A thought touched me.  I was inspired greatly by, and I'm sure some of you
have seen it, PCU.  Now, I now that it's theme isn't exactly what I got from
it (at least I don't think).  I was inspired at the gathering of all types
to enjoy each others company and music.  The "all campus party".  I'm not
one to cruze to an old dance party so there was something else that touched
me. I think that it was the fact that people let down there walls and
stopped to just have a good time and enjoy being around others who are
having a good time.  The party didn't resemble the rave scene but it made me
think of all of you guys and girls.

Tell me.

What would it take to throw a beach party in San Francisco... Let's say Half
Moon Bay.  With multi-bomb fires going and a generator for the DJ's sets.
It would, of course, have no booze because that takes away from the scene.
A sunset to sunrise ravelike get together.  This thought gives me so much
hope...  Okay.  Now I know many of you have experienced alike things or have
insight into this thought...

  a little notice about the weekend.  can you say trance??  wow
thats what i heard at both parties i went to this weekend.  i was
almost like "am i still in san francisco?"  *joke*

  but really on friday night went to dust to see james dee spin.
he rocked it really hard.  i had heard him a lot of times spin when
i was hanging out with him but to be able to dance with a lot of other
people listening to him.  really good :)
  i left early tho to go to kundalini and got there and was pissed off
by how long the drive was ans everything and when i saw it was in a
skating rink decided not to go it.  heard it was good tho.  the ride
back was really horrible trying to stay awake. oh well :P
  sat night went to diverse city.  i didnt like the trocadero, but i 
really liked it for this party.  the lights and the crowd were both really
good and the music was all hard slammin trance and the people there were
dancing and having a good time.  so it was fun party

  was glad that sunset was cancled on sunday cause it was too nasty a 
day to go dancing.  cant wait till next week tho :)

well im off. peace

>>What would it take to throw a beach party in San Francisco...

it happened saturday after some after-permit trancing  harrasment at the
Bandshell for the Food not Bombs Soupstock . Spaz renegade soundpirates had
set up and after the second warning to tone down, the cry went up, "head
for the beach" so, braving the dangers of driving fully loaded with good
vibe, we headed for Sloat Beach and aimed the Wushu Accumulator
(soundsystem) at the Pacific Ocean, with  hot broccali soup to warm us, we
bopped for 5 hours until the rain came down. a lesson in raindanceraving.
yay.

        Reply to:   RE>>Public Newpaper Post, of Our 
This thread is bringing out some really interesting posts!

Your post has a lot a wisdom, Bradley, and much of it I would agree with, but
there are a couple of points I want to comment on:

For me, the music at raves is a very distinctive element. At their worst,
techno, trance, jungle, house, etc. can be very formulaic. You can hear a lot of
bad house and techno at mainstream clubs because those clubs stick to the
formula that brings in the most cash with the least amount of risk. In addition
to the excellent vibe, I go to raves to hear music that's playful, experimental,
that I haven't necessarily heard before. My favorite DJs have no absolute set
"sound," they just always play a good set.

Also, I see underground and exclusive as very different things. Underground
results from having to elude laws and regulations that dictate the location,
duration, and type of events thrown. Exclusive results from wanting to keep
certain types of people outside. Perhaps we should try to exclude some people,
for instance, those who arrive with the fuck-or-fight attitude. From what I've
noticed, though, people with those types of attitudes find raves boring and
stupid, and usually only show up once (though I guess once can be enough to ruin
a nice small party).

For now, I agree that keeping the calendar out of the daily print is wise - more
for the underground reasons than the exclusive ones. If you're concerned about
keeping out the wrong sorts of people, consider this:
in the social order of pop culture today, exactly how cool are ravers? I find
myself thinking about Allen's recent rave/punk parallels (or concentric
curves?). I remember how the football team at my high-school took particular
delight in kicking the punks around. I don't recall any football players or
those of similar social stature wanting to become punks. I do remember, though,
that out of all the cliques, the punks were by far the most accepting of this
science geek with a bowl cut.

take care!
-nate

You know, I'm getting really sick of all the bashing of doormen that
goes on around here.  Until you have worked in that position, don't
assume you know the way the job is.  To a doorman, you are just another
potential problem.  They have to look at it that way, since no problem
persons wear badges that single them out.

I have worked in that kind of job, and have been in several fights with
drunken assholes, been cursed at by minors when I took their alcohol,
had a gun put to my head for not letting somebody's friends in the
back door, etc.

To the people complaining about not being allowed to step outside for air,
have you considered that maybe the police have given them that final
warning about the noise (which is louder when the door is open) or about
people hanging out on the sidewalk?

Please accept the fact that you do not always know what's going on.


--

Precedence: bulk

Well, it's Tuesday and I still haven't seen a post about Kundalini so I 
thought I'd put in my two cents on the party.  First I was very 
disappointed to hear that it was way out in Antioch.... what's with all 
these east bay parties lately anyway?  Is there some reason that all 
these parties are in remote locations? Or is it just that the venues are 
cheaper and the promoters feel they can make more money?  People have 
talked about the San Francisco curfew as a possible reason for the lack 
of parties in the city, but I have heard no reports of the police 
actually inforcing the curfew.  After a 50 min drive, we made it there to 
find a rather sizable line.  The security were doing very thorough 
searches of everyone going in, which at least made me feel confident that 
there were no weapons inside (my friend even had to take his swiss army 
knife out of his back pack and take it back to the car).  We made it to 
the door at about 12:03 and they were already charging $20.  I really 
think that parties that do this are just grabbing for money.  The 
promotors should mark the line and anyone there before 12:00 gets in for 
the advertised price ($15).  (The line moved condiderably faster after 
midnight).
	On the positive side, once inside the party had good sound, some 
nice lights (as you walked into the dance area most lights were at one 
end and low to the ground so people dancing were silhouetted against 
bright colored lighting & strobes) & some seriously phat beats : )   The 
vibe increased as the night progressed and I met lots of happy, positive 
people.  Everyone smiled and introduced themselves, and people were there 
to dance and share.  I had a great time with all the people I met and got 
to spend most of the evening with a truly good friend.
	Overall I had a great time and I would say it was a really good party, 
but I think that the promoters have cut a few corners from the two other 
Kundalini parties that I have been to before (both of which were 
excellent).  I'm not trying to be too critical, but I have seen this as a 
bit of a trend lately and I feel that we must let the promoters know how we 
feel.  
	
peace, love, and positive energy
Andrew

They want you to hire off duty police which is tantamount to paying for
protection.  There are also only a few "sanctioned" venues that they will
allow a party to take place in.  It has more to do with graft and
extortion then the curfew law.

BEGIN QUOTE FROM Nathan Moser:
: 
: Also, I see underground and exclusive as very different things. Underground
: results from having to elude laws and regulations that dictate the location,
: duration, and type of events thrown.

To me, underground means something very different.  It's about the music,
not the events.  Being underground means not selling your music out,
not expressing what you really want to but trying to make something
that will sell a lot of records.  It also has to do with us as consumers,
not buying into the sellouts, but to support those who are making music
from their soul.

submerge@msen.com knows what's up.

"We will never surface"

Hello all,


	My name is chris and this will be my first time posting.  A little over a year ago (Feb 94) I had the most incredible experince of my life.  An experience that can only happen once.  My life was forever changed by the sudden realization of the true nature of things.  I cannont begin to thank the people directly and indirectly involved with that realization.  I can only start with every person at Bonney Dune at the Feb Full Moon Party of 94. Thank you!! 


WOW!!!!!  It is absolutely incredible that in an instant I could go from a devoute atheist (agnostic) to a person aware of the spiritial forces around me and within me.  Ever since that moment I have been learning, forgeting, and learning again.  The world is so beautiful to me now.  In the blink of an eye I was lifted up to the top of the mountain and shown heaven, than the same force spun me around a billion times and threw me back down to the valley and said, "There is the path back up the mountain, good luck,"  Since than I have been trying to follow the path, but as you all must know, it is not easy.        

I look to the rave scene and to nature for my inspiration.  House music is awesome!!!!!!! It moves me as does the partys I've been to.  Within this scene I see a community that is just incredible.  The people I have met are all beautiful and teach me by thier actions and attitudes.  I strive to be a positive extroverted person spewing good vibes where ever I go.  I think we posses the power to make great changes.  This excites me very much.  We can and will change the world in positive ways.  If we as a group can foucus our enery in the right directions this will happen.

	Nature holds the answers.

		Love, chris

> You know, I'm getting really sick of all the bashing of doormen that
> goes on around here.  Until you have worked in that position, don't
> assume you know the way the job is.  To a doorman, you are just another

from those who are well intentioned.

little insight. Drunken trouble makers are usually easy to spot (or do 
they pretend to be "cool" so they can then cause trouble?)

Perhaps the "goons" are just too lazy to take the time to differentiate?

Then again, I've never been a doorman, so I don't REALLY know.

> 
> Hello all,
> 
> 
> 	My name is chris and this will be my first time posting.  A little over >a year ago (Feb 94) I had the most incredible experince of my life. 
>An experience that can only happen once.  My life was forever changed by the 
>sudden realization of the true nature of things.  
>I cannont begin to thank the people directly and indirectly involved with that realization.  
>I can only start with every person at Bonney Dune at the Feb Full Moon Party of 94. Thank you!! 

Yes, Bonnie Dune is a special place for me as well! About 3 1/2 years ago I had
a similar experience there.  Suffice it to say that I got in contact with
Mother Earth, the Goddess, Gaia, God, the Tao whatever you want to call it.

> 
> 
> WOW!!!!!  It is absolutely incredible that in an instant I could go from a devoute atheist (agnostic) to a person aware of the spiritial forces around me and within me.  Ever since that moment I have been learning, forgeting, and learning again.  The world is so beautiful to me now.  In the blink of an eye I was lifted up to the top of the mountain and shown heaven, than the same force spun me around a billion times and threw me back down to the valley and said, "There is the path back up the mountain, good luck,"  Since than I have been trying to follow the path, but as you all must know, it is not easy.        
> 
> I look to the rave scene and to nature for my inspiration.  House music is awesome!!!!!!! It moves me as does the partys I've been to.  Within this scene I see a community that is just incredible.  The people I have met are all beautiful and teach me by thier actions and attitudes.  I strive to be a positive extroverted person spewing good vibes where ever I go.  I think we posses the power to make great changes.  This excites me very much.  We can and will change the world in positive ways.  If we as a group can foucus our enery in the right directions this will happen.



I'm so glad you shared this with us, I keeps me going out and participating.
Some of us believe (you all know who you are:) that as long as people like 
you keep having these kinds of experiences then it makes all of the bullshit
worth while and we are getting our job done.


> 
> 	Nature holds the answers.
> 
> 		Love, chris
> 
> 

I came to the unmistakable realization that all things ebb and flow and even the
most totalitarian, faschist, polluting society is but a missbehaved baby in her
arms.  Our mother loves us as she does all of her children but it is only
our Ego that tells us that we are her favorites or special in some form.
She will not allow all life on this planet to perish so that one species
(mankind) can abuse him/herself and everyone else.  In her face as Kali, she can
destroy entire civilizations overnight but she always hedges her bets, she
always whispers... to the children with devotion.

	
	              RAVE: For a better tomorrow




				G

Well, As some of you know I have been a doorman for several parties
in and out of the scene.  The King street security are way out of
hand.  They give me shit when I go there and most of them have seen me for 
years.  A few months ago we (the Wicked crew) almost got into an all out brawl
with some of them in the DJ booth.  I've been a weight lifter in my day and I
tell you the behavior (plus the jaws on some of them) leads me to believe
that they been hittin the 'roids.

doing a door.  I have come close on a few occasions but not really
in the rave scene, most of the gangsters are wanna be (thank goodness :)

the new moon happened last weekend...on saturday.  they were going to have 
it on a beach, but it rained.  so lucky for us, jc of the il pirata bar 
on 16th and utah let us have it there.  

it has always been a secret fantasy of mine to go to a new moon there, 
just 'cause it's such a cosy comfy neighborhood raver bar with a decent 
sized dance floor.  

the only thing that sucked about having the party there was having to 
turn away so many kids who were under 21.   anyway, sorry sorry 
sorry sorry to anybody who wanted to get in but couldn't.  

the guys that did Lawndree last week volunteered to bring their system up 
from Davis for this party.  two spun records:  marc and john (aka 
glowboy!) and they brought their friend avery to help out.  they are 
great folks and say they are going to do a party on the weekend of the 
14th up near  davis.  they have an outdoor location in mind that isn't 
far and so you might want to check it out!  mark plays 
eclectic everything...from house to techno to disco...the range of dance 
music.  anyway, they will probably post about their upcoming party so i 
won't say more here for fear of getting it wrong or some such.  thanks 
very much for helping us out!  

jc, who manages the il pirata and who is the son of the owner, also took 
a turn at the decks.  new moon vet ronan h. started us out with an ambient 
dub set (sorry if i'm getting the categories wrong) that had a strong 
sprititual element, which i liked very much.  it was very much in keeping 
with ronan's personal style of music...at the time i didn't get to hear 
much but luckily i was able to hear a tape of it the next day.  the 
healing power in music came through.  thankyou. 

the very last dj to spin was felix, who completely 
blew me away with his "trip-hop heavy dub," which is what mona called 
it.  i noticed his name on a flyer for an upcoming weekly (?) called 
black diamond which looks intriguing.  and yesterday night i think he 
played at the gardening club.  you should definitely go and hear him if 
you haven't already.  i liked the records he played because they screwed 
around with my expectations and such.  but there was an underlying dark 
mood to everything he played that made me feel like a citizen of a 
future world where at last all categories have been blown apart, as they've
been promising to do for quite some time.  check him out if you can.

thanks again mark, avery, john, felix, ronan, jc, mona, gregg, morgan, 
amy, phoenix, paul, cinnamon twist, phred, and everyone for coming and 
making such a nice time.

-ann

ps it was also mona's going-away-party..she's leaving for a while to Miss

Robert Smith writes:

>You know, I'm getting really sick of all the bashing of doormen that
>goes on around here.  Until you have worked in that position, don't
>assume you know the way the job is.  To a doorman, you are just another
>potential problem.  They have to look at it that way, since no problem
>persons wear badges that single them out.


Thats a fine response to absolutely nothing we are talking about.
If I'm just another potential problem to the door men then forget that
venue with those types of door men working there.  I work in shipping/
receiving and if I treated everything as a potential problem I'd get fired.
You see theres a way to deal with things in this life time and any other
life time.  I've never heard of people treating everything as a problem.
Theres a solution to every problem, and treating people that pay their rent
and bills like shit isn't a solution.  Its a problem that the door man
made for himself.  If the door man is being a dick because he thinks every
body is a potential problem then that door man has a problem, like get
another job (its called stressed/burnt out).



>
>I have worked in that kind of job, and have been in several fights with
>drunken assholes, been cursed at by minors when I took their alcohol,
>had a gun put to my head for not letting somebody's friends in the
>back door, etc.


Understood!  And I'm glad your still alive from the pulled gun, but
theres the trouble maker and theres the human thats trying to have some fun.
When I go out to any venue I respect the door men, but when I respect the
door men, and the door men don't respect me then there is your problem.
As a door man you should use your judgement on the individual, and not
everybody as a potential problem.  Don't get me wrong cause those door men
deal with some nasty shit.  But you can be NICE to the people that TREAT
YOU nice.


>
>To the people complaining about not being allowed to step outside for air,
>have you considered that maybe the police have given them that final
>warning about the noise (which is louder when the door is open) or about
>people hanging out on the sidewalk?
>

Or has the venue/door men/owner overlooked the health of their customers?
And yes, I have considered the law side of things.  So does the law tell
owners which tell their door men to shut all doors/windows/water/air
conditioning etc. I think not!!!  If these venues supported their customers
more, instead of there pockets, things might be different.


>Please accept the fact that you do not always know what's going on.


Sorry but door men do what you see and nothing more.  Theres nothing
secretive about being a door man. Theres nothing to find out. I see whats
going on.  I have friends that are door men and ladies.  You don't need the
tough attitude 100% of the time.

So whats your point????


Noah Ruiz (SIPHON)
Someone who likes to be treated as he treats others, and not as a potential
problem....sheesh!


Siphon The Pig
noah@cadence.com

(ambient/tekno/whatever you want to call it, its muzic)
THE PIG

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

I usually don't post much to SF Raves but I thought I ought to throw in my
2 cents worth with regards to these topics.

FIRST:  Bouncers at raves etc.  Maybe they breed 'em more ornery in the
States, but up here in Canada I have found most bouncers to be polite and
courteous within the bounds of their job.  Sure, we have our assholes
(witness the scene which erupted outside MaRS a few weeks ago) but on the
whole I have never had any trouble with bouncers beyond the occasional
attitude ... and when people pull attitude I just let them pull it and back
off.  Maybe I'm a little wimpy but most times I don't feel that my rights
are being infringed on.  And it IS a tough job to be a bouncer.

SECOND:  the "underground" scenes.  underground to me means that the
general public is not aware of it, or has only the vaguest idea what a
scene entails.  It does NOT mean that it should be limited to the
"underground" crowd.  The fact that they play Moby and Orbital on Electric
Circus here in Canada, one of THE most commercialized pieces of television
I have ever had the misfortune to witness, doens't mean to me that they've
"sold out" - they just happen to have put out music which appeals to a
larger crowd.  that's all.  Music is for EVERYBODY who likes it, or at
least it should be.

I have my fire extinguisher ready for incoming flames ....!

peace all

karen

__________________________________________

- - - panic attacks make me nervous - - -

"Keep House Underground."

With all the talk about gettin us in the Guardian...

I've been checking out the Guardian Online beta, and there's a 
forum there on the web, where people primarily swap web sites.

I thought of mentioning hyperreal, then decided to check with everyone first.

Now, these are beta testers, so maybe they're more open minded/intelligent 
(assumption?), and see the positive aspects of our culture. This might 
encourage the staff at the Guardian to give us some positive publicity 
(hopefully of our choosing).

Then again, it could backfire.....and we're fucked (until we all get PGP).


later...

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed May  3 01:03:24 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id BAA02605; Wed, 3 May 1995 01:03:24 -0700
Received: from well.sf.ca.us by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id BAA02598; Wed, 3 May 1995 01:03:21 -0700
Received: (from phred@localhost) by well.sf.ca.us (8.6.12/8.6.9) id BAA28135 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Wed, 3 May 1995 01:03:23 -0700
Date: Wed, 3 May 1995 01:03:23 -0700
From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.sf.ca.us>
Message-Id: <199505030803.BAA28135@well.sf.ca.us>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Weekend Up-date
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Just got back from an afternoon floating around the exhibit hall at the
Moscone Center, chatting with a buncha suits'n'marketroids at DB Expo
(the annual database trade show).  Actually, it's a good show, and you
can get in for free if you can find one of the ubiquitous free-entry
forms.  

Got in Friday evening to SF.  Dougie Fresh, John Handi and I went over to
Dust in the Loading Dock Lounge, a nice place buried in the Stevenson
alleyway between Mission and Market at 10th.  Think Cheers, South of Market
release :-)  There was some kind of corporate get-together happening when
we got there, and some even stayed once the sound started up.  Our friend
James D was first up with an excellent set of trance, techno and trancey
house, followed by John Carroll (?) with a smooth trancey set.  Got a very
nice feeling from the Speedy J track off G Spot he played.  The room is
comfortable and sounds good, they even brought in a portable dance floor
(rubberized mats) and the beer is good too :)

James D and his friend Gilda and I high-tailed it over to 1015 Folsom to
check in with Brothers & Sisters, where Markie had a *hot* 2 am set
(he just RIPPED for about 45 minutes before reverting to more conventional
fare), and then Tracy did a wonderful house/trance set.  Just wish more
people were there, but those who were got off pretty well.  It's still
a Friday night club scene, but it's more than just ordinary, that's for
sure.  

I did a lot of spinning at Ameba Saturday afternoon.  Even let a certainw
well-known passer-by spin some of my records for a while :-)

Saturday night was the New Moon, which ended up being at Il Pirata due to
the incredibly wet and unseasonal weather.  The event didn't really get off
for me, but I think it was more my own state of mind than anything. 
Nonetheless, a good sendoff for Mona who's going back to work with her
family for a couple of months.  I stopped in for a little while down the
street at Reds, where the vibe was groovy and relaxed.  I caught a little
of Ethan's set and then the beginning of Susan's (who I haven't seen for
quite some time -- she's been in Florida).  Nice one, Tom and Monica and
Bryce and everyone who worked on that one.  Bryce gave me the coolest
hand-drawn entry stamp I've ever gotten :)

We had hopes of a Sunset on Sunday, but of course it continued to be damp
and wet.  Instead, I ended up meeting a couple of online acquaintances
from Germany who are in town until May 10th.  They are known as Station
Rose but those of us on the Well know them as <gunafa@well.sf.ca.us> or
just Gary and Elisa.  We met up at Ameba, zoomed down to the Whole Life
Expo for a quick run-through of the exhibit area, then went out tod
dinner and finally got a chance to hear Station Rose's third interactive
CD-ROM (their first was in 1991), with Gary's very fine Internet-inspired
melodic techno tracks, although we couldn't view the visual stuff because
of not having a CD-ROM player handy.  Station Rose'
s new release is out May 15 in Germany and soon after here in the states,
and I'd recommend it and not simply because they're my friends!  They'll
be back in the fall and I hope we can collaborate on some special life
events.

Monday I spent a fair bit of time at Soundworks on Valencia, and came away
wondering why I hadn't gotten motivated to check the store out (they opened
15 months ago).  Nice selection, very good on ambient and trance, lots of
CDs, and heavy on 'progressive' house.  Very little overlap with the other
DJ stores like BPM and Tweekin.  I recommend it!  They're at 228 Valencia,
near 14th, not far from Market, right next to the historic Levi Strauss
building.

Monday evening I got a chance to check in to the Gardening Club after a 
long break (usually I have to go back to Portland by Monday evening).
And it was well worth it.  I just missed Charles Edwards playing, but
Gamall cranked up an outstanding expanded-jungle set, which Allen Ameba
previously mentioned, and I'd rank it as the best single set I heard
all weekend (even including the excellent ones by Markie and Tracy at
1015 on Friday).  Felix followed with a fine dub-oriented one to finish
things out.

The music out there right now is *really* good, people, you just have to
check out the smaller and even club-based events and be prepared to take
some chances!

It may be a while before I come back to SF, so have a great month everyone!

phred

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: eidrah@wimsey.com (Karen)
Subject: addendum to my note on "underground"
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Going home last night I got to thinking ... and I realized that here in
Vancouver I could think of no less than ten nightclubs off the top of my
head each of which features at least one night of what I would term
underground.  Four of them (Graceland, MaRS, Richards on Richards and the
Commodore) are the biggest and best-known clubs in town.  The Commodore is
also the oldest club in town, having been around since the 1920's.

All of these venues frequently feature excellent local djs like Lace,
Markem (yeah okay, he came here from somewhere else), Prettyboy, T-Bone,
Czech, Isis, Little T ..... now, does this mean it's commercialized?  Or
just that people want to get out there and have a good time listening to
good music in a safe environment during the week?  Food for thought ....


peace all

karen

Frazer,
Really really cool to see you at the art expo the other day.  The more I 
thought about what Terrence said the more I realize that it has to make 
sense if, for nothing else other then logic, a result of an explosion is 
most powerful directly after that explosion not towards the end of it's 
after math; that seems to me to be just a question of basic common 
sense.  But then their is the other concept of there was a big bang at 
the super beginings of time and this (above) idea held true and we started 
off as beings so well developed that we could transcend time and location 
virtually instantaniously and that we have been going down the overall 
universal evoloution line ever since.  Also, there is always this idea of 
worlds (inc Earth) that had much more highly developed cultures/lifeforms 
in their past and, for usually unknown reasons, dissapeared/went away 
and, after a long period of absoloute stagnation, a lesser civilization 
came to take it's place.  This could deffinatly be said of Earth and 
ideas connected to this theory have been explored in books such as 2001, 
Greek/Roman mythology, The Marshian Chronicals and movies such as The 
Forbiden Planet.  It has also happened, in micro cosom, in our planets
most recent history (eg.Chiniese/Greek/Roman, then the (so-called) dark ages,
then the Rinaissance and so on.  Either way is as valid as the other and it is 
interesting to think about.
What is also interesting to think about is going to the Rainbow gathering 
in Taos.  S.P.A.Z. are going on tour then and we will try and hook up 
with you down there.  Or I might just head straight down there with you 
guys (British possie in full effect and all that).  Either way I am 
totally there 100%.  You also said that you were going to be doing a rave 
afterwards but are you not going to be doing one during the whole week?  
One week festival=7 days of 24 hour raving if you ask me!  If so, could 
me and me mate try out ideas we have had for a lazer/visual/music thing; 
and could I dj?  presumably you will have decks and all that ting? (or 
are you going to dat it?)
Also please give us a call I need you to sign more of those bloody Ga 
forms for me.  I hope you are well.
Love and respect,
Tristan.

From: "Nathan Moser" <nathan_moser@manual3.com>
Subject: sound of the underground...
To: "SFRaves list" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

sound of the underground...
True story: When I was a kid of 6 years or so, a friend once asked me what was
underground, you know, really deep below the backyard flowerbeds. Like any
budding science geek, rather than admit I didn't know, I explained that in
between the surface layers and the glowing magma center, there is this layer of
clear cold water with a ceiling and a floor of tiles more beautiful than any
swimming pool in the world. When people drill to make a well, they have to be
careful not to jab the blind octopuses and dolphins that live there.

You guys are right, there is an underground sound, feel, culture. But I wonder
whether that results from the noncommercial, anarchistic environment of renegade
or underpromoted parties, or the other way round. Being a believer in basically-good
human nature, I like to think that given an unstructured space, the mind and
soul create interesting things. Someday, I'm gonna buy me a big
acoustically-insulated warehouse (ha!) and invite all my favorite DJs and their
two friends (and their two friends, and their two friends, and so on, to borrow
a hair care cliche) to play any hour of the day or night they want!

More than for any other scene I've ever experienced, I do have optimism that
this scene will never place velvet ropes and picky doorpeople at its gates.

Thanks for the collective tips on the SF clubs to visit! I've been meaning to
get to the Gardening club for a while. For my south-bay compadres, I've liked
Open House and I often hear the Velvet Shop is good, too. 

take care all!
-nate

This is old, but some words are timeless...
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

The Void

Brothers and sisters of the underground, free you minds of the chains
of the material world.  Come with us into "The Void", a place where
time, space and value do not exist.  A place where sound draws a
picture on a blank wall.  A place where people are motivated by soul
and the need to overcome against all odds.  A place where, in Detroit,
everyone has to visit due to the hardships and setbacks of the surface
world.  Come with us to the other side.  "The Underground".  A place
where only your mind can take you!

                    See you in the other world.

                               Peace.

                                                    The Unknown Writer

Somewhere in Detroit

--------------------------------------------------------------------------




-- 
fix.er \'fik-s*r\ n : one that fixes : as : one that intervenes to enable a
   person to circumvent the law or obtain a political favor : one that adjusts
   matters or disputes by negotiation

Robert Smith: fixer@d2.com  310/314-2920  310/314-2866(fax)  310/501-3279(pager)
Digital Domain: 300 Rose Ave, Venice, CA  90291  310/314-2800  310/314-2888(fax)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed May  3 22:02:57 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id WAA00835; Wed, 3 May 1995 22:02:57 -0700
Received: from shell1.best.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id WAA00830; Wed, 3 May 1995 22:02:55 -0700
Received: (fraser@localhost) by shell1.best.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id WAA26672; Wed, 3 May 1995 22:02:39 -0700
Date: Wed, 3 May 1995 22:02:39 -0700 (PDT)
From: Fraser Clark <fraser@megatripolis.org>
X-Sender: fraser@shell1.best.com
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: RAVE CULTURE & THE END OF THE WORLD
Message-ID: <Pine.BSD.3.91.950503213627.22436A-100000@shell1.best.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

RAVE CULTURE AND THE END OF THE WORLD [part 1]

( from a speech given by Fraser Clark to 300 students at Stanford
University on May 2nd this year, at the invitation of Richard Powers,
Dance Historian.)


I'd like to correct one thing Richard said in his introduction.  He said
he was looking for someone who had thought about Rave Culture long enough
to be able to do more than sit there and say "Raving is cool..." Well, I'm
here to tell you that Raving is *not* "cool".  It's *hot*.  It's an
involving and life-changing activity.  In fact the last time I heard the
word "cool" used frequently was in London immediately before Hippy burst
upon the scene.  People would stand around at parties posing, in clothes
or opinions, looking "cool". And then Hippy burst through the door.  And
promptly tripped and fell flat on his face.  Got up, muttering something
mystical while knocking something over.  Hippy was living Life far too
intensely to be cool.  He was *hot*.  And with Rave Culture here in
America I feel we are exactly back at that point again. 

So could we have a show of hands -
How many people have been to a rave?  (about 30 of the audience)
How many people have a modem?  (same number).
Ah, weUd better check.  How many have been to a rave *and* have a modem? 
About 15 - so that tells us something.

So.  Richard gave you a pretty fair introduction to what I'm about, but
let me establish my credentials this way. I studied Psychology as a young
man in the hope it would help me understand myself and the world I lived
in a bit better.  I graduated in 1965 with an Honours Degree, but all I
came away with was more of an understanding of white rats than I actually
wanted.  To tell the truth, I was shocked to my core by the terrible
suffering we inflicted on those poor creatures and others. 

I became a hippy that summer ,1965, and lived through the whole fashion
cycle and then continued to be a hippy after that until I became a Zippy
in the mid '80s.  I had to invent the Zippy concept at that time in order
to define who I was and who the others I respected were.  Then, when the
Rave Scene exploded in 1986 in Manchester and London, I was probably the
first person over 25 to get involved, and I've been deeply involved in it
ever since, right up to now.  And, as Richard said, not just raving but
organising raves, publishing magazines, philosophising about the growth of
Rave Culture, and working politically to defend and extend its sphere of 
influence. 

So, if you accept the case I shall develop here that Rave is Hippy PART 2
(or, more correctly, HIPPY THE CONCLUSION) (and by no means all ravers do)
then there can't be a greater authority on the subject than myself. That's
just a fact, and I'm not boasting.  But I *am* boasting, because I feel
very proud to be part of the current Rave Culture that is growing in all
developed countries and in many others too because I am convinced it is
the greatest possible good news the planet could hope for. 

I am not a Hippy now, by the way.  I'm a Zippy.  The Zippy stands between
the Hippy and the Yuppy, with one foot in technology and the other in the
spiritual life.  We'll come back to this. 

When the Hippies in the '60s looked at the world they concluded that both
the current world systems, Capitalism and Communism, or whatever you want
to call them, were bad, unhealthy, anti-life systems, user-unfriendly both
to the leaders and to the led. The Hippy attitude then was .. a plague on
both their houses!  And my atttude today is:  One down, one to go! 

Now, since only 2 systems were on offer, there's no reason at all to
believe that none others exist and that it has to be one or the other. 

This System left standing, the one we live under now, the one which will
fill the tremendous gap and the goddess-given opportunity left by the
collapse of the Communist system, is based quite openly on COMPETITION. 

Now I have been criticising this current system since the T60s and saying
it was user-unfriendly both to the rulers and the ruled.  And the most
frequent response was: well, how the hell can you criticise an entire
system and say it is wrong.  Who are you?  How could *you* (and a few
hundred thousand drop outs) be right and nearly everyone else wrong? 

The collapse of the Soviet System has shown that it is perfectly possible
for an *entire* system to be based in totally wrong principles so that it
is bad for rulers and ruled.  If that was the case with Communism (as most
people will now admit) then why is it outrageous to suppose that it could
be true for this system too?  After all, Communism was originally a
breakaway from what was a corrupt, competition-based system even then! 

As a psychologist I notice every day how deeply we have been conditioned
under this system, this culture, to be competitive.  I constantly hear
adults asking young children, say, what's your favorite colour?  Favorite
colour?  We have to rank colours too?!  Or your favorite food?  And so on. 
We are taught to see the world and others in a competitive way from the
very beginning and it's very difficult indeed to see any other way. 

Now some will tell you that we would never have gotten to this great
advanced stage of technological development without competition.  I don't
believe that myself but luckily we donUt have to agree about that. 

What we CAN agree on is that the system that is now the dominant one is
based in Competition and is clearly totally inappropriate for existence on
a very small planet.  The signs are everywhere. 

One more thing.  The problem of competition is not just ecological.  An
unfair competitive system also threatens everyone on a social basis too. 
Oklahoma and the Unabomber show us that this current system is *so*
competitive that it is literally starting to tear itself apart .  From the
right and from the left there is clearly a growing awareness by a lot of
people that the System is not working.  

I mean, what would cause a human being to walk into a supermarket and blow
other beings away?  Either you conclude that humanity is just crazy,
simple as that.  Or you have to ask:  what is it in our culture that is
driving people crazy?  What fear and daily stress could such terrorists
have been under to make them do such things?  What great injustice are
they suffering under?  So we have to beef up our security, obviously, to
deal with the psychopaths the system has already created, but, much more
importantly, we have to take a good hard look at our culture to see what
is causing this stress.  And perhaps we have to pray that a new, more
cooperative spirit spreads across this land of ours - and quickly. 

Karl Marx once predicted that Capitalism was bound to fall and that, when
it did, the capitalists would compete to sell the victors the rope with
which to hang themselves.  That seems to hold true today where, as fast 
as we stop one bad practice, some other competition-besotted corporation 
starts something even worse. 


So what the planet most needs today is a new COOPERATIVE culture.  Ideally
we need to see the appearance of a cooperative meme (a cultural virus that
one sees around and on the media and which infects us with the beginning
of a new lifestyle) that will rapidly spread among the population and
pretty rapidly become dominant.  And which will make a cooperative
attitude fashionable and established that will encourage all sides to work
together. 

(I'd better explain that reference to fashion.  My viewpoint is: I don't
*care* whether someone, say, in the '60s started meditating or doing yoga or
dancing because they read about it in a magazine - what's important is to
get people to that point any way possible.  There are good and bad fashions)

There are so many things that need changing, and many many people are
doing good selfless work.  The trouble is that each of these single issues
creates more fragmentation, both with those who oppose a particular needed
change, and fragmentation with others who are working on issues that are
actually inextricably linked but not focused together. 

Somehow all these protests have to be seen and then acted upon as One
Single Overall Paradigm Shift.  If Society can make that One Shift from
Competition to Cooperation then all the lesser issues will obviously work
themselves out. 


SO, if the Human species really IS capable of changing in time, then by
this late stage in the game there should be a sign of a new cooperative
culture appearing.  And not just here and there but spreading widely and
rapidly in all western democracies. 

It should certainly involve Youth - of all ages.
It should have its own new style of music and dance.
It should provide a melting/meeting point where various activists with 
some of the answers can come together.
It should be linked with a Love of Nature It should encourage its
participants to cooperate (meaning no huge stars) It should encourage
gathering together in large numbers out in the countryside and away from
the City. 

Searching through mainstrean culture here in America there is absolutely
no sign of this happening.  Beavis and Butthead attitudes still rule.
Generation X.  Cynicsm.  Apathy.  Negativity.  Self-sufficiency.  Grunge -
whose great hero is already dead - from hard drugs.  The Punk thing, which
America is now in the dying stages of, sees no way out and merely refuses
to be part of the overall corruption and materialism.  But that is not
enough to change anything.  Certainly not in the time we available. 

Rave Culture is exploding all through the western democracies and shows
every sign of capturing America over the next year or two. 

It has no stars.  Everybody is equal on the dancefloor, and the ethos is
that everybody mucks in to help.  Rave has been going for a good 6 years
now and yet I doubt if most ravers could agree on one well established DJ
name.  Compare that to Rock'nRoll, the last great alternative/protest
culture, where already you had Superstars in the first year who are still
famous and wealthy today. And I'd guess that 9 out of 10 ravers on the
dancefloor couldn't tell you who the DJ is.  And 6 out of ten probably
couldn't even tell you *where* he is! 

In England where the economic collapse has gone much further (but it's
coming here too, believe me) young people are *forced* to cooperate.  If
you want to organise a Rave, say, someone will have records, someone else
will know a venue, someobdy else will supply a sound system and so on. 

The yuppy myth of having all the technology yourself is gone, never to 
return.

In England they call it a Depression - but it's important to notice that
that's the perception of people who believe they have something to lose. 
In my estimation, although many young people in England no longer have any
expectation of EVER having what used to be called a "PROPER JOB", there
has been a gigantic outbreak of creative energy and imagination like I've
never seen in my life, even during the Hippy times.  Everybody's
publishing their own magazines, leaflets, mixing music, organising raves
and social protests, everybody's busy busy busy being creative. 

When I arrived with some Zippy types for the US Tour last year we all felt
like we were moving at light speed compared to the constipated
competition-blocked energy we found here.  It's as if the collapse of the
Old System has unblocked this creatrvity and imagination in people.  In
*the* people. 

[cont]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
              Megatripolis - The Future Perfect State
          fraser@megatripolis.org & megatrip@well.com 
            Tel: 415 752 7702  INFOLINE: 415 LAB 2323
             Web Page: http://www.megatripolis.org/fraser.html
 Usenet: alt.culture.zippies * The Well: Topic 54, House Conference
