Hey all!
I'm back from come/unity and I'm still vibrating from it, so I thought 
I'd share some of those vibrations :)
OOOOOOOoooooWWWwweeeeeeee what a party!  The shared energy of that place 
was incredible.  It was real crowded, more so than my usual likings, but it 
didn't matter tonight as the vibe was so beautiful.  At one point it was 
so crowded on the dance floor all I could do to dance was raise my arm in 
the air a vibrate.  I noticed all those around me vibrating as well.  And 
it was great because we were all vibrating together.
There were other times with some room to dance, which was incredible 
because the shared engergy from everybody dancin was an imense joy.
Everything was so great I couldn't get away from the dance floor except 
for a couple of quick breathers.  
I hope you all can feel some of this beautiful energy I got from that 
party in this post.  I just know we all share it, because this energy is 
a shared energy.


peter

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu May  4 10:27:12 1995

X-Mailer: UUPlus Mail 1.51

Subject: Weird Cont.
Organization: Sacramento Exchange BBS
Date: Thu, 04 May 95 08:49:47 EST
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Well since I wrote that message about WEIRD to many people have
responded and too many people want me to write back.

Well guess what? I spent 2 1/2 hours writing everyone back. I used an
offline mail reader to respond to everyone. When I tried to send the
file, I guess it got corrupted or something. I erased the file to learn
one day later that my system was trying to tell me that the file was
bad. ow hell. it happens. Just another chain of weird events.

Something good did come out of all of these weird signs though.
READ ON
Because of these weird events I decided to do some soul serching of
sorts. I contacted an old friend of mine. This person read starcharts on
a very professional and realistic manner. That person told me to do
something.

That something was to tell a friend of mine a secret which I had kept
very dear to me. I've have only told very few people this THING, but I
knew that I had to talk. That person is here on the list ;) and now can
be considered to be one of the closest people to me.

The heart of the story isn't there though. It's the moral behind the
actions. After hearing about my starchart I am also reminded that
nothing is set in stone. I keep reminding myself that it's not what fate
dishes out, it's what we do with that fate. A good example is the
bombing in OK. hundreds of people pithed in to help with the hospitals
and the wounded. These people could have easily sat and watched like we
did here in Calif. but the got up and risked their lives for others.

As this letter babbles on I realize again that I ha ve complete control
over my decisions. Humans don't realize they had a good thing till they
lost it. Sometimes we look to the obvious instead of taking off our
blinders and looking at the simple forms of satisfaction.

I got a simple form of satisfaction tonight. Tonight I donated my sound
and time for an AIDS benifit concert here at Sacramento State
University(CSUS). It was a horrible night.At first(blinders still on)
The sound board went out twice(thank god I can solder 5 wires in 5
minutes) the amplifiers kept blowing the breakers, the room was really
hard to EQ for.......... the list keeps going. I didn't stop trying my
best though. Finnally the  night was over and I just turned down
the equipment. The people holding the event were nice enough to plug my
name a few times. Right after that a young female and her boyfriend
walked up to me and gave me a big smile. They said thank you and
complimented me on my preserverence(SP). I was about to say that it was
horrible but I thought for a half a second and replied"thanx", and
smiled.(blinder now off)

That second I was reminded that fate was handing me these horrible
circumstances but I kept going, and wouldn't stop until I got home. I
was in complete control tonight. Thats the satisfaction that we all seem
to overlook on a day to day basis.

This weekend I'm going to oregon to enjoy everything about it. I know
most of you probably stopped reading by now, but thats ok because I'm
kinda tired and I've been really way to busy to post lately.
I wrote a poem about self reliance.
Thank you everyone for reading:

                          Take from fate:

                       I look to the sky
                       For some king of sorts
                       A man in control of my fate
                       Who doesn't know what I want
                       Who doesn't care of my needs
                       Just sits on his butt and pulls some strings

                       I yell to the man
                       "What in the world
                         Do you think your doing?"

                       "Pulling strings, what else"

                       He made me mad
                       I was furious at what he gave.

                       A man in the high
                       He merely contorts
                       "What is your fate"
                       He looks at me as if to taunt
                       He avoids my pot of needs
                       He topples over the lanes of time

                       The man yells again
                       "your lucky,
                        all I can ever do is pull these strings"


the moral is: You have all the control!

SOUNDGOD@iccse.com is Andrew Dressler

> Hey all!
> I'm back from come/unity and I'm still vibrating from it, so I thought 
> I'd share some of those vibrations :)
> OOOOOOOoooooWWWwweeeeeeee what a party!  The shared energy of that place 
> was incredible

Yes! Come/Unity always delivers.  This party was originally started by
Malachy, Simon, Garth and Jeno and still carries some of Mal's magic.
It was originally a "scenester's" party due to the fact that it was always
the first Thursday of the Month and only folks who didn't have a job the
next day (or didn't care that they had a job :) would come out for it.
It's a lot more crowded now but still has some of that initial magic,
especially when 2:00 comes and all of the hardcore drinkers leave.
I have to put on a suit and be at a business meeting at noon today or I would
have been there :( even with that, it was still a close call, this meeting
I can't afford to fuck up though, (oh the trials and tribulations of an
Internet entrepreneur :)

On  Wed, 3 May 1995, Carlos E Soto said;

>i was really glad to see a great rave that wasn't overpriced and overhypped.

And I would have to agree.  I had a wonderful time.  Felt some really great 
vibes dancing till 6:30.  I really liked the last dj (don't know who it was) 
but it seemed like perfect morning music.  Had a couple of friends who had
never been to a rave and they really liked it to. (We started trying to leave
around 5:00 and every time we got close to the door the music sucked us back
in.)

What's with charging 50c for tap water though.  The Troc usually has free tap
water.  (They only did this after alchool sales were over.)

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: tweakin' (poem)
Message-ID: <Pine.SUN.3.91.950504190257.25192K-100000@elaine45.Stanford.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



Here's a poem I wrote (actually, the poem wrote me).
Comments?

	Tweakin'

Shimmering zing chips suffer passing adoration,
Indifferent to the mutilation others wreak,
All around now, flakes abruptly whiffed,
Cristy burns a numbing phosphor streak.

See darting eyes transfix a trembling key,
Partake phat bumps and climb a steeper peak,
What next, we tweak, I've done it all before,
Just one more shard, demands a sassy freak.

Grrrinders behold, with jaw beyond control,
The edge of sketch is sending vibes oblique,
So, converse in mutual monologue,
Welcome to the world of tweak.

Ashes to ashes, dust we must,
Borrow from tomorrow, up to a week,
It's often fun, confess the spun,
Of contradiction, the most subtle reek.

Living matter as ceaseless chatter,
Not awake, not asleep, the jaded speak,
Of tweakers watching banter dissipate,
Into the dawn, when symbols leak.



Omar Figueroa Curiel     Stanford Law School
40-A Crothers Hall
Stanford, CA 94305       xikano@leland.stanford.edu

Subject: MORE FUN FOR EVERYONE! RC = WORLD'S END (fwd)
Message-ID: <Pine.BSD.3.91.950505000116.16465B-100000@shell1.best.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


MORE FUN FOR EVERYONE!!.  
RAVE CULTURE MEANS THE END OF THE WORLD AS WE KNOW IT . [part 2] 
(an essay developed from a speech given by Fraser Clark to 300 students at
Stanford University on May 2nd this year, at the invitation of Richard
Powers, Dance Historian.)

I spent a lot of my early "Hippy" life after University exploring the
planet ln search of a culture to ally myself with which would be evolved
enough in a true sense to look at the Western model with a wise eye and be
able to say:  we like the modem, we'll take the digital recording stuff
and this and that, but we don't want the rest of it at all., none of it. 
Now look what *we*'ve got.  Check out *this* shamanic technology. Though I
found many such individuals over the years, I was finally forced to
conclude that there is no way for a culture or social system to resist the
commercial entrapment attack (unless maybe the muslim religion) . The
number of times my meditation was interrupted in India by enquiries as to
how many diamonds were in my watch!  When I never even knew of these
diamonds myself! 

Finally after 2 decades I realised that as long as the dominant driving
power is the Western competitive "progress" meme, then materialism, with
all its attendant exploitation of natural resources, general pollution and
middleclass social division, is a stage each culture must now witness for
itself before it can hope to see beyond it. 

In short, I came back to the very belly of the beast to work from within. 
And, after a few years of analysing and re-exploring where the West had
further devolved to, both in Europe and in America, re-connecting with old
colleagues and friends and defining what we were about, we hatched our
Zippy Conspiracy to Save the Planet.  This involved -

First:  An agreed analysis of the sum total of basic problems .  These
were pretty much what I've just outlined, plus the basic agreement that
the essence of the problem was psychological, no true conspiracies though
thousands of lesser ones existed, and therefore the Solution lay within
the culture itself, not within the system. 

Second we identified where the most hope for real change might appear. 
This was clearly in Youth Culture, where you find the most idealism and
experimentalism, and the least commitment to the current competitive
structure.  Plus, curiously enough, the least government control, largely
because the "pop/entertainment world" just isn't taken seriously.  So we
chose to work at the extreme end of the entertainment world - in
*edutainment*.  Not only would we gain a lot of attention before the
powers that be even took serious notice of us, but then, when they did, we
would be serious enough and with enough "serious" connections and inroads
into the system itself, as to be almost respectable.  I think we've
achieved that. 

Third we calculated, almost mathematically, just what the average new
lifestyle should be in order to return humanity to a cooperative
relationship with the planet.  Here is where Zippy first coalesced. 
Harmonising the Tecno and Hippy hemispheres, in Self and on Planet. 

Fourthly we set about making that lifestyle fashionable.  And linking in
with all people of good will who were already living that way.  Since we'd
already agreed that there were no villains, just psychological victims,
this further allowed us to agree that our Message was More Fun For
Everyone!!  And it's true. Everybody, without exception, will have more
fun under a more cooperative culture.  And zat iss an order.  And from
there to the feeling that all we would really be doing would be to provide
a stage for all good creative people to "help each other" it was not hard
to go all the way to pronoia - the sneaking suspicion that others are
conspiring behind your back and without your knowledge to help you. 

Now it's not that hard to work out.  We need a new lifestyle to rapidly
become fashionable that encourages people to feel hip if they're lowering
their consumption expectations and demands, getting more imaginative and
cooperative by trimming costs and pooling facilities, and being more
gentle and more shamanic at the same time. A Cooperative meme.  Not just
with each other but with others who are not part of the movement.  We
don't want a confrontational attitude - that will just spread the problem. 
We're fighting and partying for *their* fun too!! We're about cooperation.

We called it ZIPPY.  And here's the definition of Zippy.  A Zippy is
someone who, perceiving the imbalance in his mind between his Tecnoperson
hemisphere (which values long term planning, group endeavour, proper
budgeting, patience and perseverance) and his Hippy hemisphere (which
values spontaneity, living in the moment, personal whim, mysticism and
detachment,) and between those two hemispheres on his planet, is working
to harmonise them again, both in himself and on his planet.  Notice that a
Zippy is working towards this balance - he hasn'tt necessarily achieved it
yet. 

And of course we based in our calculations that the technology would start
becoming seriously affordable to many young people. 

This cut straight across the Old Paradigm of Straight and Alternative.  A
zippy could be a businessman taking a yoga class or a Rainbowlady setting
up her own little hemp stall business at a rave.  Each is activating their
previously ignored hemisphere.  And a businessman who wasn't exploring
his hippy hemisphere or a hippy who wasn't increasing his engagement with
the world were not Zippies. 


AND THEN THE "ACID HOUSE PARTY" BURST THROUGH MY DOOR!  

But let me back up a bit, for the truth is that, before we can plumb the
depth and breadth of the Rave phenomenon and then attempt to place Rave
Culture within its proper context, we need some real understanding of what
that gigantic social movement of the Sixties was about.  For the fact that
there are already more ravers on the planet than there were hippies at the
height of that phenomenon, AND YET MOST PEOPLE ARE STILL NOT EVEN AWARE OF
IT, testifies to the sheer scale of this nineties, millennial phenomenon
which is still, even today 6 years after its birth, only in its infancy. 
The older folk haven't even hardly started getting involved yet - as they
did in the '60s too! 

Hippy, then, involved a political component, an ecological component, and
a personal/spiritual component. 

THE POLITICAL COMPONENT was rather an attempt to go beyond the Old
Competitive Politics which seemed just destructive and unintelligent.  An
Opposition in the governing body whose *duty* was simply to oppose?! 
Basically, as I've said, what Hippies decided was that the two current
competing world systems were fundamentally user-unfriendly, both for the
masses, who were starving for soul food and peace, and for the so-called
leaders who were dropping from cancer and heart attacks.  A plague on both
their houses was our conclusion, and ONE DOWN AND ONE TO GO our attitude
today. 

THE ECOLOGICAL COMPONENT was this:  becoming a hippy involved DROPPING OUT
- of a System that we saw was suffocating everyone and killing the planet. 
It was a brave personal decision to basically reduce one's own personal
level of consumption by roughly three quarters.  That was what the planet
needed.  And that's what the Hippy opted for. 

And I have continued to live that way ever since - as have hundreds of
thousands of good people around the planet.  And I say:  we were right
about that too.  If everybody, possessed of much the same facts as we, had
had the courage and intelligence to make the same decision then, we would
today be passing on to you, the next generation, a very healthily
balanced, preserved and developed planet, instead of this terrible mess.
But most people did not have the courage or the intelligence or whatever
it was, and now they are being forced to make those changes. 

THE PERSONAL/SPIRITUAL COMPONENT brings us directly to the Rave.  The
Hippy conclusion, after many experiments, successful and otherwise
(remember that we were exploring territory that Western culture had never
delved into before, certainly not on the mass scale that we did) was that
the only hope for the planet and for WoMankind who was the only threat to
it, was that some device or technique would be discovered (or more likely
re-discovered) that would enable every person in the West to GET OUT OF
THEIR HEADS !  AND BACK INTO THEIR HEARTS AND BODIES!  To get those three
brains, the intellectual brain, the emotional brain and the
physical-moving brain (as a great teacher George Gurdjieff used to put it)
back into harmony, and working cooperatively together. 

Today, every high street in Britain, and increasingly in the rest of the
West, boasts a club which is offering just such a facility.  The ancient
shamanic consciousness-raising, ego-meltdown, boundary-dissolving
technology of African-style nonstop dancing to an insistent tribal
drumbeat enhanced by the most futuristic technolgised electronic
virtuality is getting an entire generation OUT OF THEIR HEADS and back
into balance. 


So there I was, editing & publishing the Encyclopaedia Psychedelica,
predicting a massive new outburst of "mass consciousness raising" when
through my door burst the Scoobie Doobies, two young designers dressed in
colorful clothes and looking bright-eyed and enthusiastic.  This was in
the dark days of Punk, remember .  Indeed, as soon as I got involved in
the Rave scene, I coined the phrase:  "Why is everybody still wearig
black?  Haven't they heard the Funeral's been cancelled?"

The Rave scene had been happening around the corner for 6 months!

The first rave club I attended was called SHOOM and it was run by Danny
Rampling who, if he had not remained a yuppie at heart, would now be very
famous indeed.  And the first thing I noticed and wondered about was that
the 3000 ravers there were DRESSING DOWN in simple jogging suits and big
loose t-shirts.  What spirit in these smart young people would make them
want to dress down?!  Obviously because they were seriously dancing. 

The first open-air "Acid House Party" I attended was by a possee called
Sunrise, run by a young ex-gambler called Tony Colston-Hayter, who was
soon being interviewed on all the media as the "acid house king". 

There were 20,000 kids packed in a field 20 miles from London, surrounded
by a Big Dipper, a ferris wheel, stalls selling champagne, hot dogs etc,
with me the only one over 25.  We'd gotten there by following the
instructions on our full colour flier, calling the hot lines from various
map points, all carefully organised so that 5000 people were descending on
the spot from 4 different but simultanous directions in order to prevent
the police from discovering and preventing the all-night party.  Once we
were in it was a "potential riot situation" and the cops would leave us
alone. 

I remember Tony halting the music to announce  "They've hit us with 12 
injunctions but they haven't stopped the party!"   I could see there was 
rebellion and determination in the scene.
 
The closest the mind could contextualise what I was seeing was the hippy
festival but this was assuredly a new fractal.  Social developments don't
go in cycles or even in spirals.  They go in fractals, with each bearing
self-similarities but each bigger than the one before and travelling
further and further from the gravitational pull of the Old Paradigm until
finally we fall under the pull of a new Strange Attractor and go off in an
entirely new direction with no return. 

There were differences, however, and I don't want to hide them.  And the
primary one was that these ravers were not hippies, they were yuppies. 
Smart, maybe even smart-assed, levelheaded, savvy and entrepreneurial. 
Indeed I remember one young yuppy female raver exclaiming:  "Isn't it
great?  You work really hard all week and you rave really hard all
weekend?!" She was perfectly content to be a part of the system, so long
as she could let it all rip at the weekend..  Call her a "weekend hippy",
except that those came much later in the Hippy thing when it had become
fashionable, but here they were *all* weekend ravers!  Already, so early 
in the fractal! 

If Mrs Thatcher's call for "entrepreneurial spirit" had been real, she
would not have tried to stamp Raving out, she'd have supported it, and it
would have been an entirely healthy regeneration of the culture and would
now be Britain's greatest cultural export to the world, sort of like the
Beatles and the Rolling Stones of the '60s.  I mean people like Tony were
charging $40 a head x 20000 = $800,000 in one night! 
 
But Maggie Thatcher's brand of enterprise was puritanical, mean spirited,
middleclass and middlebrow, and she was protecting her own
Conservative-supporting industrial barons and the status quo.  She did
*not* appreciate the freedom and sudden shifts of power that true
enterprise can bring about. 

And when the kids saw the full power of the state turned against them, for
doing what she had advised them to do, they began to question the system
for the first time in their lives and a long and inevitable process of
radicalisation was begun. 

Another difference was the volume and pervasiveness of the music, its deep
bass tecnotronic beats carried everywhere, and dancing continued
everywhere, people even danced to the champagne stall.  This was not music
to lay back and listen passively to, from a distance, or confined to one
place so you could get away from it.  This was involving, these kids
wanted to be surrounded by it.  And this is crucially different from the
Hippy style.  Rave culture is dance-based.  Dance is not some optional
extra.  If you watch old hippy/Woodstock footage, you'll see a few girls
dancing in the foreground (that's why the camera was set up there in the
first place) but most people are sitting around, listening to the bands,
puffing, and so on. 

And the third crucial difference was what these young people told me: 
they were NOT hippies!  They were very insistent on this.  And proud of
it.  And that's one of its strengths - this was *not* invented by old
hippy conspirators like me.  This was a spontaneous eruption from among
youth itself.  This is Rave's ultimate validation. 

And yet, without question, it was, from the Zippy viewpoint, the Hippy 
hemisphere of their minds that they were activating.

[cont]

> I just wanted to say hi and thank you to everyone for all of the positive 
> energy and good posts.  I has been so enjoyable to read my mail this week and 
> see that all of you are really doing what I believe we are all 
> about...spreading happiness and love.  Its fabulous to be part of something so 
> incredible.
> 

I agree wholeheartedly.....It's nice to know these feelings exist 
especially after all the harsh words and flames going on a couple of 
weeks ago.  I almost thought this list was a goner...i'm so glad I was wrong.

love,
Amy

Subject: Velvet Shop
Cc: noah@cds9258.cadence.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I went to velvet shop last night for the first time, and it was pretty
good.  The music was ok at first then Markie got on the wheels (X3), and
the people started pouring in. It got so stuffy in there I had to back out
to the patio to get some fresh air. I met Rich Cooley an up n coming DJ,
who by the way is spinning @ the Velvet Shop next Thursday.  I met some
wonderful people and saw some friends so it made the experience that much
better.  Its a great place to relax and listen to some music, as far as
during the week goes (work gets the best of me).

The sound at this place is pretty good.  The crowd is inbetween, and the
music depends on the DJ.  So thats what I thought of it. I'll definitely
go next week.  What do other people think?






Siphon "The Pig is PHAT"
noah@cadence.com
e-mail me for info on siphon demo
-=ambient+techno+experimental=-

I attended and enjoyed Fraser's talk at Stanford.  Some students seemed to
not understand what Fraser was saying, but many seemed inspired and stayed
after "class" for Q&A (I had to leave).  Thanks to Kate for illustration of
the concept!  I appreciate posting of the text to share.

   daily.

   (Sac)

   house, acid jazz and "alternative" music views. (415) 281-3377.

   Stanford

   noize - w/DJ Unknown, KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
   Thursday evening 9:30pm-12mid - Minor Minor KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
   Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF 90.3
   (SF)
   Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix with
   Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
   Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
   10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz and
   noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
   Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from SF
   and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
   weeknights ~9pm - the Modern Mix w/Steve Masters KITS 105.3 (SF)
   
Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, submit them! I can't possibly
   hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To svbscribe or
   unsvbscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   svbscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsvbscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To svbscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   svbscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

hey everyone,

  well made my way up to "Sac" last night for smarties.  it was my first
time really going to another party on the west coast outside of the
sf/bay scene.  all i gotz to say i,"oh yeaaaahhhhh!"

   this party rocked it hard.  i was going mostly to take pictures and
really wasnt expecting much.  went with a friend and we got to the 
location, the califronia expo around midnight.  when we first got in
the music wasnt that pumpin and the place was still filling up.  
   a beautiful set-up.  a fairly large rectangular room which at the
far end had a AMAZING set-up of lasers in one corner, the dj and the
speaker stacks in the other.   on the other side was a projection
booth and the projections of different lights slides, etc.  on the
wall.  
   there wern't any other lights, intellabeams and stuff.  i thought i was
going to miss it as the night, but it didnt.  the lasers, and the 
projections and the way they were used were incredible.  it was
a lot of fun when you just watched the laser slice through the dancing 
people in half, and create all these diffent shapes on the walls.  they 
also had mirrors positioned so that when the lasers hit them they would
go all over the place.  
   There were SO many nice pictues there i ended up taking like 4 roles.  
This lady i met, alicia,  also took another role of
pictures.  She was going all over the place :)  I'll upload the
pictures onto the sfraves hyperreal page when i get them developed
and everything.  
  after the first dj didnt get me moving.  Tony really picked up the vibe
and it was fun time dancing.  at one point i was just grooving and this 
one guy came up and was like "Show us what you have!"  over and over 
again  and you just bugged out.  then i said it to him and then he
bugged out dancing.   then we go around to other people on the dance
floor and yelll "Show us what you have!" and they bug out also.  =)
  dj dan was next.  what can i say but he is my favorite dj around here.
he can rock the fuckin house and play around with the vibe like a 
vinyl god.  man, it was so fun just watching him spin the records 
together.  
  so all in all probably the BEST big party in the area ive been to and
the best one in a long while.  The vibe, the music, the people, and the
laser ;)  made this party rock.  

peace all and see ya around, maybe at sunset =)

doug ) ( doug@squishy.com

Below is a quote, from The I Ching, of a description from the image 
created by the hexagram "Yu" or "Enthusiasm."


THE IMAGE
Thunder comes resounding out of the earth:
The image of ENTHUSIASM.
Thus the ancient kings made music
In order to honor merit,
And offered it with splendor
To the Supreme Diety.

When, at the begining of Summer, thunder - electrical energy - comes 
rushing forth from the earth again, and the first thunderstorm refreshes 
nature, a prolonged state of tension is resolved.  Joy and relief make 
themselves felt.  So too, music has the power to ease tension within the 
heart and to loosen the grip of obscure emotions.  The enthusiasm of the 
heart expresses itself involuntarily in a burst of song, in dance and 
rhythmic movement of the body.  From immemorial times the inspiring 
effect of the invisible sound that moves all hearts, and draws them 
together, has mystified man-kind.
Rulers have made use
 of this natural taste for music; they elevated it 
and regulated it.  Music was looked upon as something serious and holy, 
designed to purify the feelings of men.  It fell to music to glorify the 
virtues of heroes and thus to construct a bridge to the world of the 
unseen.  (Thus) in the temple men drew near to God with music and 
pantomime.  


TRISTAN.

The other day we were crossing the Richmond/San Rafael bridge on our way to
spend  some quality recreation time with our doggy. As the woman at the toll
booth took our dollar she handed us a doggy bone and a big smile!

of you smile too!

the religious/spiritual aspects to dance -
> 
> ...  So too, music has the power to ease tension within the 
> heart and to loosen the grip of obscure emotions.  The enthusiasm of the 
> heart expresses itself involuntarily in a burst of song, in dance and 
> rhythmic movement of the body.  From immemorial times the inspiring 
> effect of the invisible sound that moves all hearts, and draws them 
> together, has mystified man-kind.
> Rulers have made use
>  of this natural taste for music; they elevated it 
> and regulated it.  Music was looked upon as something serious and holy, 
> designed to purify the feelings of men.  It fell to music to glorify the 
> virtues of heroes and thus to construct a bridge to the world of the 
> unseen.  (Thus) in the temple men drew near to God with music and 
> pantomime.  
>

Nazi Germany realized the power of dance and devoted much resources in
its control and exploitation.

properly ( not in residential areas ), rave masses would be covered by
religious freedom laws. ( If the friggin' Christian Identity racist
religion can have churches , why not ravers? ).

Hello wonderful sfravers!, :)
	
	On Friday, June 2nd, there is going to be a party. A party with 
the name of "Beautiful People!" It is going to be in the Santa Cruz 
area. With DJ's: 

    	James(S.C.)- Deaks - Graeme - DRC - Trent - James(S.J.)
	
    Visuals by: Michael Clay    &    Dreamy Ambience by: Dionysus Dreams
                                         (plus special guests) :)

	Beautiful People is basically some of the minds from "Harmony" 
and "Re-Groove-A-Nation", and a bunch of others coming together, to 
bring a party for the beautiful people of our culture. We are looking 
foward to this one so much! Since this is a party for you, and is 
created by your energy, we ask that the attendants of the party follow a 
few simple requests...

	First, smiling is a requirement!! We ask that you do your 
personal duty as postitive, loving, caring and sharing individuals, and 
give out tons of hugs, and fill the party with the love that brings us 
all together as one culture! Bring toys, candy, animals(stuft), and lots 
of positive energy. Bring anything you want, exept water!!! There will 
be plenty of free bottled water for your dancing thirsts!! 

	We do have a mailing list, so if you are not on it you may call 
and leave the needed info, (E-mail, and snail mail,) on the Beautiful 
People Voicemail (408)450-3044 or on the Harmony line (408)486-9591. 
(The mailing list is the same list as the Harmony mailing list.)

	Speaking of voicemails, I would like to thank everyone who has 
been calling us and giving us feedback! It is a real "upper" for us when 
we hear from you guys! (And I am sure that goes for any and all party 
voicemails!) So, if you have never left a message on a party's 
voicemail, you should. If they (promoters) check their mail, they will 
be glad to hear from you!! 

	We'll see you in June!!! We love you!!!

Peace, love and harmony to all beautiful people!!!!!!!!!!!!!!,

Shroomy, Jenn, Taylor, Kelly, Joe, and the rest of "The Crew"

Ps. I forgot to put the cost! It will be somewhere between $5-10. 
Depending on our cost for props and stuff. Goodnight... (or goodmorning, 
how ever you would like to put it!) :)

Thread: Larry Ching responded to Tristan's post (via Kevin Keiper)
> 
> ...  So too, music has the power to ease tension within the 
> heart and to loosen the grip of obscure emotions.  The enthusiasm of the 
> heart expresses itself involuntarily in a burst of song, in dance and 
> rhythmic movement of the body.  From immemorial times the inspiring 
> effect of the invisible sound that moves all hearts, and draws them 
> together, has mystified man-kind.
> Rulers have made use of this natural taste for music; they elevated it 
> and regulated it.  Music was looked upon as something serious and holy, 
> designed to purify the feelings of men.  It fell to music to glorify the 
> virtues of heroes and thus to construct a bridge to the world of the 
> unseen.  (Thus) in the temple men drew near to God with music and 
> pantomime.  
> 
>  Even the godless and God-lessening regimes of the Soviet Union and
> Nazi Germany realized the power of dance and devoted much resources in
> its control and exploitation.  
>  
>  Holy dance - what about a holy church space for spiritual dance? Sited
> properly ( not in residential areas ), rave masses would be covered by
> religious freedom laws. ( If the friggin' Christian Identity racist
> religion can have churches , why not ravers? ). 


Inspired! And there is precedent: the Shakers ("The Millenia Church"), 
also known as the "Quaking Shakers," were known primarily for their 
ecstatic trance dancing in their services. This spinoff of the Quakers 
came to the States from England (appropriately) in the late 18th century 
and spread from New York State to Indiana. Very much a part of Americana now.

The movement really became strong when Ann Lee was arrested and 
imprisoned for her zeal (in England). That is when the Shakers came to 
the States and thrived.

They believed in a dual male-female deity, in unity, and community of 
possessions, pacifism, respect for and equality of the sexes. Their rituals 
were noted for their emphasis on music and trance dancing.


Hmm... sounds familiar.

-- richard

Two postscripts to my last post:


Some people believe that the reason why the Millenial Church didn't 
survive was because of the timing: that wasn't the millenium. It's now.
(depending on your interpretation of millenium)

The dancing definitely wasn't couple-dancing - the Shakers were celibate*. 
Their dancing was mass-unity-group sharing and spreading of ecstatic 
spiritual energies.  


* Oh yeah, that's the other reason some people believe that Shakers 
didn't survive. 


--------------------------------------------------------------------------

I had told myself that it would probably be a while b4 I tryed going to a 
party at dv8.  Well, with a craving to dance, and not much else in town 
to choose from, I decided to give it a go.
I got there about 2:30, and to be expected it was very crowded and 
stuffy.  The energy seemed alittle scattered to me, as I found people 
just standing around in different parts of the dance floor throughout the 
night. 
Jeno's set was good, I didn't care much for Garth's set.  A little to 
slow for my tastes.  Thomas had some really good moments.  He seemed to 
really get the crowds energy level up with his enthusiasm and dancing 
with the crowd as he spun.
I had a good time, but it was no come-unity.  Maybe I got a little 
spoiled wed night.


peter

Hey all you ravers drifting through cyberspace!
I went to Third Society last night, and it was one of the greatest nights ever!
DJ's Ken and Mikey were positively phenomenal, cutting up great sets from 
midnight until 6 a.m... the party was going strong throughout the night, and
it was easily the most underground gathering I've ever been to!  I met so many
beautiful people: Dan, Alex, Chrissy, Mike, Ti, Jessica, Michelle, Mitch, Dave,
Michael, Joe, and so many others...it was great meeting, dancing with and just
visiting with everyone.  The visuals were modest but effective, and when the
cops came around three to respond to a noise complaint, Greg and Ken (promoters)
talked them down responsibly, and the dancing and music was allowed to continue.
Every person there was friendly, caring, and happy...another sparkling night.

Peace love unity respect blowpops stickers sweaty hugs and grins to all,
Timothy

From: crunch@sysx.apana.org.au (John Draper)
To: ausrave@smug.student.adelaide.edu.au, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Weekend rave report
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Weekend Rave reprt
------------------

Well,  once again,  yet another report on the raves happening around Sydey.
Saturday afternoon,  was a demonstration against police violance,  in particular
the VIbe Tribe PIG attack on innocent ravers jast having fun.  Earlier in
the day,   I was up in the Blue Mts.   Pondering whether or not to try and
make it down there,  in the rain.    I arrive about 2:30 where a break in
the rain permitted about a hundred ravers to party and dance in front of
the Newtown Community center.   Not far away,  a petition was handed over
to the police station.   I got reports that earlir on,   some 300 people
showed up.
 
This evening, there is supposed to be ANARCHITECTURE,  a free rave out at
Balls Head Drive (Wherever that is).   My friend who has a car reports some
car problems,  and it just started to rain,  so another choice was Raveland,  
some type of Kiddie Kore event with a $50 admission price.   I phoned 
DJ Reaver asking to get on the guest list (I wasn't going to pay $50 for 
ANY rave,  no matter how big it is).   It's a good thing I didn't go,  
because later on,   I got reports of a shooting,  and it got shut down.   
And I still remember Smerf Village (A big commrcial event) getting shut down.
So this indicates that these big commercial events can be more unstable than
underground events.

This leaves Sabatage,  which is conveniently only a block from where I live
in Kings Cross,  so thats where I went this weekend.   To the Rooftop.

Sabatage was already very crowded when I arrived (Around 12:30).   The place
was rather small,   but had lots of cozy little rooms to chill in,  plus
upstairs (Rooftop).   The music playing up on the Rooftop Sucked,  playing
"Rockin Robin - a 50's OLDIE"  Yukk!!   But I didn't go up there to dance,
just to chill.

As usual,  the music was conventional trancy house,  and I immediately got
into the groove (next to the fan,  of course).  Sheen was spining when I
arrived,   putting down some seamless beats until Phil went on.   As usual,
Phil layed down some really spacey trancey house.   Look for Phil Smart in
SF in July.

At about 3 AM or so,  I met some people coming back from Raveland,  who 
reports an unfortunate incident of a shooting.   Apparently,  someone shot
someone in the leg,  and shortly after that,  the police shut it down.

Sugar Ray went on next,  and literally had the whole place shakin.  WOW!!
Some really great house.....  

Things ended around 6:30,  and by that time,  I was so nausiated from all the
smoke that I almost puked.   Later on,  I felt like having breakfast and heading
out to Recovery at the Pavillion.

I arrived around 9 am,   hardly anyone was there,  so I split and came back
later.   It seems that in Australia,  the recovery parties start late in the
aternoon instead of early in the morning.   The recovery party had lots of
Happy Hard core,  and in the following weeks,  are holding a DJ contest.  
I have no clue on how they score these contests,   but I met one such DJ
who claims that he STARTS OFF at 200 BPM,  and ends at 320B BPM,  and brags
that he can empty the dance floor very quickly.   I won't dispute that,
but after about 260 BPM,   things just get a tad strange.

I danced all day long at the Pavillion Tavern,  grooving on the Happy Hardcore
sets,  but I think I heard just about every combination of mix possible and
very limited variaty,  and throughout the day,  I heard the same song played
6 times.....

Anyway,   after dancing continiously from 12 mid to about 9 pm the next day,
I feel GREAT!!  And looking forward to yet another raving weekend.

Crunchman

>City last week, also at Troc, and it was 18+.  What's up with that?

Wicked can draw enough 21+ people to fill the Troc. The Troc makes more
money selling booze if everyone is 21+. So they probably give Wicked a
better deal if they have a 21+ party. Diverse City isn't established enough
to fill the Troc with 21+ people. Besides Dave,Diverse City's promoter
likes to do 18+ or all ages parties whenever possible.

There's a dance jam called "Sacred Movement/Sacred Sound" in San Francisco on 
the 2nd Saturday and 4th Sunday every month. Friends of mine who are into dance 
(but not raving, yet!) attended said it's very good.  Here's the rest of the 
description for those interested:
     
7:30 - 10:30 pm 
First United Lutheran Church (I don't think it's sponsored by the church) 
6555 Geary Blvd @30th Ave.
$10
     
Sacred Movement/Sacred Sound events are somewhat structured, with opening and 
closing circles, meditation, and live music.  Contact:  Sahar 707/585-6828

To: Cynthia Lopez <fritz@hooked.net>
Cc: fraser@megatripolis.org, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Raving Without Legs
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     I know this is a late response but I did want to share two things. 
     I've been reading a dance book, _Maps_to_Ecstacy_ (Teachings of an 
     Urban Shaman) by Gabrielle Roth.  In it, she speaks about teaching 
     dance and movement with children, geriatrics, mentally ill, and the 
     physically handicapped.  In one section, she speaks of a 65-year old 
     man who is half-deaf and severely palsied after an industrial 
     explosion.  In the course of 12 years of movement and dance, he's been 
     able to "move beyond his ...spastic condition and open his movements 
     and speech." Evidentally he's still dancing in his 80's :) 
     
     The point of creating a safe space, where one can explore their 
     movement through different rhythms (flowing, staccato, chaos, lyrical 
     & stillness) is extended in a rave environment hence it can be viewed 
     as a form of therapy.
     
     The second thing I wanted to put forth is that there is a dance troupe 
     and a dance jam (open to the public) in Berkeley for handicapped and 
     able-bodied people to move together.  The group is called Axis and 
     they've been performing for numerous years.  A wheel-chaired friend of 
     mine dances with them (she's in her 60's) and it definitely reawakens 
     her spirit as she is divorced and is rarely touched, held, and pushed 
     in a playful manner outside of dance.  Axis just had a performance on 
     PBS in late April...a couple of days prior to Cynthia's posting.
     
     So in summary, it's not just the physical aspects of dance that raves 
     connect us (per Larry Ching's question below).  After all, haven't we 
     heard euphemisms of our emotions and thoughts moving, dancing, racing, 
     or "doing" whatever (e.g., eyes dancing and thoughts swirling, temper 
     rising, etc.).  
     
     Warm bear-hug embraces (can you feel it?),
     Diane 


______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: Raving Without Legs
Author:  Cynthia Lopez <fritz@hooked.net> at beluga-mail

Did you happen to see the nesting swallows? They had nests along an alcove 
and their babies would pop their little heads out and look around- It was 
totally wild to watch them fly above the party and swarms of what looked 
like hundreds, flying in a totally random formation- They look like mini 
fractal jets!

We made the drive down to Santa Cruz for a beautiful Sunset party.
There were 2-300 people there, just the right size IMO.  I didn't
stay to the end, but despite a lot of cars parked along Rte. 1, no
police presence at all.  The music was pretty good; I especially
enjoyed Travis' set, who came on first.  As usual, plenty of smiles
and friendliness.  Another great job by the Pacific crew and ocean.

Lee
___________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com   (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )   lee@hyperreal.com

Yeeeaaaah!!!, a great way to end the weekend.  After being in the cramped 
space of the dv8 basement, it sure did feel good to get into the 
outdoors.  Congradulations to the pacific crew for finding another 
good outdoor space and providing a fantastic party.  Once again the the 
magic of the sunset party had the friendly vibe that made it very easy 
for me to approach many people as I danced around the beach making 
contact with all those dancing.  I could feel the warm vibe from all 
those sitting, enjoying the enviroment and socializing.
After arriving and saying hello to some friends, I was compelled to start 
dancing right away as I was swept away from the beautiful energy of this 
party.  I got to meet a few more sfravers, which was great! 
Several people approached me asking me about full moon party shirt which made 
for some good shared stories of raves in other parts of the world.  
Thank you all for being and sharing the energy.

peter

     There's a nice little party for your wednesday evenings, called Blinc.
 I went by last Wednesday and heard some excellent electronica from Jonah,
Jason Velocette (playing live and playing some wonderfully bizarre records),
and Andrew Smith from XLR8R (solid beats, both tranced and housed).  The 111
Minna St Gallery where they held it has got a great feel to it -- really high
ceilings, potted trees all over, art on the walls & cool magazines on the
counters.  This week, May 10, it's going to be Terbo Ted playing live, myself
(minor minor), and Magnetix (Craig, ex-XKP).  ...should be good...
      seeya,
        Franklin Minor

Subject: The Windscreen
To: hyperreal <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9505081440.B2338-0100000@liberty.liberty.com>

Precedence: bulk

Dear All;

	I didn't know her name, but she was one of US. I walked out of 
Kindness, in Portland, to be greeted by one of my trip compainions. He 
said that some girl under the bridge had shot herself. The emergency 
crews were all ready on the scene. I started walking towards them, it 
was less than a block away, and didn't know what to expect.

	There she was, lying in a pool of her own blood, with a hole in 
her head. A .22 caliber Ruger Automatic, about a foot from her almost 
lifeless hand. She was still barley a live, with a lites on but no ones 
home confused look on her face, like she was looking into the unknown, 
and very scared. 

	I've held the very same type of weapon in my hand, fired 
it on a pistol range at a paper target. The bullet is less than a quarter 
inch in diameter. How something so small and insignifcant can rob a human 
being of life, which goes behond everything we know and understand. Guns, 
they say, may keep us free, but they also keep us forever locked in a 
circle of never ending violence.

	I'm left with this image forever burned in my mind, and an
overwhelming sense of saddness, and lack of understanding. I been through
some really horrorific times, and have been to that edge on more than
ocasion, but was always to scared. I understand feeling, so bad, for so
long, that you just can't see the lite of day, and that death would be
preferable. But the legacy of the hurt & pain you leave behind, I feel 
just adds to all the suffering thats already out there. In essese you 
become just like the people who hurt you. 

	The choice of life, no matter what, for me a person who has lived
through it, has lead to a much greater sense of satisfaction. I wish she 
would have talked with someone, she could have found someone who could 
have given her a new perspective. I remember a lot of the sayings about 
suicide, a permant soultion to a temporary problem, it will be a new day 
tommoroe, and you will feel differently, and you do.

	Thats it, except for the song that keeps playing in my head by 
Depeche Mode, called Fly on the Windscreen, the lyrics follow:
	
	Flys on the Windscreen:

	Death is everywhere
	There are flys on the windscreen; for a start
	Reminding us that, we could be torn apart, tonight

	Death is everywhere
	There are lambs for the slaughter, waiting to die
	And I can sense the hours slipping by, tonight

	Come here, kiss me, now
	Come here, kiss me, now	

	Death is everywhere
	The more I look, the more I see, the more I feel a sense on 
	urgency, tonight

	Come here, touch me, kiss me, touch me, now, touch me, touch me
	Come here, touch me, kiss me, touch me, now, touch me, touch me

	There are flys on the windscreen
	There are lambs for the slaughter
	There are flys on the windscreen

	Come here, touch me, kiss me, touch me, now, touch me, touch me
	Come here, touch me, kiss me, touch me, now, touch me, touch me, touch 
	me, touch me, touch me, touch me, touch me, touch me, touch me,
	touch me

	Come here, touch me, kiss me, touch me, now, touch me, touch me 
	Come here, touch me, kiss me, touch me, now, touch me, touch me...	

	I hope she found peace, and is in a better place, and would just 
like to ask, that we offer her a moment of private silence, each after 
you read this, thanks.

	    Peace, Love & Saddness From Across Cyberspace
		a.k.a Brian Darkness, LMT/BSEE/CET
		(510)-547-5984 CT Active Voice & Fax
	      (510)-251-4735 Pager & Voice Mail CT Active

		Internet:	brianv@liberty.com
		Alt. Internet:	brianvan@liberty.com

		    "Please, love each other"

>And I was sooooooo looking forward to Wicked at the Troc

I too was really looking forward to Wicked but when I got there and saw 70
people in a line that wasn't moving and realized that they only had part
of the club I was very disapointed.

It seems like they get great venues in the other cities (Portland, Denver, 
St. Louis,...) so why such a crummy setup in the home town.

Craig

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id TAA20876; Mon, 8 May 1995 19:39:07 -0700

From: Amy R Starkey <sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu>
Subject: Re: Help?, Anyone Care To Talk/RE: The Windscreen
To: Brian Darkness <brianvan@liberty.liberty.com>
Cc: hyperreal <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.3.91.950508173931.11405B-100000@liberty.liberty.com>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9505081917.A11404-0100000@saclink1.csus.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



> 
> 	Hello, anyone out there care to talk? I can't get her out of my
> head, the expression on her face, the look in her eyes, god she was so
> young, another priceless masterpiece gone for evermore. Would really
> appreiate it, thanks. 

I heard about what happened through Andrew (soundgod) and I was so very 
sad (for lack of a better word) for her.  Although I have never known 
anyone who has taken their own life, I still have *very* strong feelings 
toward the subject, especially now that my life feels so complete and 
full.  

When a person commits suicide, it makes me feel incredibly sad, because 
the person must have just felt indescribable amounts of pain and 
anguish.  To know that *anybody* would feel that makes me feel so sad.  
But even more, helpless...because that person couldn't reach out.  No one 
would understand, they would think. I would have been there for a 
stranger if he/she needed to talk.  It is so frustrating because 
*every* human life is valuable - but the person in question feels 
worthless.  I just want to give that person the biggest hug and say 
that they *do* matter - *PLEASE* believe that!!!

The last time I delt with the issue of suicide was with Kurt Cobain.  I 
wasn't a fan of Nirvana or anything, but his death really shook me up.  
Here was a person whose entire life was ridden with pain and sorrow.  I 
felt so angry, too.  Anybody who commits suicide is only thinking of 
themselves.  Kurt never gave one thought to his daughter or the misery 
he was causing his wife.  We live for more than just ourselves.  
EVERYONE PLEASE REMEMBER THAT!!!  

Then with all the media coverage of Cobain's death came all the 
articles of how the people of our generation (another pathetic 
"generation x article, I know) are on the verge of killing ourselves 
because so many of us feel such pain and anguish in our lives.  I was 
surprised when I read things like this.  Was it really this bad for 
young people out there?  For the longest time, I had surrendered myself 
to the culture of rave. I was surrounded by love and positvity and so 
this was kind of a shock to me.  I guess I became naive and thought 
everyone was really happy because I was as were people who were around 
me.  I dunno....has being in the rave culture caused me tunnel vision 
in a certain aspect?  I don't think it is necessarily a *bad* thing.  
We have so much evil and  sadness in the world as it is that raving is 
my little haven - another world apart from the cold reality.  I 
incorporate PLUR as much as I can in my day to day life, so that maybe 
I will connect with someone who feels like "an outsider."  Those are 
usually the ones in trouble.  A raver committing suicide seems 
paradoxical.  It really doesn't make sense.  Too many of us care too 
much to let someone in "our" community take their own life.  

There's what I have to say, I'm sorry it's so long.

Love to *everyone*
<<<big hug>>>>

Amy

> Amy  
> 
	Raving is ofcourse ,as we all know, excellent for the spirit and 
I always like to here about the positivity of the rave culture.

  The  rave experience and culture can be very powerful as we 
also all know.  The love, warmth, and connectedness we 
feel at raves, many of us attempt to bring into the world and that is 
fantastic.

However, I also think that raves can be very confusing to people also.
The accelarated experience and intensity of positivity found at these 
parties is tough (but not impossible I might add)for many people to find in 
day to day life and that might lead to a certain state of depression.

I guess all I wanted to add is that we should "try" ,as that is all we 
can do,  to see signals and become increasingly aware of pain in other 
ravers and other people to and help them through it.  Unfortunatly I 
think sometimes raving can do a good job of camoflouging pain in many 
individuals and those are the peolpe that I feel need our help the most.

	I obviously don't know the entire situation surrounding the 
incident and I hope that what I have said offends no one, it is simply an 
observation that I feel is unfortunalty a reality in such an influential 
culture.

Hugs to all,

Dan

>It was at a hot-house sweatbox basement wicked at 1015 about 3 years
>ago that I saw the Light ;-) 
>
>How many folks remeber those friday night basement Wickeds that 
>_started_ at 2 a.m.?
>

I do! But I'm not sure if that was "the light" or just the glow emitted
that happens when everybody's Luv Phaser is going off. Those were GREAT
parties with SIGNIFICANT vibe and AMAZING dancing all night long. 
Grungy space-disco meets Native American sweat lodge. And some of them
weren't even that crowded -- there was always room to dance.

But DV8 -- i really don't like that place. It's not like there's a
tangible describable, characterizable "thing" that I don't like about
DV8... other than perhaps "clubby" and "cheezy" and that friendly body
cavity search they do when you go in. 

So When I heard that Wicky-Head was happening at DV8, I gave it an
immediate pass, and stayed up all night writing portable assembly...
err I mean C... code instead... (and you know it's gotta suck if you'd
rather geek out in C than rave...). I had already done the DV8 basement
wicky-head thing once and, though I had a good time, I thought the
crowdedness sucked -- you can't feel the "vibe" when yer getting jabbed
in the back and elbowed in the face ...

That Sunset was happening the next day was consolation -- unfortunately
I nixed that when i found out it required driving to Santa Cruz...
all's I can say is that I really appreciated the first Sunset because
I was able to take BART there and back!...

==     Niels Mayer -- http://cyborganic.com/~niels -- mayer@netcom.com     ==

Re: DV8 and those guys...

Call me nuts, but sometimes I wonder if there isn't a REASON why they do 
DV8. 

If they wanted something intimate, do you think they'd do DV8, even if 
they lost all other available spaces?

I belive there might be other motives involved:

	- DV8 brings in a big crowd (i.e. money). Gotta pay the rent somehow.
	  (FMR's sure don't do it)

	- Since DV8 is a more "conventional" crowd, it could be a method 
	  of "interdicting" those that are unaware of what these events 
	  are about and showing them what's up. If only a couple of people 
	  are affected and start to explore more "underground" events, then 
	  mission accomplished.	

Then again, I could just be slanting. These guys have affected me in ways I 
can't even begin to describe (perhaps a few can relate?).

Just some possibilities. later...

-Jonas

of the sweaty bodies,  I have taken a few people to the the old basement
Wicked got them a magic biscuit only to have them emerge in the morning
a full on Raver :)

i'm reposting this from another list... seemed appropriate :-)

------- Forwarded Message

                In a Dark Time  
                                by Theodore Roethke
     
     In a dark time, the eye begins to see,
     I meet my shadow in the deepening shade;
     I hear my echo in the echoing wood-
     A lord of nature weeping to a tree.
     I live between the heron and the wren,
     Beasts of the hill and serpents of the den.
     
     What's madness but nobility of soul
     At odds with circumstance?  The day's on fire!
     I know the purity of pure despair,
     My shadow pinned against a sweating wall.
     That place among the rocks-is it a cave,
     Or winding path?  The edge is what I have.
     
     A steady stream of correspondences!
     A night flowing with birds, a ragged moon,
     And in broad day the midnight come again!
     A man goes far to find out what he is-
     Death of the self in a long tearless night,
     All natural shapes blazing unnatural light.
     
     Dark, dark my light, and darker my desire.
     My soul, like some heat-maddened summer fly,
     Keeps buzzing at the sill.  Which I is *I*?
     A fallen man, I climb out of my fear.
     The mind enters inteself, and God the mind,
     And one is One, free in the tearing wind.


------- End of Forwarded Message

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon May  8 22:26:05 1995

Subject: Re: Help?/Raves and Individual Pain
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

[ broadcast to SFRaves]
 
 RE: The suicide reported by Brian Darkness
 
Some ideas ... none many of which are cheery ( you've been warned ) -
 
 Raves , like many crowd situations , can be incredibly lonely experiences 
especially because other people are having a fantastic time. If the 
depressed person is the type that has reservations about showing feelings , 
then others will not know that person is in trouble. People in the crowd 
may be too inwardly-focused to notice anyway. Or , the people in the crowd 
may only be keying on other ecstatic folks , in order to feed off of and 
contribute to the total vibe.
 
 Raves can be a place where nobody interferes with you , as long as you're
not hurting someone. The flip side of that is that individuals may be 
ignored.  Ignored sub-conciously , as I've posited above , or deliberately 
( the same type of ignoring that happens when one passes someone on the 
street who might be crazy or want money from you ).  There's also the 
respecting of other people's privacy , when it is the most important time 
to approach that person.
 
 Pure speculation: I don't know if the gal who commited suicide near the 
rave was even at the event, so I'm just improvising here: what if she had 
gone there to find community , and found isolation instead?  
 
 Personal input - I've been in a rave situation where I was in a very 
dangerous mental space , but was too stoic to bother my friends about it 
beyond a certain point. So , even though they were having a good time , 
I was wandering around with the Death Angel in my brainbox for company. 
I "toughed it out" obviously , or else I'd be channeling this to you from 
the Beyond via Ramtha!
 
 I've also been in a situation where folks have asked me if I was OK when I
was only resting my eyes , so I just want to say that raves aren't a total
alienation experience!  Raves are still a lot better that many other crowd
events , mood-wise. 
 
  That's it ....
                  Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

PS TO Brian Darkness - I realize on re-reading the above that I've not
offered any special words of comfort regarding the suicide of the poor 
gal. I can't come with anything that doesn't sound hollow or harsh or
cold , but I do hope that you find your way to some personal peace about 
the matter.

On monday Brian Darkness Wrote:

BR>        I didn't know her name, but she was one of US. I walked out of
BR>Kindness, in Portland, to be greeted by one of my trip compainions. He
BR>said that some girl under the bridge had shot herself. The emergency
BR>crews were all ready on the scene. I started walking towards them, it
BR>was less than a block away, and didn't know what to expect.


BR>        I hope she found peace, and is in a better place, and would just
BR>like to ask, that we offer her a moment of private silence, each after
BR>you read this, thanks.

Brian is right. No one will know what to expect. I remmber her very
well. She was the first person in the prepaid line. I was helping with
door when she walked up early. I remember another staff memebr joking
with her and saying it was cool that she was the first one there. The
whole night seemed to go off really WEIRD. But it seemed very good at
first. Later on in the evening I was getting ready to pick up Graeme and
Jan Cooley from the hotel when I heard a noise and a bunch of people
scrambling around. One other staff member starting running up the hill.
I ran after him thinking someone got hit by a car. He stopped just
seconds away from her and screaming in pain. Then I saw her. The first
thing I saw was her nose-ring. I saw her hand shaking with a gun still
clutched by her fingers. I then looked at her head.

It took less than a second for me to vomit. I turned around. I then
remembered that there was an ambulance station across the street and a
hospital three blocks away. I started to run towards the station when I
saw a bum run from the station and say he already got them. Ryan
"Tigger" was the other staff member that was in front of me. He held her
tounge away from her esophagus so she could breath. The ambulance was
there in seconds. I pulled Ryan away with my eyes closed.

We walked back to the other side of Kindness to cry. My friend JEN from
Portland came and talked to us. I would not let her see.
Every time I close my eyes I see more and more detail about what
happened. She obviously had planned it because there was a 2 page note
by her leggs, and she did not have the gun inside because we were most
thourough on the serches. I would Like to thank Brian for coming up with
me. As well as May, Autum, Lolomi, Clinton, Tigger, Jason, Irene, Myram,
and Kevin. I would especially like to thank both Jen and May for there
support when I was not feeling good.

PLEASE READ THIS PART./\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
tHE DOCTORS AT THE HOSPITAL SAID THAT HER CHANCES OF LIVING SEEM TO BE
INCREASING BY 2% EVERY SIX HOURS. THIS CAN BE CONSIDERED BAD NEWS
BECAUSE SHE MAY HAVE LOST HALF OF HER MOTOR SKILLS! I AM GOIN TO CALL
THE HOSPITAL EVERY DAY AND KEEP YOU POSTED!

Remember I said something weird is happening!

"LOVE YOURSELF AND OTHERS WILL LEARN TO LOVE YOU.
RESPECT YOUR-SELF AND YOU WILL LEARN TO RESPECT OTHERS!"
Andrew Dressler

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Wicked (money promoters and DJs); now flame bait
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This is very long, but I don't usually write to sfraves and there should be
enough inflammatory material to keep everyone interested...  To make this
more than a meaningless rant I also offer (towards the end) a simple solution
to most of the things which I am about to bitch about

>Call me nuts, but sometimes I wonder if there isn't a REASON >why they do 
>DV8. 
>
>If they wanted something intimate, do you think they'd do >DV8, >even if 
>they lost all other available spaces?
>
>I belive there might be other motives involved:
>
> - DV8 brings in a big crowd (i.e. money). Gotta pay the rent >somehow.
>   (FMR's sure don't do it)

OK stop here you got it on the first try...  hate to break it to you all but
when you get down to the nitty gritty the Wicked crew is all about MONEY.  I
don't care how many times they say Peace n Love (add English accent here) on
the voice mail, from my experience promoters in the Bay area are into
Money...  yea there are some who don't care about the money as much but I
have learned with experience that if you look at it closely the money is what
keeps em goin more than anything else...  hey in the case of Wicked someone
has to pay for the heroin.  Yea go ahead and flame me nut the truth hurts now
doesn't it?  No not all of the Wicked crew are on heroin but there are some
(some of the most important ones)  who are just a little bit more than fond
of the stuff.  I will admit that I am cynical about promoters.  I have known
too many of them who will tell you till they are blue in the face that they
do it for the people but when ya get down to making a choice concerning a
party MONEY is king.  If ya all have not noticed the scene here has gone WAY
down hill in the last year or so.  There are many reasons for this... one of
them is the promoters and money, and to go a little further I think our
little SF DJ click has also hurt the scene greatly.  I'm very optimistic
about that right now cause I have been seeing a lot more unknown DJs getting
gigs... Sorry but I don't buy into the DJ=potential rack star but an awful
lot of DJs have.  This IMHO is completely against what makes the House scene
great.  The House scene is not about rock stars... the one thing that keeps
the house world from becoming the rock scene is the anonymous nature of it...
 no pictures of the "band" on records no stage...  everybody is an important
part of the whole package.  Lately the trend has been that people are
becoming less anonymous... esp. DJs lookin for that big Sasha the "superstar"
name and image...  it is truly amazing the fame and money you can accumulate
by playing other peoples music.  So now that I have complained I owe an idea
to help solve the problem...  but because the promoters and DJs are deep down
into the money it will never happen but here I go,
I think a wonderful start would be to STOP PUTTING DJ NAMES ON FLYERS etc.
 The SOLE purpose of putting DJ names on flyers is to attract people...  to
do this a DJ needs to get his/her name and image out there just like any
other business.  Stopping this would stop the promotion of "celebrity" images
that become very valuable in selling your party... this also allows the DJ to
charge OUTRAGEOUS amounts of money...  most of which does not ever get back
to the person who actually wrote the music.  Because "name" DJs are so
expensive Promoters not wanting to lose any of their share also jack up the
prices (which they did before anyway and would probably still do even if DJs
were all free)  I know this will upset a lot of people but hey if you wanna
be a rock star learn to play guitar... yea it takes more work but if fame
were that easy there would be too many famous people-hence no real fame?(just
in case you are wondering I have played guitar for 12 years but now primarily
write house music and yes I am very confident with 2 turntables which I
consider to have been by FAR the easiest of the 3 skills to pick up)  While
I'm at it what ever became of that wonderful sound system that the Wicked
crew bought?  Normally I could care less but I remember going to more than
one party with flyers explaining that the party was 'x' amount of money
because we are going to buy this great system "for everyone to use"  peace,
love, rave etc. etc.  I don't see this system out too often...  I know they
bought it but who can use it?  Is it free to use?  Ohh it costs money to use?
Ohh so those were really donations for a source of income for the Wicked
crew?  Naw...  the wicked crew would never tell you something like that just
to make you feel good about spending money on their party...  they were
really thoughtful in collecting donations for a sound system that would
spread rave love to every one.  (yes they did put out flyers that led you to
believe stuff like this and yes I still have some)  Sorry this is so long but
I figure if Im gonna upset anyone I might as well get it all done in one
shot...
Basically I really love the scene and am sickened by the level of pollution
in it now...  we are the only ones who can stop it.  I would like it to get
back to where it was, a place where every social group could come and freak
out and dance to a "universal groove" type of music.  Remember the days when
you did not even know one DJ name?  Did it make those first parties you went
to suck?  Did you get disappointed when you missed Garth's set?  Did you even
care?  Images of people that can be sold are ruining the scene...  stop it,
don't let them force this junk on you, there are more than enough images for
you to buy on TV why can't we take break at parties?

it's sad that the girl chose such a way out. but to all you out there in 
'raveland' who think that rave is love n' piece better get your head 
outta your ass. this whole love and piece thing is all drug based/induced 
and my money is drugs had somtin' to do with her decision.
before the flames fly; i know. i;ve been there. i'm on hella medication 
just to 'feel' like i can function in the real world; just starting to 
come out of the the house. drugs fucked me and my friends up good; not to 
mention the 'rave scene'. 
used to be i'd go to a rave and after the e would get so deppressed that 
i could never gain that feeling of spirituallity and community again. few 
days later would feel better. however, two years ago i never got better. 
paranoia, anxiety, depression, the lot...

nothing is more sad than what the girl did.............
but it's more than naive to think that the 'rave scene' can cure the ills 
of the world. it creates just as many.............

dj thad

From: Fraser Clark <fraser@megatripolis.org>
