To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: RC/FUN/END OF WORLD [part 3]
Message-ID: <Pine.BSD.3.91.950509030949.13924A-100000@shell1.best.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


-------------------------------------------------------------
MORE FUN FOR EVERYONE!!.  RAVE CULTURE MEANS THE END OF THE WORLD AS WE
KNOW IT . [part 3] 

(written-up notes from a speech given by Fraser Clark to 300 students at
Stanford University on May 2nd this year, at the invitation of Richard
Powers, Dance Historian.)

SO, Rave is not just a party.  Of course it depends what we mean by a party. 
The concept is long due to be redefined.  The usual party is actually a
leftover from the industrial age, in my view, where the weekend "party"
was a release for the worker ants after 5 days hard work in the factories. 
Since most of us don't actually live that way any more, we need to
re-define it.  And the new paradigm will be along the lines of WORK-PLAY &
PLAY-WORK. 

By "party" most people think of picking up a member of the opposite (or
same) sex, maybe getting off your face, dancing a little bit, chatting a
little bit, drinking a little or a lot. None of these items would really
happen at a real rave. 

FIRST:  Alcohol is not the main lubricant.  A whole generation is now
appearing where alcohol is NOT fashionable.  That alone would make Rave
Culture a historically positive development.  If you'd told me ten years
ago that alcohol would become unfashionable in my lifetime I'd have
accused you of doing too much acid.  But it has. 

SECOND:  Raving is not just a new dance step.  In fact there are no steps. 
And you rarely dance with a partner.  You just get out on the floor and do
what you feel or just follow whatever takes you over.  This is important. 
The fact that there are no steps to hide behind makes everyone very naked. 
I love watching people raving almost as much as I enjoy raving itself. 
Everyone is unique.  Every dancing person tells their story whether they
wish to or not.  HereUs a fat girl, thereUs a skinny black dude etc. 
Since you can only do what you are you are clearly exposed on the
dancefloor.  And the fact that everyone is in the same position adds this
feeling of everyone being naked together. 

THIRD The beat is faster and each record mixes into the next (concept of
mixing is very much attended to) each record should blend seamlessly into
the next to produce a nonstop wall of sound.  Or an ocean of waves
carrying us all forward towards a not-so-distant shore. 
 
FOURTH The DJ is present, able to pick up on the mood on the floor, lift
it when it's ready and bring it down again, only to lift it to a new peak. 
When I first noticed this power the DJ potentially had to lead the crowd
mood I called the DJ the TECNO SHAMAN - the phrase has stuck and you'll
see it a lot. 

Also you don't just have a little drinky and then have a little dance with
some girl you've just met.  Nothing like that.  People dance to rave music
for HOURS. It is shamanic, tribal african style dancing for hour after
hour until your mind is stilled, your conditioning removed.  They call it
a trance state but I prefer to see it as having your trance state
*removed* so that your eyes are opened and you can see the world as it
really is. 

										

Now most raves stop there, even today, stop at what I call the First Stage
of Rave.  And, as far as that goes, that's okay.  But it's very important
to take the next steps.  If you've helped open someone's mind to new
imput, then you should have good positive new imput available.  And this
is where the Ambient Chill Out Room or rooms comes in.  Here you might
have various kinds of literature available, massage, talks (even like this
one) and so on. I'll return to this when I speak of The Mythical Rave. 


THE HISTORY OF RAVE CULTURE.

You can get most of this from mags etc so I won't spend a lot of time.

The music itself began in Chicago - called "Acid House" Music - connected
to interering with a track, even pouring acid on it, "burning" it etc to
produce another effect etc.  I've spoken on stage with Derek Carter and
I've heard him (and others at other times) state categorically that it
had nothing to do with "acid".  But then, let's face it, if the papers
were all accusing you of such a thing, what would *you* say?! 

Then it was picked up in London and in Ibiza - which is interesting,
because Ibiza was also a famous hippy hangout in the '60s and '70s - I
spent several years myself there.  It's full of intimate little clubs,
with micro dancefloors, and, of course, lovely mediterranean outdoors
weather, beach and full moon parties.  Later massive clubs like Amnesia
and Pacha were built.  So London's CLUB "trendies" used to hang out there,
pcked up on the new music from Chicago, started mixing it in, along with
the new drug from America, ecstasy (which had been almost entirely used
there for couple therapy) and then brought it back to London. 

An so appeared the first "acid house" parties.  And E Warehouse parties. 
SHOOM, as I mentioned, is the most famous of the early ones.  Afficionados
might be interested to know that Jenny, Danny Rampling's wife, grew up in
Malta which is famous for its mafia and its clubs, so Jenny certainly knew
a thing or two about making a club "fashionable". 

>From the first time I saw and heard "aceeed" House parties, I knew that
this was the spiritual revival I had been predicting.  Most of the
trendies - who seemed to see only a happy new dance style and lots of hugs
- were of the loud opinion that it would all be over by Autumn, and have
been saying the same thing ever since, but I knew right from the first
moment that it would spread and spread and that's what it's done.  An
interesting side-effect is that each place that takes it up thinks they're
the best that's ever been, and I think this is very very important and
healthy.  Not centralised. 

A key element in the development of Rave Culture (as opposed to just
ravers going to raves) was when the Ravers crossed over with New Age
travellers and festivals.  This connected Rave back to its Hippy roots,
thus giving it the social impetus, rebellion and some spirituality. 
Obviously a whole book could be written on this subject. And, of course,
wherever this has happened, the "trendies" of the local scene, who got in
early because of their clubbing past, fight the development tooth and nail
because they have a position in the pecking order which is pretty much
doomed when Rave Culture begins to broaden into something more than just a
huggy trend. 

The UK government has passed many laws against Rave Culture.  Why?  It can
only be because they see the power of it. 

And now, lastly, I'd like to read aloud a piece I wrote last night called
The Mythical Rave.  It's a bit poetic, and a bit prosaic and
informational. 



The Mythical Rave should be out in the open air and should begin around
sunset.  This rarely happens but it's the ideal I'm now describing. 
People should start drifting in as the sun goes down - checking out the
venue, finding their spot (where they can leave their things) maybe a
tent, hanging their flag so others of their posse can find them, some food
and so on. 

By now the music has started, but it's slow and drifty and only
occasionally rhythmic at this stage.  People wander around, greeting and
meeting each other, settling in, checking out what other distractions are
available.  These could include massage, body/face painting, stalls on
social, political, ecological and personal/spiritual activities, brain
machines, food and smart drinks, video-modem interlinks with other clubs,
and so on and on.  Anything really that's inspiring, consciousness-raising
or positive - no negative stuff or imges should be shown during the whole
rave.  This is how we do it in Megatripolis and I'm very aware of the
arguments about Art showing the Dark and the Light.  I'm very clear indeed
that we get the Dark six days a week and, even if we get pure Light for a
whole night, the balance is still on the side of the Dark. 

Occasionally people will hit the dancefloor and loosen theselves up with
some dancing.  Dancing at this early stage helps to get the blood flowing
round your veins and generally loosens people up, helps them to mix, drop
their social barriers, and so on. 

Gradually over the night the music gets faster and more and more people
join in. By just after midnight the place is starting to get as packed as
it's going to be.  (This is different with indoor raves where most people
probably arrive after midnight.) At my first acid house party there were
20,000 kids going for it by 2am.  Massive energy as you can imagine. 
WeU'e now participating in a tribal gathering Love Dance to absolutely
nonstop shamanic rhythmic drum rolls and electronic bleeps that slightly
unhinge the mind (where am I? who am I?). 

Gradually the Group Mind becomes more dominant.  It becomes WHO ARE WE? 
I'm part of something.  I'm part of something that's actually bigger than
myself.  I'm one of the people, these are my people, this is US! 

In "Noise.  The Political Economy of Music" Jacques Attali says this: 
"Music is prophesy.  Its styles are ahead of the rest of society because it
explores, much faster than material reality can, the entire range of
possibilities.  It makes audible the new world that will gradually become
visible, that will impose itself and regulate the order of things."

By the middle of the night people are taking a break (some go all the way
through nonstop of course) wandering around, huggng old friends and new
friends, lots of hugging, not much direct sexuality because of this group
Mind entity that's beginning to be felt by everyone present.  Ego meltdown
into Group Mind and Consciousness. 

Sunrise approaches.  Crucial time - definitely the mythological heart of
the Rave.  Everyone back on the dancefloor now, dancing up a storm as the
music gets louder and faster and more cosmic, possibly with angelic choir
samplings and even classical music samplings to help arouse a religious
sense of awe. 
								
And so we DANCE THE SUN UP!  

Like the old pagan festivals, we're all in this together, this is our
planet, She is indescribably beautiful, gigantic, we are atoms of that
Living Goddess.  Personally I can't see a better way to help people learn
a love, respect and reverence for Nature than the classic open-air
all-night Rave.  Can you imagine what it felt like with 20,000 people
going for it and actually feeling together,and the power of a people
together ... and then dancing the sun up?!  It is awesome, it is
religious, and it is life-changing. 

The current Yoga Journal has an article called Sacred Raves which says:

"These all-night dance marathons look like hedonistic escape, but raves
may just be the defining spiritual expression of a new generation."

The Rev Matthew Fox of Grace Cathedral in San Francisco is quoted as
saying:  "These kids are showing us how to pray in a new way, which is
also an ancient way - with fewer books and more dancing". 

[speech end]

On Tue, 9 May 1995 Sindar@aol.com wrote:
> 
> OK stop here you got it on the first try...  hate to break it to you all but
> when you get down to the nitty gritty the Wicked crew is all about MONEY.  I
> don't care how many times they say Peace n Love (add English accent here) on
> the voice mail, from my experience promoters in the Bay area are into
> Money...  yea there are some who don't care about the money as much but I
> have learned with experience that if you look at it closely the money is what
> keeps em goin more than anything else...  hey in the case of Wicked someone
> has to pay for the heroin.  Yea go ahead and flame me nut the truth hurts now
> doesn't it?  No not all of the Wicked crew are on heroin but there are some
> (some of the most important ones)  who are just a little bit more than fond
> of the stuff.  I will admit that I am cynical about promoters.  I have known
> too many of them who will tell you till they are blue in the face that they
> do it for the people but when ya get down to making a choice concerning a

I wont necessarily disagree up to here.

> party MONEY is king.  If ya all have not noticed the scene here has gone WAY
> down hill in the last year or so.  There are many reasons for this... one of
> them is the promoters and money, and to go a little further I think our

This I will disagree with.  A few words/names to dispute this would be 
Friends and Family, Pacific, MESS, New Moon, Spaz?, and a group I'm 
involved with the Cloud Factory.  All of these groups so far have proven 
to me that they are *not* involved solely for the sake of money.  In fact 
several of the people of the above groups have full time jobs, are 
college students, and generally do not spend all their time 'promoting', 
although i dont know about promoters of things like Wicked, Exx Why Zzz, 
Basics/Gathering.  But the fact that someone has a full time activity and 
will still throw parties is a good sign to me that scene here has 
something to offer.

> little SF DJ click has also hurt the scene greatly.  I'm very optimistic
> about that right now cause I have been seeing a lot more unknown DJs getting
> gigs... Sorry but I don't buy into the DJ=potential rack star but an awful
> lot of DJs have.  This IMHO is completely against what makes the House scene
> great.  The House scene is not about rock stars... the one thing that keeps
> the house world from becoming the rock scene is the anonymous nature of it...
>  no pictures of the "band" on records no stage...  everybody is an important
> part of the whole package.  Lately the trend has been that people are
> becoming less anonymous... esp. DJs lookin for that big Sasha the "superstar"
> name and image...  it is truly amazing the fame and money you can accumulate
> by playing other peoples music.  So now that I have complained I owe an idea
> to help solve the problem...  but because the promoters and DJs are deep down
> into the money it will never happen but here I go,

I think the reason that new djs are starting to emerge is the reason that 
hopefully some people are getting tired of seeing the same djs every 
weekend.  Although the rock star image could be left at home, lets not 
forget the shaman idea that has long been present at raves.  If a Dj is 
good he is good, regardless of whether he gets paid $200 or $1000 or 
plays for free.  If someone were going to pay you a $1000 to dj for two 
hours you'd probably consider it.  I wouldnt do it but in our world money 
is a pretty attractive thing you must admit.  

> I think a wonderful start would be to STOP PUTTING DJ NAMES ON FLYERS etc.
>  The SOLE purpose of putting DJ names on flyers is to attract people...  to
> do this a DJ needs to get his/her name and image out there just like any

I disagree here because of the reason mentioned above that the shamanic 
qualities of a dj must be considered.  Certain djs play certain styles, 
emote certain moods/vibes, I think its ok to want to see certain djs, 
obviously people like and dislike djs.  I think the best move would be to 
stop making fliers =) for all perties.  But my realistic solution here is 
to take the approach we have and not pay your djs.  This is not to say if 
we threw a $5 party and ended up making a lot of money we wouldnt give 
some money to the djs (i think supplementing djs for the purpose of 
buying records is perfectly legit).  Although this also goes along with 
our dedication to *never* letting any of the money we take in be used 
solely for one person's benenfit...the closest we come to this is buying 
breakfast for the cleanup crew/djs.  So basically its not really the djs 
that need to change or the promoting tactics but rahter the promoters 
(which you pointed out above).

> other business.  Stopping this would stop the promotion of "celebrity" images
> that become very valuable in selling your party... this also allows the DJ to
> charge OUTRAGEOUS amounts of money...  most of which does not ever get back
> to the person who actually wrote the music.  Because "name" DJs are so
> expensive Promoters not wanting to lose any of their share also jack up the
> prices (which they did before anyway and would probably still do even if DJs
> were all free)  I know this will upset a lot of people but hey if you wanna
> be a rock star learn to play guitar... yea it takes more work but if fame
> were that easy there would be too many famous people-hence no real fame?(just
> in case you are wondering I have played guitar for 12 years but now primarily
> write house music and yes I am very confident with 2 turntables which I
> consider to have been by FAR the easiest of the 3 skills to pick up)  While
> I'm at it what ever became of that wonderful sound system that the Wicked
> crew bought?  Normally I could care less but I remember going to more than
> one party with flyers explaining that the party was 'x' amount of money
> because we are going to buy this great system "for everyone to use"  peace,
> love, rave etc. etc.  I don't see this system out too often...  I know they
> bought it but who can use it?  Is it free to use?  Ohh it costs money to use?
> Ohh so those were really donations for a source of income for the Wicked
> crew?  Naw...  the wicked crew would never tell you something like that just
> to make you feel good about spending money on their party...  they were
> really thoughtful in collecting donations for a sound system that would
> spread rave love to every one.  (yes they did put out flyers that led you to
> believe stuff like this and yes I still have some)  Sorry this is so long but
> I figure if Im gonna upset anyone I might as well get it all done in one
> shot...

This really upsets me actually.  I thought Wicked were going to go on 
tour of the nation with their sound system when they got it and spread 
the rave vibe/PLUR.  Which in my mind not going around throwing $20 
parties in other cities (Portland was $18).  

> Basically I really love the scene and am sickened by the level of pollution
> in it now...  we are the only ones who can stop it.  I would like it to get
> back to where it was, a place where every social group could come and freak
> out and dance to a "universal groove" type of music.  Remember the days when
> you did not even know one DJ name?  Did it make those first parties you went
> to suck?  Did you get disappointed when you missed Garth's set?  Did you even
> care?  Images of people that can be sold are ruining the scene...  stop it,
> don't let them force this junk on you, there are more than enough images for
> you to buy on TV why can't we take break at parties?


My final point will be that as long as people pay more than ten dollars 
to go to a party no matter how good it is, people will always take 
*advantage* of you. ALWAYS.  I take pride in the fact that it has now 
been at least a year since I paid mkore than $10 to go to a rave.  This 
means if there arent smaller parties happening on a night dont sukpport 
the large ones.  When there are smaller parties, like free or cheap 
ones...give them your $20 they'll actually do something with it in a 
positive way.  Part of the whole solution comes down to the fact that a 
true rave is not a product, it is a spiritual experience, it is a 
ritualistic part of some of our lives, but it is not something you can 
buy.  Way too many people have lost sight of that and need to come back 
to the ground.  Many of my closest friends still go to $20 parties (yes 
you Matt =) but every time I ask them if it was worth it...sometimes they 
say yes and I then I say do you realize that if 'x' amount of people went 
then the promoters prolly made 'x' thousands of dollars?  Then maybe they 
feel kinda stupid but they still go again, my hope is that someday if 
they, and you, and everyone on this list and all the ravers in SF stop 
going to these parties that are put on by promoters, not organizers that 
this will truely be the best place to rave on the planet.  Think of 
twenty different renegades with two hundered people at each party think 
of the variety of parties you'd get, the variety of djs, the smaller the 
scene gets in size of partiesthe better off we;ll all be.

lovedrenalin

ps sorry this is kind of random I havent slept much in the past couple of 
days (midterms =(

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue May  9 10:23:54 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id KAA20957; Tue, 9 May 1995 10:23:54 -0700

	id AA22919; Tue, 9 May 95 08:20:17 PDT

	id AA16305; Tue, 9 May 95 08:28:58 PDT
Date: Tue, 9 May 95 08:28:58 PDT
From: bmcgonig@pacific.abbotthpd.com (Brian McGonigle)
Message-Id: <9505091528.AA16305@pacific>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Wicked (money promoters and DJs);
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



Money is not evil. Without money we couldn't buy records. Project "Open Hand" couldn't 
buy food, the ACLU wouldn't exist. 

Profit is not evil. Without profit most of our employers/clients wouldn't hire us so that 
we could have money to rave or even eat.

There's nothing inherently evil in Wicked being a for profit/for money group. And saying
"peace, love" etc. on the one hand and asking $15/20 is not necessarily a contradiction.

We all know by now that Wicked is a business. And it's a business that many of us like to buy
from. It's all a matter of perceived value: If we don't like the product, we don't buy it. 
If it's too expensive, we shop elsewhere.  At present some of us choose to go elsewhere with 
our "business" as the product (read: DV8) is not satisfactory. If that keeps up then other 
products will enter the market on a Wicked nite, and we'll "buy" from them. 

Personally I hope they get it together 'cos I luv the bastards :)

hugz

brian

A few years ago as raving was introduced to S.F. there was huge potential to 
make big money. But now that the general public considers it a trend of the 
past there is not as much money as people might guess. At this Point anybody 
who is involved with raving is doing it primarily because the love it. Being 
able to make a living doing something you love is a rare priviledge in this 
world. 

Personally I think that Rave needs to trade in some of these bloated ideals and 
trade them in for some PUNK style personal freedom. Hypocracy sucks.

allen sez:
> there is not as much money as people might guess.

This is true.  There are maybe a handful of DJs in the Bay Area who
can support themselves that way.   Every now and then there's a BIG
party like Cool World that rakes it in - but we've been over this issue
before with Martin who was hounded into revealing his finances on this
list.  This scene really isn't a place to make much money.  You really
have to rip people off consistantly to get rich, and no one seems to
be able to do that for long.  Right now, I'd say that the most blatant 
exploiters in the scene are the ones hawking "Herbal E".
 
> At this Point anybody 
> who is involved with raving is doing it primarily because the love it. 

Some promoters might be in it for the ego trip.  I can't speak for 
others, but the couple of times I organized and promoted parties, there
was a inflationary effect on my ego.  Fortunately in ravedom, it takes
about one week for most people to forget everything you've done for them, 
so my ego was allowed to shrink back down to it's miniscule proportions.
 
> Personally I think that Rave needs to trade in some of these bloated 
> ideals and 
> trade them in for some PUNK style personal freedom. Hypocracy sucks. 

Hmm.  I feel much more free raving than I ever did in the punk
scene.  Although anger, nihilism & anarchy seemed self-consistent
and liberating at the time - I soon found that package to be an 
emotional and conceptual dead end.  I'll take the inherent hypocrisy of 
PLUR over Punk any day.

Lee

lxfogel@pacbell.com   (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )   lee@hyperreal.com

allen:
> Peace Love Unity Respect could arise from people being free to be themselves 
> not from a set of Ideals or pre-conceptions about how one should be. 

Yeah.  But the concept of "people being free to be themselves" *is* an 
ideal.  It is a preconception to think that there can even be a stable 
society in which we can be so completely free.  This is tied into the 
inherent hypocricy of PLUR: Will you ever be able to respect and my desire 
to rape you?

On Mon, 8 May 1995, Larry Ching wrote:

>  Raves , like many crowd situations , can be incredibly lonely experiences 
> especially because other people are having a fantastic time. If the 
>  
>  Personal input - I've been in a rave situation where I was in a very 
> dangerous mental space , but was too stoic to bother my friends about it 
> beyond a certain point. So , even though they were having a good time , 
> I was wandering around with the Death Angel in my brainbox for company. 

I *fully* agree.  although some of my absolute best moments in life have 
been at raves, I must admit that raves can often make a bad situation 
worse. I've had 2 or three experiences at raves (2 of which were at 
richmond civic hell) during which I was absolutely miserable and the rave 
just made it worse.  I just kept thinking, is everyone happy here except 
for me??  everyone has plenty of love/friends/fun/etc and I'm just all by 
myself wandering the halls.It sucks.  especially if you happen to be on 
fry at the time, it makes your confusion and depression even worse!  
also, being depressed and not being able to talk to your friends about it 
(cuz you don't wanna bring them down  from the party or the E) can be 
frustrating.
laters.....

> >I haven't been involved long enough to know what  PLUR is?

Peace Love Unity Respect - some feel that these are the main
tenets that define rave philosophy.  For the history and more
discussion of PLUR check out the Spirit of Raving Archives
at http://hyperreal.com/raves/spirit/

> 
> >I have so far figured out IMHO, i think?

IMO - in my opinion
IMHO - in my humble opinion
IMNSHO - in my not so humble opinion
etc.

Lee

enforced PLUR gives me the creeps
the PLUR police - always on time and snappy, ready to serve,
prepared to give all and nothing for that moment of squeaky clean
brain detergent that'll wash all your grey away
relinquish your mind, your soul 
to the sunshine terrorists
give in.  hell, read a book about it
there really must be something to this shit ...
do more people find inner peace at supermarkets or at raves?
if there were 5000 people who thought the produce section was truly a
mind blowing cosmic fucking place to be would Safeway not have
the same cultish draw and underground mystique?

swan dives, 
call it belly flop if you will, 
pull the feathers off one by one and
make me a real pretty new hat.

Dave

> >I haven't been involved long enough to know what  PLUR is?
>
> Yea, What the hell does it all mean anyway??????????????????????

It means "Phoney Love, Utopian Ruse" :-)

I dunno about you, but I've found that the people that talk about this
kind of stuff too much will be the first in line to rob, steal, cheat,
and disrespect you. It's clear that Shakespeare knew a lot about human
nature when he wrote "She Doth protest too much"... 

Lately, I've been trying to decode everybody's "doublespeak"... Like
when a new boss comes out and says "I'm one of the least top-down
hierarchical people I know" all my alarm bells ring because he's really
trying to tell me he's a fucking dictator, even if he's rationally
thinking and verbalizing how he'd really like to be seen.

Maybe it's just me, but when I hear people talk about PLUR too much,
you can bet they're just trying to pull the wool over yer eyes. This
pretty much applies to anybody that claims that any one thing, whether
it's PLUR, God, E, or whatever is *the answer* to all that ills us.
Hypocricy has been the bread and butter of human thinking for the last
few thousand years -- so you might as well butter both sides... because
when push comes to shove all that verbalized milquetoast is gonna land
butter-side-down.

	"Well here are a few simple adminitions for young and old...
	Beware of whores who say they don't want money. The hell they
	don't -- what they mean is they want more money... much more!
	If you're doing business with a religious son of a bitch -- get
	it in writing -- his word isn't worth shit, not with the good
	lord telling him how to fuck you up..."
			-- William S. Burroughs, 
			   "Words of Advice for Young People"
			   on Material's "Hallucination Engine" CD.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==     Niels Mayer -- http://cyborganic.com/~niels -- mayer@netcom.com     ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

From: Christopher Chervin <r100@cs.sierra.cc.ca.us>
Subject: Re: Help?, Anyone Care To Talk/RE: The Windscreen
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 9 May 95 17:50:55 PDT
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.3.91.950508173931.11405B-100000@liberty.liberty.com>; from "Brian Darkness" at May 8, 95 5:45 pm
Mailer: Elm [revision: 70.85.2.1]
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Most of us know the beautiful feeling of E.  It is amazing.  So absolutely amazing that I think its the closest   thing to magic that we have ever created.  So happy, so joyful, and so clear.  Crystal clear.  But what about the other side?  There is one.  It is the complete opposit feeling and it can come from the same pill.                                                        



Last May I went to Vision with a very close friend of mine.  We both took the same kind of E at the same exact    time.  When it kicked in we just started grooving.  It was incredible.  But within 5 minutes Robin lost it.  She  just stopped dancing and grabbed me.  "I feel so terribly sad," she said to me and I felt it! I had to do everything within my power not to lose myself to the terrible sadness that overwhelmed her.  She had to sit down so I found a spot along the crowded wall for her to rest.  It was not good.  Even though I felt so full of joy she was in a nightmare.  She wouldn't let go.  She fought herself for 4 hours, drenched with emptiness and guilt.  She told me that she knew exactly how Kurt Cobain must have felt.  I could see this in her eyes but I didnt know what to do.  I stayed with her the whole time until the E finaly wore off.  She said the emptiness hurt so bad that she       wouldnt even wish it on her worst enemy (IMNSHO Robins only enemy is Christiantys guilt treatment).  

I am not bashing on E.  It is a beautiful thing.  I am just saying that it can lead someone to suicide.  I have   Know idea what the situation is with that poor girl in Oregon and dont think there is a connection but I do accept that it is possible.  We must be careful as a group.  If we see someone hurting we must try to help them. I am   learning that feel is stronger than site.  Energy is real.  Vibe is real.  I felt Robins sadness up and down my   body and can only say that I would never want to be overwhelmed by that.  I hope true peace realy does come in `
death because even Adolf Hitler would be dancing to the eternal groove.


Love chris

t

Hey all,

Now lets move to something positive!  smarties.  Particulary Amy and Kim, two first time ravers, first time on E. Need I realy say more?  Well of course.  Amy YOU ARE AWSOME!!!!!  Amy is the product of a mantic-depressant 
mother and a negative-creep boyfriend.  She has always been so negative and I never realized her inner strength.  All I can say is if someone is TRULY searching than they WILL find.  Yes, Yes, Yes.  If you havent experinced the enery you can gain from introducing someone to HOUSE than you need to give it a try. Amy and Kim have made me     stronger.  I felt their enery enter me and become a part of me.  They are now apart of my family and it makes me  so happy.  This is why I love house music, raves, dj's, ravers, E, and the Energy that sourrounds us all.  It is  real and I love it so much. Well got to go I think the computer lab is being attacked by teachers and students.            
Love Chris

| Most of us know the beautiful feeling of E.  It is amazing.  So
| absolutely amazing that I think its the closest   thing to magic that
| we have ever created.  So happy, so joyful, and so clear.  Crystal
| clear.  But what about the other side?  There is one.  It is the
| complete opposit feeling and it can come from the same pill.           
| 
| Last May I went to Vision with a very close friend of mine.  We both
| took the same kind of E at the same exact    time.  When it kicked in
| we just started grooving.  It was incredible.  But within 5 minutes
| Robin lost it.  She  just stopped dancing and grabbed me.  "I feel so
| terribly sad," she said to me and I felt it! I had to do everything
| within my power not to lose myself to the terrible sadness that
| overwhelmed her.  She had to sit down so I found a spot along the
| crowded wall for her to rest.  It was not good.  Even though I felt so
| full of joy she was in a nightmare.  She wouldn't let go.  She fought
| herself for 4 hours, drenched with emptiness and guilt.  She told me
| that she knew exactly how Kurt Cobain must have felt.  I could see this
| in her eyes but I didnt know what to do.  I stayed with her the whole
| time until the E finaly wore off.  She said the emptiness hurt so bad

A while back there was a thread about X fatalities and I chimed in with
a big anti-X rant that a lot of people discounted, dismissed and
dissed. I even got some mail claiming that I've been brainwashed by the
media and drug-criminalization-happy right wingers (get a clue
X-heads!). Really, all I was saying is "don't believe the hype"...

Meanwhile, I'm just adding another tally to my observation from that
previous post. 

}} Subject: Re: X Fatality (was Re: The sky is falling - And that is only your opinion - chicken little )
}} From:    "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
}} Date:    Tue, 04 Apr 1995 19:17:54 PDT

}}     wading into dangerous addiction territory if you need to do more X to
}}     make yourself feel ok...  (i've spoken to a handful of people that feel
}}    the same way).
}} ...

PS: My agenda is to inform and opine. You can do anything you want...
if you're on X and feel like hugging me. Go right ahead. I'll just hug
you back without X! A hug is still a hug. A kiss is just a kiss.... As 
tweakers go bye!!

Hmmm, enforced PLUR.  Don't belive I've been beat about the head and shoulders
with enough kindess and love to believe that the PLUR stormtroopers are in
full force yet.

Not that being skeptical isn't a good thing.  
It's a very necessary tool that should be used 
when trying to figure out the world of human interactions.
But care should be taken not to be blinded by skepticisem 
anymore than by cults, bosses, corporations, or the next
"new age of love".  Remember, think for yourself, but try
to use more than one track.  

The Newt King

i DON'T think rave is all about kids and drugs. my point was that all the 
'peace and lovism' that people expound is a by product of the drug use. 
sure there is a heavy vibe one can pick up going sober (i get it all the 
time), but it's pure crap that all these people think they're going to 
'save the world', cause when your sorted anything goes. how 'bout when 
your sober; the real world hits you, and most people don't seem to take 
the 'revelations' they made the nite before to heart.
dis me all you want, but this needs to be said: try going out to raves 
for a month WITHOUT any sort of drugs. now tell me about 'peace and 
lovism'. if it works for you fine; but chances are it ain;t gonna happen.
now i'm not jadded about the rave scene at all. i've met all sorts of 
great people(you included), was able to produce my own music and records, 
worked for toontown back in the day.
i just think that alot of the statements people make are pure hyperbole. 
and that does nothing but make a mockery of the rave scene itself.
dj thad

At  5:39 PM 9/5/95 -0700, Niels P. Mayer wrote:
>> >I haven't been involved long enough to know what  PLUR is?
>>
>> Yea, What the hell does it all mean anyway??????????????????????
>
>It means "Phoney Love, Utopian Ruse" :-)
>
>I dunno about you, but I've found that the people that talk about this
>kind of stuff too much will be the first in line to rob, steal, cheat,
>and disrespect you. It's clear that Shakespeare knew a lot about human
>nature when he wrote "She Doth protest too much"...
>
>Lately, I've been trying to decode everybody's "doublespeak"... Like
>when a new boss comes out and says "I'm one of the least top-down
>hierarchical people I know" all my alarm bells ring because he's really
>trying to tell me he's a fucking dictator, even if he's rationally
>thinking and verbalizing how he'd really like to be seen.
>
>Maybe it's just me, but when I hear people talk about PLUR too much,
>you can bet they're just trying to pull the wool over yer eyes. This
>pretty much applies to anybody that claims that any one thing, whether
>it's PLUR, God, E, or whatever is *the answer* to all that ills us.
>Hypocricy has been the bread and butter of human thinking for the last
>few thousand years -- so you might as well butter both sides... because
>when push comes to shove all that verbalized milquetoast is gonna land
>butter-side-down.
>
>        "Well here are a few simple adminitions for young and old...
>        Beware of whores who say they don't want money. The hell they
>        don't -- what they mean is they want more money... much more!
>        If you're doing business with a religious son of a bitch -- get
>        it in writing -- his word isn't worth shit, not with the good
>        lord telling him how to fuck you up..."
>                        -- William S. Burroughs,
>                           "Words of Advice for Young People"
>                           on Material's "Hallucination Engine" CD.
>
>=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
>==     Niels Mayer -- http://cyborganic.com/~niels -- mayer@netcom.com     ==
>=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

this is but one way to look at the universe, a rather miserable and
paranoid one at that. Can you ever be sure that voice in your head (usually
called higher thought) , isn't also fucking you over? And how would you
know if the wool had been pulled over your own eyes?  The question you are
posing realy is - to trust or not to trust - the problem though with not
trusting is that while you might never  lose anything, you don't get to win
anything either. Its the play it safe, and do'nt jump into the unknown (the
place where you might just, maybe, might, get fucked over) called the big
bad world. Luckily not all humans believe this, so we got to rediscover the
new world, landed on the moon and climbed Mnt Everest in spite of the
possibility of the Yeti, Falling off the edge of the World, and Evil SPace
Aliens from the dark side of the moon beating us at cosmic poker. Of course
if you ever got into a game of poker, you might like to watch your
opponents body language. To have a poker face is but one sign and yet still
no match for that thing called luck.

- david dei

    okay. I've done that. People have come up to me countless of times 
and asked what I was on and DIDN'T believe me when i said nothing. I've 
done it and can still tell you and peace and love and all that...but i do 
think it has more to do with directing your OWN energy than feeding off 
other people's. The majority of the parties I've been to IN THE LAST 
YEAR, I have been sober and still feel the same way as I did when I first 
started going out. I don't think I have any special abilities in 
achieving this high(sometimes better than with drugs)without drugs. I 
just think most people forget that drugs-E and a couple others- can SHOW 
you love, but if you want to BE love...you gotta do that yourself. 

								tracy

> Yeah.  But the concept of "people being free to be themselves" *is* an 
> ideal.  It is a preconception to think that there can even be a stable 
> society in which we can be so completely free.  This is tied into the 
> inherent hypocricy of PLUR: Will you ever be able to respect and my desire 
> to rape you?
> 
depends what you're definition of "free" and "freedom" is... if it's 
being able to do what you want so long as you don't harm others, then 
obviously rape has nothing to do with freedom.

an aside:  i don't really use the term PLUR myself... i feel like the 
words "peace, love, unity and respect" are so overused and so often 
lacking meaning that they just don't feel heartfelt to me... maybe 
there's too many '60s connotations to me as well, of leechy sexist men 
saying oh yeah, peace and love, baby... maybe peace is just a little too 
vague, too - is it the absence of conflict?  sometimes we need to deal 
with conflict... i like the respect part, tho'....

with love and @,
monicat

hmmm.... i really feel uncomfortable with the implication here that 
people (women?) "scream" sexual harassment at the drop of a hat.  the 
majority of the time, this is simply not true, and the constant charges 
of people (women?) being too "sensitive" just adds fuel to the 
patriarchal fire, considering how much sexual harassment there really is.

really consider this a violation unless i am friends with the 
person and/or the person ASKS first... touching is intimate, and i don't 
necessarily want to, or feel obligated to, be intimate with every single 
person who comes up to me at a party...

THAT said, it IS weird to go back to the "straight world" and want to hug 
people you're close to (co-workers, etc.), but it's just too weird and 
awkward sometimes... i just remind myself, oh yeah, most people don't do 
this...

Well first of all, I want all the clued in people out there to name
the clubs that you are allowed to throw legal all night dance parties in.
I'll give you a hint, there are only 5.


> 
> OK stop here you got it on the first try...  hate to break it to you all but
> when you get down to the nitty gritty the Wicked crew is all about MONEY. 

Well as far as the DJs are concerned, they don't have any other jobs but DJing.
Kinda hard to eat and support a family without getting paid in some form.


> I
> don't care how many times they say Peace n Love (add English accent here) on
> the voice mail, from my experience promoters in the Bay area are into
> Money...  yea there are some who don't care about the money as much but I
> have learned with experience that if you look at it closely the money is what
> keeps em goin more than anything else...

There are only three promoters left in the city that throw consistant
legal all night parties, none of them to my knowledge are driving fancy
cars or even owning houses, one promoter owns some property but he no longer
throws parties in the City.

>  hey in the case of Wicked someone
> has to pay for the heroin.  Yea go ahead and flame me nut the truth hurts now
> doesn't it?  No not all of the Wicked crew are on heroin but there are some
> (some of the most important ones)  who are just a little bit more than fond
> of the stuff.  

Well I don't know if I'm an important one :) but I don't take heroin,
there are a couple of people who are no longer with the management or 
financial arm of the organization that you might be alluding to but as far
as I know I don't think heroin is any big issue here.  I know at least
on of the DJs has been completely drug free for over 2 1/2 years.



>I will admit that I am cynical about promoters.  I have known
> too many of them who will tell you till they are blue in the face that they
> do it for the people but when ya get down to making a choice concerning a
> party MONEY is king.  If ya all have not noticed the scene here has gone WAY
> down hill in the last year or so.  There are many reasons for this... one of
> them is the promoters and money, and to go a little further I think our
> little SF DJ click has also hurt the scene greatly.  

I think the reason that the scene has gone down is that people stopped caring.
Some of the long timers don't have trust funds and have to make a living
"off of the scene" when you have to do something for your survival it always
tarnishes it. But when you look around 90% of the promoters who were around
3 years ago are just not around anymore mostly because there IS NO MONEY TO BE
MADE.  There are only three promoter groups or posse's that are still operating
within the confines of San Francisco on any type of regular basis.



	Stompy - Preston
	FTT/Organic - Kevin & Jerry
	Wicked - Jeno, Markie, Garth, Thomas


Basics/Vision/Gathering doesn't count because martin rarely throws 
parties in the City any more.  The above three throw parties because they
believe in what they are doing.  None of them are rich.


> I think a wonderful start would be to STOP PUTTING DJ NAMES ON FLYERS etc.
>  The SOLE purpose of putting DJ names on flyers is to attract people...  to
> do this a DJ needs to get his/her name and image out there just like any
> other business.  Stopping this would stop the promotion of "celebrity" images
> that become very valuable in selling your party... this also allows the DJ to
> charge OUTRAGEOUS amounts of money...  most of which does not ever get back
> to the person who actually wrote the music.  Because "name" DJs are so
> expensive Promoters not wanting to lose any of their share also jack up the
> prices (which they did before anyway and would probably still do even if DJs
> were all free)  I know this will upset a lot of people but hey if you wanna
> be a rock star learn to play guitar... yea it takes more work but if fame
> were that easy there would be too many famous people-hence no real fame?(just
> in case you are wondering I have played guitar for 12 years but now primarily
> write house music and yes I am very confident with 2 turntables which I
> consider to have been by FAR the easiest of the 3 skills to pick up)  While
> I'm at it what ever became of that wonderful sound system that the Wicked
> crew bought?  Normally I could care less but I remember going to more than
> one party with flyers explaining that the party was 'x' amount of money
> because we are going to buy this great system "for everyone to use"  peace,
> love, rave etc. etc.  I don't see this system out too often...  I know they
> bought it but who can use it?  Is it free to use?  Ohh it costs money to use?
> Ohh so those were really donations for a source of income for the Wicked
> crew?  Naw...  the wicked crew would never tell you something like that just
> to make you feel good about spending money on their party...  they were
> really thoughtful in collecting donations for a sound system that would
> spread rave love to every one.  (yes they did put out flyers that led you to
> believe stuff like this and yes I still have some)  Sorry this is so long but
> I figure if Im gonna upset anyone I might as well get it all done in one
> shot...

The sound system is alive and well, it is used for there parties and part of
it is used for the full moon.  It is rented out from time to time as well.
The bottom line is that the wicked crew support themselves by throwing
parties, that is what they do.  They throw the full moons to give people who
don't go to the parties for lack of funds or because of age limitations to
have a chance to hear them play.  For good or for ill some people in the scene
use drugs, some I approve of some I don't.  I have seen e-dealers who carry 
9mm and junkies who are filled with love.  It is unfortunate that some people
have been ensnared in addictive behavior, even more unfortunate that some
people judge them and think it means something about their dedication to
peace and love.  Several years ago, I endulged in a very addictive substance,
but all the while I was doing this I was still the same loving person but
I was acting out a compulsion.  I managed to get away from it through a
combination of acquiring self-respect and through several loving friends.

Perhapse that is the answer here.

On Tue, 9 May 1995, David Alves wrote:

> do more people find inner peace at supermarkets or at raves?

My second trip to Raley's was blessed by a conversation struck up with a
motherly woman over brussels sprouts, leading into purple asparagus and
the nature of such a peculiar looking vegetable.

Realizing that I was new to the area, she recommended a local produce stand
a few blocks away and went into great detail of it's location.  

Somewhere in between her words I began to realize that yes, there's a rave
going on at Raley's... in the heart of Fremont... with Muzak on the
turntables and visuals by Flourescent and actually a decent price on
bottled water to boot... 

I was brought down from my trip when her daughter approached and asked, 
"Mommy, do you know that man?".

  :)

I like Fremont.

willis

No word on the girl in oregon folks!

/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\


Well I stayed home sick today. I had a 101 temp. and was sweating
bullets when I woke. It has I lot to do with this weekend in portland.
I'm glad to be back in sacramento. In my bed. With most of my sanity. I
woke a few times because of sweating and nightmares.

Mentally I'm beat.
I'm watching the news here though around 10:45 and this story catches my
eye. The TRACY women who's two children were kidknapped by their father
3 months ago was reunited with them tonight. I smiled during this whole
clip bacause I try to think of how angry she was when they were gone,
but now she is the happiest woman on earth. I smiled for her joy, and
for the love she had. I also like the way the local media covered the
story. They didn't glamorize that it was on their station, they just
said the story like it was. I needed to see that story. I need more like
them.

LOVE YOURSELF AND OTHERS WILL LOVE YOU,
RESPECT YOURSELF AND YOU WILL LEARN TO RESPECT OTHERS!

Soundgod@iccse.com
(Sound god is Andrew Dressler with nothing else to say for the moment)

	id EAA02001; Wed, 10 May 1995 04:12:44 -0700
From: deaks@netcom.com (Ernie Deakyne)
Message-Id: <199505101112.EAA02001@netcom14.netcom.com>
Subject: Re: End of rave scene/world...
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Wed, 10 May 1995 04:12:44 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1808      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

   Wow...  What is going on here guys???  When I first subscribed to this 
list a year ago, most of the chit-chat was about parties and music.  A 
few flames here and there, but good reading none the less.  Now, dont get 
me wrong, change is a healthy thing... But most messages these days 
consit of endless babble on economiX, politiX and drug addiX...  

   Of course, these controversial topics are interesting and some of the 
debates have been quite constructive.  But lately, things seem to be 
getting very exclusive and... quite honestly, boring.

   There have been MANY different opinions expressed on MANY different 
topics by VERY few people.  And with the exception of a handfull of well 
thought out messages, a lot of it is non-sense.  This group seems to be 
becoming inefficient.  Conclusions are no longer being reached, actions 
are being taken by only a few people, and most people probably just 
delete 90% of the messages these days.  Communication with the group as 
a whole is breaking down.

   And yes, we are dealing with a very large group.  I would suppose if 
we all were to attend a large meeting on rave ethics, nothing would be 
accomplished... Because we would all have an equal voice.  So all I can 
really say is to remember who your audience is.  If your discussion has 
become a 3 person debate, take it to private E-mail.  If you want the 
whole list to hear your views, make them interesting and write them 
well.  I would hate to see this list become a big pile of junk mail. If 
each message was individualy mailed to each subscriber via snail mail, 
just think how much of it would be thrown out??  If we want to save the 
scene and if we think we can use E-mail as a tool to help us, then let's 
start using it better... :)

   Just my thoughts...

 -Ernie

             PANEL NEGATIVE.

Medical Cause of Death:  CARDIAC DYSRHYTHMIA DUE TO IDIOSYNCRATIC
             DRUG REACTION (BLOOD MDA = 0.54 MG/L, MDMA = 0.02 MG/L;
             SERUM MDA = 0.23 MG/L, MDMA = 0.01 MG/L; PERICARDIAL
             FLUID MDA = 0.70 MG/L, MDMA = 0.05 MG/L)

Coroner's Verdict
-----------------

MORGAN SHIBLES JONES DIED DUE TO OR AS A CONSEQUENCE OF AN ACCIDENT


   May 02, 1995                   <Signed>
   ------------                   --------------------------------
   DATE                           CORONER   ERVIN J. JINDRICH, M.D.

----------------------------------------------------------------------
....
IX   INVESTIGATION SUMMARY

1116 hours, April 1, 1995, received a phone call from comm. center
to contact a Twin Cities Police Department officer at Marin General
Hospital Emergency Room regarding a possible overdose.  Reporting
officer responded to the emergency room and met with the officer.
R/O was told that decedent was found unresponsive this morning after
attending a "rave" in San Francisco the night before.  Information
obtained by the officer was that the decedent had ingested a "dose"
of "Ecstasy" approximately 0430 hours, April 1, 1995, and when he
had not obtained the reaction he wanted took another "dose" at
approximately 0500 hours, April 1, 1995.  Decedent stayed at a
friends home later and was discovered unresponsive later that 
morning.  (See Twin Cities Police Department report).

....

Kenneth Harlan, Coroner's Investigator

Approved: K.P. Holmes, Asst. Coroner

----------------------------------------------------------------------

in it, is this true or does the body convert MDMA into MDA, any biochemist
out there?

Thank you Peter for posting the death certificate, It is always better to
know the facts.  I never met Morgan personally but I do feel a loss when
things like this happen.

There is a clear and present danger when you purchase drugs on the street.
I've always been worried when I see folks pop pills that they get from any
random source with any random name.


Me: What's that?
Her: It's this new drug called Illusion!
Me: But What is it?
Her(puzzled): It's Illusion.
Me: But what's it made of, what are it's properties?
Her: Gee, I don't know.

Drugs are serious business, please know your sources.

Well I went to Groove Room last night.

Rich Cooley was spinning at the time of arrival, and not a bad set I might
add. =)

Waves is ok for relaxing purposes, and talking with friends, and meeting
new friends.  There is no smoking in the venue it self except for right out
side the door.  So the air is definitely breathable in there. =)
And the venue is 18 and up =) =) =) for all you wonderful young people.
There is free ice water at the counter which is always nice.

I believe it was John Howard who came up next with a very good set indeed.
He was playing a lot of good beats, but my body was just energized for head
bouncing.  I left around 1:30, bound for sleep.  There were enough people
to fill the place comfortably, people dancing, playing pool, and of course
a BASS ale is always nice.  So if you people are close to Waves in Los
Gatos, and you just want to have a beer and listen to some good music check
it out.

Goodday,

Siphon "The Pig is PHAT"
noah@cadence.com
e-mail me for info on siphon creations
-=ambient+techno+experimental=-

>On Tue, 9 May 1995, Thaddeus Jones wrote:

>> i DON'T think rave is all about kids and drugs. my point was that all the 
>> 'peace and lovism' that people expound is a by product of the drug use. 
>> sure there is a heavy vibe one can pick up going sober (i get it all the 
>> time), but it's pure crap that all these people think they're going to 
>> 'save the world', cause when your sorted anything goes. how 'bout when 
>> your sober; the real world hits you, and most people don't seem to take 
>> the 'revelations' they made the nite before to heart.
>> dis me all you want, but this needs to be said: try going out to raves 
>> for a month WITHOUT any sort of drugs. now tell me about 'peace and 

>    okay. I've done that. People have come up to me countless of times 
>and asked what I was on and DIDN'T believe me when i said nothing. I've 
>done it and can still tell you and peace and love and all that...but i do 
>think it has more to do with directing your OWN energy than feeding off 
>other people's. The majority of the parties I've been to IN THE LAST 
>YEAR, I have been sober and still feel the same way as I did when I first 
>started going out. I don't think I have any special abilities in 
>achieving this high(sometimes better than with drugs)without drugs. I 
>just think most people forget that drugs-E and a couple others- can SHOW 
>you love, but if you want to BE love...you gotta do that yourself. 

>								tracy

   I too have gone to a few  sober (only been to about 10 raves altogether) 
and had a great time.  I've gotten a very high feeling while being there. (That
trance dance state is not dependent on drugs but on the rhythms and the drum
beats.)  The Love energy and vibe is also there to be felt by the sober ones, 
it's just that alot of our natural defenses block this and drugs sometimes
help overcome them. Some aspects are even better than when flying. 

Craig

Received: from ultima.org by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with SMTP id LAA21454; Wed, 10 May 1995 11:58:45 -0700
Received: from ultima.org by ultima.org; Wed, 10 May 95 12:08 PDT

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Wed, 10 May 95 12:08 PDT
From: tic-tac@ultima.org (Joe Rice)
Subject: Re: Wicked (money promoters and DJs); now flame bait
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 0:18 5/10/95, Geoff White wrote:

>Well first of all, I want all the clued in people out there to name
>the clubs that you are allowed to throw legal all night dance parties in.
>I'll give you a hint, there are only 5.

DV8
1015 Folsom
Cesar's Latin Palace
Trocadero
Sound Factory

I think when it comes down to it you can't always blame the promoters. Sure
there are greedy ones, but they generally don't last too long and get a
nasty reputation and have move to other cities after awhile. (Or maybe that
was just LA). I used to judge promoters pretty severely based upon my
perception of motivations. Often it seemed like the primary factor was to
throw a good party for its own sake - not what I'd ideally hope for, but
not bad.

Look at it this way, though - we all have the freedom to choose how much
we're going to pay for a party. Nobody's going to force you to drop $15-20
on a Wicked, FTT, or Vision. Personally, as a promoter, I wouldn't want to
try and make a living off of the scene and have to adjust production size
and entrance fee so I could pay my rent, but I don't disrespect those who
do. I was just talking to Martin (Basics etc.) the other day and he's not
living large. He could probably make more money as a bricklayer (his
professional trade)!

I see the bigger parties becoming more and more estranged from the true
underground spirit - tours? C'mon. Wicked in Portland was great, but the
merchandising gave it the feel of some sort of weird arena rock/rave
hybrid. Not necessarily a bad thing exposure wise, but evidence of
evolution in the scene and demostration of the need for new thinking on how
it's integrated.

Joe


(:Joe Rice:_____________:tic-tac@ultima.org:_____________:ambient@netcom.com:)

>I'm no expert but it seems that Morgan got something that had a lot of MDA
>in it, is this true or does the body convert MDMA into MDA, any biochemist

The report also showed that Morgan was 10 to 100 times below the toxic level
of these drugs.  His death was not directly caused by the drugs. It may have
allowed him to push himself over the edge of physical exertion but he did not
die from a toxic overdose.

>There is a clear and present danger when you purchase drugs on the street.
>I've always been worried when I see folks pop pills that they get from any
>random source with any random name.

>Drugs are serious business, please know your sources.

Date: Wed, 10 May 1995 12:51:32 -0700
Message-Id: <199505101951.MAA19776@scruz.net>
Subject: Re: Death of Morgan Jones
To: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White), sfraves@hyperreal.com
X-Mailer: AIR Mail 3.X (SPRY, Inc.)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>I'm no expert but it seems that Morgan got something that had a lot of MDA
>in it, is this true or does the body convert MDMA into MDA, any biochemist
>out there?

Quoting from the book E is for Ecstacy:

Overdosing affects the liver, and can cause death at doses of
between 15 and 200 tablets. He said that MDMA is broken down by the liver
into MDA and metabolites, which are excreted by the kidneys into the urine.

Urinary excretion of unchanged MDMA and its metabolites is complete within
24 hours. 65% of the dose is excreted unchanged in the urine and 7% as MDA.

-Sean

-SeanC@scruznet.com
 "House Music All Night Long"

hey everyone,


  when i fiest srarted going to raves for the first two years i never
did any drug when going to a party and was still touched by the vibe.
  im glad ive used them also cause they have given me a new insights on
myself and other people, but i still go to more events straight then 
not.

  about the vibe and it being lost:

  i think that a lot of people who have been in the scene for awhile
have lost the inital euphoria and excitement of going to raves.  Their
visions of raves are clouded by thinking how good the  "ole days" were
and how horrible things are today.  I have to disagree.
  I still go with the idea that i can go have a good time and meet 
anyone at a party.  Thats whats its really about.  Dancing, getting into
the music and carrying along the vibe within yourself to others.

  on the east coast (where im from and went to parties for two years
before moving out here last year)  everyone is complaining about how
the drugs are ruining the scene.  two people in the scene in recent
weeks died of heroin overdoses, and in baltimore the drugs people are
usually offered are k and crystal, instead of e and acid.  

  people look at SF as the shining example of what a rave scene should
be.  and even tho there are faults in both scenes,  i think that what
is here, people should feel rather lucky about.

peace 

doug ) ( doug@squishy.com

p.s. -   Ive been going to a lot of raves lately to do a photo essay
about them.  Too many actually ;)  But my essay is almost complete
and i hope to have them posted up on hyperreal.  more info later :)

I just want to say that I have only been to one actual rave but I have 
attended smaller parties.  The first time I experienced all of you and that 
incredible sound on a sustem justified to play it right, I was totally 
high...in fact it was like flipping high (and that's so insane), but I hadn't 
taken any drugs.  I was high on all of you, your energy and that incredible 
physiologically compatiable rhythm that peameates us all when listening to 
house.  

My first real "rave" I was and it was also phenomenal, and different.  What I 
am trying to say is I get high from the people and the music.  I am constantly 
on a high that this community exists and that in my own way I am part of it 
and contribute to it all the positive energy and love that I can offer.  That 
has nothing to do with drugs.  What you bring is yours.  Most importantly, 
what you bring is you.  That's what really makes me high.

Love Anais

We can be anything we want, and feel any way we want, because we are creating 
our own community based on the values we cherish!

> >> It means "Phoney Love, Utopian Ruse" :-)
> >> ==     Niels Mayer 

Pure lucy upon demand, phat loud underground revolution,
pleasure loving urban radicals, please let us rave, planet loving united 
republic, pagan legions unda' rekkids, etc.

When I first heard it, I thought it meant 'plurality', as in 'the moral 
majority isn't, people everywhere wanna party'.

> > paranoid one at that. Can you ever be sure that voice in your head (usually
> > called higher thought), isn't also fucking you over? 
> > - david dei

Many equate belief in the voice in their head to belief in their own sanity.
I'm one.

> I propose that listening to the voice in your head is a hell of
> a lot better than lining up under 10 cent e platitudes ...
> -david alves

Agreed.

> E for Bullshit and toxic levels mean NOTHING.  

Not so. I am so goddamn fucking angry that people are still forced to buy
'recreational drugs' without really knowing what they are getting. How
many side reactions in a synthetic route are accounted for by the 'chemists'
out there? When designer drugs first appeared in the mid-80's, there were
a number of narcotic analogues that quickly fell out of fashion because the
'designers' were not purifying their product, and people were getting 
really messed up. The drug itself was not the problem. My interpretation 
is that legalization would at least result in people knowing what they 
are getting. 

People do not need to die this way. People have used drugs for thousands 
of years. They will continue to do so and so will I and so will you. We 
need to deal with the situation as it is, not as we wish it was. This
is not to say drugs are a requirement for this scene, but they are a *part*
of it, and it only takes one mistake.

> How can anyone possibly suggest that ecstacy wasn't responsible 
> for that poor fellow's death?  Does direct or indirect mean Jack 
> to his friends and family??

See above. Also, in my experience, even if you have a pure substance, how
you otherwise treat yourself makes all the difference. People should just
get into the habit of making sure everyone is drinking plenty of water,
don't assume your friend knows that he/she needs water. Dehydration and
exhaustion can hurt you very badly; unfortunately, personal experience
confirms this.

> Ernie says (in part),
> > If we want to save the scene and if we think we can use E-mail
> > as a tool to help us, then let's start using it better... :)

I agree. I've flamed people on this list in the past and it produced nothing
of value.

-Dave i.

From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)
Message-Id: <199505110205.TAA16945@nexsys.nexsys.net>
To: litterbx@priscilla.ultima.org
Subject: Re: Wicked (money promoters and DJs);
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> 
> yeh the fmr is a free party but it seems to be rather exclussive in a 
> number of ways.  1 it seems like the interested public just cannot always 
> get clued in to the location( i use seems like because i am concluding 
> this from others' problems) 2 the fmr are restricted to those indidvuals 
> who own cars and can afford to get to work late, since many fmrs start at 
> 4 am and most people have to work at 8 or 9 .
> i have been just to busy trying to take care of my basic needs to prance 
> around after wicked anymore 
> tomcat
> 
The FMRs are hard to find because:

	1) It is a tradition
	2) It's suppose to be hard to find, that makes you feel
	   ever so happy when you do find it.
	3) If they are easy to find they quickly become out of control.

The FMRs start late because:
	1) There are less police patrols
	2) many of the DJ have earlier gigs
	3) it cuts down on the numbers and thus the chance of it getting busted

The FMRs are held way out because:
	1) The SFPD generally bust them immediately (except for one location)
	2) It's easier to blast sound in a remote area with no houses around
	   and live to tell the tale :)

At least one FMR ago, even I was surprised at the location and didn't find
out until 10 p.m. :)  It keeps it fresh.

hpcprod@lcc1.nsc.com (Craig Lauxman):
> The coroners report suggested that E was not responsible.
> Read it yourself, or are you just trolling for flames as it would appear.

Ahem. F...... ok, I'm going to be nice about this since you're trolling
for flames.

I read it myself. Here's how I see it.

I'm still standing by a point I made April Anti-X posting: "Re: X
Fatality (was Re: The sky is falling - And that is only your opinion -
chicken little )" 
| (2) The crap that passes for X nowadays is a joke. It's much like playing 
|     russian roulette.

Ok, so it was mostly MDA and not MDMA. I'm wondering if that happened
because the producers fucked up in manufacturing -- MDA and MDMA are
closely related. I've heard that MDMA is a harder-to-make form of MDA,
and that one is a precursor to another. They're both speed. Keed Spills.

I've heard too many people say "this is really weird X... great visuals
though!" ... I guess the more out-of-it X posi-head might say "well, at
least they were really trying to make the right thing!".... :-(

And I don't know about you, but a rave is perhaps not the best setting
for MDA, especially if you're not expecting it. And MDA is really quite
nasty to your health (liver damage). 

Anyways... If you do look at the cause of death on the report, however,
you might notice that the causes of death are "edema" and "hemorrhage",
which are exactly the causes of death in DIC (disseminated
intravascular coagulation) which is a "documented problem with MDMA,
although very rare":

See this for yourself in what looks to be Peter Jones (Morgan Jones'
father?) posting of the coroner's report to this list:

| Subject: Death of Morgan Jones
| From:    peter@island.com (Peter Jones)
| Date:    Wed, 10 May 95 08:21:19 PDT
| 
| DIAGNOSES:   1. FOCAL EPICARDIAL HEMORRHAGE - HEART
|              2. NO PATHOLOGIC DIAGNOSES - PITUITARY, ADRENAL,
|                 THYROID SPLEEN, PANCREAS, THYMUS, KIDNEY
|              3. MARKED EDEMA - LUNGS
|              4. VASCULAR CONGESTION - LIVER
|              5. EDEMA - BRAIN

Just for completeness, here's some clippings from a newsgroup discussion 
about this death that I reposted to sfraves on 4/4/95 ("Subject: X fatality"):

>jfrank@twain.oit.umass.edu (?) writes:
>Jay Majer (zilla@netcom.com) wrote:
>: I got a call from a friend of mine in the SF Bay area this morning.  A 
>: friend of his went to a rave last night where he bought and took a hit of 
>: X. An hour later he wasn't feeling much, so he bought and took another. 
>: Effects hit him shortly thereafter. Early this morning, he walked into 
>: his kitchen and passed out. His roommate came to find him puking blood 
>: all over the place. He called an ambulance, and then when he found that 
>: he had no more pulse, he tried resuscitation. By the time the ambulance 
>: arrived, he was dead.
>
>An epilepsy perhaps?
>
>Puking blood might be from disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) which
>is a documented problem with MDMA, although very rare.
>
>- --
>Lamont Granquist (lamontg@u.washington.edu)

Also in "Subject: X fatality":

peter@petermc.demon.co.uk (Peter McDermott)
> I bet it _was_ MDMA. It sounds like a classic example of death from
> Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation -- ie, your body overheats and
> you start suffering from massive internal haemmoraging. I would also
> bet that if someone was taken to a US hospital in this state, the A & E
> crews wouldn't have the first idea how to respond.

PS: As far as where I stand on all this. Legalize, Educate. Regulate.
Know. The current situation is designed to promote "war" as the
status-quo, which exists solely to sustain, enrich, and grow two armed
factions (government/police and drug dealers), neither of which would
exist without the other. And don't forget the whor(d)es of  Lawyers,
Judges, Prison Guards/Construction/etc, and the combinatorics of
possibilities that happen when corruption and graft are thrown in to
the pot. And that isn't even counting all the people on the sidelines
that are getting phucked while politicians and pimps are making fat
dollars off of misery. Why, I'll bet it's one of the largest
"industries" in amerikkka today!

Dear All;

	Thanks to all da truely beautiful, loving people that took some
risks and shared their thoughts, feelings, & experiences around suicide,
with me and for me. It still feels good everytime I readem, and I do it a
lot. 

	I'm still pretty shaken by it, I'm told that some people are
really traumaized by such harse realities of life, eg me. They call it
emotional shock, sorta like when the body goes into shock tring to protect
itself from a lot of damage, only its emotional for me. 

	Each day gets a little better, I spent the day driving around the
little towns North and West of Marin, & Novato, respectively, on da coast.
I saw my 1st Redwood Forest, ever:), it was really cool!!!! :) I just had
an overwhelming desire and need to be around something green, natural, and
alive. 

	I decided today, while driving around to restart my horseback
riding lessons, English Saddle, or Western depending on where I get to
trail ride at, that's natural beauty wise. Its's sooo pretty where I was
today, so thats where I'm looking for a stable & instructor. I don't know
what I like more, the meadows, the hills/meadows, the huge Redwood
forests/hills/meadows, the cliffs by the sea, the ocean was sooo blue, its
just all sooo fantastic, beautiful, and wonderfully unique, just like us.
I'm going driving around up there tommorroe if anyone wants to join me,
call me at one of the numbers listed below. 

	Again thanks, it really makes me feel all warm, fuzzy, cared for,
and loved, and it won't be forgoten. Love & lots of huzs/ and a million
tiny little kisses all over :) :)

Mime-Version: 1.0

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Um, excuse me pardon me -- "lick our wounds and go on"?  I gotta call
you on that one, Pete1816.  I didn't know Morgan, but I bet I know
a couple dozen people who did.  He was one of *us*, the SF ravers.
Regardless of the precise cause of his death, it affects us all.
I'm not being trite by saying that.  

In the past year, three people I knew from the Well, my online home,
died from various causes.  In all cases the online community gathered
together in its own nonorganized way, and offered remembrances and
observations.  Death is a part of life, not to be ignored and not to
be belittled.  It is a part of the life experience we have not yet
experienced, but we will.  Our lives and deaths are part of the great
chain of being on this planet, in this universe.  When someone dies,
it is important and universal in all human cultures to recognize that
fact, acknowledge their experiences and contribution to our lives, and
remember that our very existence here is so dependent on our connections
to each other.

To me, the often-debated concepts of PLUR and the House Nation encompass,
in ways relevant to our current situation, underlying concepts that help
cement human societies together.  We will need that in the troubled times
to come, regardless of what labels we put on those concepts.  When a
tragedy occurs such as what happened to Morgan Jones, it is the height
of irresponsibility and immaturity and denial of our own human existence
to say, "lick our wounds and go on," as if someone's life was a car that
was totalled in a wreck.  The car is a total loss, a machine, we can
build another and go on.  A life is unique, it is part of our shared
humanity, not just a cartoon to be forgotten when the channel is changed.

I think we should all feel humbled by Peter Jones' posting of his son's
death certificate.  This is an important lesson for all of us.  What
little I know of his response to this ultimate family tragedy indicates
a strong, positive and loving attitude that is not content, as is so
often the case in our foolish and self-centered society, in laying *blame*
for this event but instead in finding the wisdom that helps us all move
forward.

Celebrate life.

phred

Precedence: bulk


>Why are sad things like this being posted?  

Because it behooves everyone to know the truth about any drug-related incident.

>I mean yeah it was obvious that
>it wasnt the E that killed him.... so... 

Though I ain't no biochemist, I gather that Morgan took a misrepresented 
substance that caused a deadly, though rare, reaction.  The literature shows 
that MDA is FAR more toxic than MDMA, and maybe two hits of unadulterated 
MDMA would have left him alive to dance today.

>I know that i am probably gonna get
>mail back on this, but, cant we just lick our wounds and go on?

My anger is directed less at you and more at unscrupulous chemists and 
dealers.  But most of my bitterness on this issue is aimed at a country 
that, through years of ignorance and sanctimony, believes (for the most 
part) that drug use is immoral.  If the stuff were legal then we'd all know 
just what we're taking; and I'd like to think that everyone would be 
interested enough to _read_ about what they're doing to their bodies.  
Everyone would be wiser, safer, and happier.

*  Every MDMA-eater should have and read _PiKHAL_ and/or the other lit.

*  Every MDMA-eater should know and trust his chemist/dealer like a bro.

*  Let's do away with the nicknames.  Not only does using slang like "E" and 
   "Nexus" misrepresent the product, it makes the speaker sound like a    
   high-school hood.

*  Let's push ever harder to get these things legalized already. 

More later......

--
Joe Kenny     SLAC-ESHD/SHAD                 jck@dewey.tis.inel.gov or
"He who fears the dragon                      jkenny@slac.stanford.edu
eventually becomes a dragon." --Chinese proverb

supermarket the day after the party, early in the morning too as the party
had been busted.  We ran around aimlessly throught the lurid aisles of
product, yelling to each other "let's get some ice cream" and getting lots

weren't really that hungry anyway.

I read somehting about that too(Food of the Gods maybe?)  Siberian reindeer
herdsmen have been known to drink the urine of their reindeer after seeing
them eat Fly Agaric(Amanita Muscaria) mushrooms.  Apparently the deer get a
nice high,  stagger around, and do a good job of removing or reducing the
toxins.  I think those shrooms will pretty much kill a human if ingested
directly.
So the question is how to get the e outa the pee....

Ok people! =)

Death takes alot of energy out of the living!
I have delt with death receantly with my best friends wife(cancer), and let
me tell you it takes so much energy it's completely draining.  With all
this talk about death its got me thinking of how I delt with the loss.  And
what we all have to do is keep our minds busy, be strong, talk about it,
but never forget its around the corner.  All this support on the list is
wonderful.  If I had this much support last year I wouldn't have had to
take a leave of abbsence from work.  But allwell, its great to see people
caring!!! =) =)

Thought I'd put my 2 cents in....

Goodday,

Noah Ruiz
noah@cadence.com

Cadence Design Systems
