On Thu, 11 May 1995, phuture said:

>I read somehting about that too(Food of the Gods maybe?)  Siberian reindeer
>herdsmen have been known to drink the urine of their reindeer after seeing
>them eat Fly Agaric(Amanita Muscaria) mushrooms.  Apparently the deer get a
>nice high,  stagger around, and do a good job of removing or reducing the
>toxins.  I think those shrooms will pretty much kill a human if ingested
>directly.

They would also eat it them selves and save their own piss. It's a 
beautiful shroom (big and red with cool white spots all over it) that grows
in the bay area. It's toxicity varies greatly from person to person. Everywhere 
from a very mild reaction - to delirium, hallucinations, babbling and cold 
sweats - to convulsions, uncontrollable shaking, and in very rare cases, death. 
(I learned this at a Fungus Festival in Santa Cruz. It was a totally legit 
type of thing.)

Isn't weird how the exact same substance can cause such a wide variety of 
reactions in different people.  Probably some kinda lesson there or something.

The Newt King

ps. The mushrooms are up now but please don't get any ideals.

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Morgan (perhaps i'm a little late on this one)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I didn't fully realize what the story behind Morgan Jones was
due to my somewhat sporadic reading of this list.  Perhaps I missed
an entire discussion on this already.

However, my quick reaction was how Pathetic it is to be defending
the drug - "oh it's indirect", "you could/should do this", "ecstacy
is still great, how sad about that guy".

When I was first exposed to this drug I went to the Library.  What
I found at the time were mostly journal articles with a psychiatric
lean to them.  Lots of detailed accounts of the drug experience.
Among these accounts, were the occasional
Extremely Bad Reaction.

One case of a two couples, same drug source, and a fabulous
evening at home.  A month later, same drugs, one woman walks
outside and describes "the world going greyish black like a nuclear
armeggedon", she passes out and is hospitalized for 36 hours
during which time she hallucinates wildly and must be carefully
watched and medicated.  The other 3 were fine.

Now you can speculate til the cows come home about why this kinda
thing happened or can happen.  But that is missing the point.

It Does Happen.
It is a Serious Drug.  
There are Serious Risks.
 
Risks that have nothing to do with the pop-chemistry crap that passes 
for scientific proof of the wonderfulness of ecstacy.  This is the
reality of Life.  You can't justify or explain it all.

I've said this before - I think informed adults can do what they
want.  Phred said exactly what I would have.  There is a young man
who is dead, gone Forever.  That is the Big Bad world that raving
is a Part of.  There is no escape from it.  It is real.  And some
of you should grow up a little.  Immortality is for kids.

Dave

Date: Thu, 11 May 1995 13:04:04 -0700
Message-Id: <199505112004.NAA20605@taz.hyperreal.com>
Received: from ibex by SLACVM.SLAC.STANFORD.EDU (IBM VM SMTP V2R1) with TCP;
   Thu, 11 May 95 13:03:23 PST
X-Sender: jck@dewey.tis.inel.gov
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: jck@tis.inel.gov (Joseph Kenny)
Subject: Re: Death of Morgan Jones
Cc: jon@netnoir.com, jkenny@slac.stanford.edu
X-Mailer: <PC Eudora Version 1.4>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


jon@netnoir.com (Jonathan Santos) wrote:
 (I) wrote:
>>*  Every MDMA-eater should have and read _PiHKAL_ and/or the other lit.

>Who the heck are you to be preaching this?

Gah.  What would Sasha say?


>>*  Every MDMA-eater should know and trust his chemist/dealer like a bro.
>No shit!

Okay, you're right.  It is kinda trite.


>>*  Let's do away with the nicknames.  Not only does using slang like "E" and
>>   "Nexus" misrepresent the product, it makes the speaker sound like a
>>   high-school hood.
>Who cares!?  You sound like a tight ass that doesn't let himself have fun...

Had Morgan's chemist been a bit more tightassed, we wouldn't be having this 
conversation.  

Look, maybe dispensing with the street names is a bit severe, but everytime 
a raver dies from anything remotely drug-related, everytime a raver with no 
pupils gets in front of a tv camera, and everytime a rave-related accident 
endangers life/property, we get a step closer to having the guvmint end 
raving forever.  MDMA is dangerous.  Now you and I know that it's less 
dangerous than eating a Jumbo Jack, but the government doesn't make those 
kind of distinctions.  We must be on our best behavior to keep credibility.  
This doesn't mean "don't do E", it means "do E responsibly". 

>>*  Let's push ever harder to get these things legalized already.
>hmmm.

I've only been to a few ba.events, but the authorities here pretty much 
leave the MJ/LSD/MDMA set alone, which is great: we're the least likely to 
bring violence into it.  But if they wanted to, they could seize anything at 
any event under the cloak of "good faith" without trial.  Done often enough, 
it would kill the scene.  The only way we can overcome the fear that's 
causing us (and the Joneses & g-slaying victims & the incarcerated & their 
families) so much grief is to legalize drugs, tax the shit out of them, and 
use the money for education and quality control.

Okay.  I'm through preaching to the choir now.  Back to our regularly 
scheduled programming.  
--
Joe Kenny     SLAC-ESHD/SHAD                 jck@dewey.tis.inel.gov or
"He who fears the dragon                      jkenny@slac.stanford.edu
eventually becomes a dragon." --Chinese proverb

From: michael h david <mdavid01@ccsf.cc.ca.us>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: mdma
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Let us not try and manipulate statistics following the same path trodden
by the tabacco industry.

Virtually everyone has eaten fast food in america. There are few injuries
deaths per participant. It would be interesting to see how many people
who have taken mdma have experianced problems or death.

Your post reminded me of a joke i heard somewhere

Three statisticians go on a hunting trip with bows and arrows.
they spend hours getting just close enough to their prey.
one fires and the arrow lands ten feet to the right of the deer.
hurridly another fires and the arrow lands ten feet to the left.
All heads turn as the third throws his bow to the ground and yells
we got him we got him!

More often than not anyone using statistics to prove their point is 
quietly hiding a fact or two not included in the study.

Nevertheless this story leads me to think of some of the things I have
done haphazardly, or taken at raves.....and shudder..then thank god or
whoever that I am very fortunate.

			---Mike

To: hpcprod@lcc1.nsc.com (Craig Lauxman)
From: chriser@cats.ucsc.edu (Christine wong)
Subject: Re: Re:urine and shrooms
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


[Craig Lauxman on shrooms and pee]
>They would also eat it them selves and save their own piss. It's a 
>beautiful shroom (big and red with cool white spots all over it) that grows
>in the bay area. It's toxicity varies greatly from person to person.
>Everywhere 
>from a very mild reaction - to delirium, hallucinations, babbling and cold 
>sweats - to convulsions, uncontrollable shaking, and in very rare cases,
>death. 
>(I learned this at a Fungus Festival in Santa Cruz. It was a totally legit 
>type of thing.)

I have a friend who went to Oregon and picked a bunch of those mushrooms!
They looked like Super Mario Brothers mushrooms that make you get big when
you get 'em (does anyone know what I am talking about?).  Real cool.  So
anyway he and another friend dried them and ate them.  My role in this
whole thing was to call 911 if somthing were to go wrong...  (Yeah, I know
it was stupid, but we were just punk kids).

So  nothing happened for hours and hours, they ate more and more, about
eight hours later they gave up.  Later still-- They suffered from chronic
fatigue for about three days.  Their self proclaimed conclusion: "We're
sleeepy." 


>Isn't weird how the exact same substance can cause such a wide variety of 
>reactions in different people.  Probably some kinda lesson there or something.


The moral of my story:

        Don't eat strange fungi if you have important things to do in the  
                                                         future.

--
chrisT

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To svbscribe or
   unsvbscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   svbscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsvbscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To svbscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   svbscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu May 11 16:25:51 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id QAA09177; Thu, 11 May 1995 16:25:51 -0700
Received: from hal.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with SMTP id QAA09170; Thu, 11 May 1995 16:25:48 -0700
Received: from dre.hal.com by hal.com (4.1/SMI-4.1.1)
	id AA07972; Thu, 11 May 95 16:25:50 PDT
Received: by dre.hal.com (4.1/SMI-4.1.2)
	id AA04085; Thu, 11 May 95 16:25:48 PDT
Date: Thu, 11 May 95 16:25:48 PDT
From: jocelyn@hal.com (Jocelyn Cordell)
Message-Id: <9505112325.AA04085@dre.hal.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Exercising Caution
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I think we're all basically saying the same thing:
Please make well-informed choices. 

I would especially caution those with lots of known allergies.
Me, I was allergic to all artificial coloring, flavoring, eggs,
wheat, milk, perfums, wool, and corn syrup while growing up. 
I am still horribly affected by 
chocolate and certain other foods (anything fried leaves me 
totally depressed). Aside from the very few drugs I have introduced 
into my system, I know I won't be introducing any more 
unknowns- I'm just too sensitive. I've also been careful to 
monitor myself: next day temperature taking, inspecting my 
skin for weird abbrasions, checking my color, gum color, etc... 
I guess it's somewhat paranoid, but given my history perhaps 
you'll sympathize- I approach all new substances/foods/liquids 
with the tenant," If there's an allergic reaction to be had, 
it's quite likely I'll have it."

Also those who take regular medication 
for whatever ills he/she may suffer: please talk to your 
doctor about mixing stuff. 

It would be great to compile a list of internists (internal medicine 
practitioners), ob/gyns, dermatologists, etc.... who are 
rationally pro-informative towards the use of illegal substances.
Any recommendations out there? 

As for Morgan Jones, it seems completely obvious to me that this 
was one of those "rare" DIC cases. As far as I'm concerned, 
neither denial nor hysteria are appropriate responses; 
acknowledgement seems fitting. 

A world of open possibilities would be one of the ways I might describe 
raves. This being the case, it's easy enough to admit DIC as 
one of those possibilities without totally trashing or 
permanently tarnishing the positive experiences many have with E. 
For E users, acknowledging DIC might change (probably does) the 
perspective/experience of E, but, frankly, I think it changes it for 
the better simply because we are aware of one more possibility. 

If knowledge is power, then humility and empowerment are 
not mutually exclusive.

"I don't know" is better than a lie.

with gentle reverence-

Jocelyn

Something someone sent me. Don't know if it's a lark or what, but
thought it was nifty just the same:

>>-----------------------------------
>>From: rocky@syl.sj.nec.com (Rochelle Grober)
>>-|From erent009.credence.COM!moorer@credence.com Fri May  5
>>10:00:20 1995
>>-|Date: Fri, 5 May 95 09:22:09 PDT
>>-|From: moorer@erent009.credence.COM (Rodney Moore)
>>
>>   ...from last sunday's paper (SFExaminer pA-8):
>>   NASA scientists have turned their attention from the mysteries of the
>>cosmos to a more esoteric area of research: what happens when you get a
>>spider stoned. Their experiments have shown that common house spiders
>>spin their webs in different ways according to the psychotropic drug they have
>>been given. Spiders on marijuana made a reasonable stab at spinning webs,
>>but appeared to lose concentration about halfway through. Those given
>>Benzedrine or speed, spin their webs "with great gusto, but apparently without
>>much planning, leaving large holes," according to New Scientist magazine.
>>Caffeine makes spiders incapable of spinning anything better than
>>a few threads strung together at rand0m.
>>NASA scientists believe the research demonstrates that
>>web-spinning spiders can be used to test the toxicity of new drugs 
>>because the more toxic the chemical, the more deformed the web.
>>
>>-----------------------------------

Hello,

	I don't actually remember who posted about Safeway. But I did 
want to comment on it, but had to go to class so now's my chance!!! 

	I have to say that for some really strange reason, I used to 
love going to safeway while being x-cited. I don't know why. Maybe it 
was because of all the bright beautiful colors, or the fun that we would 
have playing with fruits, and veggies! We always found ourselves 
sitting in some isle, playing with some sort of food! It was always on 
our must do list for the night if we were kicking it at a house. I don't 
know.. Supermarkets in general are fun! (sometimes, like at 4am.!) 

Peace to all beautiful people, 
(including the real friendly supermarket employees!!!!!)

Greg

"fucked-up" web was on a caffeine dose. Very interesting experiment.

Hello,
	Not to drag out this subject anymore than it already has been, I 
have to say a few things...(Soory.)

	I never understood the whole money thing with promoters and 
parties, until I realized how much money they are making in one night. 
But then I realized how much money they are putting up, how much energy 
they are using, and how much time it takes to plan a party. I am not 
saying that I justify throwing parties to pay the rent! I personally 
would never think of doing that, let alone do that! But that is my 
opinion and not other peoples'. I think that if Wicked and/or anyother 
organization wants to be in it for the money, then they should be able 
to do so! (Without redicule!) I personally don't have a problem 
supporting them as long as I still enjoy their parties. As long as it is 
worth paying the price. I give a lot credit to the "bigger" promoters. 
If it weren't for them, I wouldn't have such great memories! For 
example: Who remembers... Wicked and Get Down on memorial day weekend 
(may29th) about two years ago? It was at the Santa Rosa Fairgrounds! 
That was one of the best parties (Bay Area) that I can remember!(IMO) 

	Now, I have read some posts that people don't like supporting 
them. Then don't!!! Take your energy somewhere else! There are lots of 
parties to go to where you could have the time of your life, for next to 
no money. 

	When we do "Harmony" or "Beautiful People", it is tough trying 
to figure out how much to charge. First we never really know how many 
people to expect, but eventually take a wild guess. Then divide that 
into our overall cost and get a price! We never make money, and if we 
did we would not keep it. (We would donate it!) 

	Anyways I am getting side-tracked. The point I am trying to make 
is that you can support anyone you want! If you have a problem with a 
certain group then don't support them! But you shouldn't "flame" them 
for what they do, that is their choice! I am thankful that they are 
throwing parties close to home so that I can go every once and awhile.

Peace, love, and harmony to all beautiful people,

Greg

Ps. These are my views and my views only!!!! I am speaking only for 
myself and not other members of Harmony or Beautiful People. 
(Although they probably feel pretty much the same...) Thanx!

i think all this discussion of the effects and dangers of ecstacy 
proves one thing: nobody, not nobody, not no how, really knows the 
extent of what e does to a person.  what we don't know can't hurt 
us?...

i've raved sober and i've raved high, and i've come to enjoy raving 
sober the most.  it just feels more sincere, and i remeber the party 
better.  plus, it saves me some bucks.  which is not in anyway to put 
down getting high... ;)  

i think plur should be changed to lurp, because that's the sound a 
raver makes a hour into his e trip when he remebers in a most 
unfortunite way the burger he forgot he ate at three in the 
afternoon...

love, 
sig 
                
                   ...love is the way, pass it on.

        What it all boils down to is something that we have WAY to little
of today and that is common sence.  If people used common sence, instead of
picking apart every little detail of things then we would have no problem.
People put way too much faith in the gray areas of life when the sould be
no gray areas.  This is the reason that racisim exists, (you should base
your opinion of people on what THEY are like and not anyone else). It is
also the reason for the downfall of the american judicial system, which was
built around common sence, If there is a crime commited and you think
someone did it it is black or white, he either did it, or he didn't do it.
If there is a reasonable doubt to whether he did it or not then he didn't
do it.  COMMON SENCE it is the backbone of our nation(Read the
Constitution!)  Thank you for the soapbox, and RAVE-ON!!  LATER

To: Kevin Keiper <keiper@itsa.ucsf.EDU>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
X-Mailer: Chameleon ARM_55, TCP/IP for Windows, NetManage Inc.
Message-Id: <Chameleon.950511201815.bruce@ray.ico.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello, this is Bruce Eisner. I just signed onto your list for the first time because I never had a way of dealing 
with all the mail previous to my new Netmanage Chameleon 4.5 which allows me to put things in nice little 
folders.  
Anyway, I haven't followed this thread from the beginning, but I'm probably one of the world's top four or five 
top experts on the subject of ecstasy, having written Ecstasy: The MDMA Story in two editions and having 
lectured around the U.S. I first took ecstasy back in 1978.  Thus, my first exposure was over 17 years ago.  I've 
lived through a generation with ecstasy as my drug of choice. It seems to have had no descendible ill effects 
on me.  I've studied the literature and find that it backs up the conclusion that MDMA use,when confined to 
infrequent exposures (less than once a week), and with small total amounts (under 250 mgm total ingested), 
has no neurotoxicity.
Well having said that, I'll tell you what the biggest danger to using ecstasy these days is.  It's the fact that most 
ecstasy sold in the underground is not ecstasy or is ecstasy cut with other things.  If people got pure ecstasy 
and used in moderation (that is stable people without a family history of mental disorder or any in their 
personal history), I don't think there would be a problem at all. In fact, alcohols and tobacco are the biggest 
killers by far among drugs, and even aspirin kills many times as many people a year as MDMA.
---------------Original Message---------------

 > i think plur should be changed to lurp, because that's the

> rationally pro-informative towards the use of illegal substances.
> Any recommendations out there?

If anyone does compile a reference list, or knows of an existing one, 
please tell me where I can get one!

The world-at-large considers these people "shrinks". But they're great 
general practitioners to have available if one of the main factors in 
your health (physical *and* mental) is the ingestion of drugs (legal 
or illegal).

My only caution with them is that they tend to be overly enthusiastic 
about Rxing antidepressants. (but I'm not much for popping pills and 
hesitate to take *anything*... even vitamins! so this may be an 
incredibly biased opinion)

Alex and Janice Stalcup (Walnut Creek) (510) 947-1860 or 430-4370
Howard Kornfeld (Mill Valley) (415) 383-8336

I doubt that they have time to just answer phone-in questions, but if 
you want to be a patient of theirs: Be persistent! They may not 
return your first call. You can say Alissa Feinberg referred you 
(Howard may not recognize my name at first but Alex and Janice 
definately will).

Also, tho' I don't have experience with it, one of the 
pharmacologists they work with is at the Haight Ashbury Free Clinic 
which is supposedly really great with drug-related health issues.

Take care everybody! Stay healthy!

Alissa

in the morning.....I thought it was the funniest thing in the whole world

food labels and deciding yay or nay as Barry Manilow swooned over the 
speakers.  Hee hee it was so hilarious!!! :):)

On Thu, 11 May 1995, Kevin Keiper wrote:

> >yes i quite agree with you here... raving sober is a very true way to 
> experience the communal/tribal/friendly/honest "vibe" in a party. if you 
> really connect with a person and both of you are sober, i dunno... it 
> seems this is really real and legitimate and sincere. not that i have any 

Very true.....But I have to say that you can be sincere while high, too.  
The true test is what happens the next day when you are sober.  There is 
nothing worse (imo) than someone who says all kinds of wonderful things 
to you and connects with you the night before, only to have that person 
shun you the next day.  That is a bunch of BS having that happen.
my 2 cents for the night.

love,
Amy

>Had Morgan's chemist been a bit more tightassed, we wouldn't be having this
>conversation.

Maybe if he didn't have chemist AT ALL.

>Look, maybe dispensing with the street names is a bit severe, but everytime
>a raver dies from anything remotely drug-related, everytime a raver with no
>pupils gets in front of a tv camera, and everytime a rave-related accident
>endangers life/property, we get a step closer to having the guvmint end
>raving forever.  MDMA is dangerous. Now you and I know that it's less

you said it!

>dangerous than eating a Jumbo Jack, but the government doesn't make those
>kind of distinctions.  We must be on our best behavior to keep credibility.
>This doesn't mean "don't do E", it means "do E responsibly".

Excuse me. uh..  How the HELL do you do E resposibly?  From the hours of
9pm to 2am?  21 and over?  Take a Cab?

>>>*  Let's push ever harder to get these things legalized already.

I can't believe that people think you should legalize acid and E.
LEGALIZING drugs doesn't solve any problems.  Have you ever hung out with
someone who was so Ill'ed out for drugs they would do anything?  IT's a
disgusting sight.  Alot of my old friends are E freaks now and they look
like zombies.  I think E destroyed alot of good 'rave' scenes across the
u.s.  E is just another good high.

Being from the midwest originally, My friends and I got into the scene
purely for music and vibe..  We went out till 8 am purely for music and
vibe..  i.e.  The scene was built on music.  Out here in Cali, the scene
seems like it was built on E, Crystal Meth, Pot whatever..  IT's just kinda
wacked out..

>I've only been to a few ba.events, but the authorities here pretty much
>leave the MJ/LSD/MDMA set alone, which is great: we're the least likely to
>bring violence into it.  But if they wanted to, they could seize anything at
>any event under the cloak of "good faith" without trial.  Done often enough,
>it would kill the scene.  The only way we can overcome the fear that's
>causing us (and the Joneses & g-slaying victims & the incarcerated & their
>families) so much grief is to legalize drugs, tax the shit out of them, and
>use the money for education and quality control.

This aint the sixties my friend..

Why can't we just play good fucking music, kick the drug dealers out and
shake our booties all night lone?  Why make things so complicated?

Jon

> >went to Oregon and picked a bunch of those mushrooms!
> Wasn't it just a few months ago that three people did this same thing 
> and ended up dead as a result?
> 
> Echoing what the list concensus seems to be...
> Knowledge first, caution, common sense, and have fun!

Another common result is probably worse than death -- being forced to
undergo dialysis for the rest of your life because your liver or
kidneys got destroyed by a random wild mushroom. Unless you're really
experienced, some of the mushrooms pictured in the book might look like
the mushroom you just ate, when in fact, you just ingested a highly
toxic substance which will make your vital organs do the ultimate
sacrifice just to save your life. If you're lucky, however, you'll be
dead.

My Aunt is a mycologist. Once, when I was six, she gave me a petri dish
that glows in the dark. It was a strange form of photoluminescent
mushrooms that are the cause of "witches circles" in the old world --
glowing rings of dirt with the mushroom "root" causing the glow.
Supposedly in the northeast coast of the US and canada, similar glowing
shrooms can be found in decaying fallen tree trunks.

And who was it that did that trippy sixties song "Amanita sitting in
the sun" ???

Ob rave (?) ... personally, I think mushrooms are plants from an alien
world :-)... Their whole mode of survival, growth, reproduction, FX, 
etc is completely different from any other "life" on earth. Is that a
mushroom or the 2001-monolith said the mckenna-monkey ?

==     Niels Mayer -- http://cyborganic.com/~niels -- mayer@netcom.com     ==

Subject: Introducing Me
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
X-Chameleon-Return-To: bruce@mindmedia.com
X-Mailer: Chameleon ARM_55, TCP/IP for Windows, NetManage Inc.
Message-Id: <Chameleon.950512001110.bruce@ray.ico.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well I the first mail I got was on MDMA toxicity so I never really had a chance to introduce myself to the 
group.My name is Bruce and I've been involved in the psychedelic world since I turned on at age 19 in 1967.  I 
was one of those hippies you read about in the history books and I'm one of those ravers your children may 
read about in the history books.
I've written much on psychedelics, consciousness, MDMA, and creating a psychedelic culture.  I am in the 
process of having my Island page (currently in transit at http://www.systemv.com/island/) to show more about 
what Island is about --which is focusing on the transformation of the currently culture by integrating new and 
ancient ideas into an experimental culture.  Along the way, we publish newsletters (Island Views), hold 
conferences (Bridge Conference Stanford 1991, Bicycle Day UCSC 1993) and sometimes even hold potlucks 
or salons.
My other hat is as head of a small software company called Mind Media. Our current and new url is 
http://www.mindmedia.com.  We publish software and are interested in developing psychoactive computer 
applications.  
Well, I live alone at the edge of the Pacific.  Currently I'm single and open to new friends and relationships.  
Looking toward summer with hope.  Glad to finally be on your list (now that I have my mail setup right).  So 
e-mail me if you want to chat or hook up or find out more.

Bruce e
-------------------------------------
Bruce Eisner
Island Group
Phone (408) 426-0762
Fax (408) 426-8519
E-mail: bruce@mindmedia.com

Date: 05/12/95
Time: 00:02:49

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri May 12 01:40:56 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id BAA16971; Fri, 12 May 1995 01:40:56 -0700
Received: from zip.com.au by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with SMTP id BAA16961; Fri, 12 May 1995 01:40:48 -0700
Received: from [203.7.179.39] (slper1p23.ozemail.com.au) by zip.com.au with SMTP id AA15011
  (5.67b/IDA-1.5 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>); Fri, 12 May 1995 18:41:29 +1000
Message-Id: <199505120841.AA15011@zip.com.au>
X-Sender: crunch@203.12.97.1 (Unverified)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Fri, 13 May 1994 01:41:19 +1000
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: crunch@sysx.apana.org.au (John Draper)
Subject: Probably not rave related,   but interesting anyway
Cc: nebula@netcom.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Greetings...


Its currently:  9:05:05 PM  5/12/94  PST

Well,  now am a captive person,  sitting in an airplane at the moment,
getting cought up on my correspondance.    Right at the moment,   I'm
flying across the Great Australian Bite.   It's the southern part,
that looks like someone bit off the lower portion of the land mass.
Currently flying over the Southern Ocean,  with nothing between me
and Antarctica.   Partly cloudy outside at the moment.

I'm heading to Perth... in South Western Australia,  where I'm due to
land at 1 pm local time (One day ahead of Calif).  I'm to meet some
Perth ravers,  and this evening,  planning to attend a big fat 18 hour
rave (Drool!!).   So,  here's what I found out,  about the cities I
visited so far.

Sydney - mainstream rave scene,  mostly Happy Hardcore,  or what
   old schoolers call "KiddieKore".  There is a lot of house,  acid
   trance of the hard variaty.    Radio plays a LOT of house and techno.
   ar more than the Bay Area,  thats for sure.   There is NO ban on
   using the words fuck, shit,  etc on the air,  and radio here has
   much more variaty.    Also,  there are a lot of non-commercial community
   stations coming on the air.

Melbourne - Mostly house.  Acid Trance,  little or no HardCore,  but this
   was just ONE rave I attended.   (Land of the giants).   Quite large,
   about 5000 people.

Adlaide - Lots and lots of heavy hardcore of the british variaty with
  MC's yelling in the mics.   Which I really don't like that much.   No
  particular message,  other then a lot of "fuck,  shit,  etc".
  I wouldn't mind MC's if they had a speciic message about love and
  peace.   But these are my observations so far.

Canberra - Lots of Happy Hard.   Also house.   Canberra,  being the
  capitol of Australia,  and the center of government activities,  has
  the laxest marjuana laws in Audstralia.   It's practically decriminalized
  and a bag (about 3/4th of an 8th) costs about $45 Aus.  $1 Aus = .73 US$

"E" is horrendously expensive (almost always $60 a tab).   Acid costs between
$15 and $20 a hit,  but is really good.    Daffy Ducks are really popular
and very good.

Sydney has the strictest drug enforcement in Australia.   Thus bags go
from $60 - $70.   Up north (Nimbin,  Byron Bay) is supposed to have the
cheapest pot prices.  Brisbane I have yet to visit,  is more redneck
attitudes.

I'll report on Perth/ Darwyn later..

There is a big push here to completly decriminalize pot.  Even the
authorities and police are behind this.

Medical care is FREE,   very consious of the AIDS virus here,   and they
have a very sensible approach to combating aids.   One gets free condoms,
and ALL the whores on the streets have an adequate supply on hand.

In Kings Cross (Where all the strip joints, and sex houses are),  they
have a store dedicated to Condoms.   Thats right,  a whole store of just
about every method possible to help one have protected sex.

Raves here are MAINSTREAM,  and are even advertized on Radio and TV
constantly.   Rave posters sit on sides of busses,   in railway stations,
and the trains.

Public transpo is amazingly efficient,  although rather expensive.   Best
bargain is to get a weekly pass for $19.   Gives you unlimited access to
busses,  trains,  and ferries.    Because Sydney has a lot of inlets and
bays,   ferries are used,  and are much faster than trains.    The boats
have amazing speed and accelleration.

Sydney is so spread out,  that it covers about 100 miles in width.
The entire population of australia is only 18 million people in a land
mass 80% of the size of the USA.   80% of Australia's population is
on the South east side.    Distances between cities are FAR,  and
nothing but empty land between them,  or farms.   About 60 miles west
of Sydney are the Blue Mts.    I've had the pleasure to hang out with
the Earth First Foundation,  who has a beautiful horticulture spread
of many achres of land.   They take pride in their plants and gardens.

I'm trying to help them get on the WEB,   by putting them in touch with
many of the computer folks I met in my travels.

More on Australian radio...  They have just ONE government sponsored
station that plays rock music,  techno,  and a lot of other music forms
not heard on radio in the USA.   One is "triple-j",

triplej@ozziemail.oz.com.au

All radio stations have Email addresses,  as well as mainstream TV.
Internet over here is a household word.   Just about everyond who has
a modem and a computer is on the internet.   AARNET is a cooperative
organization,  working with Telecom Australia to provide hookups to
all the universities.   APANA,  a non-profit organization offers
anyone internet hookups for $50 Aus/  year.   Anyone with a PC can
SLIP or PPP into APANA,  and most BBS's are hooked to this very slow
64kb link.

triplej is nationwide,  ahd heard all over australia.   Austrailia
is sorta  SINGLE community,  in that the whole country had the consiousness
an closeness of a single city,  just spread out over a huge huge area.

There is little or no differences in slang from one part of the country
to the next.   Little difference in accent no matter where you go.

Other Inet providers have direct hookup to AARNET backbone which has
bandwidth of 20 MB/sec.   They also maintain a 4.5 Mb link to the USA,
but new INet providers are setting up their own 64kb links,  although
are slower than the USa/Aus 4.5 mb link,  I get much better response.

Because internet is so popular with the general public,   after about
4 pm,   it's almost impossible to dial into the POPS as most phone lines
are busy.   Especially Geko.   Geko is so choked with overloaded phone
lines and such,  and is the most unpopular and unreliable system.  Their
prices are competitive with other providers.  So far,   I've evaluated

Microplex - mpx.com.au   (Fairly expensive $4/hr,  plus I/o charges
  but gives you a few free hours for a fixed fee per month.   One can
  run up a big bill surfin the WEB.    Mpx does allow telnet into and
  out of the system.

Geko - no hourly charges,  but had I/o charge,  so if you download
  lots of gifs,  you can get big bills.   This has the most users,
  but Dez Blanchard (owner of Geko),  has a policy of not allowing
  or discouraging people from telnetting into it.   They have the
  toughest firewall (even the Mail POP is behind the wall).

Zip - New kid on the block... No I/O,  and no hourly charges.  only
  3 lines at the moment,  and went on-line just last weekend.   I've
  got a 3 week free evaluation account,  and I'm helping them get the
  bugs out of their system using PPP method of connection.   They have
  their OWN links to the USA,  and appear to be the most reliable.
  They allow telnet into and out of zip.   Also the mail pop is available
  from other sites.

Ozziemail - Operated by Telecom Australia (Phone Co)  Naturally their
  hourly charges are the highest (About $6 hr - non prime,  and $8/hr
  prime.   But cheaper than using long distance (Which is $18 hour non
  prime and $25/hour prime).   Of course they have local dialups to
  about 18 Austrlian cities.

The employment here is amazingly low.   Getting jobs here are amazingly
easy (for Australians only).   Almost anyone can find work here.   There
is an especially large demand for workers in the Service industry.   In
fact,  Australia has the toughest immigration policy,  and it's almost
impossible for non-australians to get legal work here.   Now,  they are
talking about easing this,  to allow more foreign workers access to the
many jobs.

Software jobs are harder to get...  there is a large amount of programmers
here (All are graduates from Uni's).   Education here is FREE!!  through
University level.

Standard of living is Very high...  But on the 'Cross" there are still
pan handlers,  but nowhere near the level in the USA.

In general, society is kinda like the USA was 10 years ago,  but with
the general public very much into high tech toys.   For instance,  the
biggest fad is portable digital phones.  Everyone has one.   They only
cost $400 and service is $30/month plus air time.  Incoming calls
are FREE (which makes it attractive to have them),  but people calling
portable phones pay the air time,  via special nation wide area codes
(018) and (015).

Rave info numbers are the real BITCH.  They can cost $3/minute to
get location of raves.  Its like rave info numbers in the USA having
900 numbers.  Only in Aus,  they are 0055 numbers.   The real pisser
is that you have to listen to music for at least 2 minutes before any
info is given out.   And it's given out so slow that the call duration
is about 6- 7 minutes before you get the location.    Thus costing
about $15 to $20 to find out where it is.

Raves (Kiddie mainsteam ones) cost $35 if U get tickets in Advance
at record shops.   Or upwards of $60 at the door.   A typical rave
weekend would be broken down as follows.

Location info  - $15 for calling 0055 number to get location
Admittance     - $35 advance,   $60 at the door.
Hit if E       - $60
Hit if A       _ $25  (Often called a "T".

It costs up to $160 a weekend to rave.
 The After party (Called recovery) costs $7.   Mostly pays Happy Hard
core,  goes on from 9 am to about 2 am Monday morning.  Usually at the
Pavillion Tavern.   Very nice,  well ventilated and cool venue.

This next few weeks,  are having a DJ contest!! Quite unique I might
add.

WOW!! Just discovered that I'm over land again....   Batteries running
low,  and plane is due to land soon,  so will close off...  Land looks
brown and parched... partly cloudy down there.   Pilot anounced
that we are landing now,   temp in Perth 19 C.   Wind 25Km/hr.]

Gotta pack my lapop away now...

This is only rave related in that it's based on sound, creates a trance-like
state of mind and can move you spiritually.

Did anyone els go see the Gyuto Tantric Choir last night at UC Davis or a
couple of weeks ago when they were in SF?  Oooommmmmm My God.  Can I say
that what these Tibeten Monks do with sound boggles the mind---literally.
They do what's called polyphonic chanting, where each monk chants a
simultaneous, three-note chord.  Thats one voice singing three notes at the
same time, then ad nine more monks doing the same thing and....... well, I
trancended my body more than once.

Just some thoughts.

Rick

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri May 12 09:58:09 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id JAA19158; Fri, 12 May 1995 09:58:09 -0700

	id JAA16100; Fri, 12 May 1995 09:58:03 -0700

     Went to Pure Space around 1 a.m. only to find the vibe not quite to my 
     liking.  I think there was lots of crossover people from the party 
     that ended at midnight.  Maybe I'm just too picky but I don't like the 
     club scene much.  In any case,  I thought it'd be good w/the dj 
     line-up but I just can't handle the heavy vibrating bass that jiggles 
     my inners for too long.  
     
     So I headed over to Lift 'cause I always have a good time there.  It 
     took a while for people to come in from the other clubs but it 
     eventually got off.  It was a good mix of people and the music finally 
     improved when David Harness started mixing.  Sometimes it's difficult 
     to harness the energy of a group if you keep screwing w/the tempos and 
     rhythms as they did early on.  Makes you kinda wonder who they're 
     playing for...  But I've found Lift people to be forgiving and dance 
     or stand on the dance floor to almost anything :)
     
     Afterwards people mentioned Cocktails or the End-up.  It was a toss up 
     and at 6am, both were very slow to start.  I had to be in Palo Alto 
     for work at 8am so I left around 6:30 and things still hadn't 
     picked-up like last week after ComeUnity...what a shame.
     
     Still, it's been a wonderful way to start my Friday, with warm smiles 
     and hugs from old and new friends.  I just wanted to let you know how 
     Thursday night was for me and wish y'all a good weekend with whatever 
     you'll be doing.
     
     Mmmmmmmmmm, SSSSiiiiIIIIGHHHHHH!  Just breathing feels wonderful right 
     now :o
     
     Hugs, kisses, and deep, warm wishes,
     Diane

Amy's point is very good,

>The true test is what happens the next day when you are sober.  There is
>nothing worse (imo) than someone who says all kinds of wonderful things
>to you and connects with you the night before, only to have that person
>shun you the next day.  That is a bunch of BS having that happen.

I'll take it a step further though. I think E is *the* shit, but it can
definitely have some serious mental ramifications.     A while back, I
finally kissed a girl, while both of us were EXcited.    Of course the
experience was mind blowing, best kissing I've ever experienced, (an
especially strong statement for me, because I hold good kissing in SUCH high
regard).  But since then, although the memory is so wonderful, It's kind of
bothered, and sometimes even pained me.   Unfortunately, I didn't (and
probably won't) get the chance to kiss her sober, so I'll never know how much
of it was her, and how much of it was something else.   More importantly, the
whole experience was SO incredibly excellent, that I'm actually kind of
worried, and wonder if its possible to duplicate without any help?   In a
way, it almost makes kissing now a little anti-climactic, a little sad.   It
kind of reminds me of a line in "Sit Down" by James,  "If I hadn't seen such
riches, I could live with being poor"   Any thoughts???   Tom

Subject: Responsible Chemistry
In-Reply-To: <199505120619.XAA00121@hopf.dnai.com>

On Thu, 11 May 1995, Jonathan Santos wrote:
> >Had Morgan's chemist been a bit more tightassed, we wouldn't be having this
> >conversation.
> 
> Maybe if he didn't have chemist AT ALL.

Yeah, and maybe if my grandfather had never driven a car, he'd be alive 
today too.  

> Excuse me. uh..  How the HELL do you do E resposibly?  

In order:
  Read up extensively on it, both pro and con, with an objective set of 
    ears.  Pay close attention to what the medical community has to say.
  Talk with others about their experiences with it, both positive and
    negative.  Pay attention to those with medical experience.
  Buy it from someone you trust, someone you have known for more than
    a few months, someone who has a vested interest in your safety.
  The first time you take it, take it in a comfortable, calm environment
    (your home, a friends home) and with someone else who is either 
    abstaining or has done it before.  This person should also be one 
    from whom you are not hiding any substantial personal problems or
    feelings, for they will probably come out.
  
	MDMA is a powerful tool, no contest.  The results of using it may or 
may not be positive, depending almost entirely upon your state of mind 
and your surroundings.  "Set and setting".  

  When you are comfortable with its effects, then try taking it in a 
    public place.  Always have someone around who is willing to act as 
    a point of reference for you, someone who will support you if you
    suddenyl get uncomfortable.

> >>>*  Let's push ever harder to get these things legalized already.
> 
> I can't believe that people think you should legalize acid and E.
> LEGALIZING drugs doesn't solve any problems.  

A lot of empirical evidence suggests otherwise.  If drugs were legal, and 
regulated by the government or some other institution (like all legal 
drugs and food are these days), you would see:

	1) Quality control.  A large body of evidence suggests that
"drug-related deaths" are caused by pollutants in the chemicals. You would
know that when you're taking one 100mg MDMA caplets you really are getting
100mg, and not 20mg with 80mg MDA, and not 300mg MDMA. 

	2) Real drug information.  People are used to the concept of an 
acceptible blood alcohol levels, and the thought of personally acceptible 
doses of MDMA or LSD would also come about.  

	3) Lower prices.  Even if the government were to levy 1000% 
surcharges on their manufacture, it would be cheaper than buying on the 
street.

The "drug problem" is a health problem, not a legal problem, and should 
be treated as such.

> Have you ever hung out with
> someone who was so Ill'ed out for drugs they would do anything?  IT's a
> disgusting sight.  

Yes, but I've also seen people's lives destroyed by alcohol, by watching TV,
by junk food, by stress, by money, by just about every single pleasure-giving
instrument out there.  Addiction is a problem in general, and it very rarely
is a biochemical response to the object addicted to.  

> Being from the midwest originally, My friends and I got into the scene
> purely for music and vibe..  We went out till 8 am purely for music and
> vibe..  i.e.  The scene was built on music.  Out here in Cali, the scene
> seems like it was built on E, Crystal Meth, Pot whatever..  IT's just kinda
> wacked out..

I've been going to raves "out here in Cali" for about 6 years now, I've 
seen a *lot* of stuff both heavily positive and heavily negative, and for 
anyone to say "it's all about drugs" is like me saying Detroit is "all 
about cars".  :)

> This aint the sixties my friend..

Uh, you and I weren't even born then, so we really can't go about drawing 
comparisons....

> Why can't we just play good fucking music, kick the drug dealers out and
> shake our booties all night lone?  Why make things so complicated?

Because some of us like to ROLL A BIG FATTY AND SMOKE IT while we're 
grooving to that music, and there's no one who's going to tell us that's 
"wrong".  I'm all for kicking the drug dealers out, as long as they are 
replaced with the local Safeway clerk. :)

	Brian

I'm curious as to why, promoters of legit parties don't have a location
finalized until just hours before a party. Is this because club owners
don't guarantee a space, or do promoters get a better price if they wait
till the last minute to make a deal, or are they actually still looking
till the last minute? I can understand promoters not anouncing the location
until a few hours before the party, but anouncing one location and then not
changing the message until just a few hours before the party seems a little
unfair.

Specifically, anyone know what happened in the case of Wicked last weekend?

Thanks,
Shehryar

>I'll take it a step further though. I think E is *the* shit, but it can
>definitely have some serious mental ramifications.     A while back, I
>finally kissed a girl, while both of us were EXcited.    Of course the
>experience was mind blowing, best kissing I've ever experienced, (an
>especially strong statement for me, because I hold good kissing in SUCH high
>regard).  But since then, although the memory is so wonderful, It's kind of
>bothered, and sometimes even pained me.   Unfortunately, I didn't (and
>probably won't) get the chance to kiss her sober, so I'll never know how much
>of it was her, and how much of it was something else.   More importantly, the
>whole experience was SO incredibly excellent, that I'm actually kind of
>worried, and wonder if its possible to duplicate without any help?   In a
>way, it almost makes kissing now a little anti-climactic, a little sad.   It
>kind of reminds me of a line in "Sit Down" by James,  "If I hadn't seen such

Yes, it kinda makes you wonder if it's possible to duplicate the experience
without any help......  Think of it this way.  Before you had the
experience, you didn't even know it was possible......  Your mind is larger
now because you know it's possible (no matter what it takes to get there).
Knowing something is possible is the first step in achieving it on your own.
MDMA gives you a glimps of what things can really be like.  The next step is
for you to carry that vision out into the mainstream of your life.  You have
to work!!!!  You are capable of creating experiences all by yourself, you
just have to believe it.  Your mind is more powerful than any drug on the
market, USE IT.

Peace!

Rick




From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri May 12 13:27:14 1995

From: bradleyg@ix.netcom.com (Bradley Graham)
Subject: Re: Last minute locations
To: lasi@apple.com (Shehryar Lasi)
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Shehryar wrote: 

> I can understand promoters not anouncing the location until a few hours before
> the party

I have wondered about this, too.  Maybe it's because they want to keep that
"underground" feel to it even though it is being held at a "legal" venue.  
OR, maybe they don't want to scare people away because it is at a poor location 
(bad venue or inconvenient location).  For example, I really wanted to go to 
Ex Why Zzz but when I found it was in the east bay, I said forget it.  That 
left me scrambling for other options.  It kind of pissed me off because I 
really had my heart set on going.  Glad I didn't by advance tix!!!  :>)

Another problem with the last minute announcement is that the promoters are so
busy putting on the final touches to the party, they either forget to update the
message, give the wrong directions, or give general directions but forget to give 
the street address.  Each of these things has happened over the last couple of
months (at least once) for events listed in the SFR calendar.  For example, I
spent 30 minutes looking around 3rd and Army St for Mission.  I knew Mission was 
the other way but I thought maybe they meant Missouri or Mississippi.   Finally,
I dumped their "directions" and found it on my own.  When I mentioned it to the
people at the event they said "Duh, we don't know anything about it."  Actually,
the didn't even know the name of the party (so much for the hired help) so that I
could verify that I was in the right place (they had the address wrong, too).

Just my $.02 but could all you promoters out there be kind and tell us the
location as soon as possible. 

Bradley

> >flipping feeling. Anybody get the real deal on what those were?

I may have seen different stuff, but what I saw being sold as illusion 
was a blotter.  2CB is usually a 18-20mg dose, MDMA is around 120mg, 
crystal I'm not sure of, but I know you can't disolve a line onto a small 
blotter.  This doesn't offer much help as to what the stuff was, but you 
can rule out all these powdered drugs.  (Unless of course what I saw was 
not the "real illusion")

Hope this helps
Peace & Smiles

From: bradleyg@ix.netcom.com (Bradley Graham)
Subject: Re: Responsible Chemistry
To: Brian Behlendorf <brian@hyperreal.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Brian wrote: 

>A lot of empirical evidence suggests otherwise.  If drugs were legal, and 
>regulated by the government or some other institution (like all legal 
>drugs and food are these days), you would see:
>
>	1) Quality control.
>
>	2) Real drug information.
>
>	3) Lower prices.


Also, if drugs were legal, there would be a reduction in drug-related crimes
(manufacturing, trafficking, turf protection, etc.).  Organized crime really 
came into its own (i.e., financed itself for further expansion) with the 
prohibition on alcohol.  Before the prohibition crimes were mostly perpetrated 
by small time, lone operators.  During the prohibition enterprising crooks took 
advantage of the government's (and the population's) narrow mindedness to 
organize themselves into big money operations.  Then they laundered the money 
through legal business (usually cash oriented businesses such as restaurants, 
cleaners, etc.).  The drug cartels work the same way.  Legalization, like that 
of alcohol or cigarettes, would ensure, as Brian points out, consistent quality, 
safe distribution outlets (e.g., Safeway and Walgreens), variety (would you like
the mint or bubble gum flavored???), lower prices, and it make the world just a 
little bit safer.

Bradley

I went to Pure Space last night.  Other than running into a couple of
friends from Santa Cruz (always a pleasure), it was pretty dull.  I'm
guessing I missed Garth and that Tony Fader just wasn't doing it for me.

Leaving the club some perky fellow (whose name I now forget) told my
friend and I about a "party with Thomas" over at the oddball on Minna.
I really like this little club space.  It is intimate and has a very
refined, lounge-like, sophisticated feel to it.

Approaching the place we could hear Hair screeching banshee style out 
into the street.  Someone put a few couches on the sidewalk.  It was a
small free party with an older, very hip, _very_ good looking crowd. 
Couldn't say if Thomas was spinning but it seemed in the realm of
stuff he would play.  The music was eclectic with crazy funk, sick 
hiphop, and the tweakiest House you'll ever hear.  I absolutely
loved it.  I even liked the video stuff they were playing.
This lands in the nicest parties ever category.
The sweetest Afro.

Dave

From: bradleyg@ix.netcom.com (Bradley Graham)
Subject: Counterpoint... (responsible chem)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hi everyone!

One other thing that I forget to say before...

Let's not kid ourselves about the affects of drug use.
Legal or not, people will still die from using drugs
just as people die from using alcohol or cigarettes.

Please let's not argue over cancer vs. accidental death
from using alcohol.  The result is the same.  People
(purposely or inadvertently) do die because they (or
others) don't behave responsibly when use intoxicants.  
Afterall, how many of you read and fully abide by the 
directions when you use over the counter drug.  I sure 
don't.  When I have a painful headache, I take 1500mg 
of Tylenol (even though it says take only 1000mg at 
the most).  How many of you have driven after having a 
few drinks, even though you knew it was not the right 
thing to do?  I've done it (and I am definitely not 
proud of it).

Legalization is not necessarily the panacea that we think 
it is.  It will solve some problems but it will also 
create others.  We need to keep this in mind as we move
forward.

Bradley

I suggest finding a girl (not a woman -- this is important), then both
of you need to get real loaded, preferably on Jack Daniels, then do a
12 pack of cheap beer in a beer bong. Finally, both of you need to
whiffle up a huge rail of Ketamine, Heroin, or drano... then when
you're both nearly ready to puke or pass out, kiss as passionately as
you can, while trying to not vomit all over each other.

After that, regular sober kissing should seem like heaven, and you'll
find yourself feeling this incredible joyful feeling each and every
time you kiss sober. In fact, you may feel like this even when you're
kissing your grandma.

> >I think an event in everyone's trip will eventually be the trip

> >must take place. Not just food but snack food. Pringles are a personal 
> >favorite of mine. Don't eat the bacon flavored french fries.

ah, yes, i remember my first months raving in brighton, england, where 
there's scarcely anything open all night - just the 7-11 and a strange 
"diner" with pretty poor french fries and unidentifiable fried black 
lumpy things (sausages, actually)...interesting place to wind up fried 
after a party... 

my favorite morning ritual, tho', was an egg and cress sandwich and a 
cadbury chocolately milk drink...sometimes i'd get this weird lemon-lime 
soda, too, with lots of sugar, which would make me giggle like crazy for 
hours...

:)
monicat

Actually Wired Magazine donated the server for Hyperreal and Brian is an employee of wired which also puts 
up Hotwired.com and Wired.com. That costs the company a lot but Brian nothing. People have to make a 
living. I make a living off of selling software with my company, Mind Media., not talking about MDMA. That's a 
hobby.  The meeting is actually to benifit the Hemporium Bookstore, which I admire for carrying the widest 
range of books on pharmaceuticals available.  The $2 goes to them. I only get money from selling my book to 
the bookstore and that probably won't be more than $50 and I have to drive all the way to Hayward from Santa 
Cruz, almost 80 miles and spend the day there.  Well there are easier ways to make money.  Wired has heavy 
industry investment, so I don't worry about your youthfully idealistic critiques.  I hardly make enough to live so I 
don't think of myself as one of the upper class 
By the way, to the rest of you, I've gotten a lot of postive e-mal from those who I've seen at many raves and SF 
Raves events, and it is way cool to be finally getting to see first hand what people told me about Sf Raves. 
Until I got my e-mail program to route messages into folders, I was always afraid of getting too much mail.  My 
folder fills up fast.  And it seems that a lot of basic people deal with here is the nature of the ritual called the 
rave, and also the pharmacology of consciousness -- so I'm glad to be here. Talk to you!

Bruce e
---------------Original Message---------------


On Fri, 12 May 1995 bruce@mindmedia.com wrote:

> If people like me didn't devote their careers to this kind of stuff, people 
like you wouldn't even know about it.  
> Think about that.

Actually, I really think that we would be a lot better off if people like you
would stop trying to make a buck(or in your case $2) off of people like me. 
I am quite capable of gathering information on MDMA without any aid from 
you. You don't know me, so how the hell do you purport knowledge of what 
I would know without people like you? I have never read your book. I 
don't know if it is great, passable, or a load of crap. I make no claims 
to such knowledge. However, I do object to someone peddling freely 
available information on such an important issue in a forum such as SF 
Raves. If you are an "expert", and wanted to offer a "public service" why 
not do your talk for free? That would be a public service. Hyperreal.com 
is a public service. Brian carries SF Raves, information from numerous 
sources on various substances(MDMA being one), as well as a few misc. 
items. I have as of yet never heard an ad from him seeking money for what 
he does. What you offer is a product. Your product is knowledge. 
Knowledge which is available at no cost. 

                                                 Black Adder

This relates to both messages but the info on hyperreal.com is not free 
to the person providing it.  I don't think Brian pays for it all 
himself you know...there are a lot of people who contribute time and 
money to hyperreal.com, hardware isnt free.  You may have a problem with 
Bruce telling us he is having a booksigning/question & answer session but 
$2 is a lot cheaper than some of the $20 raves which are advertised on 
hyperreal.com.  In light of the recent discussion when you call what he 
is offering a product than about half the raves on the weekly list should 
be stricken as well as all the weekly club nights.  Other than Sunset 
I dont know of any weeklies that arent put on to pay the rent for someone 
(which isnt necessarily wrong but thats another discussion).  I think its 
perfectly acceptable for you to be posting your message Bruce as long as 
it stays like a public announcement, which it did and not an 
advertisement which is more than I can say for some of the things that 
we've seen on this list, like multiple postings of a party and such.

drenalin 

> is a public service. Brian carries SF Raves, information from numerous 
> sources on various substances(MDMA being one), as well as a few misc. 
> items. I have as of yet never heard an ad from him seeking money for what 
> he does. What you offer is a product. Your product is knowledge. 
> Knowledge which is available at no cost.

> > Knowledge which is available at no cost.

Since Bruce decided to make my PRIVATE message to him public, I feel I 
need to explain my response. I misspoke when I spoke of Brian exclusivly 
providing the hardware and link. Point is that I view hyperreal.com as a 
public service, as I receive the services it offers free of charge. Second, 
nowhere in his original message did Bruce mention that what he was doing 
was a benefit. What I got from the original message was " Hey if you want 
to listen to me talk, or ask me questions about MDMA, you can do so for 
$2 at such-and-such location. I know more than anyone about the subject."
If he had mentioned the fact this was a benefit, this thread wouldn't 
exist. 

Finally, I see no conflict in bitching about someone advertising what I 
believed to be a self-serving "public service" vs. someone advertising a 
party. In my opinion, and hopefully not mine alone, anyone charging 
someone for freely available information in a setting such as SFRaves is 
reprehensible. To me, charging you for information about MDMA would be like
me charging you for info about when and where a party was. I wouldn't do 
that to a friend, and wouldn't expect any of my friends to do it to me. 
An event is a totatlly different animal. If anyone needs any more 
clarification on this please send me e-mail, rather than clutter this 
listserv with what should have been a private discussion.....

                                                Black Adder

Black Adder (P. Greenwell) re. Bruce Eisner's book/talk/shinding...
> Your product is knowledge. 
> Knowledge which is available at no cost. 

Not!

Knowledge always costs money and/or time and perseverence to obtain.
Since time is money ( :-) ) I'd venture to say that knowledge is never
gained for "free" . So to say "no cost" seems pretty inapproriate (and
a tad disrespectful of Bruce and his considerable eXperience in the
subject).

The subject of Bruce's talk is germane to this list and certainly
pertinent to ravers, even if I  disagree w/ the overall sentiment that
X is some kind of wonder drug that you can pop as often as you pop
aspirin, with fewer ill effects, etc. Yes, I can clearly see a role for
it in therapy, marriage counseling, etc, and I certainly can't deny
that it might be good for blowing out the emotional tubes once in a
while (like maybe twice a year at best) but as something you can take
once a week w/o suffering any ill effects --- that's ridiculous.

			"So then I gave her some X and she got all
			 lovey-dovey then we both got on top of her..."
				-- Something I overheard a vendor once say...

>> Excuse me. uh..  How the HELL do you do E resposibly?
>
>In order:
>  Read up extensively on it, both pro and con, with an objective set of
>    ears.  Pay close attention to what the medical community has to say.
>  Talk with others about their experiences with it, both positive and
>    negative.  Pay attention to those with medical experience.
>  Buy it from someone you trust, someone you have known for more than
>    a few months, someone who has a vested interest in your safety.
>  The first time you take it, take it in a comfortable, calm environment
>    (your home, a friends home) and with someone else who is either
>    abstaining or has done it before.  This person should also be one
>    from whom you are not hiding any substantial personal problems or
>    feelings, for they will probably come out.

Well you are right about all of the above, but it just kinda sounded
silly.. Do E Responsibly.  I started to a envision public service
announcement on Saturday Morning with Crusty the Clown saying 'Do E
respnsibly'

>If drugs were legal, and
>regulated by the government or some other institution (like all legal
>drugs and food are these days), you would see:
>
>        1) Quality control.  A large body of evidence suggests that
>"drug-related deaths" are caused by pollutants in the chemicals. You would
>know that when you're taking one 100mg MDMA caplets you really are getting
>100mg, and not 20mg with 80mg MDA, and not 300mg MDMA.

I'm not saying that 'doin drugs' is going to kill us all, especially making
it legal.  I am saying that I wouldn't feel safe driving down the road
knowing that people traveling towards me at 60 mph could be legally
intoxicated on acid or somethin'.  Don't get me wrong, I have done my fair
share of psych-e-dilya, am-feta-meenes, depressants,  whatever!!   But I
don't think that the masses are ready for legal all that shit to be legal.
(pot maybe)
I remember sneaking shit (liqour) out of my parents's stash when I was real
young.  I would hate to see my kid find my LSD Stash...

and how 'bout controlling these substances?  Good luck.

>        2) Real drug information.  People are used to the concept of an
>acceptible blood alcohol levels, and the thought of personally acceptible
>doses of MDMA or LSD would also come about.

Actually, if If we had a choice- MDMA should be legal instead of alcohol.

This reminds me:  I recall someone telling me last month that MDMA was
legal somewhere for awhile?  I quickly reminded him (or her) that not too
long ago, black people had to sit at the back of busses...

>        3) Lower prices.  Even if the government were to levy 1000%
>surcharges on their manufacture, it would be cheaper than buying on the
>street.

Oh.. So you just want Cheaper E, Is that it? :)

>> Have you ever hung out with
>> someone who was so Ill'ed out for drugs they would do anything?  IT's a
>> disgusting sight.
>
>Yes, but I've also seen people's lives destroyed by alcohol, by watching TV,
>by junk food, by stress, by money, by just about every single pleasure-giving
>instrument out there.  Addiction is a problem in general, and it very rarely
>is a biochemical response to the object addicted to.

What about the big picture?  Millions of people legally tripping?  just
that thought alone scares me.  Maybe you guys can handle your trips, but in
most cases- people cannot control themselves and act irresponsibly.  You
guys are probably educated- middle class - mature - and can control your
trips quite well?  What about all of those assholes who act irresponsibly
and fuck with people just being drunk?  Or even people who aren't even a
threat to society?

We cannot teach children (and adults) to have sex properly!? what makes you
think people will TRIP responsibly?  You guys seem to forget about the rest
of America.  90% of it doesn't look at the world like a raver.  I am not a
hardcore straight-edge person; I don't freak out on people who do drugs,
nor do I prevent myself from meeting them or hanging with them.  I just
think that the US is nor ready for (legalized halucinogens)


>Also, if drugs were legal, there would be a reduction in drug-related crimes
>(manufacturing, trafficking, turf protection, etc.).  Organized crime really

Is that a huge problem right now?  I think the 90's have a new set of problems..

>came into its own (i.e., financed itself for further expansion) with the
>prohibition on alcohol.  Before the prohibition crimes were mostly perpetrated
>by small time, lone operators.  During the prohibition enterprising crooks
>took
>advantage of the government's (and the population's) narrow mindedness to
>organize themselves into big money operations.  Then they laundered the money
>through legal business (usually cash oriented businesses such as restaurants,
>cleaners, etc.).  The drug cartels work the same way.  Legalization, like that
>of alcohol or cigarettes, would ensure, as Brian points out, consistent
>quality,
>safe distribution outlets (e.g., Safeway and Walgreens), variety (would you
>like
>the mint or bubble gum flavored???), lower prices, and it make the world just
>a
>little bit safer.

Leagalized drugs would be easier for children to obtain.  I don't think
this is too safe- Do you?  How much research has been done on kids w/ E, or
acid?  What are the effects?   I don't know the answers, but common sense
tells me that's kinda bad.

>
>Bradley

Jon

	Hi, I would like to ask you to reconsider some of your points. I 
don't really want to debate because I don't feel like compiling any HARD 
evidence...( time=3:30am PS) if anyone has any statistics post it, or i'll 
do it later :) 


On Sat, 13 May 1995, Jonathan Santos wrote:

> What about the big picture?  Millions of people legally tripping?  just
> that thought alone scares me.  Maybe you guys can handle your trips, but in
> most cases- people cannot control themselves and act irresponsibly.  You
> guys are probably educated- middle class - mature - and can control your
> trips quite well?  What about all of those assholes who act irresponsibly
> and fuck with people just being drunk?  Or even people who aren't even a
> threat to society?
> 
	ok, we need to look places in the world where drugs are 
semi-legal like Holland. Check out the Frankfurt Agreement where some 20+ 
European cities signed a declaration booing the WAr on Drugs. Italy 
reversed its liberal practices toward drugs and found a sharp increase in 
crime. Germany legalized pot in small quantities. 
	Most advocates of legalization want an age 21 stipulation like 
alcohol. People will be irresponsible (I gather) but with luck they 
won't be shooting at each other at the same time. 


> >Also, if drugs were legal, there would be a reduction in drug-related crimes
> >(manufacturing, trafficking, turf protection, etc.).  Organized crime really
> 
> Is that a huge problem right now?  I think the 90's have a new set of problems..
> 

	I think it is, actually. I wish I had them, but the percentage of 
people in jail in California for Drug, and interestingly Marijuana 
related crimes is quite high (The Examiner section on pot a few months 
ago). How high? // begin bad pun routine (hehe)... It cost lots of money 
to keep these people jailed. Oh yah, 
	Drug laws have brought about Civil Asset Forfeiture, the police 
can take your property (estate/monies etc) if you are SUSPECTED of a drug 
related crime. see ftp.hyperreal.com under /drugs/politics/civil asset 
forfeiture... 



> 
> Leagalized drugs would be easier for children to obtain.  I don't think
> this is too safe- Do you?  How much research has been done on kids w/ E, or
> acid?  What are the effects?   I don't know the answers, but common sense
> tells me that's kinda bad.
> 

	See above. Also I find this kind of funny cause when I was under 
age I would always laugh at the government (and do illegal drugs) cause I 
didn't need an ID to get them. I ended up smoking more pot than drinking 
for this reason. Ok, so that's anecdotal evidence. I would contend that 
the war on drugs in facts creates the very availability we wish to avoid. 
Higher prices make people want to sell it on the street. 

	So that's it. I thin argument I know, but worthy of some thought 
I hope. I'll try to find some more hard info. It's all out there 
somewhere, some of it on the net. Check out 
ftp.hyperreal.com/drugs/politics/ it has some good stuff on it, though 
its a bit dated unfortunately. Any links (what read the paper? go the 
library?!?!?!) for recent info on this topic would be cool... 

					peace,

						-xdrone

Why is it when drug "conservatives" talk about drug "legalization" they
immediately begin to talk about how easy it would be for children and
irresponsible people to get them?

It's been my impression that it ALREADY is easy for these groups to get
these drugs. I suppose that there are people that want to imagine that
it is hard - but most people I talk with started drugging in their
early teens with no particular difficulties. What is HARD is to get "safe"
drugs ie ones that are what they claim to be and in the correct dosages...
If 13 year olds are going to do drugs anyway why can't they at least get
"clean and safely dosed drugs" ?

Recently, there was a "sweep" of grade school lockers in Foster City and
the authorities were SHOCKED to find more than a few lockers with inhalant
bottles of dangerous solvents etc. that the kids were inhaling to get high.
The human "need" to feel good and get high is both strong and universal -
in both young and old - so why do we continue to deny and think that if we
make it illegal and refuse to educate on it - it will simply go away and
cease to be a problem ?

Boy -  are we dumb or what ? 


Mike

I work in a psychiatric hospitol where I see alot of use of legal 
medications, that for the most part is being used responsibly as a tool 
to help people.  Definitely not always, but alot of the time I see these 
medications as being very helpful.  Depending on the person it can be 
very clear, that some medications can help some where it might cause harm 
to another.
If some of the illegal drugs that are discussed on this list, were made 
legal at least (to start with) for more experimentation, we might be able to 
have more scientific evidence for who would benifit, and who wouldn't and what 
conditions for them to best be used.  
Think of all the additional education and research we could do if were 
able to take just a fraction of the money that the goverment spends on 
the "war against drugs".
People might choose to not do these drugs if they knew more about it, or 
then again they might want to do it more, but will at  least they would know 
better what conditions they would be better off doing them.


peter

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat May 13 10:45:26 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id KAA19459; Sat, 13 May 1995 10:45:26 -0700
Received: from ix2.ix.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id KAA19454; Sat, 13 May 1995 10:45:22 -0700
Received: from  by ix2.ix.netcom.com (8.6.12/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id KAA09811; Sat, 13 May 1995 10:43:50 -0700
Date: Sat, 13 May 1995 10:43:50 -0700
Message-Id: <199505131743.KAA09811@ix2.ix.netcom.com>
From: bradleyg@ix.netcom.com (Bradley Graham)
Subject: More on Responsible Chemistry
To: peterf@netcom.com (Peter Fogel)
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

You wrote: 
>
>I work in a psychiatric hospitol where I see alot of use of legal 
>medications, that for the most part is being used responsibly as a tool 
>to help people.  Definitely not always, but alot of the time I see these 
>medications as being very helpful.  Depending on the person it can be 
>very clear, that some medications can help some where it might cause harm 
>to another.

Yes, and mixing drugs or drugs and alcohol can have unpredictble results.

>If some of the illegal drugs that are discussed on this list, were made 
>legal at least (to start with) for more experimentation, we might be able to 
>have more scientific evidence for who would benifit, and who wouldn't and what 
>conditions for them to best be used.  

X was legal at one time and used extensively for psychotherapy.  For some 
reason, and I am not sure why (maybe adverse affects, maybe better drugs,
maybe a change in psychotheraputic practices?), they discontinued its use
and made it illegal.

In the perfect world, the drug companies are suppose to run trials that
will determine the goodness and badness of the drugs.  Unfortunately,
most of the time the tests are incomplete, run by incompetents, or the
results are not fully disclosed. The FDA does not necessarily do it
complete due dilligence and the drug gets approved.  There's a tremendous
amount of politics and influence pedaling (read as lobbying) that goes on 
behind the scenes.  But this is not limited to the drug industry of course.

>People might choose to not do these drugs if they knew more about it, or 
>then again they might want to do it more, but will at  least they would know 
>better what conditions they would be better off doing them.

Somehow, I am very cynical about human nature in this respect.  Consider
that people smoke those awful cigarettes that are killing them (and me
through second hand smoke).  They know the affects and yet theystill do
it.  Out of habit (addiction) or for the "high."   It really doesn't matter
why.  They still do it.  So whether drugs have bad affects along with the
good, people will still use them.  They'll still suffer.  It's sort of like
surfing in shark infested water; you know there's a chance you'll get munched
but the thrill of surfing is overwhelming.

Finally, as for 13 year olds running around using drugs when they are
legalized...  I think you have that today.  Even elementary school students 
are using drugs, smoke cigarettes, drink, and carry guns.  That is a reality 
of our modern society.  Legalizing may have an impact on this as the playground
dealer will be eliminated by general availability.  But then again, we won't
know until we do it will we!?!?!?  I'm not exactly sure what the answer.  I
can tell you that trying to solve problem on the supply side is like putting
your finger in the dyke.  We need to address the problem at the demand side
to be successful.  Once we understand why people are turning to drugs (many
reasons I know), we can use the money once spent on interdication and law
enforcement more productively to achieve real results.

Bradley

P.S.  BTW, I don't personally use illicit drugs.  Maybe they are great and
      maybe the create an experience unlike anything else, but many of the 
      points discussed in the thread about responsible chemistry and MDMA
      are exactly the reason why I don't.  Net:  to much uncertainty and
      risk.  My philosophy has always been "better to be a live chicken 
      than a dead duck."  I still have a pretty good life, too.
