CyberWire Dispatch // Copyright (c) 1995 //

Jacking in from the "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" Port:

Washington, D.C. -- The Internet had its head placed on the chopping block
during a Congressional hearing today (May 11th).  

Sen. Arlen Specter (R-Pa.) put it there.  Sen. Herb Kohl (D-Wis.) tied its
hands, while Sen. Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.) welded the axe. 

Specter, as chairman of the Subcommittee on Terrorism, Technology and
Government Information, called the hearing to investigate "The Availability
of Bomb Making Information on the Internet."  The hearing focused on "the
use of the Internet by a variety of groups and individuals to propagate
'mayhem manuals,' which as their name suggests, are guides to assist people
in committing acts of violence," Specter said.  

Specter didn't mince words about his intentions.  The subtext of the
hearing was that the Internet, somehow, now represents a "clear and present
danger" to the American way of life, threatening innocent citizens and
children.  "There are serious questions about whether it is technologically
feasible to restrict access to the Internet or to censor certain messages,"
Specter said.

Feinstein rode into the hearing with blinders on.  "I have a problem with
people teaching others" how to build bombs that kill, she said.  The First
Amendment doesn't extend to the that kind of information, she said,
especially when it resides in electronic format so easily available.  

Her remarks were directed at a panel of experts who had, for the most part,
acknowledged that such information was readily available on the Net,
but nonetheless was indeed protected by the First Amendment. 

The First Amendment argument didn't fly with Feinstein, who railed at the
panel's testimony.  "You really have my dander up," she said.  "This is not
what this country is about."

That remark drew a sharp response from Jerry Berman, executive director of
the Washington-based Center for Democracy and Technology: "Excuse me,
Senator, but that *is* what this nation is all about."   

Feinstein would hear nothing of it.  "I believe there is a difference
between free speech and teaching someone to kill," she said,  "And all
we're doing here is protecting [terrorist information] under the mantle of
free speech."

Feinstein, former mayor of San Francisco, one of America's most liberal
cities, carried a lot of baggage into the hearing;  she was once the failed
target of a letter bomb addressed to her office while mayor, according to a
Subcommittee staffer.

Sen. Kohl waded into the hearing reading from a tired script,
saying that America would "be shocked" if they knew about "dark back
alleys" of the "information superhighway."   Kohl paid lip-service to the
Constitution, saying that government shouldn't "be in the business of
telling people what they can and cannot think."  However, that didn't stop
him from suggesting that government has every right to "prevent people from
endangering public safety," which really means restricting access --
somehow -- to the "dangerous" (ooohhh....) "dark back alleys" of the
Internet.

His suggestions:  (1) Parents should be notified every time their kids get
an online account.  (2) Every parent should be able to block a kid's access
to whatever areas they want.  "If we have the technology to get kids on the
Internet, we should have the technology to get them off it," he said.  (3)
Online companies should rip out a page from the video game industry, where
"industry-wide cooperation to restrict access to minors has forestalled
government intervention," he said.

The vid-game industry, right, those cozy folks that bring Mortal Kombat
into your living room and shopping malls, where even 8-year olds know how
to punch in the infamous "blood codes"  which, when enabled, show defeated
characters being gutted while still alive, leaving the screen oozing.  And
this is the same video industry which drew a sharp rebuke from Sen. Specter
himself last December when he found out that the so-called "industry-wide
cooperation" to label games with "ratings" wasn't being implemented on
anything more than a piecemeal basis. 

Fueling this hysteria-circus was Robert Litt, deputy assistant attorney
general, Criminal Div. of the Department of Justice.  Litt mouthed to the
Subcommittee  what will certainly become the "Scare Monger's Anthem":  "Not
only do would-be terrorists have access to detailed information on how to
construct explosives, but so do children."

.. And so do children...

"This problem can only grow worse as more families join the Internet
'society,'" Litt warned.   .

"... And so do children..."

But does any of this so-called terrorist information require any kind of
congressional Constitutional tweaking?  Not according to Litt's own
testimony.  There are, on the books now, "a number of federal laws" that
can be used to "prosecute bomb-related offenses," and those can be directly
transferred to any such investigations linked to the Internet, Litt
testified, adding that such laws "can be applied even when the offense is
accomplished through speech."

Read it again:  "[A]pplied even... through speech."  If that was the sound
of a hammer falling -- or an axe -- you're right.

Litt outlined how current laws protect even bomb making materials on the
Internet as expressions of free speech;  however, he noted, with some glee,
that the proposals before Congress right now, offered up by the White
House, will "permit the government to better track and prosecute those who
misuse information available on the Internet...."

The hysteria of these doomsayers, however, ran into an unexpected brick
wall during the hearing.  Sen. Specter asked Litt point-blank if he had
*any* kind of statistics or "direct knowledge" of any "criminal act" that
had resulted from anyone obtaining information off the Internet.  "No
Senator, we do not," Litt answered somewhat shyly.  Specter reframed the
question -- twice -- giving Litt a chance to weasel an answer, but there
was no weasel room.  

The cold, hard facts are and remain:  No law enforcement agency has been
able to link any criminal act to any information now residing on the
Internet.

But this wasn't good enough for Specter, who asked Litt to go back and
"investigate" the question and report his findings back to the
Subcommittee.

Another blow to Internet foes was the testimony of Frank Tuerkheimer. 
Tuerkheimer, a professor of law at the U. of Wisconsin, made his fame in
the 1970s as the U.S. Attorney which successfully argued to stop the
publication of the "How to Make an H-Bomb" article in the _Progressive_
magazine.  He won that case, which he admitted today, he had little
enthusiasm for trying because the information in the article was gathered
from public domain sources. However, all of that effort was moot point, he
noted:  Some other publication printed the article anyway.

Information will find a way to get out, Tuerkheimer said.  "We're not
talking about regulating information," he said, "we're talking about
regulating 'information-plus."  That's when the information is taken and
used in the commission of a criminal act, and it's that combination that
needs to be addressed, not the information, he said.

Putting a fine point on his arguments, Tuerkheimer noted in his
testimony that the Encyclopedia Britannica "reveals great detail on
explosive manufacture."  [It's all right there on on pages 275-282 of Vol.
21 of the 1986 edition.]   Adding insult to injury, he pointed out that on
page 279 of that section, there is a description of the Ammonium
Nitrate/Fuel oil mixture bomb like that used in the Oklahoma City bombing! 

I wonder, now, if Sen. Feinstein will rush to outlaw the encyclopedia... or
maybe she'll introduce a bill that will have librarians issued X-acto
knives to cut out just those pages. "...so the children" won't have
access....

Perhaps Tuerkheimer's finest blow was when he noted that the Department of
Agriculture Forestry Service publishes the "Blaster's Handbook" (written
with taxpayer money) that also includes a recipe for the Ammonium
Nitrate/Fuel oil bomb like that used to blow little kids into chunks in the
Oklahoma City bombing.  

America's online sweetheart, America Online, was represented ably by
William Burrington.  He admitted to the Subcommittee that although his
company monitored "selected areas" for violations of the company's terms of
service, there was no possible to keep an eye on every public message.  The
point he hammered on -- and rightly so -- is that the "information ocean"
that is the Internet is impossible to place restrictions on "because of its
international nature," he said, more than once.  Any laws the U.S. might
try to apply don't mean shit internationally, as Burrington tried to point
out, a point that apparently fell on deaf ears.

One pair of ears that didn't fail to hear were those of Sen. Patrick Leahy
(D-Vermont).  This old warhorse continued to be what increasingly sounds
like the only voice of reason on Capitol Hill.  "Before we head down a road
that leads to censorship," he said, "we must think long and hard about its
consequences."  

Leahy is bothered about "tragic events" such as the Oklahoma bombing as
much as anyone, he said.  However, the "same First Amendment that protects
each of us and our right to think and speak as we choose, protects others
as well," he said.  It is "harmful and dangerous *conduct*, not speech,
that justify adverse legal consequences," Leahy noted.

There is "little to be gained in the way of safety by banning" access to
so-called terrorist information "over electronic media," Leahy said,
especially when it's so readily available in paper form... even from the
Agriculture Department.  Hell, there's probably even an government
sponsored 800 number you can call to order the "Blaster's Handbook."  

In one lengthy discussion, Specter cited an Internet posting in which the
poster asked for bomb making information that he (or she, gender wasn't
noted) could use against "zionist government officials."  Specter asked the
panel if such a message could be considered a crime.

"No," said the Justice Department's Litt.  "But what about the response to
the
message?" Specter asked.  Such a response "approaches, if it hasn't already
crossed the line, a prosecutorial offense," Litt said.

Tuerkheimer disagreed.  "Too general," he said.  There's "no
target" identified, "it's hard to see how the Justice Department could
prosecute" the responder to that message, he said.  

Of course, Specter's query begs the question:  Would it be a crime to
respond to the "bomb information wanted" message by sending them a copy of
the taxpayer funded, government-sponsored "Blaster's Handbook"?  You make
the call, because if you don't, Congress will. 

"In other words, the industry acts now or Congress will do it for you," Kohl
said.  

I doubt he was joking.

Meeks out...




From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat May 13 11:12:17 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id LAA21292; Sat, 13 May 1995 11:12:17 -0700

CyberWire Dispatch// Copyright (c) 1995//

Jacking in from the Narco-Terrorist Encryption Port:

Washington, DC --  The other shoe has dropped.  Several times.

In the political backlash and emotional fallout of the bombing of of the
federal building in Oklahoma City, FBI Director Louis Freeh has begun to
wage his own private war on the use of private, encryption schemes.

According to Administration sources, several different proposals are now
being discussed on how to implement a policy of government mandated,
government "certified" encryption.  The most hardline of these proposals
would outlaw the public's ability to choose an encryption scheme which the
government couldn't break, under the authority of a court order.

Freeh has left no doubts about his intentions.  Not satisfied with a
proposal he successfully rammed through Congress last year -- the bill that
gives law enforcement agencies "easy wiretap access" to digital
conversations, at a cost of $500 million in taxpayer money -- his next
target is private encryption.

During an appropriations hearing May 11th, Freeh told a congressional
panel: "[W]e're in favor of strong encryption, robust encryption.  The
country needs it, industry needs it.  We just want to make sure we have a
trap door and key under some judge's authority where we can get there if
somebody is planning a crime."

That means an end to private, non-government encryption, which don't have
keys the government can use.  

Private encryption schemes allow a person to scramble an electronic message
that, if intercepted by an unintended party, renders it unreadable.  These
scrambling programs are useful from to a wide range of people and
interests, including researchers that want to keep their proprietary
breakthroughs safe from prying eyes to corporations sending trade secrets
to a distant office across the Net to ordinary folks sending a steamy love
letter to a lover.  

But these same encryption programs are being used by "terrorists and
international drug traffickers," as well, claims FBI Director Freeh, and
that makes private encryption schemes a threat to national security.

Freeh's crusade against encryption has been enjoined by members of the
Justice Department, with the gleeful back alley goading the nation's top
spook group, the National Security Agency.

And when it comes right down to it, your privacy rights don't stand a
snowball's chance in hell of outweighing pictures of dead babies or pieces
of dead babies.

During an April 27th Senate Judiciary Committee on terrorism, Freeh boldly
told a panel of lawmakers eager to give his agency more latitude to "catch
the bad guys" (and civil rights violations be damned... as long as we don't
have to watch the guts of little kids being splattered on steel girders and
broken concrete...): "The FBI cannot and should not tolerate any
individuals or groups... which would kill innocent Americans, which would
kill *'America's kids.'*"

To meet the "challenges of terrorism," Freeh said, several things must be
done, among them, deal with "encryption capabilities available to criminals
and terrorists" because such technology endangers "the future usefulness of
court-authorized wiretaps.  This problem must be resolved."

While Freeh used the Oklahoma City bombing as convenient "news hook" to
again make a pitch to "resolve" the private encryption "problem," the
Director was basically reading from a dog-eared script.  Within the last 3
months he repeatedly has testified publicly before Congress about the
"evils" of encryption.

On March 30 the House Judiciary Committee's Subcommittee on Crime he said: 
"Even though access is all but assured [by the passage of the Digital
Wiretap Act] an even more difficult problem with court-authorized wiretaps
looms. Powerful encryption is becoming commonplace.  The drug cartels are
buying sophisticated communications equipment.... This, as much as any
issue, jeopardizes the public safety and national security of this country.
 Drug cartels, terrorists, and kidnappers will use telephones and other
communications media with impunity knowing that their conversations are
immune from our most valued investigative technique."
 
 Then during a May 3 appearance before the same Committee, Freeh said:
 "Encryption capabilities available to criminals and terrorists, both now
and in days to come, must be dealt with promptly.  We will not have an
effective counterterrorism counterterrorism strategy if we do not
solve the problem of encryption."

But there's nothing to be alarmed at here, according to Freeh.  Just
because he's asking the Congress and the White House to strip you of the
right to choose how you scramble your messages, using a program that the
government doesn't hold all the keys too, doesn't mean that the Director
isn't a sensitive guy or that he has suddenly taken a liking to wearing
jackboots.  

Freeh steadfastly maintains all these new powers he's asking for are simply
"tools" and "not new authorities."  These new powers are "well within the
Constitution," Freeh told Congress.  

Freeh hasn't publicly outlined just how he proposes to "resolve" the
"encryption problem."  However, according to an FBI source, several plans
are in the works.  The source refused to detail any specific plan, but
added:  "Let's just say everything is on the table."  Does that include
outlawing private encryption schemes?  "I said 'everything,'" the source
said.

The encryption debate has been raging for years.  Two years ago the Clinton
Administration unveiled a new policy in which it proposed to flood the
market with its own home-grown encryption devices -- a product of the
National Security Agency -- called the "Clipper Chip."  

The Clipper is based on a "key-escrow" system.  Two government agencies
would hold the keys "in escrow", which are uique to each chip, in a kind
of "data vault."  Any time the FBI-- or your local sheriff -- wanted to tap
your phone conversations, they would have to ask a judge to give the two
government agencies to turn over the keys to you Clipper chip.  With those
keys, the FBI could then unscramble any of your conversations at will.

That policy raised a huge firestorm of controversy and the Clipper sunk
from sight, down, but not out.  The intent of the White House, acting as a
front man for the NSA and other intelligence agencies along with the FBI,
was to have Americans adopt Clipper voluntarily.  The FBI took it on good
faith -- and I'm not joking here -- that criminals, too, would buy Clipper
equipped phones, allowing the government to easily unscramble their
wiretapped conversations.

Why would criminals knowingly use a device they knew the government could
easily tap?  "Because criminals are stupid," was the FBI's party line.  No,
I'm not making this up.

The "voluntary" aspect didn't stop the controversy.  Indeed, buried in the
Administration's own background briefing papers on the Clipper was the no
nonsense statement that the Administration, after reviewing the
Constitution, had determined that "American's have no Constitutional right
to choose their own method of encryption."  Call it a peremptory strike on
privacy.

The  end of freely chosen encryption comes as no surprise to Jim Dempsey,
currently the executive director of the Center for National Security
Studies.  Dempsey, you might remember, walked point for former Congressman
Don Edwards during last year's tussle over the FBI's Digital Wiretap access
bill.  Dempsey, in fact was one of the bill's principal authors. "I always
felt [the Administration] had to know they would ultimately go to [some
kind of government] mandatory encryption scheme," Dempsey said.  "I don't
think it's a big leap for the government to think of private encryption
like they do kiddie porn."

An NSA source, when questioned about his agency's role in the process, was
reluctant to speak.  He did say that Clipper was merely "Act One" of a
"Three part play."  Pressed for further details, he said, "do your own
homework."

During the Senate Subcommittee on Terrorism hearing May 11, Robert Litt,
deputy assistant attorney general for the Criminal Division of Justice,
said the "widespread use of reliable, strong encryption that allows
government access, with appropriate restrictions... is designed to achieve"
a "delicate balance" between privacy rights and law enforcement needs.  

When Dispatch asked Litt to elaborate, he said his comments refereed to the
use of the Clipper Chip.  But what if criminals bypass Clipper, using
private encryption schemes, such as those now being decried by Freeh?  "If
one solution doesn't work, then we have to go to the next step," he said. 
Is that next step the outlawing of private encryption?  Litt smiled and
repeated his answer.

Dispatch has learned that one proposal being seriously discussed would,
indeed, outlaw all private, non-government approved encryption schemes. 
Here's how the government plan breaks out, according to sources familiar
with the proposal:

(1)  The government would "certify" a few so-called "Commercial Key-Escrow"
programs.  These are similar in design to the government's Clipper Chip,
but industry would hold the keys and some of these systems might not be
classified, as is the software underlying Clipper.  However, the companies
producing such "certified" programs could claim trade secrets, not allowing
the public access the underlying programs.

(2)  The government, tossing a bone to industry, would lift export controls
on all "certified" encryption programs.  Currently, it's against the law to
export encryption programs, as they are controlled by the State Department
under the same classification as munitions.

(3)  The use of government certified encryption would become a federal
mandate, making it illegal to use private encryption schemes that had not
passed the "certification" test.

The plans are "still really liquid," said an Administration source.  "We
all know what a bitch this going to be trying to sell it to the selling
public," he said.  "The flashpoint potential of this idea isn't lost on
anyone."

The Administration is hoping the public will buy off on the fact that: (1) 
It's private industry holding the keys, not government agencies.  (2)  The
availability of "choice" amog several different vendors will squash the
imagery of Big Brother.  

Expect the rise of an off-shore, black market "encryption" trade.  It will
surely come.  And it will have to be a black market;  the FBI has already
gone around the world preaching the evils of private encryption, trying to
get other law enforcement groups to push for outlawing such programs in
their own countries.  And they already have a convert:  Russia.  That
country recently adopted such a policy... nice to know we're following in
Mr. Yeltsin's footsteps.

Meeks out...

First off: it's bad ettiquette to take (what I think is a) private
conversation back to the public forum.  Please check your mail headers before
adding in "sfraves@hyperreal.com" to make sure it was there first. 

Secondly: I think it's perfectly reasonable to charge for attendance to a 
lecture.

Thirdly: Wired Magazine did *not* donate the server for Hyperreal (I paid 
for it out of my own pocket and continue to pay for its upkeep, though 
occasionally we have fundraisers), nor am I any longer an employee of 
Wired/HotWired (though I am still in the same building, and the bandwidth 
is the same).  The bandwidth is now a donation from my company, Organic 
Online.  However, doing this should not mean that information should not 
and does not need to be paid for somehow.  

	Brian

From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>

> On Sat, 13 May 1995, Niels P. Mayer wrote:
> > Knowledge always costs money and/or time and perseverence to obtain.
> > Since time is money ( :-) ) I'd venture to say that knowledge is never
> > gained for "free" . So to say "no cost" seems pretty inapproriate (and
> > a tad disrespectful of Bruce and his considerable eXperience in the
> > subject).
> 
> In the greater sense of the concept I agree with you. However, there is a 
> ton of information about the subject available at no charge to anyone. 
> That is what I am talking about. Not knowledge as a broad concept.

Gee, when I go over to my local public library and look up anything on
the subject, I don't see a single book about it.  Maybe that kind of
stuff will not be censored at a university library -- but it's rare to
be able to walk into a uni-library unless you're a student, and in case
you haven't noticed, even "public" colleges cost money and require
registration.

Oh, you mean there is information available "for free" on the internet.
Sorry, I think you don't understand -- nothing on the internet is free,
it has been supported in the past by DARPA/NSF money, a lot of the
infrastructure and software that people are using/selling was developed
on your tax dollar, and chances are, if you're connecting to the net
"on your own" you've got to blow at least $15.00 a month plus an
initial outlay of at $500-$1000.00 for equipment, and don't forget some
portion of a $9.00/month phone bill. People in college get free
accounts, but don't for a moment think they're really free -- its
either sponsored by your tuition or by tax support; people in hi-tech
jobs may get internet accounts as a perk, but don't think for a moment
that all that infrastructure is free -- it comes out of your salary.

To say nothing about the training/education/hairpulling that is
required to get a non-computer person to be able to set up a computer,
connect to a service provider, and figure out how to use these internet
resources (e.g. World Wide Web). That is typically not free either.

Furthermore, if you're talking about the "free" stuff available from
http://www.hyperreal.com/drugs -- remember that the internet
connectivity of that machine is being sponsored by Wired magazine.
Although the  costs of their inernet connectivity are amortized over
their whole HotWired site, if someone else were to attempt to put up a
site like that on their own funding, you can expect a multithousand
dollar initial outlay, plus a $1000-$3000 a month or so for a T1 (maybe
the T1 rate has dropped recently -- take these as a ballpark).

That ain't what I call "free".

> P.S. Respect is earned, not expected or demanded.

Given my past rants about PLUR, you might find it hard to believe that
I'm going to defend "R". IMHO, disrespect is earned, but you should
give everybody the benefit of the doubt first. Or would you prefer that
I disrespect you simply because I don't know you and I've never given
you the opportunity to "earn" respect? I never said anything about
expecting or demanding respect.

>make it illegal and refuse to educate on it - it will simply go away and
>cease to be a problem ?

        I would agree with this need (gee wiz i'm sure we've all felt it)
but i'm not positive if it's either an essential human genetic trait or
some reaction to being forced to live in a society that values things more
than people, a society that distracts one from seeking 'higher' (though
maybe not absolute) truths in a spiritual/metaphysical sense, a society
that posits material wealth as being an end unto itself and even if one
DOES achieve this goal (and how many ppl do you know that are in this
position?) they are often left to find "something more" or some deeper sort
of meaning, a society that, in the process of trying to sell more product,
actively attempts to alienate people from each other and from themselves to
invoke a sense of worthlessness and spiritual impoverishment which can only
be quenched by buying a new VCR, a bigger TV, a new car..etc..and HEY, if
that impoverishment WAS actually quenched by buying something (and it never
is) the whole wheels of advanced capitalism would stop rollin'
        oh yeah, i forgot to add..IMHO ;)

Don't sweat it, Bruce.  Black Adder was posting from reflex, I think,
which is why I won't bother to flame him here.

We sometimes sardonically post things with the preface, BSP (short for
Bogus Self Promotion or something, I forget how that started).

The point is, this list exists to exchange information and views of its
members.  Nobody here has tried to use this as a commercial forum.
I *really* object to any effort to squelch the usefulness of this list
by riding some self-righteous hobby horse about "commercial" use.

The Net and this list exist to help people gain access to information
and share their views.  Any effort to the contrary, be it by Louis Freeh
and Senator Exon, or someone petulantly complaining about providing
pointers to valuable events and resources, is opposed to the free and
reasonable flow of information.

To follow Black Adder's supposed logic to its conclusion, we would not
even be able to announce a party organized by Friends & Family or any
other group composed in part of members of this list if we were even
to ask for $1 donations.

I'll leave it at that.  Let's move on.  And Bruce, thanks for joining
and I for one look forward to your continued participation.

see you in the future
phred


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat May 13 18:31:40 1995

In-Reply-To: jon@netnoir.com (Jonathan Santos)
        "Re: Responsible Chemistry" (May 13,  2:57am)
References: <199505130957.CAA21933@hopf.dnai.com>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.0 06sep94)
To: jon@netnoir.com (Jonathan Santos), SFRAVES@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Responsible Chemistry
Cc: bradleyg@ix.netcom.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

What Jon's argument basically comes down to is that people can't be
trusted.  So let's not let them do mind-altering substances at all,
because sometimes they get themselves in trouble.

OK, if that's the logic you want, how about this?  Sex is prohibited,
alcohol consumption is prohibited, riding in motorized vehicles is
prohibited, *eating* is prohibited, because sometimes people do these
things recklessly and get hurt.

And I say, get *real*.  People have been doing mind-altering substances
for about as long as they have been having sex, raising kids, teaching,
eating, travelling and making art.  

I heartily recommend Andrew Weil's excellent article in the new issue
of The New Yorker about the use of coca leaves in indigenous South
American cultures, versus the development and abuse of cocaine, a
product of the same plant.  The questions, as always, relate to drug
*abuse* and abandonment of the storehouse of knowledge humans have
gained over the generations about their benefits and risks.

Prohibition never works and simply creates corruption.  Education and
taking care of each other are the approaches that work.  In this
benighted time when politicians and media figures will say *anything*
to support prohibition in search of a quick fix, we need to stand up
and call them on their abandonment of common sense and wisdom in
dealing with the human condition.

c u
phred

still had more meaning and always will.

On Sat, 13 May 1995, Niels P. Mayer wrote:

> > On Sat, 13 May 1995, Niels P. Mayer wrote:
> > > Knowledge always costs money and/or time and perseverence to obtain.
> > > Since time is money ( :-) ) I'd venture to say that knowledge is never
> > > gained for "free" . So to say "no cost" seems pretty inapproriate (and
> > > a tad disrespectful of Bruce and his considerable eXperience in the
> > > subject).
> > 
> > In the greater sense of the concept I agree with you. However, there is a 
> > ton of information about the subject available at no charge to anyone. 
> > That is what I am talking about. Not knowledge as a broad concept.
> 
> Gee, when I go over to my local public library and look up anything on
> the subject, I don't see a single book about it.  Maybe that kind of
> stuff will not be censored at a university library -- but it's rare to
> be able to walk into a uni-library unless you're a student, and in case
> you haven't noticed, even "public" colleges cost money and require
> registration.

Then I suggest you go back to your public library and talk to your 
librarian about inter-library loans. Librarians are some of the nicest
people I know when it comes to helping you find information on any given
subject.
 And I have have had no problems walking into UC Davis or UCSF's 
libraries, running through MELVYL, and getting any information I might 
want on the subject, although of course I can't check out the books.
  
> Oh, you mean there is information available "for free" on the internet.
> Sorry, I think you don't understand -- nothing on the internet is free,
> it has been supported in the past by DARPA/NSF money, a lot of the
> infrastructure and software that people are using/selling was developed
> on your tax dollar, and chances are, if you're connecting to the net
> "on your own" you've got to blow at least $15.00 a month plus an
> initial outlay of at $500-$1000.00 for equipment, and don't forget some
> portion of a $9.00/month phone bill. People in college get free
> accounts, but don't for a moment think they're really free -- its
> either sponsored by your tuition or by tax support; people in hi-tech
> jobs may get internet accounts as a perk, but don't think for a moment
> that all that infrastructure is free -- it comes out of your salary.
> 
> To say nothing about the training/education/hairpulling that is
> required to get a non-computer person to be able to set up a computer,
> connect to a service provider, and figure out how to use these internet
> resources (e.g. World Wide Web). That is typically not free either.
>

Most of the above costs, save the internet access are intangible. We are 
paying for method of distribution, not the information itself.
  
> Furthermore, if you're talking about the "free" stuff available from
> http://www.hyperreal.com/drugs -- remember that the internet
> connectivity of that machine is being sponsored by Wired magazine.
> Although the  costs of their inernet connectivity are amortized over
> their whole HotWired site, if someone else were to attempt to put up a
> site like that on their own funding, you can expect a multithousand
> dollar initial outlay, plus a $1000-$3000 a month or so for a T1 (maybe
> the T1 rate has dropped recently -- take these as a ballpark).
>
Well, gee if I am not paying for it, I sure as hell consider it to be free.
 
> That ain't what I call "free".
> 
> > P.S. Respect is earned, not expected or demanded.
> 
> Given my past rants about PLUR, you might find it hard to believe that
> I'm going to defend "R". IMHO, disrespect is earned, but you should
> give everybody the benefit of the doubt first. Or would you prefer that
> I disrespect you simply because I don't know you and I've never given
> you the opportunity to "earn" respect? I never said anything about
> expecting or demanding respect.

This is the one area in which I was a bit hasty. I should have said 
Respect beyond what one would normally extend to another human being. I 
do believe in respecting your fellow human beings, but I don't subscibe 
to the sacred cow crap. Sorry if I question your idol, but he is yours, 
not mine. This whole pointless thread developed from a simple 
misunderstanding. Bruce and I have sent mail back and forth and we have 
corrected that misunderstanding. I would love nothing more than to just 
let this whole depressing, negative thread DROP....

                                              Black Adder

On Sat, 13 May 1995, Fred Heutte wrote:

> Don't sweat it, Bruce.  Black Adder was posting from reflex, I think,
> which is why I won't bother to flame him here.
> 
> We sometimes sardonically post things with the preface, BSP (short for
> Bogus Self Promotion or something, I forget how that started).

Actually, I was developing an AI agent to automatically post bitchy 
messages when it sees BSP's, and it got out of hand... >:-) 

> 
> The point is, this list exists to exchange information and views of its
> members.  Nobody here has tried to use this as a commercial forum.
> I *really* object to any effort to squelch the usefulness of this list
> by riding some self-righteous hobby horse about "commercial" use.
> 
> The Net and this list exist to help people gain access to information
> and share their views.  Any effort to the contrary, be it by Louis Freeh
> and Senator Exon, or someone petulantly complaining about providing
> pointers to valuable events and resources, is opposed to the free and
> reasonable flow of information.
> 
> To follow Black Adder's supposed logic to its conclusion, we would not
> even be able to announce a party organized by Friends & Family or any
> other group composed in part of members of this list if we were even
> to ask for $1 donations.

Not true at all. What I objected to was what I viewed as someone charging 
for information which is available all over the place for free(or for 
nothing more over what you are already paying in tax dollars or net 
access charges(Happy Niels? ) If someone got on here and started 
advertising a service that gave the numbers and locations of parties for 
a price(also freely available info through Sf-raves and Hyperreal(thank 
you Derek and all the contributors)) I would hope that I would not be the 
only one that would be upset. 
I wasn't objecting to the advertisement itself, but to the possiblity
that someone might think they would have to pay in order to get 
reliable information on the subject(Bruce failed to mention 
that this was a benefit.) I would like to think of Sf-Raves as a bunch of 
friends that I just haven't met in person(although at this rate I may not 
be doing myself any favors.) And so I got upset. And so I posted a 
private message to Bruce. And Bruce decieded to make the matter public. 
And you know what? The whole thing is utterly ridiculous considering that 
it seems that we both feel the same about access to information...
I hope that this clarifies the matter for once and all.


                                              Black Adder

>What Jon's argument basically comes down to is that people can't be
>trusted.  So let's not let them do mind-altering substances at all,
>because sometimes they get themselves in trouble.

Hmm..   I guess that's what I am saying.. But do you trust everyone?

>
>OK, if that's the logic you want, how about this?  Sex is prohibited,
>alcohol consumption is prohibited, riding in motorized vehicles is
>prohibited, *eating* is prohibited, because sometimes people do these
>things recklessly and get hurt.

So what you are saying is.. Do what ya like..  I agree < but I still don't
trust everyone..

>And I say, get *real*.  People have been doing mind-altering substances
>for about as long as they have been having sex, raising kids, teaching,
>eating, travelling and making art.

Are you telling me to get real?  Your the one who was probably trippin'
when you wrote your letter.  (:

>I heartily recommend Andrew Weil's excellent article in the new issue
>of The New Yorker about the use of coca leaves in indigenous South
>American cultures, versus the development and abuse of cocaine, a
>product of the same plant.  The questions, as always, relate to drug
>*abuse* and abandonment of the storehouse of knowledge humans have
>gained over the generations about their benefits and risks.
>
>Prohibition never works and simply creates corruption.  Education and
>taking care of each other are the approaches that work.  In this
>benighted time when politicians and media figures will say *anything*
>to support prohibition in search of a quick fix, we need to stand up
>and call them on their abandonment of common sense and wisdom in
>dealing with the human condition.

I am not for prohibition.. I just was arguing some points for the sake of
arguement. (hey bri)

I feel that anyone in the planet has the right to do *whatever* they want
to>  So long as they don't hurt anyone else in the process.

My philosophy is that simple.

My general attitude towards halucinogens these days stem from nasty
experiences I had in 92 and 93.  I was heavy into "E" and acid;  I had some
pretty bad trips.  Everyone has their own incredible trips>> somewhere down
the line- I lost it.  I remember the last time I tripped>  I was at Ritchie
Hawtins birthday party at a small house in Detroit. I was pretty messed up:
I left someone alone that I loved:  I freaked out:  I just couldn't handle
it.  Unlike most of you who seem to enjoy your trips, I rarely enjoyed
mine.

and that's why I get so cranky talkin' about it.

Time to go out ravin'..


Jon

p.s.  I've learned quite a bit from this thread (and Hyperreal)

On Sat, 13 May 1995, June K. Eaton wrote:

> On Sat, 13 May 1995, Doug Zimmerman wrote> 
> >   on the east coast they always have the price included on the flyer.
> > and from my experiences there the $20 you spend on a party is
> > ususally better then the $20 you spend here.  (except smarties and
> > digitaria :)
> > 
> > doug ) ( doug@squishy.com
> > 
> 
> Um...I would have to disagree.  I think FIVE DOLLARS spent in
> SF is better spent than $25 on the east coast.  
> 
> Except for maybe Baltimore at Sunday Mass.
> 
> 
> 
The deliniation I was making in saying a $20 dollar party had more
bang for its buck on the east coast then in sf is because of a few
reasons:

1)  a LOT more guest dj's:  from Europe, from the Southeast, Midwest,
West Coast US, Canada, etc.   In San Francisco there has only been
ONE big party where i was charged $20 that featured dj's from anywhere
else besides the west coast.  
    So therefore i think you get more for your money cause you get to
hear a dj you have never heard before.  A typical big party has 
just big locals : tony, dan, garth,, etc.etc.etc..

2)  the music you hear at a big party on the East Coast usually has
more diverse musical taste them big parties here in SF.

  On the east coast you can hear djs spin anything from techno, house
(and all its assorted forms), acid, jungle, trip hop, et.al.  and all
in ONE party.  I grew up on going to parties and hearing a diversity of
techno/house etc.  Basically all the big parties here in SF play the more 
convental music that is out right now, and not the cutting edge music.

  Im not saying there arn't people who are playing the good toonz and
the new music out here.  And i think that the smaller parties that 
happen in SF are a great place to hear whats new (ex. Friends & Family)

but thats just IMHO.  flame shields ready ;)

doug ) ( doug@squishy.com

On Sun, 14 May 1995, Doug Zimmerman wrote:


> > > and from my experiences there the $20 you spend on a party is
> > > usually better than the $20 you spend here
*snip*> > 
june wrote:

> > SF is better spent than $25 on the east coast.  
> > 
> > Except for maybe Baltimore at Sunday Mass.
> > 
> > 
> > 
> The deliniation I was making in saying a $20 dollar party had more
> bang for its buck on the east coast then in sf is because of a few
> reasons:
> 
> 1)  a LOT more guest dj's:  from Europe, from the Southeast, Midwest,
> West Coast US, Canada, etc.   In San Francisco there has only been
> ONE big party where i was charged $20 that featured dj's from anywhere
> else besides the west coast.

> hear a dj you have never heard before.  A typical big party has 
> just big locals : tony, dan, garth,, etc.etc.etc..

> more diverse musical taste them big parties here in SF.
>

> (and all its assorted forms), acid, jungle, trip hop, et.al.  and all
> in ONE party.  I grew up on going to parties and hearing a diversity of
> techno/house etc.  Basically all the big parties here in SF play the more 
> convental music that is out right now, and not the cutting edge music.

> doug ) ( doug@squishy.com

hey throw down the shields, i think we're in agreement...
i LOVE jungle and trance and all the variety..
but you know i'm a tribal acidy trancey house junkie and
you just *don't* get that here.... hard house and deep
house but not that exact flava that i'm so addicted to
that you only hear in sf....

as far as what you're getting for the $$, san francisco
gives more vibe for the buck than anywhere on the planet.
you know it, people here know it....sf is the model scene
as far as that goes, and *that* was what i was referring to.

i hope that clarifies!   :) :)

peace & love from NYC,

June

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun May 14 15:39:00 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id PAA13275; Sun, 14 May 1995 15:39:00 -0700
Received: from itsa.ucsf.EDU by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id PAA13262; Sun, 14 May 1995 15:38:57 -0700
Received: (from keiper@localhost) by itsa.ucsf.EDU (8.6.8/GSC4.24)
	id PAA48432; Sun, 14 May 1995 15:36:39 -0700
Date: Sun, 14 May 1995 15:36:38 -0700 (PDT)
From: Kevin Keiper <keiper@itsa.ucsf.EDU>
Subject: party at 1559 Howard.
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9505141401.A115935-0100000@itsa.ucsf.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Don't know what the name of the party was but it was an absoloute 
stormer.  Just goes to show that it is possible to have a really good, 
small and intimate, organized and underground rave.  Cleverly, the 
organizers did not allow the venue to get to full so that it did not get 
to be a sweat box.  Also, donations was the entry price which meant that 
people gave money both on the way in and the way out.  The decorations 
were beautiful and the entire space was in the form of an l-shape which 
is an exellent shape for a  dance floor.  The visuals were also stunning 
because the guy was superimposing very powerful fantasy type images under 
animations of fractles; the backdrop that it was being projected on 
could have been hung a bit better though.  There was a really intimate 
crowd and, probably because it was a free party, there was a good mix of 
a crowd with quite a lot initially reacting to Gil by going "huh?"  soon 
started to dance and to get into it.
I really like Goa Gil but a whole night of him and nothing else is a bit 
hard to handle.  They should have some house and ambient techno in the 
early morning.  This is what (one) the difference is between here and 
London is that there their would have been other sets by dj's playing 
different music.  But when you can put three decks, a mixer and a video 
projector in a brief case there a lot to be said for it.
A really whicked party.  Tristan.

On Sat, 13 May 1995, Niels P. Mayer wrote:

> > On Sat, 13 May 1995, Niels P. Mayer wrote:
> > > Knowledge always costs money and/or time and perseverence to obtain.
> > > Since time is money ( :-) ) I'd venture to say that knowledge is never
> > > gained for "free" . So to say "no cost" seems pretty inapproriate (and
> > > a tad disrespectful of Bruce and his considerable eXperience in the
> > > subject).
> > 
> > In the greater sense of the concept I agree with you. However, there is a 
> > ton of information about the subject available at no charge to anyone. 
> > That is what I am talking about. Not knowledge as a broad concept.
> 
> Gee, when I go over to my local public library and look up anything on
> the subject, I don't see a single book about it.  Maybe that kind of
> stuff will not be censored at a university library -- but it's rare to
> be able to walk into a uni-library unless you're a student, and in case
> you haven't noticed, even "public" colleges cost money and require
> registration.
> 
> Oh, you mean there is information available "for free" on the internet.
> Sorry, I think you don't understand -- nothing on the internet is free,
> it has been supported in the past by DARPA/NSF money, a lot of the
> infrastructure and software that people are using/selling was developed
> on your tax dollar, and chances are, if you're connecting to the net
> "on your own" you've got to blow at least $15.00 a month plus an
> initial outlay of at $500-$1000.00 for equipment, and don't forget some
> portion of a $9.00/month phone bill. People in college get free
> accounts, but don't for a moment think they're really free -- its
> either sponsored by your tuition or by tax support; people in hi-tech
> jobs may get internet accounts as a perk, but don't think for a moment
> that all that infrastructure is free -- it comes out of your salary.
> 
> To say nothing about the training/education/hairpulling that is
> required to get a non-computer person to be able to set up a computer,
> connect to a service provider, and figure out how to use these internet
> resources (e.g. World Wide Web). That is typically not free either.
> 
> Furthermore, if you're talking about the "free" stuff available from
> http://www.hyperreal.com/drugs -- remember that the internet
> connectivity of that machine is being sponsored by Wired magazine.
> Although the  costs of their inernet connectivity are amortized over
> their whole HotWired site, if someone else were to attempt to put up a
> site like that on their own funding, you can expect a multithousand
> dollar initial outlay, plus a $1000-$3000 a month or so for a T1 (maybe
> the T1 rate has dropped recently -- take these as a ballpark).
> 
> That ain't what I call "free".
> 
> > P.S. Respect is earned, not expected or demanded.
> 
> Given my past rants about PLUR, you might find it hard to believe that
> I'm going to defend "R". IMHO, disrespect is earned, but you should
> give everybody the benefit of the doubt first. Or would you prefer that
> I disrespect you simply because I don't know you and I've never given
> you the opportunity to "earn" respect? I never said anything about
> expecting or demanding respect.
> 
> =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
> ==     Niels Mayer -- http://cyborganic.com/~niels -- mayer@netcom.com     ==
> =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
> 

It's true that not everything is free on the internet.  But does that 
justify charging more?  Just because it costs you money to use internet 
and to put information on it doesn't mean that i can not charge you 
freely.

just my $.02 worth

Monique

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun May 14 22:04:47 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id WAA05454; Sun, 14 May 1995 22:04:47 -0700
Received: from mail.crl.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with SMTP id WAA05448; Sun, 14 May 1995 22:04:45 -0700
Received: from crl11.crl.com by mail.crl.com with SMTP id AA18041
  (5.65c/IDA-1.5 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>); Sun, 14 May 1995 22:03:33 -0700
Date: Sun, 14 May 1995 22:03:33 -0700
Message-Id: <199505150503.AA18041@mail.crl.com>
X-Sender: davidmin@mail.crl.com
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Version 1.4.3
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: davidmin@crl.com (David Minuk)
Subject: UK trip summary
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well I'm back at my own home now.  It's been a long and interesting 2 weeks.

As I was flying into London, I heard on Radio 1 of an anti-Criminal Justice
Act demonstration taking place the same afternoon at Clapham Common.  I
wasted no time after arriving at Heathrow getting to the scene.  I had
visions of molotov-throwing rioters turning the place upside down.  What I
found was similar to a street fair, kind of a pinko picnic.  It seemed to be
organized by a coalition of unionists, socialists and communists.  There was
a good deal of entertainment in different tents, including Glen Tilbrook and
Blue Aeroplanes.  But where was the house music, I wondered?  It seemed to
follow that a demonstration against the CJA would include those targeted by
the law.  Indeed, there were crusty/traveller type bands (people who look
like our deadheads who are also targeted by the CJA) but the only rave
connection I could find was a guy selling mix tapes.  He indicated that
house/techno/jungle was too hot politically, and that people in the UK were
afraid of it.  I started to walk off, when I noticed a group gathered in the
distance.  As I had hoped, it was a party.

United Systems had set up a sound system on a flat bed truck on the far end
of the park, next to a carnival.  The police were gathered in numbers nearby
but chose to do nothing at the time.  They were told they could go to 9 p.m.
but no further.  The crowd grew as the groove went hardcore.  It was an "old
school" type rave sound (though the r-word was never used I think the whole
time I was in England).  I appreciated the energy of the crowd which was
otherwise similar in size and vibe to a Sunset.  An MC reminded the crowd
that the were defying the CJA ( actually I don't think so, only if the
police captain says they are) and busted lame rhymes like "hardcore, you
know the score" that undoubtedly left others attending with thoughts of
happier times.  The sound wasn't that great, but I actually found the rough
edges added to the excitement.  The DJ seemed to be operation over a pirate
station from a nearby van.

Speaking of pirates, I found numerous stations playing a variety of dance
music up and down the FM dial.  I hope we can see more pirates here.

That party wound down at the appointed time, and the day passed without
incident.  My next few days were devoted to sightseeing in London.  On
Thursday, out of curiosity I headed out to the original Megatripolis.  I was
curious about the clubs there, they are a big deal to people.  But there is
an obsession with fashion that turns me off (as well as other factors mostly
related to club-owners greed).  Megatripolis wasn't too bad, still pretty
commerical, best found in the music.  Sort of "handbag trance?"  In other
words, some trance, mixed with popular commercial trax.  There were
undoubtedly more underground clubs, more commercial clubs, but I had sated
my taste for London clubs.  The light show at Heaven sure kicks butt,
though!  Lasers, video, etc.-a pretty impressive place.  Other major
hotspots were Ministry of Sound, Club UK and Gardening Club. 

Friday, I went horseback riding.  Try it once, it's fun.  Sure is weird to
look down between your legs and find a huge beast underneath you.

Later that day, I checked out the Raincoats, undoubtedly some of you
remember this great post-punk band.

Saturday, I was on a train to the main event, the UK Tribal Gathering by
Universe and festival promoter Mean Fiddler.  It was a Big Deal over there.
Why?  It seems to be a new direction for the dance music scene by merging
raves with the festival scene, and doing it legal and properly.  As Fraser
has pointed out, the tradition of festivals and faires in the UK goes back
to medieval times.  The festival system allows rave culture to graft itself
onto the mainstream Anglo-Saxon culture.  

I found a long line for the bus to Otmoor Park when I got off the train at
Oxford, so I decided to walk.  Although I got lost a couple times, after an
hour or so I was able to find the right direction.  As I crossed the traffic
control zone, I met up with some locals who were on there way to TG who
accompanied me there.  It was another exhausting 2 hours to get to the park,
but it was a scenic walk through canola fields and a picturesque village.
Eventually, I beheld the site- 5 huge tents where some 20,000 people were
gathering.  As I approached a tent, I found that it was stiflingly hot in
the tents.  Sweat was condensing on the ceilings and dripping down the
sides.  It was an unusually hot week in England.  The tents were packed, but
the Tribal tent seemed to offer the most comfort and the best sound and
music, so I spent most of my time there.  The people were friendly
(especially some aussies that were there) but due to the size I found it a
bit impersonal.  Wandering around, I found a tent specializing in Jungle,
the other tents were mainly harder forms of techno and trance with a little
house.  Highlights for me were Richie Hawtins set and 808 State's
performance.  Groups like the Prodigy and Orbital played, but since those
arenas were steamy, overcrowded zoos, I backed off from them.  Comfort was
not a strong point there, as chillers were forced to sit in the back of the
tents, there was no real chill space provided.  Overall, the party went
smoothly as it was professionally put together and executed (but for this
reason lacked excitement for me).  The Brits seem to like the sheer size of
it, I found it a bit overwhelming.

On the way back from England, I stopped in Vancouver, Canada where I found
the weekly club Sol at Graceland.  It's a great club, worthy of any
metropolis.  The DJ was db from NY.

Now I'm glad to be back, I wish you, my friends, could have joined me, and I
look forward to seeing you all soon.

That's all I have to say for now, be on the lookout for pictures on my web
site.  Anyone know of someone who can digitize my photos?

David
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
David Minuk(davidmin@crl.com)

>as far as what you're getting for the $$, san francisco
>gives more vibe for the buck than anywhere on the planet.

the vibe is pretty damn good, but not the best on the planet..

(changing subjects)

I think most 'rave scenes' are in limbo right now.  Everything seems to
happen in the clubs these days- less undergrounds- Lack of Freshness
(Regurgitated party concepts>> Fractal bubbles and silly names)  It just
seems like the progression of the scene (in most places) stopped in '93.

>you know it, people here know it....sf is the model scene
>as far as that goes, and *that* was what i was referring to.

I like the fact that there are *alot* of parties out here, but maybe that's
why I never get that gravitational feeling at parties here.  Even if I go
to the party that I hear will be 'the best'> It seems like somethings
missing.  Like everyone else is at a different party. It's a wierd feeling<
the place would be packed and most of my friend would be there, but there
were probably 5 other parties that night.  elsewhere, the scenes were
usually small (600 to 1000 people in your area 'in to it')  and about 1 or
two parties on a saturday night.  It was cool because <everyone> was there!
There was gravity.  This was also cool because promoters didn't have to
battle each other.


but maybe I felt that vibe cuz I'm new here..

Dunno..




Jon

Well, MOVE did justice to what a rave could be: Folks, Fun, and cool door
guards.   The vibe never got to too much of a frenzied pace there was also
too many radical swings from upbeat to insta trance and such.  I heard from a
few others that the music was a tad bit low (I disagree, however, since it
wasn't too spacecious).  The politeness meter was at an all time high, which
is always nice.
The fan was a lovley idea since, only after 15min of non-stop dancing the
temperature rose considerably due to the many-o-dancers....  
Drawbacks: The ambient room lacked ambient music.  Although friendly, the
crowd didn't seem to be too receptive to random smiles (although there were
one or two of you I saw =).... The only other major complant would be that
needle skipping ( I think that speaks for itself...).  All in all it was
worth $10 for admission....


Smile-O-meter:
           Room: 5Smiles (seen closets bigger than this venue)
Friendliness: 7Smiles
            Vibe: 6Smiles (too many wild music/mood changes) Additude checks:
7Smiles (no one I saw fronting on anyone...)
 Chill factor: 6Smiles and a shrug (6.5smiles)
Overall : 6.5 Smiles
30 day review: Diverse City still tops the cake with the 4/20 party out by
Davenport in a close second.
c-ya next week all.....
Faust.

               Ode To Finals

       As I crack the books,
       And cook the java;
       As I learn a graph
       and study the chart;
       As I strive for a better me,
       I look to my future
       For what I'm about to be.

       I skip on parties,
       And don't see movies;
       I listen to music,
       Only for a second,
       For I know I must
       Concintrate, concintrate, concintrate.

       Next week I smile
       I worry no more;
       For if I passed all test,
       Cleared all finals,
       Made all scores.
       I'll have more stress next year
       But I'll make it my best.
       But soon comes summer!
       NO MORE STRESS!

                               SG

Good luck everyone in finals this week!

I think your vibe-o-meter is in good working condition! (concerning the
question of scene diffusion)

  A few years ago when the scene here was at a high point (IMHO *#*)
there were only a couple thousand or less people of all ages that were in
the know. Good, big, all ages parties happened once a month or less
frequently and EVERYBODY would show up and parties would consistently ROCK!
Essentially the whole scene could fit in a big party. Naturally, alot of
people heard what they were missing and demand soared, supply increased and
the scene went superground, with many more big parties - multiples on
Saturday night and such. From that point on I also started to feel what you
are feeling, something's missing and the scene is becoming diffused. Some
people I know that used to come out say the scene is dead but the recent
personal experiences of many (and I) argue that they are way wrong. It just
may be a bit tougher to have everything gel and have a great vibe (maybe a
more mature :) scene) . Personally, I have found that lately the best parties
(vibewise) that I have been to have something out of the ordinary (I know
this is vague) that adds that little (in)tangible , examples: (not really
in order)

1)Thrown with the right attitude by an extended group of friends which
infectiously spread vibe -FandF-NewMOON-Sunset-etc
2)Some really cool new tracks are busted out (Artists and DJs in direct
symbiosis -  both are equally important, except for a few exceptions IMHO
No need for worship, only smile big and enjoy!)
3)A beautiful location and weather - sparks communal feeling of love and
connectedness to MA and each other...
4)A badass imported or new DJ shakes up a party with extraordinary
mixing talent/records - the others rise to the occasion -Stompy w/Derrick C-
wicked w/ DJ Pierre- 
5)Traditions -Comeunity-LetFreedomRave-
6)Its someone's birthday, wedding, or bon voyage -glen and heather goat
rock NMR
7)Recent infusion of SF dwellers w/ right attitude
8)End of terms of schooling
9)Going to a (nearly extinct) new killer party space
10)That great feeling that you are actually pulling off a crazy little
renegade against the constant threat of bust - Then the Sun comes out,
YOOWSAHHH! -Launch Pad-FMR-NMR-etc. (at least a participant)
11) That you are actually enjoying a perfectly legal daylight event
and that random pedestrians have stopped to gawk and now are actually going
OFF! -Marx meadow-in the light-atomic whatever-
12)The DJs actually mix styles or mix in weird tracks and it actually works
13)An group fills a void of something (music style, perspective, new DJ
opportunity). -YourSistersHouse-Pacific-
14)Some phenomena has directed the DJ(s) on a mission to BLOW YOUR MIND!
-found some great new vinyl-recent nifty sexual developments-was flown
in and paid well to have a little fun for 2 hrs-
15)Unknown combinations of planet lineup, goodie availablity surges, 
widespread rough weeks at work, the mystical vibe *domino effect* and any or
all of the above...

Any more (in)tangibles?

Although I consider myself a true devotee to the aceed housey tribaly funkee
whateva local musical flava I wish there were more parties here with full
spectrum variety. Do y'all think it can happen here? Will they come? 

peaceout to y'all! Bye for awhile,

Lurker Lane      

*#* P.S. The good olde days exist right now - its (99.9%) your choice
<-*-> lurking device re-engaged <-*->

  (5.67b/IDA-1.5 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>); Mon, 15 May 1995 18:56:04 +1000

X-Sender: crunch@203.12.97.1
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 16 May 1994 01:55:55 +1000
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: crunch@sysx.apana.org.au (John Draper)
Subject: Perth rave/club scene
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Perth report
------------

I was met at the airport by Renato and Jason,  two Warez hackers who
frequent #hpaus, #hack and #phreak.   The other Ausravers I wanted to
meet in Perth were working.

I was surprised to find that most people in Perth have cars,  and also
found out how necessary that is.    Public transpo sux big time in this
area,  as trains mostly run North/South.

Perth is a small city,  but fairly spread out among rolling hills and
pretty nice temperate to sub-tropical climate.   It was raining when I
arrived,  and at about 2 PM when I landed,  was about 65 degrees.

We headed directly to town,  while Renato (Nickname Reno) was quick to
inform me of the local Perth scene.   He was quick to point out how he
dreaded coming in contact with Aboriginal folks,  and it became
immediate how prejudice people in Perth are to ANY race other than White
European,   which really sucked.  In talking to the local people of
Perth,  they were quick to point out that Aboriginal gangs of 20 or more
folks would gang up on whites,  and rob them,  beat them up or
do other nasties to people for being at the wrong spot at the wrong
time.

Eventually we went over to Seth's place,  who is a Gabber DJ.   Perth is
Heavy into Gapper and ultra hard core "Bang Bang!" music,  but I hardy
would call it music.   It has little or no melodic content,  is narrated
with non-singing vocals yelling out "Fuck,shit, and just about any other
4 letter word imaginable".   Centering around 250 to 300+ BPMs.   Hardy
something one could get used to dancing to,  that's for sure.

That evening,  was showers with a few breaks,  thus was the reason why
the rave was canceled.   However,  Renato who for whatever reason,
fears going into the night club area at night with fewer than 5 of his
friends,  insists on not going clubbing unless he can get together with
as many friends as possible.   So we waited around for a while,  got on
line to check our mail,   etc.,   until all arrived.   In 3 cars,  we
head down to the "Infirmary",  a small nightclub in the Westgate area of
town.   Renato was always reminding me of how dangerous Westgate area is
to be out alone at night,  although I didn't see any violence at all.

The infirmary was practically empty,  and the DJ was playing some
horrible combination of house stuff,  no very continuos,  so the
critical energy needed to keep me dancing just wasn't there.

On the corner was DC's with access into the Infirmary through the back,
that played more conventional house.

Eventually we left,  and headed back to Renato's place where I was
staying while I was in Perth.

On Saturday evening,  the Infirmary was to have some trance,  and good
hard core DJ's spinning,  and also the Globe (another night club).  The
globe had a very strict dress code,  and would ONLY admit white
Europeans (Again,  prejudice runs rampant in Perth).   Because I'm an
American,  my hosts highly doubted they could get me into that place,
so they suggested the Infirmary.   We get in OK and when things were
really looking good,   I.E.:  Good DJ,  playing house,  and a good
trance DJ scheduled next,  looked like it was going to be a really good
evening.

I had contacted Lorrie,  and her friend Roger who were to meet me at the
Infirmary.   So things were really looking great.   Then as I was
chilling outside,  noticing a huge presence if police in the area,  yet
another person said "We have heaps problems with Aboriginals ganging up
on people,  so on Sat evening,  there are "Heaps of Coppers!".

Just as I was going to go back in,  one of the door goons said "Sorry,
you can't go back in there!",  gave me NO REASON whatsoever,  and I said
I wanted to get my stuff.   One of my friends volunteered to get my
stuff and quickly ushered me away with no explanation,  other than it
being a political one.   It became very evident just how severe
prejudice Perth is towards ANY foreigners.

My hosts said they doubted if they could get me in ANY club in Perth so
advised me to stay in the parking lot.   All the people I was with were
really scared to go out in any groups less than 5 people.

In fact,  they took extra care in the selection of a parking place,  in
a remote parking lot,   totally hidden from view from any street in the
area.    I also noticed that in most of my friends cars,  they had dark
tinted windows,  so nobody can see in,  despite it being illegal,  and
as we were driving around town,   I was advised to keep the windows
shut.

When we parked,  they put a sunshade over the windshield and locked the
car.    Sheesh!!  Are these kids being extra paranoid,  or is there
really that much of a problem.   I was tripping my brains out,  and
itching to go out and dance,  and all I could do is sit in a car for
several hours while Seth sent back to try and find out why the Infirmary
wouldn't let me back in.

Eventually Seth showed up, and told me of the "Political situation" that
they just weren't going to let me in.   Seth thought it was my attire,
but I was dressed better than most of the others in the club,  wearing
casual trousers,  a long sleeved shirt with collars,  and borrowed
oxford shoes.   Sheesh!!  in the meantime,  Lorrie and Roger were in
there looking for me.

Eventually I decided to phone Lorrie at home and talked to her Mom,  who
eventually gave me Roger's number.   I called Roger,  and CJ answered,
and I explained to him that I couldn't get into the Infirmary to meet
Roger.   CJ said that he could get me in,  because he works there as a
DJ,  but didn't have a car.    I offered to pay for the cab to meet me
at Fast Eddies Diner (The only place I know the location of).

I walked back to the parking lot to tell my friends of the situation and
headed over to Fast Eddies.   On my way,  I saw a gang of about 8
Aboriginal folks,  as I walked by I had eye contact,  smiled,  one
smiled back,  but no incident happened.   I was somewhat relieved,  met
CJ and both of us walked back to the Infirmary.

We get back there,  and CJ immediately gets me in,  then explains to the
management that I came thousands of miles to meet some people in the
Infirmary.   eventually,  everything turned out OK,  but I only got in 2
hours of dancing and missed one of Perth's best trance DJ's but I put in
6 hours of insane dancing until the club shut down at 6 am.

The goons were incredibility hostile,  giving me dirty looks,  and
harassing me whenever possible.   One of the original goons spotted me
in there,  and immediately grabbed me off the dance floor,  but when he
saw CJ there,  he backed off..   CJ wasn't even looking that way.

Towards the end,  that same goon grabbed me again when CJ wasn't
looking, and took me out a side door,  knowing that I wasn't going to
get the chance to have CJ get him to back off.    Fortunately Lorrie was
outside,  and went in to tell CJ what happened.   Anyway,  so this is
what happens when I try to perform my world mission in Perth.

So,   Perth turns out to be a highly prejudice city towards ANYONE not
white,  including Asians,  and Especially Aboriginals,  which is REALLY
FUCKED,  so for all you international travelers,  avoid Perth whenever
possible,  especially if you expect to have fun in any of the night
clubs unless you know someone very influential in the scene.   DON'T
talk to a club goon with an American accent or they will throw you out.

Crunchman

Hey all,

I'm listening to NPR while I'm catching up on some work. They're talking 
about how Darwin's theory of evolution is becoming obsolete.

The idea is that because Darwin wasn't aware off chaos theory, his 
observations weren't entirely accurate. 

Further, it's mentioned that genetic engineering is actually a form of 
evolution, only at a much more rapid pace(?)

The quote is made: "Evolution occurs best at the edge of chaos"

If we're undergoing an evolutionary change with our new culture, then 
that means....chaos?

The shape of things to come?

Something for us to chew on over our coffee.

later...

Jonas

"Mister Order, he runs at a pretty good pace
But old mother Chaos is winning the race.

And behold, thusly was the Law formulated:
IMPOSITION OF ORDER = ESCALATION OF CHAOS."

>From "The Honest Book of Truth" by Lord Omar Ravenhurst, "THE ILLUMINATUS 
TRILOGY" By Robert Shay and Robert Anton Wilson.



Also, it is interesting to note that Darwin's Theory of Evoloution, 
unlike Newtons or Eistien's theories, is the only scientific 
biologigal explanation that would hold true for any kind of life form one
can think about (weather it is carbon-based or otherwise) that holds 
true.  I don't think that it is a case of Darwins Theory becoming 
obsolete I think that it is a question of Darwins theory speeding up.  
More people are at one with their souls now then at any other time in 
Earth's history and, in todays time, those people are able to live longer 
because they Are happy and are at peace with themselves.  And, as Darwins 
theory states, the more of a species that has traits that will lead to a 
fuller and more realized life the more of that kind will be born of in 
subsequent generations.  And this is what has happened: we went from 
being a small rather obscure group in the 1960's to being a movement of 
such massive and world wide proportions that Governemnts have had to laws 
to try and stop it.  So the next generation is just simply going to blow 
us away.
  Evoloution is speeding up which means Darwins theory is also 
speeding up (eg machines make us live longer which is why there has been 
such a speed to the industrial revoloution of the 1870's).
In short, Chaos Theory is about mathmatically working out why we are 
here.  But Darwins theory gives order to that chaos because it is the 
only intellectual argument that gives order to the chaos that is life.
Does any of this make any sense?
Tristan.

>whole experience was SO incredibly excellent, that I'm actually kind of

more than possible!! :)  i've had some really loving experences with 
whole groups of people all sober as the day they were born, everyone 
letting down their defenses and loving unconditionally.  i've had 
intense ecstacy experences that filled me with a sincere sence of love, 
peace, acceptance, etc., but e has still never greatly appealed to me 
because having all those emotions and sensations in a nonsorted way was 
and is so much more... i don't really have a word for it.  rewarding, 
perhaps, maybe just because i can eat a sandwich in the midst of it all 
and because the next morning i can remember the whole thing and my jaw 
isn't sore.  

manny!  what a ramble!  sorry if i strayed.  anyhow, the point was, yes, 
you most certianly can duplicate, and even surpass (if you so desire) 
the "e feeling" with out taking a darn thing.  try it, theres a good 
chance you'll suprise yourself.  as george harrison once said "realize 
its all within yourself."    

sincere love,
sig

don't know them too well...if you're ever in trouble or need help, stick

Hi, phrew, just got back from a run.
As I was waiting to cross the street, I was doing a little bopping to the 
music on my walkman.  Waiting for the light to turn green, I heard a 
loud horn blast in the distance.  As I looked up seeing this big truck 
driving by I saw this truck driver with a big smile on his face giving me 
a big wave.  Although he couldn't hear the music I was listening to, I 
know he felt the vibe.

peter

BEGIN QUOTE FROM Doug Zimmerman:
: 
: 
: hey everyone,
: 
:   i just wanted to add a little tidbit about flyers that pisses me
: off also.  All they list is the party and info number consistently.
: 
:   they leave optional:  the dj's
: 
: and hardly ever include: the PRICE
: 

As justification, flyers are often printed before much of that info
is locked in.  Price often depends on DJ's and other costs (not that
I recommend doing it that way - use a budget!).

Also, unless you know every DJ in the world, who is dj'ing should not
be as much a concern.  You go to have fun, and hopefully you attend parties
by people you have come to trust, and you trust them to provide a good
party for you.  I know if I did a party here the way I would like to,
you would not recognise any of the dj names (well maybe one or two,
being from the East Coast), but you would still have a great time.

>driving by I saw this truck driver with a big smile on his face giving me
>a big wave.  Although he couldn't hear the music I was listening to, I
>know he felt the vibe.
>
>peter


Was this in The City?  'Cause it may have been more than the vibe that he
was interested in feeling.  ;^)

Just joking!  No flamage please...

Tony

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

In-Reply-To: <Pine.BSI.3.91.950515102837.19542A-100000@taz.hyperreal.com> from "Sami Khoury" at May 15, 95 10:29:47 am

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1928      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> > I'm listening to NPR while I'm catching up on some work. They're talking 
> > about how Darwin's theory of evolution is becoming obsolete.

This comes around every few years.  What happens is that we revise or add to
our definition of "fitness" in the concept "survival of the fittest", and
some people take this revision as a rejection of the whole concept.  (Modern
Darwinians might state this as "reproduction of the fittest".)
	Stated another way: The fact that the biggest and strongest aren't 
necessarily the most successful doesn't mean that evolution isn't working;
it means that "fittest" didn't mean what we thought it did.

> It would appear that Darwin's theory of evolution has become a victim of 
> Darwin's theory of evolution.

Thus proving its own utility, in a recursive and chaotic sort of way. >%^)

Anyone interested in this topic should go read some Richard Dawkins; _The
Blind Watchmaker_ is a good place to start.  Once you're done, _The Selfish
Gene_ and especially _The Extended Phenotype_ contain further cool information
about the consequences of evolution, a seriously chaotic process.
	All these books are well-written, and fun to read without being dumbed
down.  I find a knowledge of evolution (genetic _and_ memetic) indispensable
to a clear understanding of the world and what to do about it.  Yes, 
indispensable.  Studying psychology or any form of human behavior (like, for
instance, trying to live life) without a good grounding in evolutionary
theory is like trying to study chemistry without knowing atomic theory; 
you don't know why or how anything happens, all you have is a bunch of seemingly
random and inconsistent rules of interaction.  Psychology is to evolutionary
theory as alchemy is to chemistry.

ObRave: Bare feet.  The best!  If a bare foot steps on another bare foot, no
problem.  It's those big stomper boots that get me when I bounce around in
my Tevas.

// g

: >> SF gives more vibe for the buck than anywhere on the planet.
: >  the vibe is pretty damn good, but not the best on the planet..
: 
: begging the question: where is the best vibe on the planet?

I know it all depends on how *you* define vibe, or what *you* are
looking for/expecting, but I would choose Detroit without a blink.
Sure, there have been less than spectacular parties, but it is there
that I have had several of the best experiences in my life, and I
would gladly return over and over in hopes of another one like those.
I am not good with expressing feelings in text, so I cannot describe
them to you.  I could not do them justice.

If you are looking for thousands of ravers in a circus-like environment
full of mind-altering stimulii, you are in the wrong town.  If you are
looking for music to move your soul, Detroit is all that and more!
