To: Grigsbeast <grigsby@shell.portal.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Darwin, evolution, and maybe something to do w/raves
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

"Survival of the fittest" was a reactionary slogan appropriated by the
Social Darwinists (a nice academic name for a rather nasty bunch of
pseudo-intellectuals and political bullies . . . my my, why does that
remind me of current times?!) who never bothered to understand Darwin's
rather careful theorizing, or else simply grabbed the part that fit their
predetermined views.

Genetics and population biology have been through several transformations
since Darwin, and the generally agreed models are quite a bit different
in some ways than he initially envisioned, but that's not surprising.
Galileo and Newton are still relevant to physics in the same way, even
though physics is far different now than it was three centuries ago.

I'd recommend more current reading than "The Selfish Gene," which was
written in the mid-1970s when the doctrinaire view of things was summarized
by the often-quoted maxim, "A chicken is just an egg's way of making mor
eggs."  The selfish-gene idea, though a leap forward in understanding in
many ways, turns out to be somewhat simplistic in its viewpoint, especially
since the lessons and techniques of nonlinear mathematics have filtered
into biology and the whole deterministic cause-and-effect framework which
has dominated western science starting in the Middle Ages, and with its
roots in the categorical philosophy of the Greeks, has started to come
apart at the seams a bit.

I'm not up on all the current good lit in biology, but it's important to
read current works as well as recent "classics" like Dawkins.  

Obrave?  It's about *life*.  Consider whether raving has any evolutionary
implications.  (Well, everything does, but to me it has some particularly
interesting connections . . .)

phred

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon May 15 17:51:05 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id RAA28114; Mon, 15 May 1995 17:51:05 -0700
Received: from netcom22.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id RAA28108; Mon, 15 May 1995 17:51:01 -0700
Received: from localhost by netcom22.netcom.com (8.6.12/Netcom)
	id RAA03041; Mon, 15 May 1995 17:50:30 -0700
Message-Id: <199505160050.RAA03041@netcom22.netcom.com>
To: "P. Greenwell" <blkadder@community.net>
Cc: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Free vs. real cost of internet (was Re: Ecstasy Talk and Booksigning Saturday )
In-reply-to: Your message of "Sat, 13 May 95 23:45:50 PDT."
             <Pine.SUN.3.91.950513231515.15828A-100000@odin.community.net> 
Date: Mon, 15 May 95 17:50:29 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> Then I suggest you go back to your public library and talk to your 
> librarian about inter-library loans. Librarians are some of the nicest
> people I know when it comes to helping you find information on any given
> subject.  And I have have had no problems walking into UC Davis or UCSF's 
> libraries, running through MELVYL, and getting any information I might 
> want on the subject, although of course I can't check out the books.

This is but more "let 'em eat cakism" -- what if you aren't college
educated, or aren't currently enrolled in a college? College librarians
(and corporate research librarians) are indeed helpful and
knowledgeable, and that's their job, that's why their getting paid
$30K-$60K per year, money which comes from your tuition, matching costs
on research grants, taxes, etc.

But  What if you don't have the affiliations to allow you to enter into
the library in the first place??? Most college libraries are expressly
*NOT* public libraries and they often require special affiliations
(e.g. a costly affiliate membership card, current student ID), etc,
just to get in the door. THis is especially the case in cities,
probably less of a problem at a "rural" campus like UC Davis.

Try attempting your suggestion at a public library (which is where the
masses might have to go for information) and free inter-library loans
are out of the question, as are MELVYL or other computer listings. Ask
a public librarian about some info, and unless it's real obvious,
they'll point you to a card catalog or the world almanac and tell you
to look it up yourself. Then half the leads you track down will bottom
out at books that are stolen or misplaced.... And because it's a public
library, they've already censored half the interesting material for
you.

My whole point is that nothing, or at least very little is "free", and
it helps to look at the big picture before coming up w/ an argument
based entirely on your position in the caste system. Not everybody is
you, not everybody has access to university libraries. Hell I spent 6
years at <major west coast university> and I can't even use their
libraries any more. I can't even walk into most of the good libraries
on the campus w/o a current student ID. (or pay the $250.00/yr fee for
an affiliate membership yeah, that's freee...).

> Most of the above costs, save the internet access are intangible. We are 
> paying for method of distribution, not the information itself.

In some cases this is true. It's not the direction that most of the big
investments in the internet are going. Digicash. Micropayments, 
Electronic commerce, etc. That's the future, and it ain't free by a
long shot. Once we figure out how to charge you money, you can bet that
a lot of the interesting content may very well cost you money too.
Today, the interesting content is coming at you courtesy of having to
look at an advertisement on each page you download (e.g. HotWired),
this is a "cost" too.

Furthermore, "save the internet access" is the crux of the issue.
Internet access is not universal, and it is not free. Computers,
terminals, modems aren't free either.

Furthermore, a lot of the infrastructure is "free" now because "they"
want to get you hooked on it so that it becomes a necessity of your day
to day life. THen you won't balk so much (and you'll act like a captive
customer) when this free resource ends up with a billing model similar
to the telephone, with cascading charges for distance, time and amount
of data transmitted.

> Well, gee if I am not paying for it, I sure as hell consider it to be free.

But you *ARE* paying for it. It's just being divided amongst a large
population, some of which are gaining benefit from the internet, and
some that don't even know what the internet is. Furthermore, you will
be paying for it in the future, perhaps even on a per-byte basis as
your bits travel across Amerikkka's privatized internet.

What with the privatization of the internet, it may not be much
different than paying for phone charges in the coming decades. Some big
service providers already "meter" useage and charge for it on a
per-minute basis.

Analogously, you must think the roadways are "free" too because you're
not paying a toll for every road you use. But it's coming out of your
gas taxes ($0.20-$0.60/gallon), your car registration fees, and federal
interstate matching funds that amount to extortion by the federal
government (i.e. the feds will give your tax money back to your state's
interstate system if the state government is willing to limit your
rights so as to  fight the war on drugs).

> This is the one area in which I was a bit hasty. I should have said 
> Respect beyond what one would normally extend to another human being. I 
> do believe in respecting your fellow human beings, but I don't subscibe 
> to the sacred cow crap. Sorry if I question your idol, but he is yours, 
> not mine. 

I KILL most SACRED COWS, drink the BLOOD, and BAR-B-QUE the carcass,
then PREDICT THE FUTURE from the layout of the ENTRAILS! :-) Bruce
Eisner is not my idol (see my previous anti-X rants). Chances are, I
disagree w/ about 50 % of what he says. But I want him to say his
piece, and if he wants to charge $2.00 to speak, that's his business.
The market will decide whether this is a fair and justifiable price,
and complaining about it is a waste of time.

Hell, if you want to find things to pick on, pick on Pacific Bell, or
Microsoft, or Pacific Gas and Electric, or Netscape, or your insurance
company. But it's really misplaced to pick on Bruce Eisner for charging
a piddling $2.00 donation for a talk.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==     Niels Mayer -- http://cyborganic.com/~niels -- mayer@netcom.com     ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

I just finished writing to a friend of mine and something crossed my mind 
and  I want to know how you all feel about this:

I was telling my friend how, for my design class,  I have to make this 
collage of colored shapes to show what music looks like.  I decided to portray 
my *favorite* music: acid trance.  Well, most of my class mates don't 
know what the hell I mean by acid trance, so I'm bringing a couple of my 
tapes to class to demonstrate what I mean.  Now this is where I start to 
feel funny.  I hold rave in all of its forms very close to my heart and I 
don't talk about it much to people who I casually know - such as 
classmates at school or co-workers.  I feel like by playing my music for 
the class that I am putting my neck on the chopping block.  Not that I 
*care* really if they like it or not, but when something is really 
important to me, it still hurts if people openly ridicule it.  To me, 
rave can be like religion or politics: I don't talk about it with others 
who I feel don't understand what it's about. And I don't talk about it 
unless I am asked. Do you know what I mean? 
 I'm wondering if any of you feel similarly.....

love,
Amy

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon May 15 21:13:28 1995

From: Grigsbeast <grigsby@shell.portal.com>
Message-Id: <199505160412.VAA06207@jobe.shell.portal.com>
Subject: Re: Darwin, evolution, and maybe something to do w/raves
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 15 May 1995 21:12:35 -0700 (PDT)
In-Reply-To: <9505151606.ZM9517@well> from "Fred Heutte" at May 15, 95 04:06:26 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL24]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 2029      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> I'd recommend more current reading than "The Selfish Gene," which was
> written in the mid-1970s when the doctrinaire view of things was summarized
> by the often-quoted maxim, "A chicken is just an egg's way of making mor
> eggs."

Such as...?  I'd like to find more good books on the subject but the ones I've
seen tend to be (e.g. "Not In Our Genes") arguments against popular
_misunderstandings_ of evolutionary theory.

  The selfish-gene idea, though a leap forward in understanding in
> many ways, turns out to be somewhat simplistic in its viewpoint, especially
> since the lessons and techniques of nonlinear mathematics have filtered
> into biology and the whole deterministic cause-and-effect framework which
> has dominated western science starting in the Middle Ages, and with its
> roots in the categorical philosophy of the Greeks, has started to come
> apart at the seams a bit.

I don't think there is a conflict here.  The simple mechanism of differential
gene survival in an arbitrary argument can have some fascinating consequences,
like life.

Again, the theory still works; it's people's _perceptions_ of what it means
that change.  It's tempting to twist a description of a process (differential
survival) into a moral judgement on how that process _ought_ to work (I think
I, and people like me, should differentially survive).  Thus you get master-
racism, master-classism (the fact that I was born into money proves my
intrinsic superiority), and other forms of generally being a butt.  So don't.

These arguments do not apply to changes wrought over the scope
of a few lifetimes, genetic movement (except for mass extinction)
being slower than that.  Social movements, etc., are best understood
as _memetic_ evolution, working from a genetically derived set of
base assumptions, produced _genetically_ over a much larger timescale.

This disparity in evolutionary speed (made possible by our complexity
and consequent fitness as a memetic host) causes much of our species'
current conflict.

// g

Thank you Larry !  

I also didn't detect a deep barb in that small part of the post... since
we've all discussed "PLUR" recently let's remember to practice it as
best we can... I must admit that I was less than thrilled by Kevin's 
repeated disregard for the positive aspects of our scene and VERY put off
by his put down of the F&F effort ( I wished he had chosen to be a positive
part of the scene instead - perhaps by attempting to get to know us before
popping off about things that he obviously had limited knowledge of ) On the
other hand, if he's willing to bury the hatchet and to stop rubbing our
faces in the "great UK rave scene" - I'm willing to listen. To that end I
was very happy to see a "mostly" thumbs up positive post moving in that
direction. That at least is a step in the right direction and I noticed it
with appreciation. 

Enforce the positive by living positive...

Yes There are differences between the UK and SF. Any idiot could suspect
that since they are differrent cultures. And if you don't know that, you
definitely need to travel more. But as you do so, try to remember 
"When in Rome...." and please (Kevin) try not to insult the "host". Also, 
consider that the best course of action is not to change one into the 
other but to enjoy the best that each has to offer. IMHO of course!

Now let's move on - summer is coming... too many people are saying the scene
has changed ( for the worst ) or that it is dying... we've moved through
one of the darkest, grey day winters I remember in recent times. As we move
into summer I wonder if we can work together to bring out the best in us 
all. I'm willing to work to that end and hoping that there are other like 
minded people out there who will help make it happen. So let's get going!

$.02 out,

Mike



 meclay@netcom.com          |  Alone & estatic 
 Mike Clay   (415)572-8971  |  A young rainbow learns  to levitate.

Amy,

Wow!  Playing acid trance for an uninitiated class! Did you do it? Did it
work ?  

  I'm reacting to this because I'm within a year of my first exposure to
acid trance and I like it for dancing and driving ( love Ethan's Acid 
Trance tape ). BUT I don't think I would have related to it "out of the
rave experience" context. For myself, I try to give others a more gentle
intro like the Orb or Orbital or perhaps chill out music and explain how
this "very listenable" music ( IMHO ) grew out of the scene. Then when
people feel like the scene is perhaps positive after all - comes the
OK time to dance - then the acid trance... hopefully at a party that's
really taking off with lots of friendly support. Then it all makes sense.

  Playing acid trance out of context could be coming on too strong too 
fast - kind of like attempting lovemaking without foreplay? I'm reminded
of seeing Rocky Horror at a school with no audience reaction - NOT ANYTHING
like a reactive audience midnight setting. Acid trance makes perfect sense
when you are there on the dance floor and see the energy ( or FEEL the 
energy) - in the sterile classroom I wonder? 

Just my humble opinion of course... Did it work ?

Mike ( who is too often wrong )

PS I very much agree with the idea that things such as raving, music etc
  that have deep meaning are best not flaunted publicly without some care.
  And if your young classmates have trouble understanding just think how
  most of my peers feel - ie think about many of your parents since they
  are closer to my age...  ouch I must be getting older.... But I can
  still dance so I'm definitely not dead yet ! 


 meclay@netcom.com          |  Alone & estatic 
 Mike Clay   (415)572-8971  |  A young rainbow learns  to levitate.

On Mon, 15 May 1995, Niels P. Mayer wrote:

> 
> > Then I suggest you go back to your public library and talk to your 
> > librarian about inter-library loans. Librarians are some of the nicest
> > people I know when it comes to helping you find information on any given
> > subject.  And I have have had no problems walking into UC Davis or UCSF's 
> > libraries, running through MELVYL, and getting any information I might 
> > want on the subject, although of course I can't check out the books.
> 
> This is but more "let 'em eat cakism" -- what if you aren't college
> educated, or aren't currently enrolled in a college? College librarians
> (and corporate research librarians) are indeed helpful and
> knowledgeable, and that's their job, that's why their getting paid
> $30K-$60K per year, money which comes from your tuition, matching costs
> on research grants, taxes, etc.
> 
> But  What if you don't have the affiliations to allow you to enter into
> the library in the first place??? Most college libraries are expressly
> *NOT* public libraries and they often require special affiliations
> (e.g. a costly affiliate membership card, current student ID), etc,
> just to get in the door. THis is especially the case in cities,
> probably less of a problem at a "rural" campus like UC Davis.

You totally ignore the case of UCSF which I walked into, no problem. Does 
this campus count as being in a city?

 > 
> Try attempting your suggestion at a public library (which is where the
> masses might have to go for information) and free inter-library loans
> are out of the question, as are MELVYL or other computer listings. Ask
> a public librarian about some info, and unless it's real obvious,
> they'll point you to a card catalog or the world almanac and tell you
> to look it up yourself. Then half the leads you track down will bottom
> out at books that are stolen or misplaced.... And because it's a public
> library, they've already censored half the interesting material for
> you.

I tell you I have. Inter-library loans are commonplace, and I have 
requested several texts ranging from cars to law. I live in Fairfield 
which is the middle of nowhere technically. And even here we have the 
SNAP system which is connected to MELVYL and other services. And on more 
than one occasion the librarians have gone out of their way to help me 
locate obscure information, like where to find parts for a '73 Opel 
GT(boy was that fun...) and info on labor law, etc...


> 
> My whole point is that nothing, or at least very little is "free", and
> it helps to look at the big picture before coming up w/ an argument
> based entirely on your position in the caste system. Not everybody is
> you, not everybody has access to university libraries. Hell I spent 6
> years at <major west coast university> and I can't even use their
> libraries any more. I can't even walk into most of the good libraries
> on the campus w/o a current student ID. (or pay the $250.00/yr fee for
> an affiliate membership yeah, that's freee...).
> 
> > Most of the above costs, save the internet access are intangible. We are 
> > paying for method of distribution, not the information itself.
> 
> In some cases this is true. It's not the direction that most of the big
> investments in the internet are going. Digicash. Micropayments, 
> Electronic commerce, etc. That's the future, and it ain't free by a
> long shot. Once we figure out how to charge you money, you can bet that
> a lot of the interesting content may very well cost you money too.
> Today, the interesting content is coming at you courtesy of having to
> look at an advertisement on each page you download (e.g. HotWired),
> this is a "cost" too.
> 
This is one area I heartily agree with you, and I really think it stinks, 
considering the exponential lessening of cost of bandwidth. 

> Furthermore, "save the internet access" is the crux of the issue.
> Internet access is not universal, and it is not free. Computers,
> terminals, modems aren't free either.
> 
Except for freenets, which are gaining in popularity and are becoming 
more common. Costs for a Internet-connective machine are negligible at 
worst. You may not have that DEC-Alpha, but you can get something for 
almost nothing.

> Furthermore, a lot of the infrastructure is "free" now because "they"
> want to get you hooked on it so that it becomes a necessity of your day
> to day life. THen you won't balk so much (and you'll act like a captive
> customer) when this free resource ends up with a billing model similar
> to the telephone, with cascading charges for distance, time and amount
> of data transmitted.

But Niels, I have been hooked for *YEARS* I have been modeming in one 
capacity or another since 1984. I agree with with you that if they can 
figure out a way to fuck you they will. Now that people are discovering 
the talk command and using programs like Internet Microphone, I am sure 
the RBOC's(Regional Bell Operating Companies) will jump on the charge 'em 
for everything bandwagon. 

> 
> > Well, gee if I am not paying for it, I sure as hell consider it to be free.
> 
> But you *ARE* paying for it. It's just being divided amongst a large
> population, some of which are gaining benefit from the internet, and
> some that don't even know what the internet is. Furthermore, you will
> be paying for it in the future, perhaps even on a per-byte basis as
> your bits travel across Amerikkka's privatized internet.
> 
> What with the privatization of the internet, it may not be much
> different than paying for phone charges in the coming decades. Some big
> service providers already "meter" useage and charge for it on a
> per-minute basis.
> 
> Analogously, you must think the roadways are "free" too because you're
> not paying a toll for every road you use. But it's coming out of your
> gas taxes ($0.20-$0.60/gallon), your car registration fees, and federal
> interstate matching funds that amount to extortion by the federal
> government (i.e. the feds will give your tax money back to your state's
> interstate system if the state government is willing to limit your
> rights so as to  fight the war on drugs).

Well you forget to mention that the state has to support the 55 MPH 
limit. That is what gets them the money.

> 
> > This is the one area in which I was a bit hasty. I should have said 
> > Respect beyond what one would normally extend to another human being. I 
> > do believe in respecting your fellow human beings, but I don't subscibe 
> > to the sacred cow crap. Sorry if I question your idol, but he is yours, 
> > not mine. 
> 
> I KILL most SACRED COWS, drink the BLOOD, and BAR-B-QUE the carcass,
> then PREDICT THE FUTURE from the layout of the ENTRAILS! :-) Bruce
> Eisner is not my idol (see my previous anti-X rants). Chances are, I
> disagree w/ about 50 % of what he says. But I want him to say his
> piece, and if he wants to charge $2.00 to speak, that's his business.
> The market will decide whether this is a fair and justifiable price,
> and complaining about it is a waste of time.
> 
As I have stated before, I wrote a PRIVATE message to Bruce, and he made 
the discussion public. It was never meant to become this big public thing 
that it did. That was his lack of tact. I would love to send you some of 
the mail this guy sent me. From the jist of his messages his a real 
egotistical prick. He only chose to make a response public after he had 
already sent several messages establishing his prickiness(oh well, 
prickiness sounds like a word to me...) And complaining about it is
not a waste of time if it has some effect, which I like to feel it has.

> Hell, if you want to find things to pick on, pick on Pacific Bell, or
> Microsoft, or Pacific Gas and Electric, or Netscape, or your insurance
> company. But it's really misplaced to pick on Bruce Eisner for charging
> a piddling $2.00 donation for a talk.
> 
Well three out of four ain't bad. My only problem with Netscape is the 
encroaching commercialization and the associated costs it will create.

You know, for the most part I agree with what you are saying. Again, the 
whole thing should have been a private discussion. I really feel like the 
whole thing was taken out of context. I don't have a problem with him 
advertising his *LECTURE* What I take issue with is that he IMO was 
offering to *SELL* answers to questions about MDMA, which are available 
from a variety of sources. I understand your nothing is free argument, 
and again am 90% in agreeance. So if I said these variety of sources cost 
you nothing more than what you are already paying in I-net access 
charges, taxes, etc., would that make us more in agreeance? That it is 
not necessary to pay $2 more than you already have? 

I hate to feel that I am arguing with you, because you make some very 
valid points, and I really feel that we share similar views on a 
multitude of issues. I just don't want to see SF-Raves devolve into a 
Prodigy(don't know if you have ever seen this service but I swear there 
are more ads than content)  for raves. 

                                                   Black Adder

Well,

Phunny thing,  you all are talking about Darwyn.   And here I am,  just
arrived in the city of Darwyn,  Australia.   If one would bother to look
for it on the map,   it's at the topmost point,  on the Indian Ocean.

And let me tell you,  it is HOT!! STEAMY!! SWEATY!!  and MUGGY!!  And this
is supposed to be the DRY season.    Yow...  I went to Dripstone Beach,
on the Indian ocean.   Water temp is 85 degrees.   Luke warm bath water
temperature.   It was raining when I landed this afternoon,   right now
it's about 5:47 PM.     1:18:44 AM  5/17/94 Calif time.

Well,  I won't be doing any raving here,  but plan to take a break from
it actually,  and visit the father of my friend in Sydney.   Ian Banaser
is his name,  and he sorta reminds me of Crocidile Dundee...   He runs
a tour group,  and tommorrow,  plan on going to Litchfield Natl park to
see some big huge awsome crocodiles.   These reptiles are so powerful
that they can crush a pigs skull.

Other amazing wildlife is there to be seen as well.   I'll give a report
and plan on taking pictures,  which I plan on putting up on the WEB as
soon as I can get them all scanned in.

Anyway,  I've got to get ready to go out to dinner now,  and Crocidile
is on the menu....  Yum Yum!!  Larf!!  Better to eat them,  then to have
them eat me!!

Crunchman

Bill the cat writes:

> feel funny.  I hold rave in all of its forms very close to my heart and I 
> don't talk about it much to people who I casually know - such as 
> classmates at school or co-workers.  I feel like by playing my music for 
> ---------------
> |   _  ,/|    |
> |  '\`o O'    |
> |   =(_^_)=   |         Amy Starkey
> |     |U|     |         sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu
> |     | |     |      
> ---------------
> 

Hey! Now THIS is why I subscribe to SFRaves!

I talk to my co-workers about raves often - because this is what we do on 
mondays, is talk about what we did over the weekend.  They are mostly 
aged 30-40 and have no other exposure to rave except for what's in the big 
news and an occasional 2-Unlimited song played at a Sharks game.

Out of 20, one person understands what I mean when I say I "felt so good" 
at the party or try to describe the vibe.  (There's just no good way to 
do this!) And she often tells me about parties she went to in South 
America when she was younger and how people danced all night.  I doubt 
she will ever take her children to The Gathering or anything, but I think 
she understands.

The other 19 people just seem make up their own ideas about what it's 
like.  So I don't really go into detail with them because it then becomes 
some kind of interrogation. Some people probably think I'm wasting my 
time but they don't say so.  It's just like alot of them go out on friday 
nights to the Los Gatos Brewery after work and buy rounds to work off the 
tension... but I don't tell them they're wasting their time.  Because 
that's just my perception.  So when someone refuses to understand raves, 
I don't feel any more uncomfortable than they would if I asked them why 
they drink beer and talk smack about the boss.

Does that make sense?  What I mean is that I know I enjoy it, and if 
someone asks me, I tell them about it.  If they don't like what they hear 
then that's their choice.  But what they do respect is that I told them 
what I do.  It's the honesty which my co-workers see and not the 
intellibeams!

Willis 
p.s. my parents are this way too...  

"You're not going to those raves tonight, are you?"
"Uh huh."
"Ok, well you better not take any drugs!!" 
"Ok, Ma."

On Mon, 15 May 1995, Brian McGonigle wrote:

> > I really like Goa Gil but a whole night of him and nothing else is a bit

> I was telling my friend how, for my design class,  I have to make this 
> collage of colored shapes to show what music looks like.  I decided to portray 
> my *favorite* music: acid trance.  Well, most of my class mates don't 
> know what the hell I mean by acid trance, so I'm bringing a couple of my 
> tapes to class to demonstrate what I mean.  Now this is where I start to 
> feel funny.  I hold rave in all of its forms very close to my heart and I 
> don't talk about it much to people who I casually know - such as 
> classmates at school or co-workers.  I feel like by playing my music for 
> the class that I am putting my neck on the chopping block.  Not that I 
> *care* really if they like it or not, but when something is really 
> important to me, it still hurts if people openly ridicule it.  To me,

Hello,

Brian McG wrote:
>just so that we "know our friends/enemies" some of the most ardent
>and famous "conservatives" are pro-legalization, e.g., William F Buckley.

This is because conservative philosophy revolves around getting the 
government out of people's lives as much as possible.

When exceptions are made (by those other than Buckley), they are usually
due to some sort of personally held fear.

For example, few know that Reagan, coming from a showbiz background, 
knew many gays and thus was not homophobic.  In fact, he once did an
AIDS benefit commercial.

Cheers,

From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9505161450.AA05268@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: musical motivator
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I recently acquired Lowdown Motivator by Freaky Chakra, a full
length release by Daum Bently (with some help from ex-sfravers 
Jon Drukman and Michael Wertheim). A few comments:

- It kicks ass: thick powerful acid-funk-trance, excellent production
with lots of deep growling bass synth sounds.  On the Astralwerks label.

- Daum is a really nice guy, local to the SF scene, can be often be
found dancing and sharing the vibe at Sunsets and other parties.  Some 
of the music will sound familiar since he's been giving 12-inch preview 
copies to Galen who has been debuting them at Sunsets since last year.

- The CD insert contains a nice photo of a Sunset party at the Berkeley
Marina.  It was the one with the naked guy, and with everyone up on
the hill just about anyone who was there that day is in this picture.

So here's a chance to support and get your hands on some great musical
creations that have in part been inspired by us.

Lee
___________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com   (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )   lee@hyperreal.com

>  I'm wondering if any of you feel similarly.....
> 

Most definitely, Amy. I been working with the Bay Guardian, trying to get a
forum for Rave Culture, but they're getting cold feet. The don't like the 
fact that the music has drug connotations (acid trance).

I guess that's what we have to deal with. Not everyone is going to 
understand what we're about, or see that our intentions are positive. I find 
this frustrating.

I've found that I can usually "feel" most people as to their receptivity 
to what we do. I usually discuss other controversial topics first. If 
they're open with that, then I mention what I do. 

Too  many times I've tried to explain myself to people, only to receive 
blank looks in return. 

More to say, but I gotsta scat. later...

Jonas

At 6:46 PM 5/15/95, Amy R Starkey wrote:
>I just finished writing to a friend of mine and something crossed my mind
>and  I want to know how you all feel about this:
>
>I was telling my friend how, for my design class,  I have to make this
>collage of colored shapes to show what music looks like.  I decided to portray
>my *favorite* music: acid trance.  Well, most of my class mates don't
>know what the hell I mean by acid trance, so I'm bringing a couple of my
>tapes to class to demonstrate what I mean.  Now this is where I start to
>feel funny.  I hold rave in all of its forms very close to my heart and I
>don't talk about it much to people who I casually know - such as
>classmates at school or co-workers.  I feel like by playing my music for
>the class that I am putting my neck on the chopping block.  Not that I
>*care* really if they like it or not, but when something is really
>important to me, it still hurts if people openly ridicule it.  To me,
>rave can be like religion or politics: I don't talk about it with others
>who I feel don't understand what it's about. And I don't talk about it
>unless I am asked. Do you know what I mean?
> I'm wondering if any of you feel similarly.....
>
>love,
>Amy

        COMPLETELY. When i did a small 'rave related" (as, IMHO, this is
about living and therefore everything is related to that) project for my
sculpture class i got responses like "oh yeah, that superficial drug-fest
circus meat market pickup joint" blah blah blah..
        It's tough to stick your neck out when there is so much bs and
misinformation out there (well, actually, for some ppl it IS a drug fest..)
but i guess the only way to 'inform' others is though dealing with them and
being sincere and understanding and 'setting an example'.
        it still sucks to be called a fad-chasing druggie but when you know
the truth you can deal with it..

> I'm wondering if any of you feel similarly.....

Very much so - sometimes it boils down to explaining the music 
as "electronic music," which in a way doesn't do house any justice, but
communicates somewhat of an idea of how the music is made.

I've tried explaining the Vibe, technoshamanism, etc. to the uninitiated
with mixed results.  Its been scary sharing how spiritual raves have been
to some people and haveing them look at me like I'm some whacked out 
fiend.  I'm reminded of a Spun mix tape titled "what we do is secret"

Subject: Re: Darwin/evolution
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

In-Reply-To: <v01510102abddee235d50@[204.19.170.86]>; from "ecto" at May 16, 95 12:27 (noon)

Precedence: bulk

Hi all,

Recently I watched a program on human evolution.  According to scientists homo sapiens 
competed for a niche in nature with another hominid species.  The other species appeared to
be more physicaly fit than humans yet somehow homo sapeins won out.  Scientists cannot figur
e out why we were able to outcompete them.  

This leads to the book Food of the Gods, which I have just started reading.  Terrance M. 
believes that by eating the mushroom are brain was able to grow at a rapid rate.  A rate
that many scientists cannot explain. IF humans were competing with another species that
may have been more physicaly fit than a bigger brain would have been an excellen selection
for survival.  So those homo sapiens that ate a particular species of mushroom gained an 
advantage over their competitors.  This advantage leads to reproduction and survival of 
humans.  

These ideas dont really have any scientific proof to back them up but it still is neat to 
fancy that we exist because of a psychadelic substance.  I think its possible.

love chris

>the class that I am putting my neck on the chopping block.  Not that I 
>*care* really if they like it or not, but when something is really 
>important to me, it still hurts if people openly ridicule it.  To me, 
>rave can be like religion or politics: I don't talk about it with others 
>who I feel don't understand what it's about. And I don't talk about it

Yea, Amy, I know what you mean.  I write music mysefl, some of it acid
trance, and when I'm alone or at a rave or with people who understand, most
all rave or ambient music (including but not limited to my own) is infinite,
huge, all encompassing.  But sometimes I bring tapes of my stuff to my day
job (office, business type stuff) and play it for my coworkers and some
times the music loses  some of its multidimensionality.  I guess it's
because I'm still a little wrapped up in what people think of me (a hard
thing to admit, but I'm working on it).  I could go on and on about this,
but the point is I understand.  Music=religion=spirituality=life...

Even if they don't like it you still will have shed some wonderful light
into thier lives and greatly affected their conscienceness.  Peace.

Rick

Subject: Re: something to ponder

     Amy, I really liked what you touched upon because I think it hits alot 
     of us as we try to integrate significant things in our life.  
     Sometimes it's difficult to decide how open you should be and if you 
     can handle the off-the-cuff comments & criticisms that may come from 
     people _until_ they are more aware of (God, I hate this term!) "rave 
     culture"--including all of it's aspects.
     
     What works for me may not work for everyone else but what I do is try 
     to live my life as an open book.  I've had people who lived this way 
     influence my life and I like not having to think about what I've told 
     and to whom.  _But_ I do use discretion.  Sometimes you just need to 
     take care of business and for me, that means sharing the joy of raving 
     w/my son through the music and events (e.g., Sunsets, drumming 
     circles, etc.) but not clueing (sp?) him into other aspects of raving 
     at this time (he's only nine).  If he can feel the love and 
     connectivity naturally then I've accomplished something in sharing 
     this gift.  
     
     I like to think that I can apply this to co-workers, classmates, and 
     friends too.  It may not be in the same manner (i.e., taking them to a 
     rave) but learning to communicate with them on a level that eventually 
     doesn't require words...maybe a smile, a song, etc. So what I share 
     w/co-workers and classmates that don't know me well, is my joy and 
     love of dance and music.  People who don't know me see my vitality and 
     often want to get to know me.  In part of that process, I reveal what 
     I'm into and what feeds my soul.  As a result of this, I've found that 
     I'm drawn to more people that can relate to me hence the widening 
     circle. :)
     
     I spoke with an Irish friend of mine recently and he said they don't 
     really use the term "rave" anymore in England.  So to me the 
     distinction is not as clear, in fact, as you said "rave can be like 
     religion or politics", it's an influence that has connotations.  If 
     you loose the terminology or labels and just express the feelings, I 
     think more people can relate to you _without_ the initial bias.  (I'm 
     not saying this in denial or anything, it's just a backround way of 
     letting people see what you're into...if you want to share in that 
     manner.)
     
     In any case, the effervescence you want to convey to others may not be 
     welcomed...then again, try intentional smiling and making eye contact 
     with people as you walk down the hall at work or on the street and see 
     what their reactions are :)  I like to think of it as infectious.
     
     Thanks again for your post and apologies to all for my long 
     windedness.
     
Diane

______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: something to ponder
Author:  Amy R Starkey <sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu> at beluga-mail
Date:    5/15/95 6:55 PM


     
I just finished writing to a friend of mine and something crossed my mind 
and  I want to know how you all feel about this:
     
I was telling my friend how, for my design class,  I have to make this 
collage of colored shapes to show what music looks like.  I decided to portray 
my *favorite* music: acid trance.  Well, most of my class mates don't 
know what the hell I mean by acid trance, so I'm bringing a couple of my 
tapes to class to demonstrate what I mean.  Now this is where I start to 
feel funny.  I hold rave in all of its forms very close to my heart and I 
don't talk about it much to people who I casually know - such as 
classmates at school or co-workers.  I feel like by playing my music for 
the class that I am putting my neck on the chopping block.  Not that I 
*care* really if they like it or not, but when something is really 
important to me, it still hurts if people openly ridicule it.  To me, 
rave can be like religion or politics: I don't talk about it with others 
who I feel don't understand what it's about. And I don't talk about it 
unless I am asked. Do you know what I mean? 
 I'm wondering if any of you feel similarly.....
     
love,
Amy

        Reply to:   RE>something to ponder

> I'm wondering if any of you feel similarly.....

Exactly!  I work with quite a diverse group of individuals.  One is into
Blues, one is into Country, one is into Jazz and Classical, and two are into 
to rock.   Unfortuanltly, the last two are the ones who have control of the
stereo.  So I'm stuck listening to Rush and Queensryche (SP?)  all day. 
Every now and then they will put on something interesting like Peter Gabrial
or some old prog rock stuff, but for the most part, its rock and roll all day
long.  I've brought in a few tapes, mostly house stuff, and all they say is
"it sounds like disco!"  Surprisingly, they liked FSOL and the Orb, but, I
think its because its ambient.  They say it reminds them of Pink Floyd (?).  


--M

I just finished writing to a friend of mine and something crossed my mind 
and  I want to know how you all feel about this:

I was telling my friend how, for my design class,  I have to make this 
collage of colored shapes to show what music looks like.  I decided to
portray 
my *favorite* music: acid trance.  Well, most of my class mates don't 
know what the hell I mean by acid trance, so I'm bringing a couple of my 
tapes to class to demonstrate what I mean.  Now this is where I start to 
feel funny.  I hold rave in all of its forms very close to my heart and I 
don't talk about it much to people who I casually know - such as 
classmates at school or co-workers.  I feel like by playing my music for 
the class that I am putting my neck on the chopping block.  Not that I 
*care* really if they like it or not, but when something is really 
important to me, it still hurts if people openly ridicule it.  To me, 
rave can be like religion or politics: I don't talk about it with others 
who I feel don't understand what it's about. And I don't talk about it 
unless I am asked. Do you know what I mean? 
 I'm wondering if any of you feel similarly.....

love,
Amy

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: tony@xinet.COM (Tony Rotundo)
Subject: That Rave Feeling...Equated
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Amy Starkey wrote:

To me, rave can be like religion or politics: I don't talk about it with others
who I feel don't understand what it's about. And I don't talk about it
unless I am asked. Do you know what I mean?

There have been a lot of responses to Amy's lament about people not
understanding what the rave culture is about, and why we do what we do.  In
my experience, it is has been difficult to explain the phenomenon known as
raving, and when I was into the Dead I had similar difficulties.  What I
began doing was to give people examples of other life experiences that
offer the same (well, maybe 'similar' is better there) energy.  Hoping they
might understand better the "feeling" of a rave.

Brief history of experiencing shared positive energy:  If you have never
been to a Dead show, about five minutes prior to the first note and about
five minutes after there is this intense excitement in the air and it's not
uncommon to see people running around (blindly) with HUGE smiles on their
faces hugging strangers.  It's a great moment and one in which there is a
universal connection with every person in the building; a shared positive
energy.  Flash now to a professional football game.  The Buffalo Bills had
just beaten the N.Y. Jets in overtime, at home, and the fans ran down on
the field (pictures of it were titled "Fandamonium").  As I was crossing
the 50 yard line high-fiving just anybody and everybody, hugging strangers
and the like, I was suddenly struck with the thought that what I was
feeling was just like the start of a Dead show.  Virtually everyone in the
whole stadium just sharing one huge positive energy.

Flash now to now.  Raving in San Francisco.  Walking into the main room for
the first time.  Hearing your favorite song get mixed in and smiling when
it turns out to be everyone's favorite song and the crowd lets out a loud
cheer.  Dancing hard on stage at 1015 Folsom and feeling that maybe a
smidgen of the cheering is directed toward you. Shared positive energy!

With all that said, here are some other experiences I have had in my life
that I would use to explain the feeling I get from raving.  Please feel
free to add on to the list. Maybe someone could compile the results (I
don't have time, really).  I suggest you have a couple of your own on hand
so the next time a friend/parent/whoever asks, "Why the hell do you go to
raves?  What's the big deal?"  You can say, "Well, remember how excited you
felt when you came home on Halloween night to sort your candy?  That's how
I feel at a rave."  :^)

Here's what I came up with in a couple minutes.  Some are singular
experiences, some I shared with thousands.  How's this for a title: Things
that have given me that intense tingly feeling that I so often get at
raves:

Coming home on halloween to sort the candy
Christams morning
Just as the Dead are starting
Wrestling in front of a packed crowd (and winning)
Graduation (high school & college)
Having a favorite team win a tight game
Midnight on New Years
New Orleans Jazz Festival
Reggae on the River

And remember, don't try and force feed the feeling to people, if worse
comes to worse, just think of a great time you had at a rave and sit back
with a big peaceful smile on your face  as if to say, "You just wouldn't
understand...."

;^}

Tony

technoshamanism explained

shamans have traditionally used rythmic sound generated by gourd, rattle, or
drum to induce trance-like states for various purposes - healings, journey
to the underworld, spirit retrievals, etc. -
to those of us who have walked in both worlds (traditional shamanic and
rave) the similarity of "altered state" achieved by either method of trance
induction is markedly similar - the only thing lacking is that the
technologically induced trance state usually lacks clarly articulated
"intention"
there are many who believe that a good dj on a good night is quite capable
of inducing mass trance states - just like a tradition shaman - only using
new technological toools and sound sources, hence technoshamanism - it will
never be a true shamanic state until intention is understood (IMHO)

hope this helps

> Here's what I came up with in a couple minutes.  Some are singular
> experiences, some I shared with thousands.  How's this for a title: Things
> that have given me that intense tingly feeling that I so often get at
> raves:
> 
> Coming home on halloween to sort the candy
> Christams morning
> Just as the Dead are starting
> Wrestling in front of a packed crowd (and winning)
> Graduation (high school & college)
> Having a favorite team win a tight game
> Midnight on New Years
> New Orleans Jazz Festival
> Reggae on the River

Hmmm....I've been sitting here for the last few minutes thinking of what 
gives me that same intense tingly feeling I get at raves.  You know what 
- I hate to say it, but *NOTHING* compares!  In all of my 25 years on 
this planet, there has been absolutely nothing that compares to the feelings I 
have when I'm dancing and vibing with everyone on a higher plane of 
consciousness.  There is just nothing like it in the world!!!!  

love,
Amy

>
>On Tue, 16 May 1995 BCHA@middlebury.edu wrote:
>
>> I've tried explaining the Vibe, technoshamanism, etc. to the uninitiated
>
>Speaking of which, just what exactly is technoshamanism?  It's a term 
>I've heard a lot, and always wondered exactly what it means...
>

A whole book could be written on it, but briefly (I'm at work) here's my
interpretation:

Music and sound in many ways create reality.  When music is playing it
creates a space to be.  It creates a mood, a feeling, a vibe.  Music and
sound trigger emotions and feelings from within our selves.  The feelings
include the entire spectrum.  When at a rave and dancing it is possible to
be swept up in the feeling and vibe of the music and be profoundly and
spiritually moved.  Think about it, the music is almost completely
controling the reality of the situation....if it's on the people are
dancing, moving running around, jumping sometimes completely out of
control... if it stops, everyone stops....it puts everyone on the sames
wavelength with a very similar focus...with everyone on similar wavelengths
an energy can be created that is tangable...you can see as well as feel it.
This is technoshamanism; using technology (ie. records, turntables,
speakers, etc.) to move people in such a way as decribed above.  The dj is
the shaman.  He/She decides what music to put on.  He/She (ideally) feels
the vibe of the croud and is able to direct the flow of energy (through
choice of music) to gain the maximum benifit for everyone involved.  If you
are ever in a situation (any situation) where you feel like the energy isn't
flowing well, try changing the music that is playing, and if there is none
playing, put some on and watch the whole atmosphere of the room shift.
Sometimes the shift is subtle, but sometimes quite profound.  IMHO ofcourse.

Rick

> I'm wondering if any of you feel similarly.....

  You know, I gotten to the point where I'm really having fun with
this......as most of you know me.....I am a somewhat sedate 43 year old Jr.
college English instructor...gray-haired...but with a definate twinkle in my
eye...People used to come up to me at parties and ask what I was doing
there...or wanted to know if I was a narc.....However, now...when I pull up
to stop lights and the windows and mirror in my BMW are shaking..( I've got
200 watts thumpin inside)...I get the strangest looks...Also,......I"ve got
turntables and a mountain of speakers in my living room now....and while my
house was for sale, I had the most interesting time trying to explain to
people what I was doing with all that equipment.......Never fear...What they
don't know, won't hurt you.....Anyway...I'm moving out into the country,

Origin Of Man and The Descent Of Man were Darwins first publication that 
he solely dedicated to scientific knowledge, never did he intend to have 
it turned into a political propaganda by the Facsist nor the Nazi's.

Herbert Spencer (1820-1903) was a freind of Darwin who took Darwins work 
and applied the term SOCIAL DARWINISM which in Spencer's ttheory meant 
that low class people are destined to die according to survival of the 
fittest theory. His theory became popular among the Nazi's and Facist 
government.

Historically Herbert Spencer is responsible for hinting toward racism by 
using Darwins scientific ideas and applying it to his own sick beleifs.

On Tue, 16 May 1995, Tony Rotundo wrote:

> Amy Starkey wrote:
> 
> To me, rave can be like religion or politics: I don't talk about it with others
> who I feel don't understand what it's about. And I don't talk about it
> unless I am asked. Do you know what I mean?
> 
> There have been a lot of responses to Amy's lament about people not
> understanding what the rave culture is about, and why we do what we do.  In

Well, I think a lot of misunderstanding comes from the sensationalistic 
media. People (majority) don't want to be informed, they want to be 
entertained. Have you seen the HUGE number of outrageous talk shows 
lately? There are just more and more every day. Look in the paper;
what passes as "news" goes way past the four W's(who,what,where,why) and 
the one H (how) and delves deeply into the realm of editorialization and 
putting a spin on a story. When I have seen anything regarding rave in 
the mainstream press it has been negative. Just this weekend there was an 
article from an AP writer on a couple of kids that OD'd. It started "Why 
did Chris have to die... They went to a rave party and..." We all know though
that this is a very uncommon ocurrance, but when people read this and hear 
JUST these messages it adds up. While I think it is sad and wrong, it is 
no mystery. Rave is something we all know about, and we know the picture 
painted is a false one. Think about this the next time you pick up a 
newspaper or watch the news: If the media is SO wrong about a subject 
that we all know intimately, just how much can you rely on them to give 
you accurate information on the multitude of subjects you don't know about?


                                                Black Adder

hi everybody!

well, here i am with philip and amy at philip's job about to listen to
neato snippets of techno from hyperreal.  cool.

we're deviating from our usual musical tastes by checking out, courtesy
of p., an rem concert.  woohhoo!

anyway, last saturday we went to Satchitananda at a beautiful house the
woods of bolinas.  ethan, cyril, ronan, dante plus guests played pretty
much all night long, despite a noise complaint.  oops.

the location was soooo beatiful!  since the last new moon got rained out,
i was really ready to see friends and listen to incredibly wonderful
music all night.  the music was very very good.  very much on the harder,
faster techno tip in cyril's and ethan's set, which i really got into.
but also very trippy.  ethan's set got everybody all sweaty.  it was
really cool, because it was like a little bit of kommotion in effect out
there in west marin.  ethan's got a serious vibe goin' on that's all his
own.  thanks for playing, man, it was great!  (the tapes for you are
coming along nicely...)

cyril also did a great set, which i loved.  he is one hell of a good dj.
and then, the end the party, was ronan's amazing, much more mellowed out
but still VERY intense musically set.  wow.  this is a side of his
musical life that i haven't seen in a while.  i can't wait to hear more.

amy says:  lighten up you guys.  darwinsism is kool but let's talk about
parties!!!!

anyway, i have to say again this party was one of the more satisfying
experiences party-wise and music-wise that i've had in a while...'cause
of the people involved who are so talented and so much fun.  let's do it
again, over and over until we're sore.

thanks you guys a millions times over and over,

i love you all,

ann

X-Mailer: AIR Mail 3.X (SPRY, Inc.)

Hey Amy,
Great Post, I've been dying to respond to this all day.

Back in 1986 (shit, was that really 9 years ago?!?) I had a similar assignment 
in my 2D design class.  We had to do a design project to go with a piece of 
music and we had to play the music for the class when we presented our work.  
This was in leu of a final exam so we had to make a powerfull statement.  
Since we didn't have acid trance I used an old Dead Can Dance song and my 
presentation generally blew people's minds, except for my one freind in the 
class who blew all of our minds with some old Throbbing Gristle (this was my 
first exposure to this kind of freaky drug music and it opened quite a few 
doors of perception for me).  

The reaction of the class was one of general bewilderment?!?  What was this 
new kind of tripy music??? (really not new at all, just underground, sound 
familiar?).  Was this punk?, new wave?, alternative? (gag me).  They really 
could not classify it and I think that alot of people are uncomfortable with 
that.  But in the end no one reacted negatively.  If anything it was very 
interesting to them even if they didn't like it.  

It was really quite a high for me.  It was like giving each one of them a 
little glimpse of this secret world that they didn't know existed.  If I had 
it to do over again today, I would have chosen the deepest, hardest Acid 
Trance track in my crate and then painted the tripyest, most psychedelic, 
colorful world I could imagine to go with it.

So my advice is go for it.  Don't hold back because part of your spirit is in 
this music and you already know how good it feels to let it shine.  This is 
another chance to show a little part of the outside world that there is 
something deep and mysterious out there that is starting to make some wild 
things happen.  It is also a chance to show them that we ravers don't just run 
around banging our heads to T99 and 2unlimited all day ;).  Our music has 
evolved into a very well developed and expressive art form and I think most of 
the outside world is unaware of that.

Try not to worry about negative reactions.  The nature of true art is to 
expose the artist.  No one has to like it except YOU!!!  And beleive me, if it 
comes from your soul someone is gonna like It.  You have the vibe, Keep It 
Alive!!!  :) 

So good luck to you, and be sure to let us know how it went.

later.
Bliss

Amy wrote:

>I just finished writing to a friend of mine and something crossed my mind 
>and  I want to know how you all feel about this:

>I was telling my friend how, for my design class,  I have to make this 
>collage of colored shapes to show what music looks like.  I decided to 
>portray 
>my *favorite* music: acid trance.  Well, most of my class mates don't 
>know what the hell I mean by acid trance, so I'm bringing a couple of my 
>tapes to class to demonstrate what I mean.  Now this is where I start to 
>feel funny.  I hold rave in all of its forms very close to my heart and I 
>don't talk about it much to people who I casually know - such as 
>classmates at school or co-workers.  I feel like by playing my music for 
>the class that I am putting my neck on the chopping block.  Not that I 
>*care* really if they like it or not, but when something is really 
>important to me, it still hurts if people openly ridicule it.  To me, 
>rave can be like religion or politics: I don't talk about it with others 
>who I feel don't understand what it's about. And I don't talk about it 
>unless I am asked. Do you know what I mean? 
> I'm wondering if any of you feel similarly.....

Subject: Deep music, deep thoughts
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I would tend to agree with Max's recent posts .. the SF list has TONS of
cool stuff about life, the universe and everything .. on NW raves it seems
to be more discussing parties, comparing parties, or flaming the party
throwers.  *sigh* oh well ... I wouldn't have expected anything less from
SF Ravers !  I look forward to meeting some of you when I'm down there.

As for the music ... I don't believe there CAN be any such thing as "just
music".  For me, music is such a huge part of my life that to lose it would
be like losing my touch.  Music can make me laugh, cry, sing, get angry,
love, remember, sleep, dream ... music permeates my entire being, and being
at a GOOD rave just brings it home all the more.  I have preferences as to
what kind of music I prefer, of course, but ... music is life to me.

except for accordian solos.


peace

carebear

__________________________________________

To me, boxing is like ballet, except there's no music, no choreography, and
the dancers hit each other.

in this instance.  I was merely commenting on the fact that if it had been 
a similar type of party in London that what I said in my previous 
post on the matter would have been the case.  I just wanted to give a 
nuetral commparison partly because those were the kinds of parties I 
used to help throw in London (similar venue, different djs and free).  If I 
implied that having a 
100% trance night was a bad thing I am sorry; ( I love Gill and I 
love trance.)
  Also, I was not the only one to make this comment about the 
night lots of other people said the same that I talked to; and they, like 
me said it as a mere quible and not as serious critisisom of the night.  
Nothing can not change the fact that it was one of the best parties I, 
and everybody else I spoke to had been to in ages.

>   Although that it is a thought you know: a party were the main floor
>plays everything from hard techno to Acid house/house to dub and ambient.

I remember a party called "Stop the Pigeon".  It was one of a series of
parties put on by VOOM producions in 93.  The theme of the party was based
on the soviet revolution (if your wondering why a party has such a freaky
name).  It was brilliant < Everything from the way they promoted the party
to the way the warehouse was decorated.  It was the most original 'rave' I
have ever seen.

relevance?

the DJ line up was amazing:  D WYnn (KMS records), Stacey Hale, Kevin
Saunderson, and Richie Hawtin.  Stacey Hale started off with some deep
house, D Wynn played some stompin' techno and acid, Kevin Saunderson played
some freaky house music, and Richie closed with trance and ambient stuff.

truly diverse..  truly amazing..

and the wierdest part of all:  I started skateboarding at about 6 am with a
friend while the crew was cleaning up the warehouse.  Soon, about 20 people
joined in!  I couldn't believe it:  a full on skate session at 7 in the
morning!!!

(little flashback)

Jon

Dear All;

	Sorry for the late post, but once again Liberty.com had some mail 
problems, but here it is anyway. Sorry.

Brian

Dear Anais & All;

	Wow!!!, Move was great at 7th & Folsum, I just can't say enough
good things about this venue, comeon guys get it legal, I'll get the
permits me self, ppplleaseeee!!! God knows that I needed to have a good
time, way to stressed, more on that later. Killer music all night long, a
nice intimate space where you can always find room to talk, without
yelling into the person next to you's ear, a house party by any other
name, $5 - $8 to get in for 7 - 8 hours of good times, and the most awsome
massage room I've thus practiced in sooo far, it mite as well been my
office. I actually found the good kind of #, ya know the kind dat gets you
really high, for really long, and you feel ggrreaaattttt!!!, in da
morning, thanks #### for hooking me up. 

	 I was told that this mite be the last of 7th & Folsum, due to the
pol-lice, I hope not. It was great meeting you little Steven, and the
owner who's name I'm forgeting, damm. To Corey(way to sexy, & she gives a
nice massage, then again I'm a slave to loving touch), Sasha, Greg S.(da
"man" from Santi Cruz), Lydia(Horseback Riding for sure girl),the names of
the people I'm forgeting, and especially Karma(dis womyn is just too cool,
I've never met a womyn, who has experienced & done as much of life, both
good & bad, as I have in the short time, we been on the planet, so I'm
impressed(not meant to be egotistical)), thanks for making my night a
little special, by sharing your magnificient presents, and lives with me.
Its soooo hard to find a soul mate, or even a little Shelter from the
Storm, for that matter. 

	Ohh!!, almost forgot, I felt sooo good, I actually went out to an
after party at 111 Minna Street, Gallery. Its really cool, even though I
felt I was on a MTV video shoot set, it just reminds me of a lot of the
back dropping they use on a lot of there videos. I love art, because it
reminds me of how we are all wonderfully unique, different, dark, and
beautiful, masterpieces each of us. The nice thing about art is that I can
take one home with me and keep it, it's mine, unlike people, which for the
most part are unfortuately only temporary in our lives, but no less and
definately more rewarding, and enjoyable. I don't know who or whos
responsible for the visuals at 111 Minna Street Gallery, but they were
better by far than any of the big expensive overhyped "raves" I've been to
ever, and dats a lot. Much more interesting, engauging, approaching almost
3D VR, without having to wear the glasses, it just kinda jumps off the
screen on to you, without the aid of psychedelics, or serious lack of sleep.

	As for me and my status, just takin it one day at a time, and no
I'm not in 12 Step recovery, I took what I liked and left the rest, which
was most, leaving that is. I'll never forget what happened to her, its one
of the those bad life experiences, I hope she's up there dancin in heaven,
to a neverending groove, with no need to ever hurt or feel pain again,
just unconditional love & beauty, all in her vision of happiness & peace.
Its just sad we have one less masterpiece to enjoy & experience, I'm 
sorry if that sounds selfish. Again thanks for all the sweet, concerned & 
wonderful posts, I love ya all just the way you are.

		Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		  a.k.a. Brian Darkness, LMT/EE/CET
		    a.k.a :) Da Massage Guy :)

addes to more world dis-harmony, and aren't enough people doing that all
ready, like our governments, and the press. For example we all laugh,
smile, & hug the same way, there's a start. Or aren't you up for the

Subject: NON-RAVE/Windows 95 Preview Program
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.3.91.950517051336.23628C-100000@liberty.liberty.com>

Precedence: bulk

Dear All;

	For those PC Users out there, I would just like to share some 
brief experiences with the MS Windows 95/Beta Final Release I just got 
promoed to me.

	First of all, its a real pain in the ass to setup. You basically
lose DOS, which may or may not be benefical to you. I have some pretty
werid hardward. VL/EISA 486-DX2-66 with a EISA/ESDI controller 
card.

	It doesn't like to regconize them correctly. Which means you must
use them in DOS Compatibility mode, which is slow slow slow, like .125 of
the maxiumun data ftransfer rate. Though I'm told there will be Protected
Mode drivers available for these devices in the WIN95 street copy. Which
considering that they don't make ESDI drives anymore, and Ultrastor is
coming out of Chapter 11 is actually preety cool thag for them to do,
MS that is.

	It resembles either an OS2 or Mac front end, so much for look
and feel. If your a reseller, you will be able to make a lot of money 
confiquring this system for people, because its comlicated, and I feel 
above the average computer user. You basicaly have to configure all your 
hardward, either manually or though an automatic detection process, but 
everyone likes to tweak peramaters, right???

	It does have a lot of nice features, like built in mail & network
stuff, including fax suppport. Automatic V-Memory support, no more
creating a swap file, yeah!!!!, so make sure you delete the old one,
because it doesn't us it, it dynamic allocates it on the run. If you are a
reseller get this product now and play with it, it will save you the
frustration of tring to fiqure it out while your working on a clients
machince You have to re;load most of your applications, you can load it on
top of your old windows program, but it does work very well, due to the
fact, the longer you have windows working the more junk, it makes and
collects causing windows 95 to misinterput files, addresses ...etc

	Documentation is as always from MS poor, and minimul. Thats it, I 
off to reload it, know that I made a fresh start for me self. Oh, I 
almost forgot. Because you get to make long files names in the new WIN95, 
you can use dos disk tools like Norton Disk Doctor, as these program 
don't know what to do with the large file snames. Be careful, and 
conservative when you setup it up. Try one thing at a time, and make sure 
its working first before you go on to the next. If you have any hardware 
conflicts it will findem and won't work properly.


          Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
            a.k.a. Brian Darkness, LMT/EE/CET
          (510)-547-5984 CT Active Voice & Fax
          (510)-251-4735 CT Active Voice Mail & Pager

          Internet:      brianv@liberty.com
          Alt. Internet:      brianvan@liberty.com

   The kinda guy that bites mints in stead of sucking on them :)

	Shinning brighter than burning magnesium

crunch:
> Tommorrow I visit the formost world expert on Crocodiles,  and speaking
> of nasty sick beliefs,   Crocs also are very nasty preditors indeed,  and
> remind me of other nasty faschist things....   I couldn't help thinking
> of all these nasty faschist things as I saw 30 foot Crocs crush pig heads
> in their jaws. 

I can understand the analogy, but please don't equate the instinctual
eating habits of these magnificant creatures to the racist acts of
oppression perpetuated by humans upon one another.  I think you'll find
that unlike the discrimination you recently encountered in Australia,
crocodiles will be happy to crush your head in their jaws irregardless
of your skin color, nationality, or whether you prefer trance over house.
It should also be noted that some species of crocodiles are endangered, 
clearly demonstrating they really aren't nasty at all when compared to 
the predatory behavior of homosapiens.

Lee

At 9:17 PM 5/16/95, James S. Curnow wrote:
>Can anybody give a concise definition of acid/trance
>Does Orb fit?
>and
>What are some the favorites on the Ravers top 10?
>
>
>
>REPLY TO: jcurnow@netcom.com |

        in no particular order:
                Krakpot         -plastikman
                Horses          -Voodo Child
                Rrroar          -Hardfloor
                Aceperience II  -Hardfloor
                Three o' Three  -Public Energy
                Anything by     -mike dearborn
                anything by     -air liquide, walker and/or jammin' unit

        and so on..i guess there is a difference between acid trance (which
i would say is a mostly european thing, labels like Harthouse, Labworks and
others) and acid house (robert armani, plastikman) and hard acid (DJ ESP,
stuff on Drop Bass Records, Adam X, etc.) and ambient acid (air liquide,
Higher Intelligence Agency).  I love all of this stuff, showing that one
small little silver box (the 303) can produce a wide variety of tonal
textures and vibes...
        :) brad

From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9505171625.AA23272@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Cultural Darwinism in Las Vegas
Cc: jlf3@mofo.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

In the area of cultural evolution, elements of a culture often
demonstrate their fitness to survive by their ability to demonstrate
some kind of value to the forces that dominate human behavior.
 
This is very apparent in Las Vegas, where my parents live.  The big 
hotel/casinos there usually adopt themes based on the following traits:
 
- High degree of sensory stimulation
- A sense of otherwordliness or fantasy
- A theme of power or importance or awe
- Some mystery, but familiar enough to not be fearful
 
Examples: Ceasar's Palace (Roman empire), Luxor (Egyption tombs,
pyramids), Mirage (tropics, volcanoes), Excalibur (knights,
castles, magicians), Treasure Island (Pirate ships, booty), 
MGM Grand (Hollywood, special effects)...
 
So, as a cultural anthropologist, I found myself drawn to the brand
new Hard Rock Cafe Casino.  Here it was at last: Rock'n Roll (and not
just Elvis) at the pinnacle of cultural permanence - now deemed fit to
survive as backdrop fodder for the promotion of the mindless gaming
and the meaningless transfer of wealth that serves as the main form
of entertainment in this town.
 
In Vegas, the culture is all image for the sake of image;  suitably
diluted into colorful wallpaper for simple sensory (i.e. not mental)
digestion.  Amongst the displays of famous leather jackets, guitars
and motorcycles, there was one sight that stood out most of all in
this relatively hip (for a casino, anyway) venue.
 
It was the bank of PURPLE HAZE slot machines.  There he was, Jimi Hendrix, 
his head surrounded by the swirls of a psychedelic cloud, his eyes rolled 
up to capture the moment of "'scuse me while I kiss the sky."  My eyes
were drawn to the big letters that spelled out a slang term for LSD. Safer 
than the white tigers in the Mirage's plexiglass cage.  But at least the
world will get a little more exposed to what the Voodoo Child was about,
I thought.  But then I realized that the old lady pushing quarters into
Jimi's face probably would never even know what instrument he played.
 
So I hear that Paramont is now building a casino theme park based 
on Star Trek, another childhood inspiration of mine.  I suppose in 15
years, the "successful" integration of Raving into the mainstream will
result in the Raveland Hotel And Casino or somesuch, where I'll be able
to throw coins into an Ecstacy slot machine, and bet my paycheck
on Empathy roulette before catching a techno act in the Megatripolis  
lounge.
 
Where humans control selection, the fit do not survive nearly as much
as the survivors are made to fit.
 
Lee
___________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com   (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )   lee@hyperreal.com

On Tue, 16 May 1995, Michael E. Clay wrote:

>  Acurate information from the news ? Seldom happens except for saying things
>  like LA had an earthquake... when drugs, politics, governments etc. are
>  involved we ALWAYS get a forced and filtered agenda... Now I only wish I
>  could figure out exactly WHO sets it....

For an interesting perspective on who's setting our national media 
agenda, go see "Manufacturing Consent," a 
film that documents Noam Chomsky's take on the U.S. media, the 
military-industrial complex, and their various games and deceptions.  
Fascinating (and frightening) stuff. "Manufacturing Consent" plays 
periodically at the Red Vic and Roxie in SF and, I believe, at the 
Pacific Film Archives (?) in Berkeley.

Kathryn

as a complete alternative to darwinism, may i suggest anyone with
  a slight scientific inclination try reading the book "gaia", by
    Joseph Lawrence (that name may be way off)

anyway, it's a chronology of Lovelock and Margulis' work on the
  notion that the planet is a single living organism, and that
    life evolves for the purpose of sustaining a livable biosphere,
      and not necessarily out of competition...

if that ain't pronoid, i don't know whut iz!!!

Dave SCruton

> It was the bank of PURPLE HAZE slot machines. 

That's what happens when something is dead (25+ years, in this case)...

the buzzards come in and rip out a few chunks.

Then the blowflies move in, then the maggots, then eventually the fungi.
Soon whatever Once Meaningful Thing was alive is now a seething mass of
mass-market memetic takeover, shedding pop-culture viruses and media-
parasites by the millions.

If something is fundamentally weak and sickly, the same can happen while
it is still (barely) alive.

A healthy, viable scene doesn't have to worry about being co-opted like this.
Usually they succumb to 'hipness disease', which causes otherwise thriving
organisms to commit suicide upon being discovered by the buzzards, blowflies,
maggots, or even another scene.

People have predicted the 'death of rave' for many years.  If it does die, 
we'll all know, because we will have let it die.

// g

on 5.17 Lee Fogel wrote:
>In the area of cultural evolution, elements of a culture often
>demonstrate their fitness to survive by their ability to demonstrate
>some kind of value to the forces that dominate human behavior.

I fear those forces are pretty fucking powerful ones - they are embedded
deep in our human psyche (ego, super-ego, id).  Perhaps thats why they
survive.  Some of these forces show themselves in our human desire
for love, compassion, friendship, communication, etc.  Others are more
powerful - our base human cravings for sex, power, murder etc.  Society
is created and bound by social contracts intended to restrain such cravings
as they are manifested as rape, murder, theft, etc.  I think our cravings
don't disappear as quickly as we would like though.  In addition to
surviving in society  - murder is age old and still with us - they mutate.
Our glutton yields a toxic waste.  And thus we have Ceasar's Palace.

>So I hear that Paramont is now building a casino theme park based
>on Star Trek, another childhood inspiration of mine.  I suppose in 15
>years, the "successful" integration of Raving into the mainstream will
>result in the Raveland Hotel And Casino or somesuch, where I'll be able
>to throw coins into an Ecstacy slot machine, and bet my paycheck
>on Empathy roulette before catching a techno act in the Megatripolis
>lounge.

Whoah. . . 

"I have seen the Evil, and he is us."

ciao! - ben

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Wed, 18 May 1994 17:47:15 +1000
To: SCRUTON@JOYCE.dnet.hac.com
From: crunch@sysx.apana.org.au (John Draper)
Subject: Re: Darwyn,  theory and city
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>hi ho mr. crunch, or (should i say) g'day!
>
>could you pleeze talk a little more about the scenery and the terrain
>  in Darwin?  is it wet and tropical? is it mountanous? are there any
>    coral reefs in the ocean nearby?

Sure!!   Terrain is mostly flat up around the northern coast.   Lots of
coconut palms,  low shrubs,  some large trees,  like banyon trees,  sand
palms,   etc.    Well,  here we're supposed to be entering the dry season,
but while I've been here,  it's warm humid thunderstorms.   I'm amazed
at how little regard people have while swimming during lightning storms.
No coral reefs,   but smooth sand.   No surf on this coast,  as this
portion of the Indian Ocean is similar to the Mississippi gulf coast.
Little or no surf to speak of.    Water kinda murkey on or near the
beach,   but clears up out past 100 meters.   Tides are VERY HIGH.  about
7 meters difference,  and turn every six hours.

>
>i see on my map that there are two islands off the coast, too...
>
>what are they like?
>

Bathurst and Melville Islands... Very picturesque tropical islands,  owned
by the Tiwi clan (Aborigionals).   Very first attempt to colonize Melville
failed because of the agression of the Tiwi people.   Quite physical,  more
attractive compared to mainland aborigionals.   Excellent fishing,  lots of
crocs.

Fishing reorts are really nice.   Lots of fresh water lagoons,  for swimming.
Pockets of monsoonal forests.   Thax to Ian (My tourguide) for being here to
answer your questions.

Oh!  No real mountains,   some coral reefs on the islands.   We are about
12 degrees S. Latitude (well into the tropics).

>Dave Scruton

Crunchman
