what's really interesting is that obviously a lot of monkeys chose *not* 
to try the mushrooms and *all* humans are descended from monkeys who took 
psychedelic mushrooms for generations (according to terence, this is)

I often feel when i'm playing with a few freinds that those other monkeys 
are still hanging out up in their trees and shouting down to us "don't 
touch that stuff, come on back up in the trees, it's not *safe* down 
there!  don't mess with that evolution stuff"

fraser

On Tue, 16 May 1995, Christopher Chervin wrote:

> Hi all,
> 
> Recently I watched a program on human evolution.  According to scientists homo sapiens 
> competed for a niche in nature with another hominid species.  The other species appeared to
> be more physicaly fit than humans yet somehow homo sapeins won out.  Scientists cannot figur
> e out why we were able to outcompete them.  
> 
> This leads to the book Food of the Gods, which I have just started reading.  Terrance M. 
> believes that by eating the mushroom are brain was able to grow at a rapid rate.  A rate
> that many scientists cannot explain. IF humans were competing with another species that
> may have been more physicaly fit than a bigger brain would have been an excellen selection
> for survival.  So those homo sapiens that ate a particular species of mushroom gained an 
> advantage over their competitors.  This advantage leads to reproduction and survival of 
> humans.  
> 
> These ideas dont really have any scientific proof to back them up but it still is neat to 
> fancy that we exist because of a psychadelic substance.  I think its possible.
> 
> love chris                            
> 
> 
>

Precedence: bulk

since I coined the word (in 1987 I think) I suppose it's for me to define it.
I first used tecnoshaman in that year to decribe the DJs role in the 
Rave.  "harmonic navigator" is a term we started using in 
megatripolis/London last year.  
basically the DJ is in charge of the group mood/mind.  he senses when 
it's time to lift the mood, take it down, etc just as the shaman did in 
the good ol' tribal days (which are still very much alive, of course, 
outside the west)

tecnoshamanism has a wider meaning.  think of it this way.  a shaman 
can't really opeate with more than say 20 people over a period.  if you 
reckon that every raver today is responsible for getting 20 people into 
RC then their job is personal shaman.
tecnoshamanism is using the technology, media (despite what some think) 
to help spread the vibe, the meme, sketching out a rough map for the trek 
ahead of them

need to stop.  I've been a bit sick this last week and I'm way behind on 
fololowing sfraves.

fraser

This is all exactly right on.

But, it isn't a conspiracy, it has to do with what sort of person *wants* to
be
a journalist, combined with the whole process of putting out a regular
product.

They have to fill up the whole newspaper or the whole hour on TV/radio, 
regardless of how much actually happened.  They are afraid to go out to
report on something and then tell the editor it was a false alarm, nothing
really happened....

Pure Consciousness is the basis for everything. 

It is not in time and space.

It did not derive from anything physical, rather the other way around.

consciousness.

The rave/vibe experience and philosophy (PLUR) makes much more sense from
this perspective than the scientific materialist one.

         -->>     Jesus Chrysler -- jchryslr@catch22.com      <<--

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Tue, 16 May 1995 22:43:32 PDT
From: Aaron Baum <baum@jumpjibe.stanford.edu>
To: Jesus Chrysler <jchryslr@Catch22.COM>
Subject: Re: funny message

Thought you might appreciate this, if you haven't seen it already;
it's from an (obviously geeky) comics newsgroup:

Spider-Man could beat Jesus! I haven't read all of Jesus' appearances,
but I think I can state from what I've read of them from Jesus collectors
here on the newsgroup that this thing would be possible.

First off, all of the old Jesus writers really didn't know his character.
That's because they're not writing him today. Jesus has never shown the
ability to resist a punch capable of shattering steel in his face! You'd
think that if the Jesus writers wanted him to be able to survive such
a punch, they'd have put him in a situation where they could show that.

So I don't go by the old Jesus appearances. But let's not argue back
issues, because I don't have any. Let's just consider Spider-Man:

1. Spider-Man has reflexes much faster than any human. Jesus is supposed
to be a god, yes, but he's also, more importantly, a man. And Spider-Man
is faster than a lot of gods, anyway, as shown by his defeat of Firelord
and Thanos. Spider-Man could react really quickly to anything Jesus
would like to do.

2. Spider-Man has his spider-sense, which will allow him the ability to
react to Jesus before Jesus can even throw a punch! This, combined with
his speed, makes Spider-Man easily capable of beating Jesus.

3. Spider-Man's web-shooters. I'd like to see Jesus multiply fish by
magic when he's trying to concentrate with a big glob of webbing in
his face! Especially when Spider-Man starts whipping him around with
his super-strength, I don't think Jesus will be able to do much about
that.

The way I see it, though, it could be an even match if they fought
outside a city or someplace. I mean, Spider-Man needs buildings
to swing on, and big trees aren't all that useful, since Jesus could
just curse them and make them wither away. And out on a lake Jesus
would win, since he could walk out over the water where Spider-Man
couldn't reach him! Well, except for his web-shooters, but I don't
know if I'm allowed to actually combine arguments into a coherent
whole. Hmm. This is a puzzler, no doubt!

And anyway, Jesus knows a lot more about surviving in the desert
than Spider-Man. Spider-Man could hide in a basement, however, until
the sandstorms pass, and then he could use his spider-sense to find
Jesus and pound his face in. Perhaps if Jesus snuck up on Spider-Man
in the basement with a crowbar, though, Jesus could take him out. After
all, Aunt May once did that, and that was because Spider-Man's spider-
sense didn't recognize her as a threat! And if there's one thing Jesus
ain't to Spider-Man, it's a threat! Well, it could work, but that was
actually written by an older writer, so maybe he didn't know anything,
anyway. If lead pipes were supposed to exist in Spider-Man comics,
you'd think the writers would show them occasionally, but since they
don't, it's obvious that crowbars aren't supposed to exist in Spider-Man
comics.

Really, most of Jesus' powers are really lame. I mean, he could make
Spider-Man drunk before the battle by changing all the water in his
building to wine, and his ability to cast out demons is pretty cool
(Jesus vs. Ghost Rider would be an awesomely kool match!), but Spider-Man
is fast, and, you see, that means he's basically fast, which means
he will win, because that's the way the writers have it nowadays.


And also:

If A=6, B=12, C=18, D=24, and so on until Z=156, then add up the values of
the word COMPUTER.  You get 666.  Hmmmmm.  But, what TYPE of computer?
Add up the values of the words IBM PC CLONES... you get 666 again!


This person went onto insist that he was not a freak.

socio-political-evolutionary raps.

nature' so i think i'd lump chemicals in with that..

No music...but great visuals! This Saturday is Guest Day 95 at McClellan
AFB, 7am-9pm.

SEE...

10:45am  Security police drug dog demo :)
12:20pm  AV-8 Harrier (or) F-111 flyby
12:35    A-10 ground attack demo (real bullets..watch a tank be disintegrated!)
12:55    U-2 flyby (they practice out here... I think they sound neat)
 1:45    F-16 demo
 2:10    Apache gunship ground attack demo

See the drab building where I work! See my apartment (if you want..).

Guest day is free and open to the public. Easiest way in is to take I-80
out of the bay, stick with I-80 Reno (not business 80). About 20 miles
past the Yolo Causeway, take the Winters Rd. exit, and turn left. The
gate is about 1 mile ahead. If you miss Winters Rd., take the Watt
exit, turn left, and about 1 1/2 miles are more McClellan gates.

If anyone wants to crash at my place Friday night, send me email by
5pm Friday.

Sorry for lack of rave content, but I thought someone else might not
want to miss the chance to see these demos... :)

Sean

The third anniversary of Basics is being celebrated on Saturday, and
Progress is here again with a couple of new faces.  Friday, in the
SF ares, there's only the mystery ;) party and the weeklies - Dust
and the Bulletproof party were both pretty cool when I went.

The calendar web page and the SFR home page have been redesigned; I
still need to reupload the top image, so check it out after I do that.


                               THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
             http://hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/sfrcal.html
     _________________________________________________________________

       Progressive house, acid jazz and "alternative" music views. (415)
       281-3377.

       90.1 Stanford

       experimental & noize - w/DJ Unknown, KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Thursday evening 9:30pm-12mid - Minor Minor KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills

       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To svbscribe or
   unsvbscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   svbscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsvbscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To svbscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   svbscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.3.91.950518180041.7984C-100000@B17.Catch22.COM>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Recently I've been seeing this really cool show on the Discovery show 
called The Brain or something like that, and besides some of the best 
computer graphics I've ever seen (The beginning and ending credits mostly 
- blew me away), the show is actually very cool.  They look at a lot of 
different aspects of the brain, such as how psychoreactive drugs effect 
it, and how fasting and sensory deprivation causes hallucinations.  It 
was very non-biased, and they actually interviewed this painter who takes 
acid to help him pain.  I can't remember his name, but his work looked 
very familiar.  Anyway, it's pretty cool, and worth checking out.  It's 
on Wednesdays at 10 pm, on Discovery (Channel 36 in San Francisco), and 
I'm pretty sure that it's on other times too.

         -->>     Jesus Chrysler -- jchryslr@catch22.com      <<--
        -->>           Big Chief of Programming at             <<--
       -->>  22 Solutions -- We should leave well enough alone! <<--

Well here is what my experiences with this weekly have been:

in short:

1  the doorguy is an asshole:  I brought 4 friends of mine to 'DUST' last
week and we all had Michigan ID's.  He accused us all of having fake id's.
He even called one of our 21 year old friends a "19 year old".

2  the girls at the door wouldn't let anyone play pool even though nobody
was dancing!  So what do you do?  Sit around and do nothing? (so fucking
boring this place is)

3  The venue sucks:  it reminds me of Dennys with the lights out and a
sound system in the kitchen.  It's kinda like a hotel bar or something.

4  The bartender refused all of us drinks for the rest of the night because
she accused us of having fake id's also.  My girlfriend and I have lived in
California for 9 months now.  We use our Michigan ID everywhere in SF and
*NEVER* have any problems.

5  Why was she complaining about us buying drinks anyway?  There was only
10 other people there to buy drinks?!  How else were they gonna make money?

6  Speaking of money:  I take back the part about making money.. they
charged 5 bucks cover!!  It should of been free cuz it sucked so bad.

7  MUSIC:  The music wasn't any different than anything else going on that
night.. So why go to that club?

8  The only thing that was decent was the light setup.  Except for the fact
that there were too many for a 10' by 10' dance area.  By the way, the
light guy was from Michigan, how come nobody gave him a hard time? :)

9  all in all:  the venue sucks, the people are rude, if you look
young;watch out, the dJ's were o.k., the lights were o.k., the vibe..
there was no vibe, and 5 people dancing?

but hey..  everyone else might of liked it..      ?


Jon
(dusted, one too many times)

Hello everyone.  I have been on this list for a while but this is my
first post.  So let me start by asking a question which might concern
me in the near future:

How well do the (standard?) drug tests detect MDMA/ MDA?  How long
does one have to be clean to avoid testing positive?  Is there some
substance that helps clean one's system and thus makes this time
period shorter?  Finally, are there designer drugs with similar
effects to MDMA that are not detectable by drug tests?

Thanks.

SASA (it's pronounced ``SASHA'')

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri May 19 04:57:46 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id EAA01831; Fri, 19 May 1995 04:57:46 -0700

Received: from [203.7.177.17] (sldar1p01.ozemail.com.au) by zip.com.au with SMTP id AA31660

Message-Id: <199505191157.AA31660@zip.com.au>

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Fri, 20 May 1994 04:57:51 +1000
To: SCRUTON@JOYCE.dnet.hac.com
From: crunch@sysx.apana.org.au (John Draper)
Subject: Re: Darwyn,  theory and city
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>i see on my map that there are two islands off the coast, too...
>
>what are they like?

Well,  in answer to your previous question you asked me a few days ago,
You're in luck..   I just got back from Bathurst Island today.   Now I
can really tell you about it.    I also took a lot of pictures on one
of those disposable 35 MM camaras.   I hope to scan them in so I can
put them up on my web page.

Bathurst Island is the smaller of the two islands.   The larger Island
was on the tour,   but due to the wet season staying on a lot longer
than expected (probably because of me,  and all the rain I bring with
me).

The Tiki Aborigional people own the Island,  which was origionally discovered
by the Dutch in the late 1800's.   The Dutch tried to conquer the folks
living on the Island back in those times,  thus the Tiki people has had
to learn how to fight to keep their land,  thus are famious for being very
agressive and hostile,  and have learned how to make effective weapons
designed for gorilla warfare.

In WW 2,  when the Japanese bombed Darwyn,  a lone radio operator on
Bathurst radioed the warning,   but it was put down,  and essentially
ignored,  or shrugged off as American.

Historically,  Darwyn has been literally wiped out by the Japanese during
the war.   The USA,  hasn't entered the war at this stage.

Since that time,  the Catholic Mission has established the Cathlic religion
and integrated it into their OWN culture.   In fact,  the Tiki say that
they had incorperated Cathlic religion into their Culture.

They make pottery,  water bowls,  and live entirely off the plants that
grow there.   Their knowledge the planlife is exemplarary.   They are also
not that anxious to share their knowledge.   The land is the same as the
mainland,  with typical tropical plants like coconut palms,  Mango trees,
plus the plants in the bush.

As we were driving along,   one of the Aborigional women yelled for us to
stop.   She quickly got out of the vehicle and headed out into the bush.

She stopped in front of a tree,  and pointed out a frilled lizard (Which
they regard as a delecacy).   I swear,  that tree must have been at least
150 meters off the road.    She "Whacked" it with a stick,  picked it up
by the tail,  and whacked it against the tree,  and handed it to me and the
rest of us who were out on this tour for close inspection.   Now I know
why they don't get close to the head when it's alive.

You had asked if there were any reefs.   Well,  I was on the sourthern
side of the island,   but as I was coming in from the air,   I could see
the northern side,  and it didn't have that turquoise color that a reef
has, when seen from the air.   In fact,  the water looked murkey along
the shore,   and it's very dangerious to swim there,  because of the
stingies,  crocs,  and sharks.   stingie is Aus-speak for sting ray.

Aussies like the "ee" words.   Ekkie,  stubbie,  smartie,   etc.

The day was stickey and hot...  no breeze,   just hot muggy tropical
yukk!!   The last 3 days,   my energy has been zilch!!   Not used to
this climate.

The night before,  went to Darwyn's sunset market.   They had massage
tables,  live music,  and was near a beach.   Nobody was in the water,
dispite the water temperature of 86 degrees.  Warmest ocean water I've
ever experienced.    At night,  I walk down to the water,  and a waft
of warm air comes from the waves.   I stick my hand in,  and it was
just as warm as bath water.   It's almost two warm to swim in,  anyway.
learned why nobody was swimming.   Stingies were out in force.

Anyway,  I head back to Sydney tommorrow for Totum (Good acid trance),
to get my pictures processed and scanned.

Crunchman

>there was no vibe, and 5 people dancing?

The venue is strange, but no worse than DV8 or many other clubs in the city.
The 21 and is admittedly annoying.  The Dj line ups looking quite good.  The
people who throw this party are some of the nicest I've met at any Party.
The DJ's play for free, they're not making any money and the promoter...
Well she's taking a loss.  The vibe?  The vibe is what YOU make it.  The
people involved are working damn hard to get this party going, and if you
don't appreciate it i'm sure they'ed love some constructive feedback.  There
are definetly more positive ways to influence your environment than defaming
someone elses cration.   

>but hey..  everyone else might of liked it..      ?

sarcastic attack.  I know quite a few people who like dust; I'm sorry you've
decided not to be one of them.  I encourage anyone who enjoys smaller
parties to experience dust first hand and see for yourself what it's all
about.  And for those like Jon maybe you'll like us after we've grown a bit
more :)

At 6:30 5/19/95, buvac-lists@cs.Stanford.EDU wrote:
>Hello everyone.  I have been on this list for a while but this is my
>first post.  So let me start by asking a question which might concern
>me in the near future:
>
>How well do the (standard?) drug tests detect MDMA/ MDA?  How long
>does one have to be clean to avoid testing positive?  Is there some
>substance that helps clean one's system and thus makes this time
>period shorter?  Finally, are there designer drugs with similar
>effects to MDMA that are not detectable by drug tests?
>
>Thanks.
>
>SASA (it's pronounced ``SASHA'')

It will show up as an amphetamine in drug tests. You should be ok 48 hours
after ingestion although I beleive it can occasionally be detected up to
96. That's for a urine test, dunno about hair.

Joe

>about.  And for those like Jon maybe you'll like us after we've grown a bit
>more :)

I love small parties.  SMALL GOOD PARTIES.  Obviously, this was a small
shitty party.  Face it, sometimes people throw small shitty parties.  I'm
not saying it will always be shitty.  I'm saying it was shitty the last two
times I went.  I'm not trying to piss you off.  this message was originally
posted to share my experiences with others.

Jon

p.s.  I also encourage those of you who haven't gone to go and check it out
for yourselves..

and about still having a Michigan ID>  I don't drive in SF so there isn't
any  urgency for me to get a CALI drivers license.

Hey, I like dust. 

I've met some really cool people there.  Usually end up talking to
more people there than at other parties because it's small and quit
enough in the booths to talk.

I think the space is pretty cool.  The arched ceiling and the mirrors work
great with the lights.  The dance floor is small but when I've been there
there's usually 20 people or so dancing.

For a kinda mellow trancy evening I think it's great.

The Newt King

Hey Jon!

Chill, man.  Your tone is too fucking harsh for a Friday.  You didn't like
Dust...got it.  'Nuff said.  You don't need to grind it into the ground
like a kid stepping on a bug.  Others have gone and enjoyed it.  I am going
tonight no matter what you say, because contrary to your opinion, the DJ
line-ups are quite impressive, especially since they're playing pro-bono.

It's unfortunate you got hassled at the door (and the bar).  The price of
looking young; one day you'll appreciate it.  As you said, last time the
doorwoman was cool.  Maybe the guy at the door had poison oak or something
and was feeling a bit testy.  These things suck, but they happen and must
be taken with a grain...(or a gram, for that matter :^).

>Why should I or anyone else who enjoys a good party support something that
>SUCKS!

That's not nice.  :^(

>Dave does a great job.

That's nice.   :^)

>I have also worked my but off to throw parties since 1992.  I know what
>it's like.  but> I always made sure that everyone that was working at the
>event was super cool and friendly.

your Super Cool and Friendly party in the perfect venue with perfect
workers with absolutley unbiased opinions.

Tony

P.S.  Sorry for the sarcasm, but the truth of the matter is, I'm certain
the people from Dust are working hard to create the best weekly party they
can.  They deserve both support and criticism, but they don't deserve
obnoxious, unconstructive bashing such as:  >Why should I or anyone else
who enjoys a good party support something that SUCKS!

That's not what this news group's about.  We're friends here and we should
treat eachother as such...

Have a great weekend gang....*twirl*...Out!

Yea so Jon wa a little harsh but I think you guys should lay off him...
 sfraves is such a "politicaly correct" list when it comes to party
reviews...  maybe this has to do with the promoter presance?  I have never
been to dust so I have no opinion obviously on the party,  I do have an
opinion on the post.  Im glad someone finaly posted a review that did not
have all of these clarifications about how everyone "tried sooo hard" etc.
etc.  I personaly like to see the real un censord reviews like this...  Im
sure this is the same thing jon would have told any of his friends  not some
net version compiled to not hurt anyones feelings.  I think if you thought a
party sucked and you were treated badly then you should be alowed to say so
without being flamed.  OK so here is my main point: )  the problem I see with
the SF scene is that there are too many rules now.  It is almost to the point
that if you don't medditate before you go to arave you are not a "true"
raver.  The scene here has lost a lot of energy...  more so than other parts
of the country.  Yes I know there are still good things goin on but I would
love to talk to someone who can _show_ me that it is still goin off like it
was 2 years ago. (and I do not mean just one party but the scene as a whole)
 SF is considered to be different by most people than other parts of the
country because of the _heavy_ emphasis on the spiritual side of raves,  I
just wonder if this is not corralated to the scene losing energy?  The rave
scene in SF is not as RAW as it was...  I mean god forbid anyone play
anything techno...  it's gotta be DEEP or super deep spiritula tribal trance.
 I think a lot of people droped out of the scene because too many new age or
whatever things were being pushed on them.  Remember raves when ther were no
"rules" no politicaly correct social image?  That was when EVERYONE could
come and just be.  That is what makes that old time rave feeling happen...
 not crystals or alters (those work for some people but not everyone wants to
be involved with that)  Old raves had this danything goes vibe that let
people forget about all the bullshit images that they normaly felt required
to uphold,   now SF raving has it's own image to uphold.  Watch out!  If you
don't fit in with our idea of what a great spiritual thing rave "is" then we
think you are neg energy and we don't wanna talk to you...  From talking to
other people around the country I don't think this attittude is as bad as it
is in SF.  I think it is great Jon said what he really felt!  I do not care
if most SF ravers consider it bad karma to be neg. about any party...  go
ahead and disagree with Jon that is fair too...  I just think it is week to
attack him for being "neg."  I would think all of you "possitive" ravers
would want to help poor negative jon with some possitive vibes: )
See ya
Rob

Fraser Clark <fraser@megatripolis.org>:
| what's really interesting is that obviously a lot of monkeys chose *not* 
| to try the mushrooms and *all* humans are descended from monkeys who took 
| psychedelic mushrooms for generations (according to terence, this is)
| 
| I often feel when i'm playing with a few freinds that those other monkeys 
| are still hanging out up in their trees and shouting down to us "don't 
| touch that stuff, come on back up in the trees, it's not *safe* down 
| there!  don't mess with that evolution stuff"

On the other hand (devils advocate here), look at how bad "our" group
of monkeys have messed up the earth. I don't think the monkeys in the
trees have ever knowingly and willingly killed ecosystems, perpretrated
mass genocide, invent and *use* weapons of mass destruction against
themselves....

But maybe that's because we lost our way as "modern culture" (or
whatever it is that we've been doing for the last 4000 years) led us
down the garden path... forcing us to stray too far from that mushroom
patch / garden of eden.

So perhaps the moral of the story is "eat of the forbidden fruit, or
you'll end up in some zoo flingin' shit at passers-by" ... 

-- Niels.

PS: I hear there's an upcoming movie called "Twelve Monkeys", and I
vaguely recall hearing something w/r/t the concept of the "twelfth
monkey" mentioned on this list a while ago. I even more vaguely
remember that this was from some book that someone found rave-relevant
or inspiring.  The movie is about a time travelling dude that hunts
down viral/bacterial disease outbreaks before they do major damage.
What's the connection, if any? Does the movie have anything to do with
the book? Am I confabulating and confused?

PPS: speaking of potential germ warfare gone awry (ebola anyone?), I
read in the paper that scientists recently revived 135 million year old
bacteria that had gone dormant (spore) and have noticed that they are
quite resistant to "fungal pathogens" (which, reading between the
lines, is a gentle way of saying that they're "antibiotic resistant").
The bacteria are from 70 million years before the dinosaurs went
extinct, and were revived from the stomach of a bee that had been
preserved in amber (petrified tree sap)...

supported my thoughts with facts and some opinions.  I didn't just say
'DUST SUCKS' and that's it.  I'm sure the Dust Crew is a bunch of cool
people, I didn't say I hated them did I?  I just stated what happened to me
and my friends and I commented on the party!  Is that a crime?  I'm really
not a negative person but if someone serves me soup with a fly in it.. I'm
gonna complain!!!!!

> I have never
>been to dust so I have no opinion obviously on the party,  I do have an

>net version compiled to not hurt anyones feelings.  I think if you thought a

exactly!!!!

>party sucked and you were treated badly then you should be alowed to say so
>without being flamed.

Actually, I want to hear people's flames.  This is a public forum, and as
much as I wanna talk about how I didn't enjoy something, I would like to
hear feedback, good or bad..

> SF is considered to be different by most people than other parts of the
>country because of the _heavy_ emphasis on the spiritual side of raves,  I

The spiritual side of SF makes SF unique, but I don't like the fact that
parties aren't that diverse out here (right now).  Hate to say this
but>I've noticed that in SF, the 'rave' crowd is primarily white.  It seems
like Latino's got their own thing, Blacks got their own thing, Gays got
their own thing, Asians got their own thing etc.etc.  This is not meant to
be a 'racial' statement, it's just an observation.

>just wonder if this is not corralated to the scene losing energy?  The rave
>scene in SF is not as RAW as it was...  I mean god forbid anyone play
>anything techno...  it's gotta be DEEP or super deep spiritula tribal trance.
> I think a lot of people droped out of the scene because too many new age or
>whatever things were being pushed on them.  Remember raves when ther were no
>"rules" no politicaly correct social image?  That was when EVERYONE could
>come and just be.  That is what makes that old time rave feeling happen...
> not crystals or alters (those work for some people but not everyone wants to
>be involved with that)  Old raves had this danything goes vibe that let
>people forget about all the bullshit images that they normaly felt required

I wasn't here two years ago, but I think most scenes right now are in this
wierd limbo..

>to uphold,   now SF raving has it's own image to uphold.  Watch out!  If you
>don't fit in with our idea of what a great spiritual thing rave "is" then we
>think you are neg energy and we don't wanna talk to you...  From talking to
>other people around the country I don't think this attittude is as bad as it
>is in SF.  I think it is great Jon said what he really felt!  I do not care
>if most SF ravers consider it bad karma to be neg. about any party...  go
>ahead and disagree with Jon that is fair too...  I just think it is week to
>attack him for being "neg."  I would think all of you "possitive" ravers
>would want to help poor negative jon with some possitive vibes: )
>See ya
>Rob

Jon

p.s.  I was not personally attacking the Dust Crew, whoever you guys may
be.  In fact, I think it's great that you guys are doing a weekly trance
gig on a Friday..  AGAIN<  I have the right to complain

 It would be OK by me , with the following hints:

1. Mr. Eisner , your posts seem to consistently have lines of text that
   seem somewhat long - resulting in "wrapping" to the next line. I don't
   know what the capabilities are of the word processor you are using, but
   maybe you can arrange things so that your email has less than 80
   characters per line. It makes for easier reading!

2. You could have the text put somewhere in hyperreal's ftp archives. Those
   who can ftp to other sites can get the file if they want, and others
   could get it emailed to them. 12 pages don't seem too long to me though,
   so emailing it straight to the SFRaves list doesn't seem too bad to
   me.

Jonathan,

I think that we all understand how you feel.  I feel for you that you did not 
enjoy yourself.  It seems that this continued thread is adding to that unhappy 
feeling.  Please don't take this the wrong way, no one here believes that you 
don't have the right to express your opinion, but I feel that we are really 
trying to create a community based on acceptance, love, understanding and a 
good vibe.  My best suggestion, let it all go.  You had a bad time and this is 
only continuing that negative feeling.  Brighten up, there are lots of other 
good parties.  Go out and enjoy yourself doing something you love and come 
back and share all of that good energy with us.

I hope you have a fabulous weekend.  

Drop to the pulse of life....
Love Anais
bliss@rain.org

Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

Subject: Why We Get High

Well so many of you asked for this essay that I'm sending it.  Blame 
15 people on the list for the leaky bandwidth.  Enjoy...and remember, 
you read it first here. 

Why We Get High

By Bruce Eisner

Almost all of us have gotten high.  Each of us might have a different
 name the experience--getting stoned or tripping or having a session or 
going on vision quest or partying--but the urge to switch channels,  and move to
 another and less usual state of consciousness is as old as our species itself.
  Actually this quest is even older!

Eons before humans found their first psychactive plant, Ronald Seigal, in his book, 
Intoxication,  documents numerous animal species that get high, or as he calls the 
the state achieved,  "intoxication." He also describes similar intoxications among a
 variety of human cultures, past and present.  Seigal proposes that after food, drink
 and sex, Intoxication is the fourth drive. He demonstrates--through the study of animals that
 intoxicate themselves  and drug use among a variety of human cultures--evidence that the urge to
 get high is among the most basic of motivations. 

Andrew Weil MD and Wilfred Rosen, in their wonderful  book
>From Chocolate to Morphine -- explaining psychoactive drugs to the young -- reaffirm this idea. 
 They point out:
	Human beings it seems, are born with the need for periodic variations
in consciousness.  The behavior of young children supports this idea.  Infants rock
 themselves into blissful states, many children discover that whirling or spinning is a
 powerful technique to change awareness, some also experiment with hyperventilation 
(rapid deep breathing) followed by mutual chest squeezing or choking, and tickling to produce
 paralyzing laughter.  Even though these practices may produce some uncomfortable
 results such as dizziness or nausea, the whole experience is so reinforcing that children do
 it again and again, often despite parental objections. Since children all over the world
 engage in these activities, the desire to change consciousness does not seem to be 
a product of a particular culture but rather to arise from something basic.  As children
 grow older they find that certain available substances put them in similar states
. The attractiveness of drugs is that they provide an easy quick route to these experiences.

Many drug users talk about getting high.  Highs are states of consciousness marked by
 feeling of euphoria, lightness, self-transcendence, concentration and energy.  
People who never take drugs also seek out highs.  In fact, having high experiences
 may be necessary to our physical and mental health, just as laughter and dreaming at 
night seem vital to our well being.  Perhaps that is why a desire to alter normal consciousness
 exists in everyone and why people pursue the experiences even though they are sometimes
 uncomfortable side effects.

Most of us do it, but how many of us have asked what I believe is a
fundamental question:  Why do I get high. Certainly many people would be better
 off if they asked this question each time they set about taking a mind-changing compound. 
 Culturally,  and as a species, we must also ask this question in its collective sense, 
Why do we get high? I believe the urge to get high is an essential element of human
 nature and that  it has and in the future will continue to shape the evolution of our species. 
 While I dont propose to have an complete anf final  answer to this enormous question,
 here are some of my thoughts.

Lets begin by looking at some of the most extreme or intense states or goals of a
 number of mind  (and matter) changing technologies including lucid dreaming,
 psychedelic drugs,  virtual reality, sensory  deprivation, near-death experiences 
and nanotechnology.  In each of these experiential phenomena, there is movement
 from the structured experience of the ego as it filters the world of consensual, 
well-boundaried reality into experience which is less structured and with less defined
 or even no boundaries at all.

Stephen LeBerges outstanding bookLucid Dreams, first popularized perhaps the
 most incredible dream experience imaginable: lucid dreaming.  Lucid dreams occur for some
 people rarely, with others more frequently, and others not at all. These are dreams in
 which the dreamer wakes up  while still dreaming and can then begin to change 
the dream as he or she likes.  There isa tremendous sense of freedom that accompanies
 this experience, in that it empowers the dreamer to create any experience he or she desires. 
Certainly this lies at the far edge of the domain of dreaming, which also encompasses
 more mundane activities, such as  dream analysis and dream journals.

In the realm of consciousness change catalyzed by the major psychedelic
 drugs--of which there are many, the most common being LSD. mescaline and psyilocybin
, the active constituent of .the sacred mushroom of Mexico,  users debate which experience is the
 highest...  ranging  from experiences of what Stanislav Grof MD calls the
 metacosmic void and supracosmic
 mind experiences of  transcendent awareness to Terence McKennas  
vision of machine-elves babbling about the end of time in the year 2012
  What  most psychedelic explorers report though as their most profound
 experiences are those in which the tripper can loosen the boundaries to
 the point of creating whatever experience he or she wishes.  They may
 experience this as a fast-moving collection of experiences or realities.
 Tim Leary calls the measuring quotient of this psychedelic stream "R.P.S."
 -- realities per second.  

While recalling Timothy Leary we should remember that it was this venerable
 philosopher of the psychedelic world that introduced many of us to virtual reality
 (VR). Virtual reality is the experience of a simulation of reality induced through 
sensory apparatus driven by a computer.  VR had it's  birth with the military but has
 found its way into commercial applications--including amusement parks in Silicon Valley,
 where youth flock to play computer games that use helmets and gloves instead o
f video screen and joystick.  

The cyberpunk genre of science fiction, iwriteen by such authors as
 William Gibson, Bruce Sterling and Greg Bear have collectively created a future
 in which virtual reality travel into vast computer networks with the Net, becoming a way of life
. Non-fiction 
 books as well, including those by authors Howard Reingold, Myron Kruger
 and Brenda Laurel, all point to a future VR technology in which humans interact in a
 cyberspace environment completely created by computer simulation.  
G. Harry Stein in his non-fiction bookThe Silicon Gods e, ven
 speculate that we will be able to put on non-evasive helmets which
 link the brain and computer  directly , skipping body suits and gloves entirely.
  Brett Leonards film Lawnmower Man tells the story of an evolving VR technology
 that synergizes with biofeedback and nootrophic drugs, permiting its pioneer explorer 
access to the electronic nervous system of earth, freeing him from the constraints of his body --
 and his humanity.

As in lucid dreaming and psychedelic exploration, the goal in VR is the freedom
 to create and to explore realities without bounds. Its goal may be achieved sometime
 in the early decades of the new Millennium. And mystics must note the similarity of the
 Net to ideas of  the nooesphere  (the concept of an emerging "world mind")  of
 Tiliehard De Chardain, and easterner Sri Aurobindo speculations about human
 consciousness evolving in this same direction of global consciousness.  

In the mid-Sixties, scientist John Lilly,  MD,. built the first sensory
 deprivation tank while working on a National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH)
 project in the Virgin Islands.  Sensory deprivation is, as the name implies, a state in
 which all of our normal senses are almost entirely restricted.  Earlier studies had shown
 that experimental subjects would report hallucinations when confined in rooms
 with no stimulus for several days. 

Lilly built a coffin-like tank that circulated salt water at body temperature
 and included a lid to shut out light and sound.  In salt water, humans float and so taking  
a sensory deprivation session is often called floating.  

Lillys excursions into the tank confirmed earlier reports of hallucinatory
 mental journeys while in sensory deprivation.  Perhaps it is no
 coincidence that NIMH had also handed John Lilly some LSD --with instructions
 never to take it alone.  He told me, in an interview in 1971, that the
 reason for this was that another researcher had taken it alone, and had to
 be rescued when he thought that his heart had turned into an cuckoo clock and was
 striking the hour.  This caused a major scandal at NIMH.

Lilly ignored the warnings and his experiences and resultant mapping
 of consciousness as revealed by sensory deprivation and psychedelic compounds
 became the subject of a number of his books, including Programming
 and Metaprogramming the Human Biocomputer, The Deep Self, Center of
 the Cyclone and his recent second autobiography, John Lilly...So Far published
 in 1991 by J.P. Tarcher Books  In each, sensory depr vation experiences, with
 or without powerful augmentation by large does of Ketamine or LSD, became
 a way in Lilly was able to Fix a hole where the rain gets in and stops his mind
 from wandering, as the Beatles once sang.

Another fascinating area in which the consciousness is freed to take new direction
 has been reported by people having Near Death Experiences (NDE).  These are
 people who have had a close brush with death, but survived.  The reports from these
 individuals traverses a wide range of experiences and are reported on in books by
 Raymond Moody and Kenneth Ring. Like the other experiences we have considered,
 these NDE experiences free one up from normal worldly constraints and  provide for a
 much wider range of experience than we enjoy here on Planet Earth. The experiences
 reported seem unusually close to transpersonal experiences catalyzed by psychedelics.

One last consciousness-changing technology that I will mention is purely theoretical --
 nanotechnology.  Nanotechnology as a popular notion was first popularized by Eric Drexler
 in his book, Engines of Creation.  It proposes that as robot machines become smaller and smaller,
 eventually we will get to the point where they can reconstruct the world according to instructions
 given by humans.  By manipulating subatomic particles, these robots can do the work that chemists
 do but without the usual barriers that chemistry presents us with, in which complex routes to
 synthesize chemicals must be invented and through which some transformations are impossible. 

Some nanotechnologists speculate that eventually, we can send tiny robots to the DNA
 of humans themselves, allowing us to reconstruct ourselves through nanotechnology
 aided genetic engineering.  We could also have these machines reconstruct the material
 world itself according to our specifications.  We may learn to shape the world as a sculpture
 shapes a statute.

Why do we do it?  What is the purpose human experience of these human experiences,
 whether intentional or accidental, which thrust us into new and unfamiliar realities? 
 Certainly these other modes of conscious experience are not all pleasant, which is perhaps
 why Huxley named the sequel to Doors of Perception, Heaven and Hell.   Yet, like the
 microscope or telescope, they allow us glimpses into parts of the universe and ourselves
 that we previously may not have known to exist.

As in the senses of hearing or vision, Information coming back from a variety of sources
 gives an added dimension to our experience.  We see or hear in stereo, and this give
s things depth.  Getting high and seeing things from a variety of views gives us an experience
 of relativity.  And it is through this relativistic way of viewing reality that we can get a inkling
 of what ithe fabric of life is really all about. 

 Getting high also challenges the very fabric of mind. Classic psychological theorist Sigmund 
 Freud, called these kinds of experiences "regression" in service of the ego.   According to
 Freud, these mind-adventures are excursions into the realm of the id, or infantile awareness
, for the benefit of the adult personality.   Jung disputed this view, stating that these experiences
 were spiritual in nature and helps us get in touch with our collective unconscious in the same way
 that psychotherapy helped us get in touch with our personal unconscious. 

 It was left for contemporary psychological theorist Ken Wilber to explain the relationship
 and finally reconcile these two polar views in his book Eye to Eye:  the Quest for a
 New Paradigm, Wilber shows that Freud and Jung have staked out territories on both sides
 of what he calls the "pre-trans fallacy." This fallacy, to capsulize Wilber,  is that there is a
 great deal of confusion when looking at altered states of consciousness and individual growth. 
 This confusion is between experiences which transcend the ego and those that are regressions
 from it into more primitive or less evolutionary modes of functioning.  

Transcendental experiences are experiences that go beyond the ego but also continue of
 maintain and  encompass the ego.  Transcendental experiences are based upon solid foundation
 of life in the world, or  "chopping wood and carrying water" as the Zen Buddhists  put it. 
 For those with no strong foundations, altered states might lead downward into more primitive
 and barbaric states of mind -- "the pre" portion of the "pre-trans" split.  Thus the warning should
 be given:  make sure that when you reach for the sky that your feet be planted firmly on
 the ground. 

The key point made and affirmed by both Freud and Jung also, is that the development of
 the ego is an absolutely necessary requirement for healthy human functioning.  In the 
 transcendence of the ego  it is important that the experience be given time and space to be
 reintegrated in to ordinary life, or we become "spaced-out" not capable of functioning in the
 world.  And if we weren't supposed to function in the world, what are we doing here anyway?

If you find all of this hard to understand, then the key to the confusion may lie in the term "ego",
 which has as many meanings as "love" or "God" or any of those other  words people are alway
s trying to define but which they can never quite seem to agree upon.  In the '60s, we talked
 about "ego-death" as the ultimate act of mind.  John Lennon once commented, after reading
 the Psychedelic Experience and taking acid a few hundred times, he didn't even realize
 who he was or that he had written all of those great songs for awhile.  

But "ego-death," no matter how intensively experienced, always leads to "ego rebirth." 
 And why shouldn't it, since the ego is not some undesirable thing that has to be gotten rid of.
  It is the very vehicle which allows us safe passage through life.

 We also link ego with "egotistical," as with the person who is always patting themselves on the
 back verbally in front of others or putting on airs.  But having a strong ego in the psychological
 sense doesn't have anything to do with that either.

The father of self-actualization theory, Carl Jung believed that  as a person becomes self-actualized,
  first there needs to be a healthy ego developed.  But then, after it's proper establishment takes place,
 there is a turning away from "ego-centeredness" toward the development of the self, of which
 the ego is only a part. He called this process "self-actualization."

The question of why  we get high translates into "why do we want to transcend our
 ordinary awareness and what purpose does this transcendence have in our evolutionary
 development."

Ron Siegal never actually tried to account for the reasons for his proposed "fourth drive" 
 But Andrew Weil and Winfried Rosen listed a variety of reasons for searching for a high,  
These included:  to aid religious practices, to explore the self, to alter moods, to treat disease,
 to escape boredom and despair, to promote and enhance social interaction, to enhance sensory
 experience and pleasure, to stimulate artistic creativity and performance, to improve physical
performance, to rebel, to go along with peer pressure, and to establish a unique identity.

In writing my book Ecstasy: The MDMA Story I was forced to face the question of why people
 get high head on, with respect to one drug in particular, MDMA or "Ecstasy" as it is popularly
 refereed to these days.  I came up with four primary reasons people use this enormously pleasant
 (for most) psychoactive compound.  These were:  therapeutic, creativity-enhancement,
 self-actualization and recreation.  Ww might  examine each of these in terms of the more
 general question:  "Why do we get high.

Certainly, psychotherapy as is it currently constituted is an art more than a science. 
  One thing that became clear to me:  psychotherapy seems to change it's language and
 theoretical framework every few years.  New buzzwords and truisms quickly become adopted
 by the members of the psychological profession.   For one cohort of psychologists, early childhood
 development is the "cause" of all their patients' problems,  A few years later, a generation of
 psychologists proclaim that only the present moment should be talked about.  Then later, the
 pendulum swings the other way. Therapy and it's parent psychology are obviously in their early
 infancy  as far understanding and controlling the human mind and nervous system.

Transpersonal experience and other altered states of consciousness  induced by hypnosis, meditation
, guided imagery, psychoactive compounds and a variety of other means of inducing  are certainly
 part of the repertoire of a small minority of current psychotherapists.  These psychotherapists and
 psychiatrists feel more akin to the shaman of tribal cultures or perhaps the gurus or teachers of India
 (although I doubt many psychotherapists would accept this  label willingly) than to their colleagues. 
 They view their role as helping a client to get in tune with their own unconscious by serving as
 guides on their life's journey. 

In tribal cultures, the shaman or medicine man usually takes a plant drug, often a psychedelic
, and goes on a vision quest where they  enter into alternative realities from which they
 can heal members of their tribes or perform other kinds of magic.  

In the modern version of shamanism practiced by transpersonal therapists, the individual
 in search of healing is usually given the psychoactive medicine, whether it is plant derived
 or one of the new and powerful synthetic compounds and is guided on their own vision quest
.  The modern shaman does not usually take the psychoactive medicine with their clients
 (however a small percentage do).  But every one of these new breed of healers has to
 have experience with mind-changing medicines themselves before they can lead others
 on their journeys..

Here, the goal is to have the medicine open up alternative states of consciousness where
 they can gain insights and visions to help them in their ordinary lives.  Certainly there is
 no agreement on the exact mechanism by which they achieve this purpose, but many
 U.S. Government-sanctioned studies have demonstrated the effectiveness of what researchers
 refer to as "psychedelic therapy." Psychedelic therapy which uses one or a few high-dose
 psychedelic sessions, aimed at producing the transpersonal experience, has been demonstrated
 to be useful in the treatment of alcoholism, severe neurosis, heroin addiction and the trauma o
f terminal cancer, in a series of studies conducted mostly in the 'Sixties and Seventies. "

In the mid-'Seventies to mid-'Eighties, therapists took advantage of the lack of illegality of
 a more gentle psychoactive compound known as MDMA. MDMA therapeutic session
s aimed at treating less severe disorders. The experiences produced by MDMA or Ecstasy
 involve much less sensory distortion than those produced by major psychedelics such as LSD.  

MDMA helps individuals  access a state of consciousness in which they  view their existence in
 the world as different.  People report that the external world seems brighter, more perfect and lighter
 than usual.  They also find it easier to open up with other and express their real feelings.  Inwardly
, they feel more relaxed, their self-esteem increases, and they feel a lifting of the pressures of time.

In therapy, MDMA has been used successfully in marriage and couples therapy
, post-traumatic-stress-disorder and in trauma produced by terminal disease to name
 just a small number of uses already found.  Again, the new breed of shamans use
 their clients experiences in an alternative state of consciousness as a means of healing. 

The major psychedelics, MDMA and marijuana--which some consider a
 minor psychedeliic--nd even stimulants and narcotics have been used in the quest
 to enhance creativity both in the arts and in problem-solving.

The Beats, with their excesses and excursions into the realm of drug-induced creativity,
 were not the first but certainly now the most well known and respected of those who
 experimented with the written word while "high."  In fact, it was the Beats who invented
 the word.  Allen Ginsberg, William Burroughs and Jack Kerouc, now three of the most
 respected literary figures of the 20th Century smoked marijuana almost as a religion as well,
 as dabbling in writing while on peyote, LSD, the opiates and amphetamine.

Peter Stafford, in his first book, LSD--The Problem Solving Psychedelic  documents  the last
 LSD study conducted in 1966,  shortly before the compound was made illegal.  Performed by 
Willis Harman, current head of the Institute of Noetic Sciences, then at the Stanford Research
 Institute, In the experiment , small doses of mescaline were given to engineers.  The engineesr
 were given assignments to develop an alternative to the record player for reproducing sound.
  The CD wasn't born that day but certainly the unique solutions proposed by this group of
 engineers illustrate the way that mind-changers shift your view, allowing for the emergence
 of natural creativity.

Earlier, Oscar Janiger, founder of the Albert Hofmann Foundation, had his LSD subjects
 paint an Indian Kachina doll before and while under influence of the compound. The 
experiments yielded fascinating paintings, some of which are now worth many thousands
 of dollars because the subjects have since become famous artists. 

Ecstasy too has had its artistic adherents.  A study of creative writing was done during MDMA'
 grace period--before criminalization--with at least promising anecdotal evidence of success
 in increasing creative output.  

In creativity, as in the previously-discussed use in therapy, the chief mechanism is entrance
 of the individual into another state of consciousness where they might have an  insight, have a
 feeling, see a vision, hear a voice or get a unique perspective which they then bring back to
 the world by way of pictures, words or music.

Psychologist Abraham Maslow, introduced earlier, coined the word "self-actualization" to
 describe the next important use of intoxication.  Maslow gave birth to new schools of
 psychology, which he called "humanistic" and  "transpersonal."  A major theme in humanisti
c psychology is that psychologists should study healthy and exceptional people rather than
 only those with mental problems.  Up until then, abnormal psychology was THE psychology

 Instead, he saw a continuum starting with those who were mentally ill through the range
 of more normal individuals and ending with the "self-actualized" individual at the other end.  

These self-actualized individuals were those exceptional people in our society who came
 up with the great theories. produced exceptional novels or art works, were the leaders and 
successful business-men and so forth.  These were the people whose lives Maslow thought we 
should examine.  Along with Jung's notion of self-realization, this idea of self-actualization marked
 a new direction in the study of human consciousness, one that had roots in the myths and religions o
f cultures around the world but which until then had been mostly ignored by western science.

During the past half century, there has been a surge of interest in this "spiritual search." Ram Dass,
 whose life's work and teaching on the spiritual journey has made him one of the most popular
 lecturers in America, notest on his trips though the U.S.. that when he talks about spiritual experience
, he finds that the crowds have changed.  In the 'Sixties and though much of the 'Seventies
, it was the young Baby Boomers, the Children of the 'Sixties who came to see him.  

But more recently, the audience has become more diverse. Not only do the Boomers come
, but people from many generations and all walks of life. In one of his Mid-Western lecture
s when talking about a very profound experience he had in India, Ram Dass noticed a old woman
 nodding knowingly as he described his mind-adventure.  Later, the woman came up to the stage 
to greet him Ram Das took her aside and asked her how she knew about experiences such a
s he was describing.  She smiled back at Ram Dass after the question, and said, "I crochet."

Experiences called "spiritual"  did not start, of course, with Ram Dass or Maslow or LSD. 
 They go back to the earliest of recorded history, where  certain individuals  have reported
 mystical experiences including saints, artists and many other happy people.  
 These have been documented in works like Huxley's Perennial Philosophy and Bucke's
 Cosmic Consciousness..  What is remarkable is that what was once referred to  by Western
 mystics as the "beatific vision" has been translated by moderns into "getting high."  But the
 experience remains largely the same.

The vision quest, like excursions from the mundane for therapy or creativity, is a process.
  The individual seeks to experience states of consciousness beyond the ordinary, and t
 bring back that vision to help guide their own life and inspire the lives of others.

The last category of uses which I discussed in my book is currently the least socially-sanctioned..
.but perhaps the most important.  That is the "recreational" uses of getting high.
  Again, one can go in two directions, and certainly it must be acknowledged that there
 are those who should never try a mind-altering substances and many who abuse them 
with destructive consequences.  

Peter Stafford, in an article in the  Journal of Psychoactive Drugss' 
 special issue, "LSD in Retrospect," notes, "Adaptation of the term "recreational"
 by the government has about it a connotation that such experiences are rather trivial
, frivolous and/or of  a rather vulgar and lower order nature.  In fact however, the
 impressions conveyed by most individuals engaged in such activities with LSD seem
 to have been to the effect that the consequences have been of a higher order. 
 The bulk of those responding have repeatedly indicated that they thought that
 their use of LSD has been among the most important experience of their lives
 and that the drug's effects have been re-creational {author's italics].

Stafford's transformation of "recreation" to "re-creation" is not elaborated on
, but I believe that it is essential to the understanding of what I consider the
 primary significance of the drive to get high.  This basic urge has as its underpinnings
 the desire to recreate ourselves as we wish to be rather than how the seemingly random events 
of life mold us.  Certainly many developmental theories recognize that although endowed at  birth with
 certain potentials, we are, in a way, "programmed" by our experiences.  Whether you follow the
 eastern schools and call it "liberation" or the western and call it personal growth, psychoactive drugs,
 most specifically those considered mind-expanding, have been part of the repertoire developed.

Biologist Ralph Berger once commented that humans might better be called Homo Ludens 
 than Homo Sapian.  Homo Sapian means "thinking man". while Homo Lundens  names
 our species "playful man."  He argued for the later term because while every one of the
 more-developed animal species plays, humans play for a much longer proportion of their life
 span than any other creature with the exception perhaps of the whales and dolphins, 
which some argue play their entire life.  

Most of us don't realize it,  but play is essential for learning and growth.
 Play is a highly creative behavior in which we act out our fantasies.  
By doing so, we learn many of the behaviors which grow more complex and evolve into our
 "grown up" culture and civilization.

In fact, the philosopher Alan Watts when discussing the heights of
 Vaspasana Hindu insight that he has experienced through psychedelics and  meditation in his work, 
The Book on the Taboo Against Knowing Who You Are ,described the entire evolution of the
 universe by the Hindu term Maya , or "play."  What is all of this play for, what is it good for.
  The answer that he gave was that it is all art, like a good piece of music or an admired painting.  
 It is to be enjoyed, and that is why the universe evolved consciousness.  Consciousness is simply the  universe 
appreciating its uniqueness and the wonder of its unfolding playful creation.  

We can get high for therapy, spiritual growth, pleasure,  or creativity
 but the key element that makes getting high so useful is that it allows us, as adults, to play.
  Externally, our relationship with others and the environment changes and becomes more novel
 and experimental. Internally we consider our thoughts and emotions in a new light,
 or from a new and "higher" level.  

By opening this doorway into a way of being which is essentially more playful, it enables
 us to "deprogram" ourselves, to rid ourselves of habitual acts and stultified ways of seeing things.
 We try on new behaviors and modes  of thought the same way an actor dons a costume and mask. 
  This breaks us free of our earlier programming, and allows us to consciously choose
 to become who we want to be and to think what we will.  

Often , the mystical or spiritual experience is talked about in terms of th
e individual experiencing themselves as "god."  Instead of god out there, god
 become located in ourselves as well as in everything else.  And, as we become god,
we can "recreate" ourselves in our own image.

Those who write about mind-changing compounds have always recognized this
 core purpose of drug-taking.  Bouldiare called it entering an "artificial paradise."
  Peter Stafford refers MDMA sessions as an occation for "mini-vacations." 
 The youth these days ccall it "raving." And of course the hippies in the 'Sixties when
 on LSD, "took a trip." Their destination, a place of magic and mystery,
 where they could  imagine
 a better, more peaceful world. A place where we can play peacefully.

On Fri, 19 May 1995 Sindar@aol.com wrote:

>  sfraves is such a "politicaly correct" list when it comes to party
> reviews...  maybe this has to do with the promoter presance? 

	I would think it goes along with a phrase I personally do not 
like "It's all good". I do not think there is any corralation to 
promoters being on the net, more of a lack of people who have an ok or a 
shite time just not wanting to deal with people getting angry (and 
getting e-mail being told to be more positive).


>  the problem I see with
> the SF scene is that there are too many rules now.  It is almost to the point
> that if you don't medditate before you go to arave you are not a "true"
> raver.  The scene here has lost a lot of energy...  more so than other parts
> of the country. 

	When Tristan first posted stuff about the F&F in March, I saw a
lot of this. There have been/are still a lot of times when I am out, that
the vibe holds a if-you-don't-have-a-big-grin-on-your-face-you-are-
being-negative quality to it. I don't attribute it the "scene" losing 
energy; if you find the right people and the music to suit them, things 
happen. Well, maybe the scene as a whole is losing energy, or maybe the 
memories are being romanticized as the novelity wears off so some. I 
would agree there are more "rules" now and things are not so dark with 
the spine of power which every human neuron once connected into as the 
music washed over them (damn it). This is what I had thought of sunset 
last year (here come the flames) because by the time I was getting my ass 
down to the marina, all the image had invaded the place (it seemed I was 
always walking in behind a group of people talking about how dope they 
had while hiding their bottle of Mickey's or St. Ides in their coats... 
makes a wonderful first introduction to something people are saying is 
the best thing to hit this area in a long time).
	Someone had said something a little while back about enforced 
PLUR, but it had just been laughed off because how could anyone have too 
many hugs or whatever. Yeah, and how could anyone have too many good nazi 
ideals? I mean really, make yourself and everyone like you feel really 
great and all... Because nazi ideals are horrible... Not when they are 
favoring you. Because people don't think about what is they are doing and 
why they are doing it and how it might affect others. Ok, so enforced 
PLUR does hurt anyone (so we like to believe) if my last comment there is 
ignored, but PLUR is empty if people don't think about what they are 
doing and why they are doing it. Like the thread about e changing people 
so that they are acting in ways they would not act sober. All of that I 
think is happening more and more. And I think it really does degrade the 
"rave scene". I seem to fuming my pent up angers with what I have been 
seeing for the last 4 months. 

>  I mean god forbid anyone play
> anything techno...  it's gotta be DEEP or super deep spiritula tribal trance.

	Do you consider gabber techno? If so, you just have to find the 
right places... Though I cannot say everyone was going off the last time 
I saw people dancing to good ol' 190 bpm music...

>  I think a lot of people droped out of the scene because too many new age or
> whatever things were being pushed on them.  Remember raves when ther were no
> "rules" no politicaly correct social image?  That was when EVERYONE could
> come and just be.  That is what makes that old time rave feeling happen...

	This I can see in one sense, but no matter how one tries, there 
is going to be some statement other people can infer from what that one 
was/is doing. So were they ever free of political nonsense or were they 
just immune to it internally?

	Hopefully there are a few thoughts worthy of ponderment within my 
typical load of dribble...

dave

>>  I mean god forbid anyone play
>> anything techno...  it's gotta be DEEP or super deep spiritula tribal trance.
>
>        Do you consider gabber techno? If so, you just have to find the
>right places... Though I cannot say everyone was going off the last time
>I saw people dancing to good ol' 190 bpm music...

Gabber isn't the only kind of techno.  there is a alot of good techno that
doesn't get any play in SF simply because it is techno.  What about
Underground Resistance, Richie Hawtin, Dave Clark, Carl Craig, Rob Hood,
Dan Bell (DBX), Kenny Larkin, Juan Atkins, Paul Johnson and the entire
Chicago underground, the list goes on.... It seems like if you mention
techno in SF, people look at you funny.. They think you bang your head to
the sound of 190 bpm chainsaws with overdriven 909 bass ontop; or they
think Moby is techno.  I remember sitting in a restaurant talking about
this exact topic and the waitress butted in (without knowing what we were
talking about) and said 'yeah I know.. you cannot tell people that theyr'e
playing techno, you gotta call it tribal or something.. People in SF *hate*
techno'.  It was kinda humorous

Jon

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri May 19 21:42:59 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id VAA12576; Fri, 19 May 1995 21:42:59 -0700

Date: Fri, 19 May 1995 21:37:35 -0700
Message-Id: <199505200437.VAA03092@coyote.rain.org>
Subject: Re: Idealized Community
To: "'Dave Bayer'" <dlb@ocf.Berkeley.EDU>, SFRaves! <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
X-Mailer: AIR Mail 3.X (SPRY, Inc.)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Dave,

I appologize if it appeared that I was trying to present an idealized view of 
our community.  I would like everyone to consider the fact that what we are 
doing, and continually working at doing, takes some effort on an everyday 
basis.  No, its not hard to be nice to people, and smile.  But, sometimes it 
is hard to recognize that you may be in a situation that is not what you 
expected or wanted and make it the best.

I am not trying to minimalize the feelings that Jon had.  I think that it's 
really a shame that he did not enjoy himself.  I also think that its great 
that each person who has the courage, resources (personal, financial, etc) and 
energy goes out there and trys to provide an arena for those of us to come 
together and groove.

>	How can it be based on acceptance, love and understanding if it
>does not acknowlegde that not all things are good?  Granted, one can get
>carried away, but when oter people turn around and flame someone for
>getting carried away, are they not getting carried away themselves? 
>(I think someone pointed that out already though). Shall it become a 
>community based on ideals of acceptance, love, and understanding or just 
>be an accepting, loving, understanding community? 

First off our community needs these ideals to make realities.  I was in no way 
trying to flame or slight Jon's experience.  I must say though that it makes 
me sad when I see people on the defensive on subjects and a series of 
arguments (more the negative type than logical) ensue.  This is not the way to 
come together.  We can freely share are dissapointments, anger and love.  All 
of this requires acceptance.  We need to hear what the other person is saying. 
 This is often hard via email and requires added reading.  What I felt reading 
Jon's posts was that he was upset because he felt that he had a bad time and 
then this was only accelerated by a method of cross talk which put him on the 
defensive.  I am not claiming that anything anyone said was right or wrong.  I 
only hoped that acknowledging, honestly, that I understood and could relate to 
what he was saying and trying to help turn the situation around could help 
bring back that good feeling vibe.  There is nothing in the world like 
groovin' on the inside...with people you love and that sweet bass!

If for any reason I failed either to enact the principles I believe so deeply 
in or live them, I appologize, or if I merely misconstrued them.

To all:  Have a fukengruven weekend!  Let the vibe move you through each 
moment and seize life by the reigns.  It's all what we make of it and I plan 
on making it better than I ever dreamed.

I am so glad that we are us and you are you! :)

just to go on a bandwith binge

Love Anais
bliss@rain.org

> country because of the _heavy_ emphasis on the spiritual side of raves,  I

much to do with the scene losing energy... for example, friends and 
family has its "spiritual" side with altars, etc. and there is certainly 
A LOT of energy there...also YSH was a pumping party and it had its 
altars, etc.  

and i seem to find A LOT of techno  and harder trance in sf, but maybe i 
 just know where to look...(in fact, i don't think i get ENOUGH tribal and 
house in my life - got to get out to deco on weds more, at least for the
house ...)  i think one segmentof promoters in sf focuses on "DEEP super 
spiritual tribal trance" but there's a lot more than that...

I think a lot of people droped out of the scene because too many new age or
> whatever things were being pushed on them.  Remember raves when ther were no
> "rules" no politicaly correct social image?  That was when EVERYONE could
> come and just be.  That is what makes that old time rave feeling happen...
>  not crystals or alters (those work for some people but not everyone wants to
> be involved with that)  Old raves had this danything goes vibe that let
> people forget about all the bullshit images that they normaly felt required
> to uphold,   now SF raving has it's own image to uphold.  Watch out!  If you
> don't fit in with our idea of what a great spiritual thing rave "is" then we
> think you are neg energy and we don't wanna talk to you...  From talking to


again, i think there are A LOT of parties in sf, and not all of them have 
a  "spiritual" side...

i happen to like making altars and throwing parties with a pagan 
(not "new age") emphasis 
(celebrating the season, pagan holidays, etc.) myself, but i'm not trying 
to bring back an "ole time rave feeling" or anything... i'm trying to do 
w something new and integrate the rave trance experience with my 
spiritual practice...however, i don't want to "force" this on anyone...i 
prefer to make it clear when i throw a party what it is celebrating, and 
i expect anyone who is not interested or who would not be open and 
respectful to stay home or go elsewhere...

however, i have noticed, at least on sfraves, a kind of, oh, how shall i 
put it? "happiness fascism?"  "happy correctness?"  like if you go to a 
party you're supposed to be spreading positive  energy ALL the time... i 
like sharing positive energy, but i don't always feel very happy when i'm 
out at a party... sometimes i'm tired...sometimes i'm in pain ...sometimes i don't 
i don't deal with large crowds and become anti-social... but gaia-forbid i 
i spread 
"negative energy" by not forcing a smile or jumping up and down gleefully 
 sometimes i just go out to hear good musick and if i'm lucky i 
start feeling better (ecstatic even!) as the evening wears on... because 
, and i'm going to sound therapeutic here but what the fuck, as people 
we need 
to feel and acknowledge our feelings and not force ourselves to 
pretend everything's hunky-dorey (sp?) andd rave-y and happy and all 
that when we just don't feel it...

take care,
monicat

On Fri, 19 May 1995, Niels P. Mayer wrote:

> Fraser Clark <fraser@megatripolis.org>: 
> what's really interesting is that obviously a lot of monkeys chose  *not* 
> to try the mushrooms and *all* humans are descended from monkeys who took 
> psychedelic mushrooms for generations (according to terence, this is) 
> 
> I often feel when i'm playing with a few freinds that those other monkeys 
> are still hanging out up in their trees and shouting down to us "don't 
> touch that stuff, come on back up in the trees, it's not *safe* down 
> there! don't mess with that evolution stuff" 

> > On the other hand (devils advocate here), look at how bad "our" group 
> of monkeys have messed up the earth. I don't think the monkeys in the 
> trees have ever knowingly and willingly killed ecosystems, perpretrated 
> mass genocide, invent and *use* weapons of mass destruction against 
> themselves.... 

> > But maybe that's because we lost our way as "modern culture" (or 
> whatever it is that we've been doing for the last 4000 years) led us 
> down the garden path... forcing us to stray too far from that mushroom 
> patch / garden of eden. 
> 

other way round, niels!  according to terence (and it's certainly the most
believable version of early history I've ever heard) the first species of
psychedelicise3d monkeys spread a civilisaztion acrosss algeria and east
to the middle east and north as far, I think, as the west coast of ireland
but then ran out of regular mushroom contact. 

this early species was tribal groupmind-oriented, monthly full moon orgy
celebrations where "everyone humped in a heap".  communal in that nobody
knew their father etc. also (and here I may be going somewhat into my own
vision of it) all decisions were made unanimously by the whole tribe. 

so imagine the disaster when full moon comesand the shaman (who has
emerged as the keeper of the mushrooms around which the entire culture
revolves) has to annouce "we have no mushrooms".  so they drink the beer
which was actually from the honey they used to preserve the mushrooms,
fermented mead really.  but how much good would that actually have done? 

anyway by the time the third full moon comes around (and still no
mushrooms) group decisions are being held up by lack of general sense of
agreement.  (oh yes, terence claims that the mushroom prevents the growth
of the ego which he sees as a cancerous tumor on the human p0syche) so all
these egos are starting up. 

finally, I reckon, some teenage male leaps up in frsutration at all the
different opinions and announces that he for one is going off to do
whatever and he doesn't care who comes with him.  as he pounds off I see
an ancient crone of a female psychedelicised monkey screeching: 

"DON'T GO!  DON'T BREAK THE CIRCLE!" 

the young male turns: "why not? what's so fuckin' sacred about the
circel?" 

"war, suffering and strife, you'll see, you'll see!"  she croaks, 
unable to express her natural psychedelic knowledge in words.

and so what we call "History"  began, a new species evolved and set forth
on a career of invasions, looting, dominance, subjugation of woman and the
psychedelic side, agriculture and cities and competition and ... the
history of EGO.  right up to the present day.  now the species must remake
the Sacred Circle (Cooperation). and that, for those fretting that this is
off-subject, is exactly where Rave Culture comes in. 



> > PS: I hear there's an upcoming movie called "Twelve Monkeys", and I 
> vaguely recall hearing something w/r/t the concept of the "twelfth
> monkey" mentioned on this list a while ago. I even more vaguely
> remember that this was from some book that someone found rave-relevant
> or inspiring.  The movie is about a time travelling dude that hunts

you probably mean The Hundredth Monkey which has nothing to do with any 
movie called 12 Monkeys.
Very very very briefly scientists on an island studying a colony of 
monkeys found that a new eating parttern spread one by one until a 
certain critical mass was reached at which point ALL the monkeys changed 
their behaviour overnight.  They called the principle The HUndredth 
Monkey Principle.  these scientists also reproted that all the monkey 
colonies on other nearby islands also changed on the same day but some 
doubts have been raised about this.

the RC connection is that, as a new cooperative culture achieves critical 
mass, YOU could be the Hundredth Monkey that kicks it all loose.  :-)

fraser
