Dear All;

	Friday the 19th of May, 1995 had to be the most boring day in SF 
rave history. Even at 1015 Folsum I didn't regonize a sole, let a lone 
the vibe. I kept asking myself if I was in the wrong place or not, it 
looked like the Sound Factory, and no I was doin acid, I wish, oh maybe 
not. Lots o suits, old, old people and button down shirts, with straight 
legs, it was fuckin werid. Maybe I was in the wrong place or just 
illinformed, I think I was in hell, the music was bad to, no offense, but 
it just wasn't there ***for me**** lastnight. I left at 3am, dats earlly 
early for me. Well, I guess ya gotta have the SUCK nights along with the 
good ones, god, how bad can it get though. If anyone else had similar 
experiences please do let me know. I'm really confused, considering I 
knew about 30 people there last Friday, and the fRiday before last ...etc 
and had a great time, go figure.


		Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace

> the SF scene is that there are too many rules now.  It is almost to the point
> that if you don't medditate before you go to arave you are not a "true"
> raver.  The scene here has lost a lot of energy...  more so than other parts
> of the country.  Yes I know there are still good things goin on but I would
> love to talk to someone who can _show_ me that it is still goin off like it
> was 2 years ago. (and I do not mean just one party but the scene as a whole)
>  SF is considered to be different by most people than other parts of the
> country because of the _heavy_ emphasis on the spiritual side of raves,

As anyone who was going out 2 or more years ago can tell you there was
even _more_ emphasis on the spiritual side of raving then, then there
is now, many of them will tell you that it has gone down hill because this
is not the focus today, if you don't believe me just read the SFR archives 
from that period.  Also don't confuse spirit with religion.



{stuff deleted]

> anything techno...  it's gotta be DEEP or super deep spiritula tribal trance.
>  I think a lot of people droped out of the scene because too many new age or
> whatever things were being pushed on them.  Remember raves when ther were no
> "rules" no politicaly correct social image?  That was when EVERYONE could
> come and just be.  That is what makes that old time rave feeling happen...
>  not crystals or alters (those work for some people but not everyone wants to
> be involved with that)  Old raves had this danything goes vibe that let
> people forget about all the bullshit images that they normaly felt required
> to uphold,   now SF raving has it's own image to uphold.

Well some parties had crystals and alters 3 years ago and some didn't.
I distinctly remember seeing god with my head in a bass bin 3 1/2 years
ago listing to the hardest techno :) so it doesn't have to be deep or
tribal to be spiritually moving.  I must admit that it is easier to go
into trance with deep or tribal stuff and for me as well as many others
IT'S ALL ABOUT TRANCE.  New raves like the old ones still have an anything
goes attitude as long as you respect the other party goers.  I think if new age
is not your thing then fine, I don't recall anyone requiring anybody
to be into _any_ thing spiritual at any party.  If you just want good music
without the overtones there are plenty of good parties that don't take
that bent.  Try Funky Techno Tribe or Spundaes, the music at these parties
are generally good and they aren't into all the crystal stuff.

>  Watch out!  If you
> don't fit in with our idea of what a great spiritual thing rave "is" then we
> think you are neg energy and we don't wanna talk to you...  From talking to
> other people around the country I don't think this attittude is as bad as it
> is in SF.  I think it is great Jon said what he really felt!  I do not care
> if most SF ravers consider it bad karma to be neg. about any party...  go
> ahead and disagree with Jon that is fair too...  I just think it is week to
> attack him for being "neg."  I would think all of you "possitive" ravers
> would want to help poor negative jon with some possitive vibes: )
> See ya
> Rob
> 

Well since were on the subject, no I don't think it's bad for Jon
to post his feelings but I have also been doing a lot of soul searching
about this subject and I have come up with the following questions for
myself and others.

	"In the old days" folks were more open to going to something
	that they didn't already know about, why isn't that the norm
	today?

	What would it be like if every person that came to a "bad party"
	felt that it was their personal duty to generate enough vibe to
	turn the party around?

At 1:04 AM 5/20/95, Fraser Clark wrote:

>you probably mean The Hundredth Monkey which has nothing to do with any
>movie called 12 Monkeys.
>Very very very briefly scientists on an island studying a colony of
>monkeys found that a new eating parttern spread one by one until a
>certain critical mass was reached at which point ALL the monkeys changed
>their behaviour overnight.  They called the principle The HUndredth
>Monkey Principle.  these scientists also reproted that all the monkey
>colonies on other nearby islands also changed on the same day but some
>doubts have been raised about this.
>
>the RC connection is that, as a new cooperative culture achieves critical
>mass, YOU could be the Hundredth Monkey that kicks it all loose.  :-)

>fraser

        I have a short article written by Colin Wilson dealing with two
different theories, one of which being that of 'morphic resonance' which is
the 'hundredth monkey' thing.  It's quite interesting and pretty short so
if there are no problems with me posting it, it'll be in yer mailbox later
today.
        I've heard that that the monkey island thing has been explained by
'real' theory..it's highly disputed but i've had difficulty trying to find
more info on it.
        Morphic resonance and the 'critical mass' theory is also mentioned
in mc kenna's "archaic revival" p. 212, as well as being one of the
insights in James Redfield's 'The celestine prophecy'
        I think it's neat :)

Precedence: bulk


Every moment only happens once in a lifetime... Wow!  I have never heard
that one.  A very cool little thought and true to life.  But in reading into
it a bit I'd say that the physical moment will pass depending on the time
frame of a moment but the context of that moment can be felt and enjoyed
throughout ones life.  It's not the actual moment but rather what is gained
from the time in that moment that counts.  You see, everything is a memory
and therefore each moment constitutes a memory.  Each of these memories can
be compiled into an experience.  I'd say that an experience can happen over
and over again and enjoyed over and over again.  Humm.  This experience may
not be the same but the compiled moments may.  And therefore these various
moments can be enjoyed continiously throught compiled experiences.  A
lifetime full of compiled moments and experiences.

With all that said it sounds very much like one must live in the past
(mind).  Well, not exactly.  You see, it's what's gained that sticks, not
the time in which it happened.  

Neat.  I like the way that sounds.  I think that I'll make a note of that
somewhere in my steel memory >Right :)<


Bye-Bye

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Dana Watanabe <dwatanab@hydra.acs.uci.edu>
Subject: Re: dust & negativ club reviews
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (sfraves@hyperreal.com)
Date: Fri, 19 May 95 16:29:32 PDT

       ,
(wow. dana has free time to post to sfraves. my shock. not yours.)

I've been thinking about this quite a bit recently,
because on the Socal list, more and more promoters and what
not are happening on to the list and i wonder how that is
changing the dynamics of it all.

I think there is a difference between saying 
"Don't post bad things about my friend's club"
and saying 
"Hey, i know the person who does that club, and..."

A lot of people on this list are heavily involved in SF
and know a lot of the people who throw clubs,
therefore they know a lot of the background info that 
is behind some of the clubs.  

When i first got into going to clubs or raves or whatever,
there was this mythical treatment by me and my friends 
of some of the Promoters and DJs.

This brought silly respect for them, but also silly critiques of them.
Saying "Well.. they should have thought about (such and such)
because that is obviously a problem."

For some reason we assumed that the experience they were having
was identical to the one that we were.  Or that SOMEONE
would have told them by now about the problem.

Hell, a friend of mine owns a club space and he is often there when i am,
yet has no idea what type of attitude the door people have
and when i tell him he gets upset.  But few people bother telling him
because they assume thats just how he or whoever wants them to act.

So, while criticism to the list is a good thing, criticism to the promoter
is a much better idea, because i know lots of promoters
who want to not have the problems or who have explanations
that may or may not be acceptable.

Some people are out there just to scam us out of our money
giving us the minimal amount that they can, but a lot of people
want to have good parties where people have a good time.
So people who know those people tend to defend them 
because they know their heart is in the right place.
(Not that having a heart in the right place is
a good replacement for people having a bad time)

 ,
dana

Comment from a student in my Semiotics class, in a discussion 
about words that do or don't take 'S' for pluralization:

"Some words just don't sound right, we don't say 'DATAS' do we?"

REVIEW/RAVE CULTURE/STANFORD 

(The following aarticle is from the Stanford Campus Report.  There are at
least 6 factual mistakes in this article, to say nothing of slight
unintentional distortions, but we decided to leave everything in because
one of the main reasons we publish such articles is to show that the media
are not necessarily our enemies.  Though they may often misunderstand what
is after all a very rich and diverse culture, the thinking Zippy type
understands the crucial importance of media in getting the best aspects of
our culture OUT.)


HEAD            'Ravers dance the sun up and celebrate global cooperation"
by Diane Manuel

The dark blond ponytail was the first clue, but, when he launched into an 
earnest dissertation on social change, cooperation, 'green' issues and 
the doomed planet, there was no doubt.  Fraser Clark is a tie-died-in- 
the-wool '60s hippy.
But Clark hadn't come to campus to talk about the good old Haight and 
harmony of yesterday.  As he leaned towards the microphone and spoke in a 
deep Scottish brogue, he was looking toward the tomorrow that he thinks 
could spring from one of today's fastest growing sub-cultures - the 
all-night dance and music phenomenon known as the rave.
"Ravers are not inventions of old hippie conspirators like me" he told 
300 atttentive students sitting cross-legged on the parquet floor of 
Roble Dance Studio on May 3.  "This is a culture that is exploding all 
through the Western democracies, and we are in for a period of massive 
social change."
Clark told his listeners that he attended his first rave in 1987.  More 
than 20000 people had paid more than $40 each to gather in an open field 
near Manchester, England, with the Big Dipper overhead and a wall of 
sound reverberating for miles around.  "I was probably the only person 
there over 30 and it was very, very exciting."
A guru of underground British culture, Clark is an editor and social 
activist from Glasgow who moved to San Francisco nine months ago to be 
closer to what is fast becoming the new mecca of the international rave 
scene.  He still publishes three magazines on alternative lifestyles and 
is the owner of London's trendy Megatripolis Club and a record company 
that produces music by what he calls "technoshamanic bands".
But Clark is perhaps best known as the founder of the Zippy movement - 
Zen Inspired Pronoia Professionals - an international community whose 
members claim the internet as their country of origin.  Pronoia is the 
lurking suspicion that others are conspiring to help you, and Zippies, 
many of them old hippies, are a gyrating promotional force for raves.
"Is a rave just a party?" Clark asks rhetorically.  "No.  And it's not a 
new dance step either.  It's a new cooperative attitude and culture which 
is spreading very rapidly across the planet."
"There are many people doing good, self-less work today" he continued.  
"This one's saving the robins, this one the whales.  But these are all 
separate causes and we have to find a way to bring everyone into an 
overall paradigm shift.  Rave Culture ofers a way to do that."
As an example Clark pointed to the artistic revival that he sees in 
England today, at a time when Europe is in the grip of an unprecedented 
economic depression.
"Thousands of young people in England today accept that they're never 
going to have a proper job" he said. "And yet I've never seen such 
creativity and imagination.  They're producing magazines, organising 
social protests, painting and putting on exhibitions.
"People in the rave scene are being forced to cooperate out of economic 
necessity" he added.  "This one contributes the music, that one the 
venue, and that one the sound system.  They're realy getting things back 
to a proper balance."
After receiving a degree in psychology in 1965 and learning "more about 
white rats" than he learned about himself, Clark struck off on a 20 year 
trek around the world in search of a hospitable culture.  He ended up 
back in England in the mid '80s where he sat down with a group of 
similarly dissatisfied friends and tried to sketch out what some of the 
"signs" of a coming new order might be.
The hoped-for culture, as Clark conceived it, would be a youth 
phenomenon, feature a new style of music, be linked with nature and a 
return to the countryside, and ultimately would be capable of spreading 
widely and rapidly.  The first rave he attended convinced Clark he had 
found his long lost grail.
"Anyone who's young and intelligent in today's world has to be interested 
in the rave scene, he advised his listeneers, 30 of whom indicated by a 
show of hands that they had attended a rave.  "It shows every sign of 
capturing America over the next year or so, and will soon replace the 
current grunge culture."
Among the many pluses, Clark noted that alcohol is "not the main 
lubricant for ravers".  "Raves are producing a whole generation which is 
simply against alcohol" he argued.  "They just don't drink.  Alcohol and 
the life-attitude that goes with it, are gone."
But what about the new, so-called designer drugs he was asked.
"Any drug taken in the wrong context is bad" Clark said.  "I haven't taken 
Ecstasy myself for about two years. I found it too toxic, and I prefer 
'smart drinks'.  But basically now I don't take anything."  
The fact that Clark and several of Britain's most popular disc jockeys 
recently have moved to the Bay Area prompted questions about the 
commercialism of rave culture.  But Clark contended that there are no 
'stars' on the rave scene, unlike rock'n roll or heavy metal.  DJs, he 
said, are simply the "technoshamans" who follow the moods at a rave.
"They know when to take the music higher or faster, and when to let it 
down.  This is shamanic, tribal, African-style dancing, with people 
waving in the wind like trees, and dancing till their minds are stilled.
"Then, finally, the group mind becomes dominant, and the question becomes 
not 'Who am I?' but 'Who are we?'"  [end]

 Usenet: alt.culture.zippies * The Well: Topic 54, House Conference

Subject: Re: *Moment*
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Good Morning!

> what you gained from it would be irrelivant if you didn't have 
>that moment to gain from. so each moment should be lived fully, 
>rather than relying thon moments passed.

I'd say that moments happen whether or not one plans for them.  To put a
strain upon the enjoying and learning of any given moment is, but, only
setting expectations for future experiences based on learned pasts.  You
see, it's those unexpected times and passing moments that just suprises one
and makes one take a step back.  But if you're attempting to create a "fully
lived" moment then, in effect, you are creating an experience.  These fully
lived experiences are actions and compilations of remembered past moments.
It's hard to say what fully living is unless past moments, in which one has
gained, define what this experience shall entail.  I should think that you
are trying to create an ever expanding/existing experience without letting
random moments to be learned from.  But, in effect, in thinking randomly
about not fully living you are creating a random moment of thought that
expands and creates avenues for thoughts you'll have tomorrow and therefore
allowing for a compiled history of thinking which will, in effect, create an
experience to be treasured (as they all should).

> why is school work so hard to get oneself to do?

Well.  It's not very hard actually.  It seems that perceptions about "school
work" has taken effect in almost all students that ential unhappiness.  All
it takes is taking a step back and looking to past experiences and moments
of learning.  I know that you may not be in "the mood" but look at it this
way.  Inside those books hold a treasure of knowledge.  This treasure
anables one to draw parallels to current thoughts and experiences.  These
parallels help us all get along and understand each other... Even the most
remote mathmatics asks for the mind to open up and accept new concepts.  So
in taking the time to learn such remote knowledge you are, in effect, saying
that I shall accept what this book has to offer and therefore can be
paralleled to current happenings (opening the mind to other concepts).

>--------------------------------
>
> all the things which imply
>peace to exist, must first
>be at peace with themselves
>
>--------------------------------

Good.  All the things that imply peace allow for each of us to be at peace
with one another as well as the self.  One must love yourself for others to
love you.  You must respect others for others to respect you.  Accepting
others freedom alows you to be free.  With all this in effect, you can Unify
and be at peace...  Something to ponder.

Bye-Bye
__________________________________
Name:   T.S. Brown
E-mail:  Nomad@ccnet.com
Website: http://www.ccnet.com/~nomad/index.htm

Freedom~Love~Unity~Respect~Etc.
__________________________________

Hello everyone,
	I went to Basics last night and I loved every minute of it!! The 
night kinda didn't start out too well for me. I drove out there and 
finally got to the party. I was sooooo excited I kinda rushed getting 
out of my car and locked the keys in the car, with the lights on! 
(Stupid) But thank god for the handy security guard who knew how to 
brake into my car. Adn I guess my friend Joe had fun directing traffic 
while the guard did that!! 
	Anyways we got inside to be completely amazed by the location. 
Tony was spinning!!!! AAAWWWEEE!!!! (Good) That started the night of 
just amazing music, that just took the crowd for the ride of a lifetime, 
(or at least me and everyone that I talked to!) Rob Vaughn from Dallas 
was completely amazing!!! I have never ever danced that hard in my life! 
Or at least my sober life! :) 
	In all Basics was really, really good! The crowd was so into it 
(great energy!,) the music was excellent (not one bad song in my 
opinion!,) and the location was great! To me, it felt like all the 
energy from all the Basics parties in the past three years combined, 
came back out!!! People that I haven't seen came out, and just made it 
extra special!!!! Thanx to the Basics crew, and to all the people how 
made it so special!

Peace, love and harmony to all beautiful people!

Greg

Maaaaaan... the party put on by the folks from Komotion last night (Friends and
Family crew I'm assuming) for Ethan's birthday was phenomenal. Almost indescrib-
ably excellent, but I'll try anyways :)
The space was reaally homey and intimate, and there was none of that corporate
sort of mentality that sometimes comes with bigger gatherings.  The crowd knew
exactly what it takes to make a great rave, and everyone was smiling and talking
about anything they felt like to each other.  There was such an intense feeling
of *universal* love there, and it was unconditional.  Everyone helped each other
whenever they could: Jesse talking with the young woman from Concord, Tracy
spinning an ear-dazzling closing set, Reza jumping in to refill pitchers of 
water when the vibE was hitting hardest and the kitchen was empty, Black Adder
introducing me to Brian Darkness, Regan (sp?) with her buzzball toy, the way the
organizers had blowpops and apricots for all of us (YES!)--I could ramble away
for pages with stories about everyone I met!
And of course HAPPY BIRTHDAY ETHAN!  Hope you didn't mind the squawkiness of
our 'happy birthday to you' rendition :)  Thanks for letting all of us celebrate
with you.
Love to you all
*twirl*
Timothy

talk about cool

We got there around 11 or so and walked in to TONY spinning. The vibe at
first didn't seem bad but awkward because everyone was talking at the
back of the space.
BUT- at around 1:15 when I beleive it was harry who he spun the best
fast tracks and drum tracks. Everyone ran to the dance floor and started
cheering.

The best part IMO was the peak of Duran. He went so high I felt like I
was flying(in some ways I was). I talked to him afterwards and he said
that he was glad to spin in SF again. I caught TONY dancing later in the
night with a big smile. That guy from texas was good. Good music with a
good feel of a set that built up gradualy with a good sense of beat and
tribal kinda set in the background.
PROPS to all of the DJ's.

Thank you again Martin for a good party and a Comp.

We left at 7 or so and drove to miltons house and crashed there.
Thanx Milton!
Thank you to everyone else!

If we can't admit that all aspects of life come together (ie: RAVING and
politics,RAVING and moon calendars) then we are no better than our
government, who has one of the first admendments(separation of church
and state) but chooses to control how they interact.

If we would start to accept others ideals (yes even fraser's) than we can
become more educated and will make better decision to improve our
future.

If you can't accept the fact that even fly farts effect our raves then
you should check out a book called THE BUTTERFLY EFFECT. I don't
remember the author, but we had to read it for one of my physics
classes. It might be a paper written for the class only, I don't
remember. It has many good theories about the effects of small items on
large masses. Who would have ever thought that man, a bug less then
1,000,000,000 times smaller than the earth could do so much damage.

DOS post or the Lunar calandar were _directly_ tied to raving where jons post
was.

about how bottled water was made etc.  well people at raves do drink water
right?   Well in that case some people drink a beer before going out to a
rave so maybe a post on how Bud is made would then be appropriate?  I think

AAaaaaahhhh, what a nice weekend.  Went to the party celebrating Ethan's 
b-day.  A super friendly vibe.  It was a party that was really nice to 
meet people and socialize with.  Happy to have met few more sfravers as 
well as some other very friendly people.  I gotta say that sitting in the 
chill room during Allen's set was full of some surprizes.  First time I 
got to hear some punk in a chill room.  And the funky tunes had some of 
us groovin, which even brought in a street person who started really 
gettin down with us.
Thought it was real cool to see ethan raving with his dad.  Wow 3 
generations of ravers in ethans family.
Left about 5:30, with my energy level running low.  Sorry to miss Tracy's 
set, but was happy to be able to catch her at the next party at the 
berkeley marina on sunday.
This party was a party, that didn't have alot of people, but shows me 
once again you don't need alot of people to have a really good rave.  
This party had a atmosphere that let me let it all loose on the dance 
ground.  The friendly vibe brought in people walking by who just couldnt 
resist and joined in.  Got to meet some more super friendly people.  For 
those at this party, TRANCIN is the word that mostly came to my mind.  
There was some really nice shared trancin at this party.
Thanks to everyone for sharing the vibe this weekend.


peter

On Mon, 22 May 1995, Brian D. wrote:

 >Dear All;
 >
 >	Friday the 19th of May, 1995 had to be the most boring day in SF 
 >rave history. Even at 1015 Folsum I didn't regonize a sole, let a lone 
 >the vibe. I kept asking myself if I was in the wrong place or not, it 
 >looked like the Sound Factory, and no I was doin acid, I wish, oh maybe 
 >not. Lots o suits, old, old people and button down shirts, with straight 
 >legs, it was fuckin werid. Maybe I was in the wrong place or just 
 >illinformed, I think I was in hell, the music was bad to, no offense, but 
 >it just wasn't there ***for me**** lastnight. I left at 3am, dats earlly 
 >early for me. Well, I guess ya gotta have the SUCK nights along with the 
 >good ones, god, how bad can it get though. If anyone else had similar 
 >experiences please do let me know. I'm really confused, considering I 
 >knew about 30 people there last Friday, and the fRiday before last ...etc >
 >and had a great time, go figure.
 >

Interesting. I was at there till almost 7am, and for me the place *went 
off*. (Then again, things may have picked up after you left).

I've been thinking a lot about this, how the same event can be viewed 
entirely differently be two individuals, based on their perspectives.

Looks like the same thing happened with the DUST thread.

I've found that if I go out looking for something (expectations), and 
I don't find it (those expectations aren't met), I get dissapointed.

It's been difficult, but now I go out without expectations, and try to 
create the experience I want, by putting out the vibe that I want 
created (much like Geoff's been talking about). 

Even if the venue/crowd/vibe is less than ideal, I usually end up having 
at least an o.k time, because I'm enveloped in a bubble of the vibe I enjoy.

Scoop somethingorother from KFOG says "If you don't like the news, go make 
some of your own".

Perhaps we can take it one step further and say "If you don't like the 
vibe, go create one of your own".

later...

Jonas

P.S. this is just my PERSPECTIVE. That means it's true for me (I think ;) , 
but not necessarily true for anyone else.

Wow! Whata weekend!!
I got to meet some really wonderful people this weekend...

I got to stay with Peter F. and met him in person the first time.  What a 
guy! :)  We went to Ethan's birthday party @ Komotion instead of going to 
Basics.  I got to meet some more sfravers: Tony, Black Adder, Monicat, 
Lydia and I got to see Brian B. and Brian D. again...nice to see you all 
again.  Real nice vibe going on there. 

On Sunday we went to Berkeley Marina for a great little outdoor party. 
Not many people at all, but the vibe was incredible.  The afterglow from 
the night before gave me alot of energy and I danced hard for a long 
time.  David Munik showed us his pictures from the UK and he even gave me 
a couple of flyers from there (thanks David!)  I met Geoff and some 
others as well.  Tracy spun a good set and Josh finished off the night.  
All in all, I had a teriffic time and I can hardly wait to come down 
again.  I just *LOVE* San Francisco!!! :):):)

Take care all!
love,

     Dear Jon,
     
     Hope this finds you well.
     
     Your email and the issues it raised really concerned us -- but we 
     appreciate your criticism.  
     
     In regards to dust, you are correct -- this is something we all work 
     very hard at (lights, sound, promotion).  It is not perfect, but every 
     week brings new people, new perspectives and new ways to make it 
     better.
     
     In regards to the space, most people enjoy it simply because of the 
     layout; it is easy to have a conversation in one bit, while dancing in 
     another.  A lot of people enjoy the arches and mirrors -- they create 
     a sort of intimacy that helps define our club.  This venue may not be 
     the best, but it is what we have to work with at present.  It is also 
     unfortnate that the permits we have to work with allow us only a 21 
     and up crowd.
     
     In regards to the security guy, Scott -- he does work with us, however 
     he has been cautioned several times by the owners to watch out for 
     false ids.  We have had a few cases where we have had to refuse people 
     because their ids were sketchy (I didn't see yours so I wouldn't 
     know).  In any case Scott does work at another bar in Berkeley and is 
     familiar with security work.  I am sorry that you had a rough time 
     with him -- he is actually a really nice guy.  This is the first 
     complaint we have had about the bartenders; they are employed by the 
     owners of the bar.  They enjoy working with us and have never 
     complained about any of our guests.
     
     In regards to the pool table and having nothing else to do but play 
     pool:
     On the night you were there, I believe we had a dj from the Gardening 
     Club spinning -- that could account for why people were sitting down 
     initially as opposed to dancing.  However if you had stayed, you would 
     have seen people dancing.  The dance floor gets going at about 11:30 
     p.m. and usually stays busy until closing. I was the person sitting at 
     the door.  Often, when people play pool, they bang the ends of their 
     cue sticks into the heads of those working the door.  I have not ever 
     asked anyone to stop playing pool, however, I have asked them to have 
     some consideration for those sitting at the door; I don't think anyone 
     can tolerate having their head banged consistently by a cue stick.   
     
     
     In short, while we appreciate some of your comments, we don't think 
     that you experienced our club sufficiently for us to merit some of 
     your remarks.  I would therefore welcome you to dust at some other 
     point, and perhaps your experience will differ from your initial 
     visits. We understand that sf-raves is an open forum for these sorts 
     of discussions and wanted to see what people had to say about the 
     whole issue  first before responding to you -- hence the delay in our 
     reply.  To be honest, I didn't foresee the whole dust-bsp issue 
     generating the sort of feedback that it has.
     
     Thanks for your time.
     
     Saira

Well, I have to add my voice to those in appreciation of Basics this
weekend.  I haven't danced so hard in months.  The music was nothing short
of excellent all night, on a nice sound system.  The people were all
really into it... and I'm still flying from all the good energy I
came into contact with.  Hats off to Martin... cause I just had
a damn good time.

Martin) together when the lights came on in the morning.

That's all.  *grin*

Hello to all who made it out to the smaller party for Ethan on Sat. I want
to say that it was really great seeing and being part of a wonderful vibe.
It was also great to see many of the faces I know and to meet a few new
faces... I'm still trying to put names and faces together and it usually
takes me a couple of times to get it right. I'm still looking to meet more
of the people from the group so if you see me come and say hi! I've wanted
to meet Black Adder, Amy Starkey, Derek Chung ( who's not Larry ) and others
who often post so I can put faces with the posts I see passing through 
sfraves.  

  Also thanks to everyone who gave me positive feedback on the visuals. I
really love the support and it's the vibe that keeps me doing it. So very
definitely EACH OF YOU make it happen and I do my best to think of things
that you might like to see or might be stimulating to you. When I run my
visuals at home nothing happens - but when I'm able to touch or excite a
group "everything" happens and if it all comes together I know EXACTLY
why I do it - so accept my heartfelt thanks to you all...

Also, I really got my share of hugs Sataurday and smiles... makes me realize
I've been deficient lately... everyone needs 12 hugs a day - right Milton ?

Finally, if you can think of things that would be cool to see let me know..
I'm working on an erotic set now - since I am overly tired of seeing our
society overplay violence and underplay the sensual. Also, I've made a 
tape of outtakes from movies such as Dark Crystal, Legend, Dr. 
Strangelove, some old B&W which I used on Sat. A while back we filled 
some bandwidth with movies people would like to see outtakes from and I 
got some of them. If you think of others you can always E-mail me with 
suggestions. I always seem to "blank out" when I walk into a video rental
store...

Love ya all and all of you make it happen each time you come together and
celebrate !

Mike

From: bill@thelema.queernet.org (Bill Richard)
Subject: Re: Darwin and Social Darwinism
Message-Id: <D90466.2oC@thelema.queernet.org>
Organization: House of the Apostles of Eris Electric
References: <Pine.ULT.3.91.950516155302.9876A-100000@bobo.csustan.edu>
Date: Mon, 22 May 1995 22:37:18 GMT

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

In article <Pine.ULT.3.91.950516155302.9876A-100000@bobo.csustan.edu>,
Hoss Sarbaz  <hsarbaz@bobo.csustan.edu> wrote:
>
>Herbert Spencer (1820-1903) was a freind of Darwin who took Darwins work 
>and applied the term SOCIAL DARWINISM which in Spencer's ttheory meant 
>that low class people are destined to die according to survival of the 
>fittest theory. His theory became popular among the Nazi's and Facist 
>government.

I believe that it was Spencer, not Darwin himself, who also coined the
phrase "Survival of the Fittest". The problem is that "survival of the
fittest" isn't that good a description of how evolution works. A
better phrase might be "survival of the fit enough" or maybe
"non-survival of the completely unfit". It is not necessary that a
particular trait be the "fittest" in order to remain in the gene pool,
it only needs to be not too harmful. Consider hemophilia and other
hereditary diseases. Shouldn't "survival of the fittest" have
eliminated these traits long ago? But they survive because they don't
kill _too_ many of the people who carry them.

But "survival of the fittest" become popular because it provided a
neat "scientific" justification for some people to decide that since
their kind of people were obviously the "fittest" they should naturally
dominate the "unfit" people, and even "help" evolution along by
eliminating them from the gene pool by programs of forced
sterilization and such.

This really has very little to do with actual evolutionary theory.
People who want to dominate other people will always find
rationalization to justify themselves. And generally have no trouble
finding apparently "neutral" people to promote it for them.  For
example when religion was a much stronger force in the world than
science, the church preached that the nobility were chosen by God
himself to rule over the peasantry.

-Bill




From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon May 22 15:41:57 1995

night at Ethan's birthday.  (And I'm not just saying that because he let me
work the control panel. :^)

the contribution he makes at an event.

This reporter was happy with what he saw.

felt like Snoopy at dinner time.)  I swear I reached new heights, which for
me is always a welcomed change.  I heard someone mention that he was "so
proud of her" and I must say that she made us all proud, and happy, and
sore as hell today.

sets back-to-back, keeping the crowd of 35 on their feet until 3, and then
many stalwarts headed to 1015 Folsom to end the night/begin the day.

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: crunch@sysx.apana.org.au (John Draper)
Subject: Totum report from Sydney
Cc: ausrave@smug.student.adelaide.edu.au
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Totum rave report
=================

Greetings fellow SFRavers,  AusRavers,  and AdRavers...   This Cyber
Gypsy is back in Sydney down from hot, sweaty,  tropical Darwyn.   Makes
me appreciate the wonderful winter of Sydney....Which,  by the way,  is
warmer than the summers of San Francisco...  At this time of the year,
Sydney appears to have spring-like weather in the winter.

I arrived home about 10 PM on Saturday,   just enough time to shower and
relax before heading out to the following party.


Saturday May 20th
        -Spirit Ov Thee Times - Totem Launch of "Zeitgeist"
         CD on If? Recordings featuring
         Voitek (Melb), Hi Fly (Melb), Calix (Syd), Blac (Syd),
         + DJs Biz E, Michael MD, Zeitgeist (Melb)
         Underground Cafe - 22 Bayswater Rd, Kings Cross
         $15/$12conc.       Tickets available at Hardwax

I arrive kind of early,   because it's less than 100 meters from where I
live.    Ohhh!!!  How convenient....  to have my OWN private Chillout
area...  Tee hee!

As I arrive,   Michael MD was spinning some good house trance but nobody
was on the dance floor.    After my flight back from Darwyn,   I wasn't
quite ready to get into it,   so I schmoosed around,  saying hi to all
my Sydney friends who were all wondering where I was for the past week.
Sheesh!  Already,  people are missing me.

I get the usual  "I see you everywhere!!" person coming up to me... and
after not raving for more than 13 days (OH!!!  how horrible!!  I
certainly was ready.   I had popped a couple o Daffy's about 30 minutes
before arriving,  and it was starting to come on....   WOW!!  what 13
days can do to ones tolerance...

Yet more time passed,  and the dance floor was still totally empty,
and I said  "FUCK THIS!!" and wasted no time getting out there to loosen
up.

Almost immediately,  this girl came out,   with a big smile and urging
me on.    After that,   I would say,  within about 3 - 4 minutes,  there
were 15 people dancing.   People were swarming into this small and cozy
little venue (The Underground Cafe).   It's entrance to the place has an
iron gate,  leading to the front door.   The doorman was checking ID's
(remember - 18+ to go to bars in Australia).   The door then leads
downstairs below street level where you pay $15 to get in.

As I entered the Cafe,  they had sheets hanging from the ceilings,   off
to the left,  in a raised section,   there were rows of electronic
instruments,  synthesizers,  and the like.    It became clear the this
was to be a LIVE performance of acid trance.   OBOY!  My favorite....

Down on the dance floor,  towards a back stage,  situated ONE of the 3
chill areas,  with lots of pillows,  and mats to flop down on.

Off to the right,  were tables (Cafe style),  and way in the back to the
right was the bar.   Other rooms leading to more chill areas,   and
pinball machines.   The DJ booth was just to the right, up in an
elivated section,   facing the Cafe part,  and Mike Dagn was behind the
turntables.

Mike Dagn maintains the AusRaves mailing list,  and had been a wonderful
source for rave information,  and the local radio stations use his party
list every day to announce upcoming events.   In fact,  Mike was one of
the first AusRave folks I've met (While I was in Calif.).

When the first live musician came on,  I hardly noticed it.   When I
did,  I was amazed at how well he put together his set.   It seems a lot
of people here are making their OWN music to each individual taste.   As
a result of this,   there is such an amazing amount of variety that it
boggles the mind.   Initially,  when Dagn went on,   he stayed around
the usual 120 BPM range,   but as the evening wore on,   the BPMs
gradually increased upwards to about the Australian standard of about
150 BPM.

As usual,  I literally went insane,   hopping around the dance floor
until it got so crowded that all I could do is go up and down.   As I
was chilling outside,  a few young Aussie dudes said "You're FUCKIN
SICK! - How long have you been raving?"   My American accent always
seems to get people to believe I'm from Canada.   Not very many people
from San Francisco come to Sydney,  and I'm always deluged with
questions about the SF rave scene.   I would say ... They have mostly
House and trance,  and what the Aussies call Garage house.    They would
say..  "What!  no hard core?" in total disbelief!!!

The live music acts were totally brilliant!!   All fresh new stuff.

When the live stuff was over,   I went home for a few minutes to chill
out and stretch.   As usual,  Kings Cross is insane on a Sat evening.
Kinda like North Beach in SF.   It's so crowded that you can hardly walk
on the sidewalk.

I eventually headed back to the underground cafe to hear the other DJs
from Melbourne (See the info above).   All were incredible...  And thanx
for Mike Jay for putting on such a great party.

The party went on until about 7 am.    Afterwards,   I went home,  took
a shower,  and headed off for breakfast.

Recovery party - Pavilion tavern
---------------------------------

After breakfast,   I headed down to the Recovery,  only to learn that
the trains weren't running.   They offered busses (for free - gee,  how
nice),   I eventually get there around 9:30 am.   Hardly anyone there,
so I touch base with those coming from other parties.   Learned there
wasn't much going on last night.   Other a talked to which they had come
to the Totem event.

As usual,  happy hard-core was on the menu....   I wasted no time
getting on the dance floor,  and had it all to myself.   Eventually
others followed.

It appears that Aussies usually don't stay up and rave all night and
into the next morning.   They go home,  get some sleep,  and head out to
recovery in late afternoon.

The Pavilion is having a DJ contest,   where each set is 20 minutes
long,  and breaks between each set they do.   Most all sets were happy
hard (sometimes referred to as "Kiddie Kore").   There was some Jungle,
breakbeat and hose played as well.   In fact,  one of the house DJ's
layed down a brilliant set of some really great house trance,  and
literally filled the dance floor.

As one would expect,  I heard the same songs over and over,  as each DJ
had the same record in each of their collections.   Other than that,
and a few inexperienced DJ's I heard an amazing variety.

Later on,   I meet this black dude from the UK in dreads.   Actually,
he saw me getting in on in the dance area,   and I found out he was a
DJ,  and picked up on my vibe.   Later on,  I heard him spin some really
good house (in the small room).   Which was so crowded and hot,  there
was no way anyone can dance.

Besides,  I liked the happy hard-core,  and stayed out in the main area
where is was much cooler.

I stayed at the pavilion from 9:30 am until midnight,  pretty much
dancing all the time,   except to chill and go out and eat in the
evening.

I eventually went home,   feeling really great...

So,  this wraps up yet another report from Sydney...  More stuff to
follow,  as next week is DUMBO - A huge massive rave/circus event,
alongside yet another rave "Space Cadet"...  HOLY SHIT!!   which one do
I take in next week...    Upcoming on the 3rd of June,  and my LAST RAVE
in Australia is MDMA-2 which is supposed to GET OFF!!   big time...
will be my big last Australian bash before heading back to San Francisco
on the 5th,  where I'll be at Come/Unity for my welcome home party,  so
save all that good vibe for me when I get back....

Oh!! what can I do,   no more happy hard-core....

Crunchman

well this goes out to the promoters
Recently the Cactus Club in San Jose decided to shut down on Sunday nights
Previously they had tried to make an 'underground/techno' take off
They failed miserbly.
Mainly due to lack of promotions In the underground scene

Well anyway, Cactus Club has the advantage of being 18+ club. The only 
one in San Jose that I know of. Furthermore they had previously done all 
day shows for 16+.

So If there is a promoter who thinks he can pull people in On a Sunday night
I think he should go look at cactus.

Saira:

I appreciate your resply.  I did not mean to wrek havoc with you or the
crew.  I was just telling everyone how I felt and what happened.  Your
response to me proves that you are concerned about the welfare of the Dust
partygoers:  Thats all that matters.  I appreciate the fact that you guys
are working hard to provide a Friday night trance environment and that you
(I remember you now) were very polite to us when we did go (twice).  I
apologize for the shrewd remarks I had made about people involved.  There
was some misrepresentation.

I think i've been sitting in front of this screen for too long.

anyways>  I expect some more friends from out of town next week, maybe
we'll go to DUst!

See you soon

Jon

p.s.>    Lets end the thread here please!



>     Dear Jon,
>
>     Hope this finds you well.
>
>     Your email and the issues it raised really concerned us -- but we
>     appreciate your criticism.
>
>     In regards to dust, you are correct -- this is something we all work
>     very hard at (lights, sound, promotion).  It is not perfect, but every
>     week brings new people, new perspectives and new ways to make it
>     better.
>
>     In regards to the space, most people enjoy it simply because of the
>     layout; it is easy to have a conversation in one bit, while dancing in
>     another.  A lot of people enjoy the arches and mirrors -- they create
>     a sort of intimacy that helps define our club.  This venue may not be
>     the best, but it is what we have to work with at present.  It is also
>     unfortnate that the permits we have to work with allow us only a 21
>     and up crowd.
>
>     In regards to the security guy, Scott -- he does work with us, however
>     he has been cautioned several times by the owners to watch out for
>     false ids.  We have had a few cases where we have had to refuse people
>     because their ids were sketchy (I didn't see yours so I wouldn't
>     know).  In any case Scott does work at another bar in Berkeley and is
>     familiar with security work.  I am sorry that you had a rough time
>     with him -- he is actually a really nice guy.  This is the first
>     complaint we have had about the bartenders; they are employed by the
>     owners of the bar.  They enjoy working with us and have never
>     complained about any of our guests.
>
>     In regards to the pool table and having nothing else to do but play
>     pool:
>     On the night you were there, I believe we had a dj from the Gardening
>     Club spinning -- that could account for why people were sitting down
>     initially as opposed to dancing.  However if you had stayed, you would
>     have seen people dancing.  The dance floor gets going at about 11:30
>     p.m. and usually stays busy until closing. I was the person sitting at
>     the door.  Often, when people play pool, they bang the ends of their
>     cue sticks into the heads of those working the door.  I have not ever
>     asked anyone to stop playing pool, however, I have asked them to have
>     some consideration for those sitting at the door; I don't think anyone
>     can tolerate having their head banged consistently by a cue stick.
>
>
>     In short, while we appreciate some of your comments, we don't think
>     that you experienced our club sufficiently for us to merit some of
>     your remarks.  I would therefore welcome you to dust at some other
>     point, and perhaps your experience will differ from your initial
>     visits. We understand that sf-raves is an open forum for these sorts
>     of discussions and wanted to see what people had to say about the
>     whole issue  first before responding to you -- hence the delay in our
>     reply.  To be honest, I didn't foresee the whole dust-bsp issue
>     generating the sort of feedback that it has.
>
>     Thanks for your time.
>
>     Saira

I thought that's what the DELETE key is for.
I'm not going to subscribe to a new list with no-one I know, post one
message about a simple program(the message wasn't even 1k long) then
unsubscribe to that list. and have 100 programmers offer their services
for $60 an hour. Id rather give that money to a raver and keep
supporting our commun. NOW THAT'S RAVE RELATED!

Just like if someone needed sound for a party. I'd be the first to reply
and the first to give a discount. IT'S CALLED WORKING TOGETHER
NOW THAT'S RAVE RELATED.

I think in everyone's heart on this list they all want to do at least
one thing that will benefit others. If they don't then they are selfish.
I feel bad if I can't put in my fifteen minutes of sweat to help
some-one. And BTW. That DOS post of mine was more rave related than you
think. Although I can't give details, my intension are to connect more
of sacramento to the Internet. Therefore exposeing more people to
sfraves.
NOW THATS RAVE RELATED

Hello all...I am new to this list (boy I am pretty sure you are tired of 
hearing that line).  I am currently trying to set up a big rave in the 
Northern California area.  I have a piece of property in the Tahoe 
National Forrest perfect for an outdoor rave.  It is not near lake Tahoe 
but instead 30-45 minutes from grass valley/nevada city (to those of you 
who knwo the area).  I am planning on having it on the 4th of july 
weekend.  Currently nothing is too firm.  I am not gonna charge anything 
for this rave cause I really think we should all enjoy the music an a 
truly amazing setting (with nochance of getting busted).  I have already 
recieved some support and encouragement from people in the SoCal area.  I 
already have a few small pieces of equipment and some volunteers, however 
if I am going to pull this off I am gonna need a lot more help.  People 
suggested that I write to you guys because you were really friendly and 
helpful and that maybe you would provide some support.  I have only been 
planning this now for about a day and already close to 30 socalers want 
to attend (I hope all of you can attend too).  However I have nil-factor 
experience in throwing raves.  I am trying to contact Moontribe (has 
anyone heard up there heard of em?) to see if I can borrow their sound 
system/generator.  If any of you guys can loan me some equipment I would 
be really be greatful.  I need anything from a generator to a sound sytem 
to lighting equip to strobe lights...etc.  Anything would be greatly 
appreciated (especially volunteers to help clean up).  I am also looking 
for some DJ's.  If anyone knows any DJs that will work for cheap/free 
please tell me.  Everything for this rave is either gonna come out of my 
own pocket or donations so please help if you can.  This location is 
utterly beautiful and I would love to see a huge rave take place there.  
I am not sure, but I am kinda leaning toward a multiple day rave (like 2 
or 3 days).  I hope all of you guys can attend.  Again if you can provide 
any help to this newbie to rave orgainzing please email me or call me at 
(714) 509-0537.

Thanks in advance

	-Christian

Subject: Thoughts
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hi all,
I've been thinking about this recently, and it seems kind of weird and hard to
explain, but I figured you guys might know what I was talking about. 
Have you ever been at a rave and maybe you're mellowing out in a beanbag and
you kind of wonder, what in God's name am I doing here?  Why is everything so
weird?  Shouldn't I be at home reading at a desk or something?  I know that
maybe now you guys are all thinking, "To have FUN is the point!" and stuff like
that, and believe me, I think Ethan's birthday party on Saturday ended up being
the best night of my whole life, don't get me wrong, but there WAS a point in
the evening when everything sort of seemed overwhelming to me. 
Keep in mind, I'm VERY new to the scene, and maybe I'll just get used to it, and
I certainly do love it. Also, I do partake in EvErything thE ravE EXpEriEncE
involves, too! ;)  Maybe it's that stuff more than anything else, but each
time I'm therE I usually go through an initial phase of sort of a loneliness and
unsettling sense of loss, followed by, thankfully, beautiful acceptance and
friendship and love and smiling and all that good stuff.  So the night always
ends on a great note, and so I'm back out there next weekend and I start the
whole process over again.  Does this, umm, ever happen to anyone else?
And one more thing that happened on Saturday: after I was thinking about the
whole night on Sunday, I almost wanted, for aesthetic reasons, to never rave
again.  Because Saturday was so perfect.  It's like retiring after you win the
Super Bowl, you know?  
Of course, my artistic sense could never compete with my hedonistic side ;) and
who am I kidding--I'm sure I'll be dancing away next chance I get.  But ooooooo
after a night like that it'd be so cool to wave goodbye and walk into the sunset
(yeah, I realize how 'sunset' works in a couple of ways there!). Has anyone ever
thought that?
Sorry if this post is kind of self-centred but I was just wondering what you all
thought.  
Peace love and never stop dancing
Timothy

I want to thank the crew & posse of the Sunday thang @ the Berkeley Marina!
The party was right on and I had a great time while I was there.  I also
want to thank them for letting me spin a few tunes!

It was a pleasure meeting Noah (DJ), and of course seeing Josh again!  I
wish I didn't have to leave, since I knew that it was gonna take off!

to all who, like me, are a bit jaded @ the whole "rave" thing...it ain't
dead, it's just changed again, and IMHO, for the better.  The folx who do
the :), are the REAL deal.  It ain't about money, it ain't about
superstars, it's about getting relaxed, & having a good time outdoors.
Once again, people who decided to make a difference have taken their own
destiny in their hands.  The result is, beauty.  I wish more people would
take their example to heart.  If a party don't suit you, you *always* have
the option of throwing your own!  If the DJ sucks, you *always* have the
chance to become your *own* DJ.  And if you're tired of the money aspect,
you can *always* attempt to do show people your vision of what the real
deal is.

The :} posse is the bomb!

Peace out.
Audi 5, BMW 325i, & Honda Civic Si,
John


                "Prejudice is the reason of fools." - Voltaire
              jsl@netcom.com - public key available upon request

> 
> 
> Hi all,
> I've been thinking about this recently, and it seems kind of weird and hard to
> explain, but I figured you guys might know what I was talking about. 
> Have you ever been at a rave and maybe you're mellowing out in a beanbag and
> you kind of wonder, what in God's name am I doing here?  Why is everything so
> weird?   
I'm at a point now that I don't usually ask why everything is so weird, 
but appreciate it.  Actually I was talking about this with a friend at 
the last rave I was at.  While chilling and watching the other ravers 
dance I said to my friend " isn't S.F. great where its normal to be weird."


> maybe now you guys are all thinking, "To have FUN is the point!" and stuff like
> that, and believe me, I think Ethan's birthday party on Saturday ended up being
> the best night of my whole life, don't get me wrong, but there WAS a point in
> the evening when everything sort of seemed overwhelming to me. 

Having FUN is great, but I think one can get alot more from raving.  I 
know I do.  I learn alot about myself, psychologically and spiritually.  
Alot of times its fun but not always. Usually ends up being fun if I'm 
willing to learn about whats going on.  
What I learn alot is that theres alot that I don't know whats going on, 
for  I can't understand it intellectually, but I'm finding that I can 
understand it more spiritually.  THat is a place that we share.  Its not 
just about what *I* know but what we experience.


> time I'm therE I usually go through an initial phase of sort of a loneliness and
> unsettling sense of loss, followed by, thankfully, beautiful acceptance and
> friendship and love and smiling and all that good stuff.  So the night always
> ends on a great note, and so I'm back out there next weekend and I start the
> whole process over again.  Does this, umm, ever happen to anyone else?

Tim,
I think its great that your able to talk about this with us.  No your not 
the only one who doesn't always feel great at raves.  I've had my moments 
here and there as well.  I could do without those moments, but I also 
appreciate them, because I've learned alot from those times.  I think we 
all have are ups and downs whether at a rave or not.  They may vary in 
different degrees.  I think one can experience many different and varied 
states of mind at a rave.  I know I have, and with that have had the 
opportunity to learn more about myself, by looking within and also 
learning to look outside myself, moving toward a greater sense of 
connectedness.


> Sorry if this post is kind of self-centred but I was just wondering what you all
> thought.  
> Peace love and never stop dancing
> Timothy

I don't think you have to apologize for sharing your experience.  Sharing 
whats going on with yourself and with others just adds to our overall 
shared connectedness.  I think its ok to feel lonely, but we might as 
well feel lonely together by sharing these feelings as well.  With that 
we can transcend the feeling of loneliness  to one of shared harmony that 
allows us to be alone and together.


peter

>Have you ever been at a rave and maybe you're mellowing out in a beanbag and
>you kind of wonder, what in God's name am I doing here?  Why is everything so
>weird?  Shouldn't I be at home reading at a desk or something?  I know that
>maybe now you guys are all thinking, "To have FUN is the point!" and stuff like
>that, and believe me, I think Ethan's birthday party on Saturday ended up being
>the best night of my whole life, don't get me wrong, but there WAS a point in
>the evening when everything sort of seemed overwhelming to me.
>Keep in mind, I'm VERY new to the scene, and maybe I'll just get used to
>it, and
>I certainly do love it. Also, I do partake in EvErything thE ravE EXpEriEncE
>involves, too! ;)  Maybe it's that stuff more than anything else, but each
>time I'm therE I usually go through an initial phase of sort of a
>loneliness and
>unsettling sense of loss, followed by, thankfully, beautiful acceptance and
>friendship and love and smiling and all that good stuff.  So the night always
>ends on a great note, and so I'm back out there next weekend and I start the
>whole process over again.  Does this, umm, ever happen to anyone else?
>And one more thing that happened on Saturday: after I was thinking about the
>whole night on Sunday, I almost wanted, for aesthetic reasons, to never rave
>again.  Because Saturday was so perfect.  It's like retiring after you win the
>Super Bowl, you know?
>Of course, my artistic sense could never compete with my hedonistic side ;) and
>who am I kidding--I'm sure I'll be dancing away next chance I get.  But ooooooo
>after a night like that it'd be so cool to wave goodbye and walk into the
>sunset
>(yeah, I realize how 'sunset' works in a couple of ways there!). Has
>anyone ever
>thought that?
>Sorry if this post is kind of self-centred but I was just wondering what
>you all
>thought.
>Peace love and never stop dancing
>Timothy


        Well, i too have been at this/these points too.  I've even said to
myself "i don't want to go out to a party ever again" (though it's more
from a negative stimulus) and you often do have to reach deep down inside
and question WHO you really are.  And, IMHO, if you come up with an answer
that can be written out in stone it's probably not the 'right' answer ;)  I
think that we, as ppl, and this culture in general, are in a constant state
of flux and change.  That old saying goes that the 'only constant in the
universe is change,' and i totally beleive it.  I've often hit those points
though where i ask (either on a personal level or in terms of 'raving')
"where do i/we go from here?"  it's kind of scary to look to the future and
see it as being so unpredictable but, hey, that's chaos theory for ya!
Also, i just finished reading this interesting book by Robert Anton WIlson
called the Masks of the Illuminati (kinda a metaphysical detective story)
wherin one of the main elements is this archetype birth, death,
illumination, birth...like you are born in the dark, walk through a valley
of darkness and then are reborn into a golden dawn and then go back to
birth.  I think that raves culture is like this, constantly changing, and
i'd say that now we're past the birth stage and are sorta walkin through
that valley of darkness waiting for the next step in things, that golden
dawn :)
        hugs,
                brad

/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\

>>>>>>>>>brad finlay>>>>>>ectographics
>>>>>>>>>design>>>>>>>>ecto@magnet.ca>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>->"so it never changes much, but it never stops changing" <-<<<<<<<
                                        -the irresistible force

/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\

> called the Masks of the Illuminati (kinda a metaphysical detective story)

> illumination, birth...like you are born in the dark, walk through a valley
> of darkness and then are reborn into a golden dawn and then go back to

such wonderful experiences now, while we are still in that "valley of 
darkness..."  I hope I don't disappear like the people on the on the 
airplane in the "Langoliers" because that light was so beautiful when we 
do get to the golden dawn...:)

Amy

From: Christopher Chervin <r100@cs.sierra.cc.ca.us>

	HI Y'ALL!!

		This is not from Chris, I'm just using his account.  Chris and I went to X-FILES,
		did anyone else out there?  

	Unfortunately I was disappointed with this party.

		X-FILES had greatD.J.'s who were pumpin and a lot of people groovin, including myself
		and Chris.  But supposedly this party was all TOP SECRET and just some birthday bash
		celebration.  That night on the phone message, they said that they got too big of a 
		response to the party and would close the dorrs around or before 2:00a.m., if it got
		too packed.

	They never closed the doors and throughout the night, more and more people packed this tiny,
	car maintenance garage in Rancho Cordova.  
		
		And it got packed and more crowded, too crowded that there was nowhere to sit down.
		They had to bring ice in for the D.J.'s cuz they were sweating lakes.  You didn't even
		have to dance to have sweat dripping down your face.

	There were no windows in this cement bldg.,...basically there was no air.  And I Couldn't dance
	after awhile because people kept elbowing me and I them.  There was ONE loveseat to sit down on
	by the front door.  They told two of my friends that they were going to start charging anyone
	who sat on it $1.00, CAN YOU BELIEVE THAT?  They Stamped our hands when we paid $10.00, but
	if you stepped outside you couldn't get back in.  WHAT?!?!  What was the stamp for?  

 		But then they started letting their friends outside, telling all the rest of us sweating,
		hyperventilating, dehydrated dancers that there are,"No Outies!".

	Screw this!!!!  So after two hours of a poorly organized party me, Chris and all my friends left.


*@*@*@*@*@*@*@*@*PEOPLE OUT THERE!!!  UNDERSTAND THAT HOUSE IS FOR THE MIND AND@*@*@*@*@*@*@*@*@*@*@*@
			THE SOUL!!!  IT'S TO REUNITE OUR FAMILY UNDER ONE ROOF!!!
		WE ARE A HOUSE NATION,  THROWING PARTIES IS NOT TO FILL YOUR
			POCKETS,....HOUSE IS TO FILL YOUR MIND, BODY AND SOUL!!!!!


p.s.  X-FILES made a hefty sum of $$$, they didn't have to rent out the bldg,(it was dad's) and people 
      donated the decorations and lights.  We, the ravers looking for a good time, spending our hard 
      earned pay were the ones who got jipped.  But as a hard core raver-it's the price you pay and risk.

PARTY PEOPLE IN THE PLACE!!!!!

	DORENA :)

Yea, I went.  I dj'd in the ambient room.  I spun for the first three hours
of the party, then took a breather outside.  I just walked back in with no
problems.  I was never questioned regarding in's and out's.  The people at
the door did not know me, so it wasn't just a friendship thing.  I saw the
big "no in's and out's sign", and wondered why knowbody ever said anything
about it all night.  I personnaly sat on that loveseat for about 15 minutes
with no hassels what so ever, except for a friend who was very hap-EEEE who
kept walking by and kissing me.  And really that wasn't so bad ethier.   I
danced for a while and although it was hot, it wasn't so bad for me.  My
only beef was that there was only one bathroom.  I would like to note that
although there was only one bathroom, it stayed fairly clean and well
stocked with paper all night, which is amazing for a rave (or atleast the
ones I've been to.

I know two people who had just about the times of their lives that night,
with now hElp from chEmical substancEs at all.  They were higher than I had
ever seen them, and it was all pure consciencness.  At around 2:00 a.m. or
so they were letting people in and out with no questions and had opened the
huge garage door about 4 feet up to help air out the place.  There were
about 50 people outside or maybe more, and the dance floor didn't seem too
crowded.  All in all it seemed to be a very good party to me, and I
personally know alot of people who had a really good time there.  I am not
trying to devalue your experience Dorena, I just want everyone to know that
some people had a really amazing time at the same party you were miserable at.  

Just trying to balance out the Universe.

Rick

>Sorry if this post is kind of self-centred
Its actually the kind of post I keep reading this funky ol' list for --
communicating <personal> experiences.

I think you just became disconnected from the vibe -- it happens.  Usually a
friend or other kind soul will come over and talk to you , give you a neck
rub, water, candy ,etc. -- refreshing, reviving, reconnecting.  So if you see
someone sitting there and looking spacy and disconnected, go over see if they
need reconnecting :-)  
Also, I think it has to do with many parties limited enviroment choices--its
hard to beat an intelligently planned outdoor event.  Indoors, I will
sometimes slip into a mood where I don't feel like being in the main room
because I'll  have to dance ;-) outside is too cold if its even an option and
if its there the chill room is spacy and relaxing but kinda putting me to
sleep.  Sometimes a bar area will have a lounge enviroment and that sorta
works, but what I think I want a lot of times is a creative cafe kind of
enviroment where I could get something light and yummy to eat, a cool
beverage, and fun stuff to do: read, make art or music, play with a computer,
TALK, etc.  Come to think of it, the Gardening club is pretty close to what I
was thinking of in terms of overall feel.

phuture

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue May 23 15:03:23 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id PAA04707; Tue, 23 May 1995 15:03:23 -0700
Received: from bethe.ucdavis.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with SMTP id PAA04686; Tue, 23 May 1995 15:03:17 -0700
Received: by bethe.ucdavis.edu (4.1/UCD2.05)
	id AA00365; Tue, 23 May 95 15:03:15 PDT
From: alves@bethe.ucdavis.edu (David Alves)

Subject: xfiles  (RE: hmm)

Precedence: bulk


> Chris and I went to XFILES
> did anyone else out there?  
> DORENA :)

I did.

I was in Sacramento that night on business.  This was the second
time I've been up there and, wanting to go dancing, have found a
party by dropping by Tom's coffee shop in midtown.

Around 1:30 there was no guy in yellow overalls at the map point
only a sign that said "party full, sorry".

I drove to the nearest gas station where around 6 car loads of
people had found one guy who knew where the party was.  We caravaned
to the midsized workshop/warehouse area.  One small street was lined
with cars.  The security patrol car was bribed or *real* rave friendly.

I talked em down to $8 cuz that was all I had.  I went
in and out many times without a problem.  They had 1/2 dozen fans
in there plus sliding door was cracked.  Quite honestly, I did not
consider this a hot (temperature) party.  Super tiny chill room
even had AC.  The whole party was a pretty big production
with a good sound system, lots of lights, and lots of
alien decorations.  And lots and lots of Acid House.

The crowd was more fun than what I've seen the East Bay draw.
It kinda reminded me of a outdoor summer freebie crowd at 19th
and Ill.  It was a mix of somewhat "serious" raver folks and
people who "had been at another party and heard about a
place to go dancing ..."

I couldn't help but think that an allnight, bust free,
illegal, map point, good production, acid, warehouse party was
the kinda thing that can be pulled off in Sacramento but is
probably very difficult (rare) down here.

It was pretty fun.  Nice for a little afterhours 
dancing in a town lacking many places to do that.  
Anyone else go? 


Dave



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue May 23 15:12:46 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id PAA05734; Tue, 23 May 1995 15:12:46 -0700
Received: from ns.PacBell.COM by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with SMTP id PAA05723; Tue, 23 May 1995 15:12:43 -0700
Received: from srv.PacBell.COM (mother.srv.PacBell.COM) by ns.PacBell.COM (4.1/PacBell-11/15/94)
	id AA23333; Tue, 23 May 95 15:12:16 PDT
Received: from pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM by srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.0)
	id AA17635; Tue, 23 May 95 15:12:15 PDT
Received: from lizard.srv.PacBell.COM by pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA04239; Tue, 23 May 95 15:12:13 PDT
Date: Tue, 23 May 95 15:12:13 PDT
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9505232212.AA04239@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: timothym@ocf.berkeley.edu, Phuture@aol.com
Subject: Re: Thoughts
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Phuture:
> I think you just became disconnected from the vibe -- it happens.  Usually a
> friend or other kind soul will come over and talk to you , give you a neck
> rub, water, candy ,etc. -- refreshing, reviving, reconnecting.  So if you see
> someone sitting there and looking spacy and disconnected, go over see if they
> need reconnecting :-)  

But on the other hand, sometimes we have to accept that connecting to
the vibe may not necessarily be the solution to what's really going on.
While raving may be a truly spiritual experience for some of us, there may 
be times when all this connecting, oneness, love, fun, etc. just is not 
gonna provide a satisfying answer to some of Life's big questions like: 
Who am I?  Why am I doing with my life?  Where is my life heading?  What 
am I looking for?  Can anyone *really* understand me?

Raving is very much an of-the-moment thing, a place in spacetime where we 
can sometimes transcend ourselves and connect with larger forces.  But we
can't always live life in these kinds of moments.  Unless we are in a 
state of continuous escape, reality will come to us in forms that raving 
may not be able to address.  I think it's important not to avoid the 
deeper unknowns, the fears, our doubts and confusion about our place in 
the Universe.  Because these things tend to creep up on us eventually.  

I have known of many people who at some point find the rave vibe to be 
contrived and meaningless.  What I think really happens is that it just 
becomes irrelevant to one's more immediate concerns.  When this happens 
to me, I just take some time off from raving and focus my energy 
on a different positive direction; reading, writing, composing music, 
configuring a software package... something that feels productive and
worthwhile.  To rave is to affirm.  Transcendence is not the same as
self-avoidance, it is more of an extension of who we are and what we're 
about.  Life will always be a challenge, and raving is one way to 
celebrate our willingness to rise up to it.  Sometimes we have to step 
outside of raving to do that.

Lee
___________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com   (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )   lee@hyperreal.com
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Rantin' Review of the Weekend
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     This weekend unexpectedly opened up for me so I was able to go out all 
     weekend :)  Starting the networking buzz w/some friends, the line up 
     of events included Brothers & Sisters, the End-Up (always!), invites 
     to two parties on Saturday, Basics, and the Boat Party.  With a 
     line-up like that and with friends who have more stamina than me, I 
     ventured out with a positive feeling towards the weekend.
     
     In lieu of Brian Darkness' description of Brothers & Sisters/Zendada, 
     I had a terrific time.  It was my first chance to check it out and 
     lots of "scenesters"/friends were there en force.  Since I had a big 
     weekend ahead of me, I worked myself into a natural glow by the time 
     it ended.  Taj's set completely trancended me and Tracy's?? set got me 
     moving even higher when I went upstairs after the end of the Taj's 
     set.  
     
     After 1015, we headed over to the End-Up where we continued to groove 
     until it was time to close (~1pm).  I always have a great time there 
     'cause I can be a freak and be with all the freaks.  Unfortunately 
     even this party gal got sidetracked (for you geriatrics, I felt like 
     Pat Montandon of the rave circuit :)  I didn't make it to the two 
     parties but I was able to get over to Basics w/a friend, Dana, who was 
     catering for the event.
     
     This was my second Basics and based on my previous one, I was looking 
     forward to it.  Though I had reservations of some aggro vibes that I 
     experienced from another East Bay 18+ event, I had a warm, glowing 
     feeling that this was going to take off when I was driving there.  
     From the moment I walked in the door, I knew this party was happening! 
     The enthusiasm and openess from so many young people flattened any 
     negative vibe or thought for miles around.  From the people directing 
     traffic, to the door people (we got to bypass the line :)  to the 
     owner's son & friends working the snack bar, everyone (except possibly 
     the owner of the rink who seemed overwhelmed) was enjoying the 
     vibe--even if they didn't know what a rave was.  I even got a kick out 
     of some people thinking I was 1) associated w/the skating rink; 2) 
     married to my Dana and just happened upon this; or 3) thought I was a 
     narc in the parking lot.   I guess I just don't look 18 anymore :}
     In any case, like many others have said in previous posts:  the music 
     was excellent; _and_ Martin and his crew did another exceptional, 
     beautiful gig.  I'm still glowing from this experience!  bzzzpht!
     
     Driving back to SF, I went to the End-Up and heard reviews of Progress 
     where an acquaintance of mine (Al-Jay) dj'd.  I was sorry to miss his 
     set but it was good to hear this one went better than the last one...I 
     guess they're making progress ;)   After some R&R, I made it to the 
     BulletProof Boat Party where we continued our roll and onto the 
     after-party at Mission Rock.  
     
     The music at BulletProof and the after-party was great.  Lots of funk, 
     jazz, dub, and even some rock.  (Excuse me if I get the music terms 
     wrong, I tend to have my own labels...)  It was definitely a great way 
     to mellow out after another lost weekend in paradise.  If you've never 
     done the boat party, I'd recommend it.  It's pretty special to feel 
     the rhythms of Mother Ocean in synch with rhythms of our hearts and 
     the music.  We even had a guest appearance from the sun before it set! 
     I'm looking forward to doing it again.
     -----
     Well, work has been hectic yesterday and today, so I'm finally sending 
     this out as choppy as it is.  Hope you all had a great weekend, too.  
     It was especially nice to finally meet Jonas, Milton (and the 
     E-Bee)from sfraves and even Duran from LA.  As always, I look forward 
     to meeting more of you at other gatherings.
     
     Hugs and warm embraces,
     Diane

hi all!
I was at X-files also and had a great time.  I was afraid we weren't going to
be let in because we left berkeley a little on the late side, but we got in
no problem.  I had been looking forward to this party for a while now and was
not disapointed.  As soon as I got in, I had to use the bathroom pretty badly
and had to wait in line, but I'd say that was pretty much all I wasn't too
happy about.  I got to see a lot of my sacramento friends and even quite a
few of my SF friends there.  The music was amazing and I thought one of the
best sets was the second to last (Dennis).  I only got to hear part of Mike
Moss, but what I heard I loved.  Carlos blew everyone away, as usual and the
ambient room was great also.  I spent quite sometime in there.  Overall,
everyone was friendly and I know the promoters did not expect quite such a
large turnout, but I was very happy.  I'd even say I liked it better than the
Basics party the next night (but then again, I was running on no sleep at
Basics!).  The music at Basics was unbelieveable though.

I'm new on SFRaves, so hi everyone!!!

Love,
Mary
