On Tue, 23 May 1995, Timothy McIntyre wrote:

> 
> Hi all,
> I've been thinking about this recently, and it seems kind of weird and hard to
> explain, but I figured you guys might know what I was talking about. 
> Have you ever been at a rave and maybe you're mellowing out in a beanbag and
> you kind of wonder, what in God's name am I doing here?  Why is everything so
> weird?  Shouldn't I be at home reading at a desk or something?  I know that
> maybe now you guys are all thinking, "To have FUN is the point!" and stuff like
> that, and believe me, I think Ethan's birthday party on Saturday ended up being
> the best night of my whole life, don't get me wrong, but there WAS a point in
> the evening when everything sort of seemed overwhelming to me. 
> Keep in mind, I'm VERY new to the scene, and maybe I'll just get used to it, and
> I certainly do love it. Also, I do partake in EvErything thE ravE EXpEriEncE
> involves, too! ;)  Maybe it's that stuff more than anything else, but each
> time I'm therE I usually go through an initial phase of sort of a loneliness and
> unsettling sense of loss, followed by, thankfully, beautiful acceptance and
> friendship and love and smiling and all that good stuff.  So the night always
> ends on a great note, and so I'm back out there next weekend and I start the


hey timothy, 

I too have felt the sort of confusion that you are feeling.  But Timothy 
,listen to me very carefully, you are growing.   Many times the rave 
experience can in some inexplainable way get us to face our insecurities, 
deep questions about ourselves(questions that we may not have even 
thought we had, ones like you taliking about),
and to generally begin a path towards self acceptance.  In addition, it 
seems that the level of love and acceptance that we experience 
in our relationship with other ravers during the party, leads us to want 
to find those same feelings in real life relationships that are on the same 
level. To find others with which we give and recieve  
enough trust, warmth, and sincerity that we can really be ourselves without 
feeling guilty or out of touch with our true inner spirit.

It is in my opinion that it is your choice to look at raves as occaisonal 
escapes from reality or to view them as vehicles to help analyze yourself 
so you can effectivly bring yourself to peace at many levels.

The door has been opened, it takes courage, work, and willingness to go 
forward.

peace
dan

ps

found this in a book I'm reading
by Wayne Dyer

This is it
and I am it
and you are it
And so is that
and he is it
and she is it
and it is it
and that is that

:)

> whole night on Sunday, I almost wanted, for aesthetic reasons, to never rave

> Super Bowl, you know?  
> Of course, my artistic sense could never compete with my hedonistic side ;) and
> who am I kidding--I'm sure I'll be dancing away next chance I get.  But ooooooo
> after a night like that it'd be so cool to wave goodbye and walk into the sunset
> (yeah, I realize how 'sunset' works in a couple of ways there!). Has anyone ever
> thought that?
> Sorry if this post is kind of self-centred but I was just wondering what you all
> thought.  
> Peace love and never stop dancing
> Timothy

 My experience with the Santa Cruz Civic , rave-wise , was an event
called Lighthouse. It was great! Music-wise , and also interesting
were the tables set up with political and philisophical information.
Smart drinks , clothes , etc.

 The crowd was a great mix of ravers , hippies , body-pierced black
leather folks , and other folks.

 RE: criminals - one of the worst rave experiences I've ever heard
of was near a beach park many miles north of Santa Cruz . Folks
beat up and robbed. But the S.C. Civic , like the Richmond Civic,
is in close proximity to the city police department.

     Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com
 

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue May 23 22:06:46 1995

Hey I had a big wet one at friday's party in the basement of 1015.  
Free to SFRavers!  (before 2:30am I think) Ya gotta love that.

Ok there were basically three different clubs going on, which may be abit 
confusing.  But there is something interesting to see here.
I mean sometimes we want to hear Tone Loc in the front room yapping about 
his Wild Thing and it's always good to stand around the walls of the main 
room and watch serious faces grind their posterior regions into others to 
undeterminable melodies and wayy too much bassss.  It was reflections of 
the way life used to be (sing that part) and I'm glad that we have 
alternatives nowadays.

Walk down to the basement and be pleasently surprised by a 
decent groove and a fair amount of sweat.  The floor was slushy and fun 
to slip around on.  The music was there for the taking.  This party is a 
good thing coming.

o.O
( )
walrus

Whoooaaaaa! I can understand all of your complaints about the people and
the heat but don't say what you don't know.

Pierre happens to be one of my good friends and I happen to know for a
fact that he did not make much money. He and his dad spent all day
fixing up the place instead of working on cars. Right there they lost
money. They had to pay me for sound. More money gone. They paid for all
of the supplies. More money. Also they did shut down the map point but
everyone somehow found out where the party was.

I do greatly appologize though for the overcrowding. It was way over
promoted, and he realizes his mistake.

All I can do is appolagize.

Subject: Info on Beautiful People
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Precedence: bulk

Hello everybody,
	First I want to say an extra special thanx to the Basics crew, 
(again.) I am still on after glow from that party!!! (It's wonderful!) I 
also want to wish Ethan a happy birhtday again. I hope you had fun!! 
	
	Now, coming up in... two weeks, (geez, that came quick, I 
thought it was farther away!,) Harmony and Re-Groove-A-Nation, bring you 
our first actually party together. We tried to do a free outdoor, but 
got rained on. So we are really looking forward to presenting this one:

	In the Beautiful month of June, Friday, June 2nd to be exact,
	
		We invite everyone to join us for a night of hugs, 
		smiles, love, joy, and industrial strength fun!!!!
		
			 "Beautiful People"

	Djs: Graeme La Paix		DRC
	     James (Santa Cruz)         Ernie Deaks
	     James (San Jose)           Trent

	Visuals: Michael Clay
	Ambience: Dionysus Dreams + many guests 
	(408)450.3044   & (408)486.9591

This party will be somewhere in the range of $5-10, most likely 
according to the time you arrive. It will be indoors, and go from about 
8pm-6am, with a possible (weather permitting) free afterparty. 

We have invested sooooo much time and energy in the parties that we have 
done, and especially this one! I don't know if you all know the reason 
we are doing this party, or why we named it Beautiful People. Well I 
will go over it real fast:

At Harmony on March 31st we all were watching the party, and noticed how 
beautiful it was that these 400 or so people had all come together in 
one room to dance and form a beautiful vibe. There is just something 
really special about people coming together like that! We felt that 
throwing that party was not enough thanks to everyone. We put hella time 
and energy into it, but we wanted to do something more.. So we are doing 
another party, trying to make it better than the last one. So that was 
our inspiration... Now the name represents everyone in this world, not 
just some, not a few, but all!!!! No matter how mean, nasty, or evil a 
person is, we believe that they are beautiful. Maybe beautiful way deep 
down inside, but still everyone is beautiful and everyone should realize 
that!! 
	Now, one of the members of Harmony, Joe, was at Richmond Civic 
one day. He was laying down in the chill room after a long night of 
dancing, when a certain person walked up. His name is Baktash (I don't 
know how to spell it!), and he basically inspired Joe in such a way that 
I had never seen before! Baktash said," Come on! The party is not over! 
Get up and dance! You are all Beautiful people!!!!!" And with those few 
words came our inspiration for the name! 
	Call the info lines for more info on our parties, and/or give us 
your e-mail/snail mail addresses, for our mailing list!!
(408)450.3044------(408)486.9591

Peace, love, and harmony to all beautiful people,

Greg (shroomy)

At  4:09 AM 5/23/95 -0700, Timothy McIntyre wrote:
>Have you ever been at a rave and maybe you're mellowing out in a beanbag and
>you kind of wonder, what in God's name am I doing here?  Why is everything so
>weird?  Shouldn't I be at home reading at a desk or something?

Alexandre Dumas was a party animal.  So when I stumbled across this line in
The Count of Monte Cristo I had to write it down.  I think it's pertinent
here:  "Joy has that peculiar effect that at times it oppresses us just as
much as grief."

I too have been slapped with overwhelming feelings of cumpunction, but have
gotten through them by sharing some mellow time with a friend, or alone.
Maybe gotten some air.  Heave a sigh.  Share a smile.  Focus on the DJ for
a while.  Whatever it takes to overcome those black-holes of thought.

>I certainly do love it. Also, I do partake in EvErything thE ravE EXpEriEncE
>involves, too! ;)  Maybe it's that stuff more than anything else, but each
>time I'm therE I usually go through an initial phase of sort of a loneliness
>and
>unsettling sense of loss, followed by, thankfully, beautiful acceptance and
>friendship and love and smiling and all that good stuff.

I think it's more than just a coincidence that ecstasy and epiphany both
start with e.  ;^)

I would have to agree with your assement, Tim, it has more to do with "that
stuff" than anything else.  Drugs are funny like that.  Especially
hallucinogens.  When I first started "that" I kept telling everyone that it
was truth serum, then I told them that I loved them...

Tony

To: timothym@ocf.berkeley.edu
From: reza@uclink.berkeley.edu (Reza Morin-Dayani)
Subject: Cool Thread |^)
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Wow!!!
     Ethan's Party was soooo much fun!!!  I know what you mean about the
moments of introspection and the desire to ride off into the sunset with a
contented smile.  I'm often torn between embracing the vibe or rejecting it
as a as a state of drug induced mass euphoria.  It helps to kow that short
of a few dazed and drooling peking moments I can dance just as hard, feel
the same elation and experience the same childlike fascinations without the
use of pharmaceutical refreshments.  Until recently I'd never mixed drugs
and dancing.  I love the things I've experienced so far, I've learned so
much about my self and life in general.  It's wonderfull when positive
individuals can congregate todance, talk and share in experiences which can
seem only too unusual in every day life.  A smile and a hug will go a long
way no matter where you are.  

My first ExpErience was at a full moon on a beach in santa cruz.  Everything
about that day was so perfect that I couldn't imagine how anything could
ever compare.  I waited a while before partaking again and in the interim I
did alot of thinking.  I came to the conclusion that so long as I continue
to be happy with my life and my progess towards short and long term goals
it's quite alright to experience whatever life has to offer to it's fullest
degree.  E is for ecstacy but like anything else can also be used for
escape.  In my limited experience I have found that drugs can be educational
when used not to escape life but to enhance it.  That's what I believe life
is all about:: learning, growing, and experiencing the world around you.

                                        Smiles,
                                                  Reza

Well, even though it is several days after the fact(came down with the 
infamous "raver cold") just wanted to say that Ethan's B-day party was 
GREAT! (thank you Ethan) A big hello to all the wonderful people I met, 
Amy, Tony, Lydia, Timothy, Michael, Monicat, Gringbeast, Brian D.(thanks 
for the awesome massage), Brian G.(does give a mean hug), Brian T., and 
everyone else I may have inadvertently forgot. It was really nice to sit 
down, and start talking like old friends. As impersonal as text can be 
sometimes, it was a nice feeling to think that I came to know people 
through this list and the discussions we all have had. 

                                               Black Adder

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> Jon>p.s.  Punk IS dead
> 
> Then what is The Rollins Band,  and KMFDM ?

The Rollins Band _was_ punk, cf. Life Time, Hot Animal Machine.  Their
latest album is the most unlistenable bunch of jazz-metal bullshit wank I
have ever had the displeasure to hear, with the possible exception of "Liar"
which manages to rise above the music.  I mean, ads for PowerBooks and The
Gap speak for themselves.
	I won't slag on him too badly, because his older books, spoken word
shows, and music have been a source of strength for me in hard times.  Anyone
who can write passages like this:

	"To try and walk through walls...Brilliant people sit perfectly still 
with contented smiles on their faces, their end calculated down to the last
breathing moment.  They know damn well that you can't walk through walls.
That's brilliant.  This brilliant guy once asked me "How did you get all those
bumps on your head?"  "From trying to walk through a wall, you idiot!"
I replied.
	
deserves a great deal of credit.

	KMFDM is guitar-industrial that occasionally sounds almost as good as
Ministry did circa "Burning Inside".

	Neither currently challenges anyone's assumptions about how life can
be lived.  By this standard, rave is more punk than punk has been for a long
time, with the possible exception of Fugazi and other hardcore DIY bands.
There is nothing different about getting up on stage at a club and playing
rock instruments, no matter what you sing about.

// g

I caught nice sets from Ruben and Mark Farina at Simply Done last night,
the joint doesn't get going full speed until about 2am, but it's reliable.
This weekend, try the Stompy party on Friday, Funky Tekno Tribe on 
Saturday (if you don't mind driving to Santa Cruz for a big party), and
then Sunset (if it's happening) and the big Spundae party on Sunday.  

Orb tickets are on sale now at Rough Trade in the Haight for $20, no
service charge.  

I'm not going to make the text version of the calendar for ftp'ing anymore
unless there's a big protest.  Those of you without web access can ftp
the HTML file directly (/raves/sf/calendar/sfrcal.html) or use lynx
(lynx http://hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/sfrcal.html).

Thanks for all of the input so far.


                               THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/sfrcal.html

       281-3377.

       90.1 Stanford

       90.3 (SF)

       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To svbscribe or
   unsvbscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   svbscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsvbscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To svbscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   svbscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

Dear All;

	Did someone say fundraiser, just a friendly reminder that I'm
available to all promoters to provide massage therapy/first aid at the
fundraising events, for sliding % proceeds given to a cause. Which means,
depending on the cause I provide massage at your event, and donate a
percentage of the proceeds to the cause. Like AIDS & FOOD type benefits
get +110% of by proceeds, and others causes vary depending on how
important it is to me. Of course 1st aid is always free, as it should be, 
and can be there at our event to do just that. See ya

Precedence: bulk

Dear All;

	The warmer weather is upon us. Dehydration and Heat Prostration
are our to biggest ememies and some of my biggest concerns. During the
hotter days please please drink lots o fuilds, if you start getting a head
ache that just won't go away, or a general shitty feeling, these are some
of the 1st signs that your on da road to trouble. Be aware, check in with
your body, it only takes a few seconds to do that, take frequent breaks.
Ampfedtamines can speed up this process, dramically, so please promoters
have ice avilable, & fans or a room with da AC on, 1st aid people have a
oral thermometer available to access body temperature(I always have one
available), you can literally cook your brain, please if in doubt, find a
cool, shadey place, and rub yourself or have someone else(ew ew :)
prevention can be fun) with ice and drink fuilds. Don't hesitate to
approch me or another and ask for help, its never too much trouble and I
promise I won't thing you're neurotic. I want to meet your all with smiles
on your faces, not crying because you thing your going to die, even though
thats ok too. The best way to deal with this is to prevent it, and as
always I''m available to hold your hand if your scared :).


		Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		  a.k.a. Brian Darkness, LMT/EE/CET
		(510)-547-5984 CT Active Voice & Fax
	     (510)-251-4735 CT Active Voice Mail & Pager

		Internet:		brianv@liberty.com
		Alt. Internet:		brianvan@liberty.com

As a service to you and my pals who own some of these stores, I'll go ahead
and give away the goods.  You can dial 411 for info & number:

SF
==
BPM - on Polk St.
Star Alley Records - 1 block South of Hayes cross street is Gough
Tweekin - lower Haight.  Pierce is the cross street
Soundworks - Valencia & 15th (415-487-3930)

Berkeley
========
Leopold
Primal - on Telegraph

San Jose
========
Solid Grooves/Outer Rhythm - S. Bascom (408-999-0259)


There are lots more that have used records and the like.  But the above is
where the bulk of dance music is distributed.  Some of the stores have
serious attitude unless you're one of the major DJ's.  But most of them
have staff that are willing to assist you in your selection of material.
Shop around and see which store suits your musical taste and style.  IT
will take a while to see  the relative strengths of each store.  Discovery
of this is part of the adventure.

Have fun, but most of all have deep pockets.  It's a drug that should  be
illegal ;).

Audi 5000, Mercedes 350 SL, & Acura Legend,
John

P.S.  You think that there's a heirarchy in the clubs when it comes to DJ's
huh?  You ain't seen nothing when it comes tno record shopping.  The
pecking order, & perks that come with being a well-known, constantly
playing DJ, makes the club stuff look lame.  Maybe one day I'll post some
of my observations.


                "Prejudice is the reason of fools." - Voltaire
              jsl@netcom.com - public key available upon request

 A side note to visiting record stores - you may make a good impression
if you bring your own headphones to preview the music with. The store's
headphones get beat up from constant use , and are expensive to replace.

 1/8" stereo plug size seems to be the norm - none of the stores I've
been to use the old 1/4" stereo plugs on their amplifiers.

Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri May 26 08:34:34 1995

Larry C, bay area old-timer sed:
 A side note to visiting record stores - you may make a good impression
if you bring your own headphones to preview the music with. The store's
headphones get beat up from constant use , and are expensive to replace.

 1/8" stereo plug size seems to be the norm - none of the stores I've
been to use the old 1/4" stereo plugs on their amplifiers.

Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

Counterpoint & addition:
I agree with Larry.  What I have found is that some stores discourage use of thier phones (like BPM & Solid Grooves).  So it is a good practice to bring your
own phones.  The other thing is the type of headphones @ each store are in
various states of either disrepair or functionality.

My lowdown:
BPM - shitty headphones, terrbile listening stations.  Bring phones.  If you
can bring some new turntables and amps too.

Star Alley - What listening sation?  Know what you're looking for, since
they generally do not allow the general public behind the decks, IF the
DJ ain't busy they might play something for you (Charlotte aka the Baroness
is quite kind and will play what you want w/o any 'tude).

SoundWorks - 4 listening stations with cheap-ass headphones.  Bring your
own.  BTW: Observe the common courtesy in these stores.  Try not to bring a friggin caseload of record to listen to during busy days.  One day @ Soundworks
some schmuck literally had over 150 records and hogged a station for 2 hours
during the most crowded time.  Very selfish.  Be reasonalbe and give folx a chance to purchase.  The merchant will thank you.

Tweekin - 2 Listening stations.  Terrible tables, 1 of the amps is real shoddy.
Also the listening station is way too close to the "preview/wannabe" area. SO you'll have to turn your shit up loud at times.  Also, even w/ a no smoking sign posted, bastards still light up in there.  I think next time I'm there, I'll politely 
ask the offender to stop.  Other than that it's ok.

Primal Records - 3 Listening stations.  Actually quite nice compared to the drivel displayed in other stores.  The headphones are nice, the tables in good condition (btw ALL of the decks there are 1200's).  You do have to turn it up a bit since Rob
is usually previewing stuff, and often times people are practicing w/ the latest.

(Note: Soundworks also sports all 1200's at their stations).

Solid Grooves - 4 sations.  Fairly nice equipment.  Bring your own phones else you might get a pair in disrepair.  So far though that has happened to me just once.  Good stations, even a cd listening area, only 1 cornball 1200 wannabe deck.
The others are 1200's.  Their preview/wannabe area is controlled pretty
well so you should be able to hear what you want w/o too much interference.


Record store owners:  If you want people to buy your goods, be sure that folx have a chance to listen to their chosen cuts.  Turn the demo/preview/wannabe area
down some will ya!  geez...

Like larry said, bring phones that will do either 1/8" or 1/4".  You can't go wrong then.

Pax,
John

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri May 26 09:00:51 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id JAA03979; Fri, 26 May 1995 09:00:51 -0700
Received: from netcom20.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id JAA03970; Fri, 26 May 1995 09:00:47 -0700
Received: by netcom20.netcom.com (8.6.12/Netcom)
	id IAA24028; Fri, 26 May 1995 08:55:05 -0700
Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 08:55:05 -0700
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Message-Id: <199505261555.IAA24028@netcom20.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Record Stores part #3 - The 'tude is loose.
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Ok, I'm going to bust myself and give up some more goods about our
wonderful record stores in the area.  They are from my *own* experiences,
and my observations of other folx experiences.  Your mileage may vary.


Tweekin' - I have had hit and miss experiences w/ this store.  First let
me say that their selection is impressive.  A fvorite haunt of the
old-school cracker jack set, as well as mf's tryin' to push up.  I have
never had a good time at this store.  Yes, I've bought some great records
there, but their general attitude is, "You ain't so-and-so, so you ain;t
shit."  I get a wierd vibe in there everytine I visit.  I've4 talked to
one of the owners about it, and I will start dealing exclusively w/ him.
The other two blokes who work there are not helpful and are really into
being 'tude dudes.  Go in with heavy armor, pick out your records, buy
them, go home and practice, get really good, play out, become known, play
some really big parties, get even better known, and *THEN* you can go in
and be greeted w/ some respect.  Until then, welcome to the thrall.  They
do have some good records though, and even I have had to backpeddle from
saying "I'll never go in there again." due to the bombs they have had.

Soundworks - I really like this store.  The people are REALLY nice.  It's
run by some of SanFrandisco's gay set and has none of the pretense other
stores in the area may or may not have.  They are very happy to help you
choose your records, and they will tell you what they are playing and
whenre it's located.  I really can't go on enough about the attitude in
the place, since I have had nothing but good experinces w/ this store.
Tom is the guy I usually deal with, and if you wanna know about any music
the store has, he's the man to ask.  The DJ preview area does get loud at
times, but in general it does not hamper you choosing records.  If once
of the boys are behind the decks, and you hear a song you like, ask 'em,
and they'll tell you where it is.  Oh, is that the last copy he's
currently playing?  He'll usually take it right off and hand it to you.
They wanna sell records, and it shows.  It is also THE cleanest record
store in the area, and nicely laid out.

Solid Grooves/Outer Rhythm - One of my favorite places to shop.  The
staff is always ready to help and goes above and beyond the call of duty
to get the track you want.  They are more than happy to gtet you what you
want, and, if you ask real nice, will sell their own records to you *if*
you ask real nice, and want it bad enough.  More importantly, they care
about their customers.  There is a freindly rapport they have with
everyone who enters the store.  You are greeted w/ a smile and if all the
staitons are full, they will invite you to the wannabe/preview area so
that you can listen to the records you chose.  They do hella special
orders.  Brandon's the man, or talk to Ryan, or Mark.  All of them are
down to earh and ready to help.  The record selection is really good.
You'll find what you want, if not they'll order it for you!

BPM - Hmmmm...I haven't shopped there enough to give any critique other
than what I witnessed there while shopping a while back.  Most of the big
DJ's like to shop there. Uhhhh...yeah, that's it.


Part #4's coming up...the pecking order.

Pax,
John

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri May 26 09:49:24 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id JAA08261; Fri, 26 May 1995 09:49:24 -0700
Received: from netcom20.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id JAA08248; Fri, 26 May 1995 09:49:20 -0700
Received: by netcom20.netcom.com (8.6.12/Netcom)
	id JAA04795; Fri, 26 May 1995 09:48:30 -0700
Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 09:48:30 -0700
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Message-Id: <199505261648.JAA04795@netcom20.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Record Shopping - Are *you* a *DJ*?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Undeniably, the second worse feeling in this scene is not having
enough juice to be considered *worthy* during record shopping (of
course for any real partygoer the worse thing is Not being on the
guest list ;) ).  What I mean is:  "Hey, how do those guys get the
bombs before everyone?" or "Why is that guy unloading a box directly
into a brown bag labeled 'DJ x'?" or "Why can't *I* buy that record,
NOW!?"

If you're asking yourself or other people *ANY* of the above
questions, consider yourself part of those that are not to be
considered.  Not to be considered that is, unless you spend lotsa
$$$'s in any particular store.  Short of that, you've gotta have a
name to have game.  And, IMO, it sucks!!!

Most stores in the Bay Area do the bulk of their business w/ people
who "wannabe" a DJ.  The other chunk is people who love house music,
the other 1% are the DJ's who spin to eat.  The one's who spin to eat
are in a category of their own (let's face it, their pro's), and are
treated like it.  For these top 1% of DJ's the stores will generally:

-Get a shipment in and reserve the choice cuts for the pro's. 
-Give heavy discounts to the pro's. 
-Give all kinds of preferential treatment. 
*If you have a cut on hold, and it's the last one, and a
DJ needs it, it may be removed from your bag and put into that of the
purchasing DJ. 
*Some of the stores are owned by DJ's and they *do*
look out for each other.  Some stores owned by DJ's look out for
themselves occasionally and will deny you a cut because they need it.
 Sometimes people forget *who* the *customer* is.

-Preview a shipment for a DJ and reserve the cuts they think a DJ
might like. 

*I have NO evidence for what I am about to say.  But
let's just say I do notice trends as they happen.  In short, I think
that often times a record store orders tracks for a DJ, or finds a
single cut for a DJ.   Until the DJ plays the cut, you will *not*
find that cut.  Once the cut is played, you will notice "new
arrivals" of material that you heard 2 - 3 weeks ago.  If you're
lucky 1 week.  I think this is intentional.  I also think it is a
necessary pact w/ the devil (read pro DJ).  If I'm a store owner, and
I have a feeling DJ x will like a tune, I would order it.  Just one
copy (I have a biz to run and I have to keep my inventory as low as
possible).  If he/she plays it out, and they crush hella heads, I can
rest assured that if I order more they will sell.  But since the DJ
has not used it out all that much, they want to get some wear before
the biting public (read DJ wannabe's) has access.  So I suspect that
they notify the dealer that the track works.  The dealer delays the
order by a week to give the DJ time to work it.  Next thing you know
it's readily available.  It works, but this sucks.

DJ's view or pref-treatment:
Let's face it, if you know your favorite DJ shops @ a particular
store, and you wanna buy some records, like the ones your fav DJ
plays, where you gonna go? Probably to the store they shop @.  And
beleive me, a DJ knows this and uses it to their advantage. 
Rightfully so, IMO.  It sucks, but I can understand how/why they
leverage their juice.  Hell, I know that if *I* am bringing bizness
to a store in really large volumes, that I want to be compensated for
the store actually cashing-in on my rep.  The buck has gotta be
passed.

(BTW:  On the above note, I am supplying this info as a favor to an
inquiry. Right now it is diffuclt to glean info from anybody about
anything. I am doing this to bring bizness to my friends, and to also
keep house music alive and well.  It can only flourish if people
purchase. Simple as that. I am NOT posting this info to get
discounts/treatment/whatever.  Where I have juice I have juice.  Where
I don't, I don't.  I shop everywhere I can, and enjoy buying
records. Just thought you wanted to know if my angle was anything
other than being the Oracle of the Sphinx.)

Not all DJ's do this, but I know if I could, I would take advantage
of it. I use my economic clout to get what I want.  The problem is I
can;t spend enough money to have juice everywhere, so I concentrate
my spending in areas where I'll be the most comfortable.  So far that
has been Soundworks & Solid Grooves.  Now I don't get any set-asides,
but I do get treated well @ both locations.  Primal has also been
very good to me, and I hope to increase my bizness there during the
summer.

In short, don't get mad.  There's really not much you can do.
Boycotting stores that give pref-treatment is non-effective. 
Especially since everyone wants to be a DJ these days.  Where 10
people drop off, there are another 30 ready to buy.  I think most
importantly it's good to know who you're doing bizness with.  Develop
a rapport with the owner, order some stuff special order thru them,
and thank them if they help you out.  Introduce yourself so that they
get to know you, and shop there often.  Spending money also helps
them get to know not only you as a person, but you as a money
spending record buying junkie who'll they'll have hooked in a
fortnight.  One more fortnight and you're theirs.  They know it and
use it, you should use it as well.

Peace.....


Part 5 - The dealers in the game of vinyl heroin.


-John

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri May 26 14:43:32 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id OAA06451; Fri, 26 May 1995 14:43:32 -0700
Received: from netcom20.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id OAA06445; Fri, 26 May 1995 14:43:28 -0700
Received: by netcom20.netcom.com (8.6.12/Netcom)
	id OAA01365; Fri, 26 May 1995 14:42:38 -0700
Date: Fri, 26 May 1995 14:42:38 -0700
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Message-Id: <199505262142.OAA01365@netcom20.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: whatsa "wannabe"
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I received a pice of mail from someone on the list, noting my use of
the word "wannabe".  By the tone of the note, the person took it as a
slightly insulting word.  Au contraire mon frere...

I use the word because IMO it is accurate.  If you are buying records
in the hopes of spinning out, then you must wanna be a DJ.  If you
have aspirations of playing for one of the large parties, or even the
now mythic "Wicked", then you too are classified as a wanna be. 
Hell, I even box myself in that corner.  It's not meant to be a
slight against anyone, or any person aspirations.  But there are
people who are DJ's, and there are the rest of us hoping for *any*
chance to play outside of our homes & dwellings.

There is of course the other wannabe that I really despise.  You will
definitely meet them as you shop.  Yes, they are the ones who get a
huge stack of records,  and *try* to mix.  Now, once again, I have
nothing against people mixing, and having a blast, but why do it @ a
store.  More importantly why do it when you have NO INTENTION OF
BUYING.  Hell, I've seen it plenty of times.  Someone comes into a
record store, not to buy, but to listen.  Now while some of you might
say , "Hey man, music is for everyone.  Why not just take some time
and listen to some tunes.  There's no harm in that!", you would also
forget about people like me, and others who are there to BUY. 
Therein lies the difference.  People like us, the purchasers, the
hooked, the junkies, are the lifeblood of this cottage industry.  If
a wannabe is hoarding records , just to listen, then I have no
opportunity to purchase the tune, especially if its the last one in
stock.  I leave the store w/o making the purchase, the store loses my
business, but the wannabe has had his fill, and has left the
establishment w/o purchaing anything.  Everyone loses then.

There are certainly times when I'm not so hardcore.  Mostly when a
store has a slow day.  Or if a store, like Ameba (I've not been in
since they started selling discs), or Behind the Post Office,
Tweekin', Primal etc. has some decks and someone wants to go off,
then its all good.  But when a store has got new product to sell, and
the store is packed, DJ practice time ain't then IMO.

I guess my last experience @ Soundworks w/ the guy who had over 100
records is still sitting bad in my gut.  I have also spotted the same
weenie @ Solid Grooves, doing the same thing.  Hogging the decks. 
Death row, whata wannabe know!

I'm quite done for today.  I did not mean to offend by using the word
wannabe, since I apply it to myself in my ambition to get better @
this particular art form.  But as you can see, the hunt & lust for
vinyl has it's ugly side too.  Its a fight of the fittest for the
best vinyl.  She's a tempestuous mistress, that shiny Jet Black,
sometimes, Clear woman we know as Lady Vinyl.

Peace & have a good weekend all!, 
John

P.S.  That P-Dog is throwing a little hoe down tonite.  Stompy Stomp
All Night Dance Concert w/ John Howard, Mark Farina, & Frankie
Feliciano.  Should be a good party, even for a Friday.  Yep, it's @
Townsend so it's 21+ (suprise huh?).  Bring ID, they have even carded
Crunch.  Yikes!!!

At 1:10 PM 5/26/95, Hoss Sarbaz wrote:
>What is the funniest or the cutest thing or situation you have seen,
>heard of, or come across at a party or "rave"????
>
>I bet there are some juicy stuff out there too!! so spill the beans people!!
>
>Hoss

        Dancing and chewing some gum and blowing bubbles at like 6-7 am
(when EVERYONE wants gum) and having this wide-eyed ;) girl come up to me
and grab my shoulder and say "Hey Hey how are you? Can i have a piece of
gum?" I say "sure!" and as i reach to get it out of my pocket she says "I
hope it's watermelon flavour, that's my faaaavorite" "ha ha ha" i say as i
pop a piece in her mouth.
        She must have thought she was having taste hallucinations, i mean,
how many ppl chew watermelon bubblegum other than me?
        I think she might have cracked a couple of ribs with her hug. :)

Subject: The Queen Of Between
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Here is a poem I thought some of you might like ... not much to do with
raving, but it caught my attention.  The author is a woman from Coquitlam
named Renee Norman, and it was recently published in The Vancouver Sun.


____________

The Queen Of Between



deep in cyberspace

i tap out clever messages that

sizzle

my reluctance has given way to

full screen abandonment

i am naked but unseen

i am sultry in my

old jeans

i will say

anything be

anyone and

with a flick of

control x

i send waves of

emotion spiralling through

the net

entering entering

internetting

i am the queen of

between

seduced by a computer

until the dog throws up

and cyberspace dissipates into

rug cleaner

i rub circles with

my cloth wand

i am spreading oil

on water

i am coloring the

world with

foam

one reality

another

i am bent but willowy in

supplication

i will rub

anything be

anyone

i am the queen of

between

seduced by a rug cleaner

then the phone rings

and =8A

bye, renee

________________________

__________________________________________

vuja de ... the strange feeling that none of this
has ever happened before.

Hi, this is Bruce Eisner, author of the venerable Ecstasy: The MDMA Story.  Since I'm probably one of the 
oldest ravers, my roots go back to the 60's, when I was a "hippie."  Hippies liked rock music and along the 
way to the 'Ninties and raves, I had a few favorite rock bands.  One of them, Stone Roses is playing at the 
Warfield on the 31st.  Now I realize this doesn't have anything to do with raves (at least not recently, back 
when the Stone Roses first came out in England, they were considered part of a new genre of bands 
connected with the rave scene there, playeed on the Isle of White etc.).  The Stone Roses came out with a 
great first album but tried to change labels.  Their old label got an injunction and they couldn't release 
another album for three years.  Now, they have released Second Coming and are touring.  I heard about 
the concert and found out it was sold out simultaneously. If anyone has an extra ticket and would like to sell 
it and have the company of a ex-hippie who is still somewhat a hippie and definitely a good story teller, 
please let me know soon. I found out about the concert on Alt.music.psychedelic but everyone there wants 
tickets too. I just thought someone might have wide ranging music tastes (like I do) and have an extra 
ticket.  You can contact me at any of the means below and I';ll pay  a little above face value but I'm not rich.
-------------------------------------
Bruce Eisner
Ecstasy Author 
Phone (408) 408 429-1676
Fax (408) 426-8519
E-mail: bruce@mindmedia.com

Date: 05/26/95
Time: 06:27:59

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri May 26 21:45:13 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id VAA05554; Fri, 26 May 1995 21:45:13 -0700

Subject: Re: Bay Area record stores... 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Fri, 26 May 95 06:24:50 -0800."
             <v01510101abeb8f573a29@DialupEudora> 
Date: Fri, 26 May 95 22:45:02 -0600
From: ozymandias G desiderata <ogd@selway.umt.edu>
X-Mts: smtp
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


	I gotta agree with John on this one (although I'm not from SF,
this situation holds almost everywhere you go): Store 'tude sucks
balls (to put it baldly). I have with my own eyes watched a big-name
DJ from a good-sized Northwest city open up a crate of new records and
start throwing them on the in-store deck, putting aside ALL copies of
the things he likes becase "<person X> and <person y> [both themselves
Good-Sized Northwest City Big-Name DJs] might like this" and when I
tremulously asked (tremulously because I knew what was coming) if I
might be able to buy a copy I received the Hairy Eyeball of Death.
	Fuck that! I'm a complete music fanatic. I consume records and
CDs the way most people eat or do drugs. Hell, I buy records the way
most people _breathe_ -- compulsively and instinctively. If you, as a
store-owner, refuse to sell me music because I'm not cool enough, you
are needlessly pissing off a potentially loyal and big-spending
customer (I have an order for 49 records (that's over $200 worth!) in
at Submerge in Detroit right now, f'rinstance). When I find a store I
like, I stick with it until it goes out of business (and, sadly
enough, most of my favorite stores _have_ gone out of business -- I
hope it's not my breath ;).
	However, more often than not, store employees condescend to me
and act like my enthusiasm (and cash) are unimportant. This ties in
closely with the clannish idolatry that I find to be the root of most
scene evil. This sort of bullshit has happened to me so many times
that I now buy almost all of my music by mail-order as a matter of
principle: it's cheaper, the people I deal with are friendlier, and I
can always get the music I want.
	It doesn't help that every wannabe (and I _do_ use the term
with condescension, unlike John -- there are DJs (people that spin out
or in their bedrooms or for money or at free parties but do it because
they love the music and care about the crowd) and there are wannabes
(foul leeches that DJ because it enhances their standing with their
peers and makes them "cool")) immediately jumps on every big track and
throttles the life out of it. Wannabes have a bad habit of buying
records without even listening to them, just because someone better
known than them said it was the thing to buy. I think an awful lot of
Josh Wink records get sold this way, but then again, Josh has a fair
amount of talent as well, so I won't hold it against him. You should
never buy music because it's trendy -- you should buy it because you
think it's good. This is what separates the wannabes from the real
deal -- wannabes all buy records that other people play, the DJs I
respect buy records that they like. If I owned my own store I'd be
pretty dismayed (if not disgusted) by the lemming-like behavior a lot
of the lower-echelon DJs evince.
	With that said, I do agree with John that it's a good idea to
establish a rapport with a friendly salesperson at a store. Even
though they're still pandering to you, if you're nice to them they'll
be nice _while_ they're pandering to you. My experiences at this
mysterious NW store have gone from horrendous to tolerable since I
started actually talking to the owners & employees of the store. I'm
still not gonna spend much cash there, but I can go in there without
grinding my teeth now.

	I thought I might add that my friends who frequent the Bay
Area stores recommend avoiding BPM because its records are overpriced,
and if any of you out there are technoheads, Rasputin's is the place
to go. My girlfriend was in the Bay Area a week or two ago, and she
found me two very nice records there (Mr. Ballistic Volumes 1 and 2 if
you're curious), and said that the salespeople were knowledgeable and
friendly. I know that Rasputin's has a bit of a reputation for some
people, but it's got the goods and every time I've been there (all two
of them) I've left feeling good about the store.

ONE OTHER IMPORTANT THING:

	If you know what you want, don't overlook mail-order. Granted,
none of these places can let you listen to tunes, but if you know what
you want, you don't need to, do you? Here are some of my strongest
recommendations:
	EAR/Rational music (ear-rational@xmission.com) can get just
about anything for decent prices. Dave's a nice guy and works
exclusively through the Net. I've dealt with him many times and always
been satisfied by the result. I think it speaks volumes that he's
still in business and his advertising is almost exclusively through
word of mouth.
	If Detroit music is your thing, Somewhere in Detroit
(submerge@garnet.msen.com) and Record Time (RecordTime@aol.com) are
where the greats themselves frequent and are run by genuine Detroit
techno heroes. Submerge has unspeakably great prices for the stuff
that they distribute -- four bucks per slab of vinyl, and dirt cheap
shipping. They're the true soul of underground techno, straight from
techno's motherland. And they do carry a lot of house (Simply Soul,
Happy Records, 430 West, Teknotika, Red Planet), although you and I
could have a chat on the various merits of Detroit, Chicago, New York,
and San Fran house. Record Time carries a variable quantity of stuff,
but they quite often can get you stuff nobody else in the world can.
	If you're into East Coast house and European techno (from soft
to blisteringly hard), Planet X (SpikePx@aol.com) out of New Jersey
will do right by you. Spike and Larry at Planet X are great -- tell
them what you like and don't like, and they'll set you up with good
stuff. These guys have impeccable taste. They've also been known to
mix up tapes of stuff that they think you might like and send it to
you so you can pick out the stuff you really like.
	OK, I think I've balanced the ranting and useful information,
so I'll stop here. Sometimes I just gotta let all of this stuff out of
me.

yrz,
ozy

PS - If you have cherished memories of reading "Johnny Mnemonic" from
years past, steer well clear of the movie. Good acting on the part of
Messrs. Rollins, T, Lundgren and Reeves (really! These guys are all
right in an action flick like this), great sets and wonderful graphics
sequences cannot overcome horrible directing, trashy cinemetography,
poor casting, and a cheeseball script (sorry, Mr. Gibson!). Yet more
reinforcement of my belief in Hollywood's ability to screw up my
childhood memories.

ozymandias G desiderata
personal info : http://www.mbc.umt.edu/ogd/
discographies : http://www.mbc.umt.edu/ogd/aaxz/discogs
Missoula raves: http://www.mbc.umt.edu/ogd/aaxz/raves/

Go head Bro TELL IT LIKE IT IS!
Yeah, many of these stores have reserved piles for the name DJs.
I've been shopping with some of these name DJs so I know that they
get very special treatment, including material that never makes it to the
shelves unless they don't want it.





> -Get a shipment in and reserve the choice cuts for the pro's. 
> -Give heavy discounts to the pro's. 
> -Give all kinds of preferential treatment. 
> *If you have a cut on hold, and it's the last one, and a
> DJ needs it, it may be removed from your bag and put into that of the
> purchasing DJ. 
> *Some of the stores are owned by DJ's and they *do*
> look out for each other.  Some stores owned by DJ's look out for
> themselves occasionally and will deny you a cut because they need it.
>  Sometimes people forget *who* the *customer* is.
> 
> -Preview a shipment for a DJ and reserve the cuts they think a DJ
> might like. 
[stuff deleted]


> 
> In short, don't get mad.  There's really not much you can do.
> Boycotting stores that give pref-treatment is non-effective. 
> Especially since everyone wants to be a DJ these days.  Where 10
> people drop off, there are another 30 ready to buy.  

Yup, all boycotting will do is keep you from gettin _any_ bombs
cause there are ALWAYS some hungry jackles ready to crawl over you
to get in there.  I learned this lesson personally with soundwerks where
I didn't like the fact that they would put records on my visa but wouldn't
pass the 4% discount on to me.  I decided to not shop there, problem is
that have been getting HELLA bombs these days, really good stuff, the
only person getting hurt in the boycott was me :(


>I think most
> importantly it's good to know who you're doing bizness with.  Develop
> a rapport with the owner, order some stuff special order thru them,
> and thank them if they help you out.  Introduce yourself so that they
> get to know you, and shop there often.  Spending money also helps
> them get to know not only you as a person, but you as a money
> spending record buying junkie who'll they'll have hooked in a
> fortnight.  One more fortnight and you're theirs.  They know it and
> use it, you should use it as well.
> 

Yeah, folks are worried about Acid and E and illegal drugs,
I keep tellin them it's the MUSIC that is the real subversive
force,  I spent 10 times the money last year on records then any amount of
"drugs" that I've taken in the scene.

I'm pretty happy with most of the dance stores in the Bay Area.  You deal
with the listening environment they give you as best you can.  I do *not*
buy in stores that don't have listening stations.  

My only wish is that would-be purchasers not put their fingers all over
the vinyl.  Especially if it's not a track that will go out the door
with them.  I know lots of people do that, but it leaves finger oils
on the vinyl (clearly obvious) which are dust and gunk attractors over
time.

phred

	Pure Space at the Sound Factory?!  I have to admit that I was
	totally prejudiced to this venue, I had been there before and
	the bouncers were out of control, I don't like the sound
	factory, but Donavan, Jason and crew have PROOVED that any
	venue can be redeamed if there is enough vibe (well _almost_
	any venue, I still ain't going to 16th & harrison :).  Last
	Thursday was DubTribe and Spun and the Vibe was strong, not a
	lot of people, maybe 100 tops but all came with smiles and a
	serious intent to Rave. (yes, the "R" word ) I haven't felt
	this kind of vibe within club walls in a very long time (though
	I haven't been going out as much lately) But I must say that
	Pure Space will now be on my "high rotation" list, especially
	if I got a light workload on friday. Shouts go out to peterf
	who was in the house.

by far the best store IMO is solid grooves. brandon, harry, jeff, the 
rest of the crew are the nicest people in the world. they are very 
receptive to anyone that walks thru the door, and try to accomidate 
everyone's musical taste.
as far as getting the 'bomb', know the music.. it's not that hard to find 
out what is being released and most people have fav. labels, and 
producers, so order the stuff in advanced.
i personally order all the jungle for solid grooves, mainly for my self, 
but because i know the music.
just MHO.

dj thad

Precedence: bulk

Well, I've really been enjoying jsl's running commentary on DJ stores.
Most of it reflects what I've seen, although I wouldn't put quite the
same emphasis on some of it.  But a lot of the tugging for the hot traz
goes away if you look at it like this: buy what you like, not what you
need.  Unless you're in the 1% spinning 4 food, it doesn't matter.
The great tracks that are also popular always get reordered, and they
will be around.  Case in point, Pierre's "Shine
remix of Midi Rain.  OK, that's a bit of a stretch, that one's three
plus years old, but it's findable.  

Second point, for every great track you think you need, there are three
more in the same store you haven't heard yet.  Patience and persistence
pay off.

I never had the treasure hunt mentality until I started DJing again :-)

phred

Right sed Fred sed:

>My only wish is that would-be purchasers not put their fingers all over
>the vinyl.  Especially if it's not a track that will go out the door
>with them.  I know lots of people do that, but it leaves finger oils
>on the vinyl (clearly obvious) which are dust and gunk attractors over
>time.
>
>phred

Man, I thought I was the only nit-picker when it came to this shit.  Maybe
Im just really old school (my dad taught me how to handle records
*properly* many moons ago).  But this *touching* the track shit during
buying is one of my major peeves.

Oh well, I guess the old-school must @ some point make way for the new
school.  I for one will *always* have respct for others, and the vinyl, and
keep my grubbin' junkie hands & fingers OFF the tracks.

Peace,
John

When I can wake up early enough,I like to watch it because there are many 
cool references to geek talk, like the little kid wanting to increase his 
clock speed but instead turning the rest of the world into 8-bit.  
Everything was rendered in low resolution with 16 colors and the 
characters were all dumb.

Or whenever someone seeks the sage advice of the old man Fong, they have 
to first beat him at a game of life-sized Pong.  And he quotes scriptures 
from "Old readme files".

I dunno if they still show after it Bump in the Night - 30 minutes of 
claymation and a way cool blue-bathroom-scrubber-guy named squishington, 
or squishy for short.  Yes!

Someone gave me some herbal ecstasy (I don't think I'd want to pay $20 
for it).  I took the whole package (just to be safe), and drank a lot of 
water (which was recommended).  I definately felt it, but it certainly 
didn't feel anything like the genuine artifact. It made me feel very 
awake and energetic, and it seemed to heighten tactile sensation a 
little bit.  It was kind of interesting, but I don't think I'd become a 
regular customer.  It's a little overpriced.

---------- Text of forwarded message ----------
Date: Wed, 12 Apr 95 18:38:13 EDT
From: "Philip A. Todd" <PATODD0@UKCC.uky.edu>
To: Cybertribers <umt@nexsys.net>
Subject: Request for contacts and information

     Dear Cybertribers:

     I attended a memorial rave here in Lexington several weeks ago, and I
 really enjoyed myself and expanded my horizons (this was my first rave,
 though I had previously enjoyed some of the same kind of music during visits
 to Chicago's "Cabaret Metro"...

     Among other things, I am finishing my coursework at the University of
 Kentucky towards a PhD in Musicology, which is where music theory, practice
 and history intersect with anthropology and sociology -- i.e., not just what
 kind of music is happening (or happened), but why, and why did they do that,
 and what did it mean to them, and what did it mean to the audience, and what
 does it mean now???... among other questions like the meaning of life...

     Anyway, I am presently involved in a graduate seminar on Ethnomusicology,
 which used to be the study of "ethnic" or "world" or (excuse this awful term)
 so-called "primitive" music -- which really means, non-Western-European-Art
 Music, which is actually TOO complicated for our Western music theory systems
 to handle sometimes...  and I would like to correspond/e-mail/talk/chat with
 any and all Cybertribers and Ravers...

      PRIMARILY, because I want to learn more about Rave and Techno and the
 whole Temporary Autonomous Zone -- Dance -- Music -- Family thing I saw at
 the rave in Lexington...

     SECONDARILY, because I would like to interview DJs, practitioners, fans
 and anyone else even remotely interested in this form of music/dance/event
 so that I can try to explain this to my fellow ethnomusicology students, who
 have never experienced this type of thing before (other than the several who
 are percussionists, and have a little experience in the electronic drum arena)

     FOR THESE REASONS (plus the fact that I really like what you are doing and
 want to participate again in the near future...) I want to ask anyone who is
 at all interested to contact me with information or insight or wisdom about
 any of the following:
     + When did you first experience Rave or Techno dancing and/or music?
     + What interested you in the Cybertribe or Rave family and/or music?
     + Who started this, or where did this originate, or how did this start?
     + When did you first DJ or record or create or sample or mix...?
     + What does this music/dance/experience mean to you?
     + What are your favorite artists/groups/recordings to mix and/or play?
     + WHEN and WHERE are the next Raves happening (I wanna be there!!!) ?
     + Would you be willing to share recordings/articles/books/ other stuff?
     + Who are the real authors of (Beltane 1993) "Cybertribe Rising" ???
     + How does Rave affect (or fit into) your "other" life (day job) ???
     + How do you meet/interact/communicate at Raves? away from Raves ???
     + What are the unwritten or unspoken rules of conduct at Raves ???
     + How much sponteneity is welcome at a Rave (for instance, what would
 happen if I showed up at a Rave with about five or six of my percussionist
 friends with Trinidadan steel drums and bongos and Brazilian samba toys and
 bells and brake drums and other noisemakers, and we passed them out to all
 who wanted to participate, and added some more sound to the Electronic ???
 (RELAX -- I am not at all suggesting this, I just threw out a hypothetical
 situation -- DON'T PANIC, I AM NOT GOING TO CRASH YOUR NEXT RAVE !!!)
     + What is the worst situation you've ever encountered at a Rave ???

     I have many other dumb questions, because I am fascinated by the Rave and
 wish to understand it better -- so I can participate more fully the next time
 I attend (which I hope will be soon !!!)

     PLEASE RESPOND -- NO STRINGS ATTACHED (you would just be helping me out)!

     I am especially interested in meeting Ravers in the Lexington - Louisville
 - Knoxville - Cincinnati - Indianapolis - Chicago - St. Louis - Columbus areas
 since these are readily accessible to me (just south of Lexington on I-75 in
 beautiful Berea, KY.

     Thanks!!! Peace and Much Love...

     Philip A. Todd (Phil)  (606) 986-3279  patodd0@ukcc.uky.edu


----- End Included Message -----

I just got back from the Funky Techno Tribe.  A pretty girl gave me a 
blue slip of paper.  Written on it:
Deinition of a RAVE
     A place to let go of everyday tensions. To express yourself in a 
way that's completely comfortable. It's a melting pot of souls and a 
place to learn.  You'll find truth here, I promise you.  The word 
negative has no place here.  You won't be judged, just understood.  
A place where strangers become friends and the air you breathe is 
filled with LOVE!  Lesley

-------------------------------------
Bruce Eisner

At 10:29 PM 5/27/95, Amy Titherington wrote:
>Someone gave me some herbal ecstasy (I don't think I'd want to pay $20
>for it).  I took the whole package (just to be safe), and drank a lot of
>water (which was recommended).  I definately felt it, but it certainly
>didn't feel anything like the genuine artifact. It made me feel very
>awake and energetic, and it seemed to heighten tactile sensation a
>little bit.  It was kind of interesting, but I don't think I'd become a
>regular customer.  It's a little overpriced.

        I think that a lot of the 'e' in herbal 'e' is _expectation_.  If
you think you're going to be flying, you probably will. (too bad placebo
doesn't start with e).  Seriously, though, if you want an energy boost from
hell, try getting your hands on a liquid extract of ma huang (ephedra).
I've tried this stuff and about 75-125 ml kept me dancing until 11 am (!).
It's about $20 Canadian for a 1 oz bottle.
        hugs,
                brad

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun May 28 12:52:35 1995

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: faster sweetie
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I went to Liquid at cat's alley last wednesday.  The music
was good.  People were nice.

I went to Stompy at 177 Townsend.  The music was not doing it
for me.  Stripped down 4x4 bass drum booming for it's own sake
and nothing else is At Best an amusing reference to, oh fuck, who
cares ... John Howard improved it some but I was bored so I left.

now on Saturday night

there was a private party for Malcolm Mclaren
at the Rococo Lounge and I'd been invited.  Punk rock hero and
dance music icon.  I had read of his recent involvement with fashion
show choreography; including a new runway influenced album.
(are you 'punkers' getting a clue yet?)
 
Naturally, my pre-party prediction was for a room full of 7ft tall
super vixens.  My friends know of a certain weakness I have for Cavorting
About with model thin Amazon women dressed to the nines.  I was not
disappointed.  

Mr Mclaren was introduced  - he babbled about flying in from Warsaw 
where his album is #1 and said something about the Sex Pistols last gig.
I introduced myself later.  On Satie (featured prominently in his new
music) he said "Romantic but not Stupid".  Chit chat with NY models here
for the weekend - "People from San Francisco are so much more hip".
Girls, I couldn't agree more ...

DJ melodrama.  My friend Glenn stuck to his guns.  He was asked to take
it from lounge to funk to house.  I know he was out there buying Diva stuff
to mix with Mclaren's music earlier that day and he did an excellent job.  
Glenn has a tendency to tell me endless stories of Goa Trance, Trance This,
Trance That, Crossover Trance and, as you might imagine, he sped things up
later in the evening.  People dug it.  The dance floor was full.  I step
outside and upon returning find him booted from the turntables by "a 
friend of Malcolm" who proceeded to clear the dance floor.  He was 
actually a party promoter guy for SOMA magazine (party sponsors) who
thought he could do better.  Glenn was outraged.  "I was hired to play
my music" -  "The crowd was into it" -  "I've played this stuff at regular
(non-rave) parties and people went off!"  So he reclaims the turntables and
then Mr Mclaren walks over there.  I was hoping for a truly Dramatic Blowout.
Something Spectacular.  But alas, all he did was say hello and thank him for
a job well done.

This party was all writers, radio, and industry types.  I admit to feeling
a bit like a spy there.  I had great fun, though.  I grabbed my free gift bag
and stepped outside.  Two gentleman came up and had a conversation in front
of me.  They spoke of my Entourage (twins I came with and, yes, I do like
entourages) and without blinking an eye said "Sacramento crossed with LA".
Other than the Bay Area those are the two places I have lived.  
That is a *really* wierd ability to have, in my mind.

:^)
Dave 

PS. his web page -  http://cos.gdb.org/mclaren/

Here is my story......

When we got to SantaCruz, we had to wait in line until about 10:30 because
the DJ was late... That would have been cool if it haddent been for the 4
sodas and a car full of people talking about dripping faucets and
waterfalls... Anyway, once in there I had a great time
The Music wasnt TOO loud and everyone had lots of smiles and energy.   About
oh midnite or so i started feeling EXtatic about teh whole world and began
handing out hand lotion and Vapo rub to anyone who wanted some..... about 2 I
began dancing around, asking people if they wanted some, gave some massages,
met a lot of nice people, and even saw some people I worked with.  :)

From: crunch@sysx.apana.org.au (John Draper)
Subject: Space Cadet 4 review
Cc: ausrave@smug.student.adelaide.edu.au

Precedence: bulk

Yet another wakey report from Sydney
------------------------------------

Well,  I'm finally back into the swing of things and fully recovered
from last weeks trip to Darwyn,  back into the cool spring-like winter
(if yould call it that) of Sydney.

On Monday,  went to Brackets and Jam..  Not an actual rave,   but
learned that it's een around for 7 years,  and is a place for upcoming
musicians to play and get heard.   After about 1 pm,  they close the
downstairs area and the drumming starts upstairs.   It must have been a
good night,  as there was a long line at the door to get in around
midnight or so.

Things promptly closed around 3 am..  So headed home  with good vibe in
my head,   still happy from last weekends Totum event.

On Wednesday,  I wound up at the Bently Bar for the Clan meeting.  I
wasn't impressed this time,   little or no beats,   seemed mostly noise
to me,   but I kept myself entertained,  schmoosing.

I herd on the radio,  about this new weekly gig at the Underground cafe,
so decided to check out Energy.   WOW!!  Really good trance,  hard and
fast,  just the way I like it,  mixed in with the usualy Happy Hard and
its limited selections.    I had a GREAT time,  thanx to the staff at
the Underground cafe for keeping the air conditioner running and
resetting the circuit breaker all the time.

As usual,  I danced myself like there was no tommorrow,  thanx to some
Daffy's someone handed me...   Yummm!!

Things broke apart at about 7 pm.   So I had breakfast and went to work.
It's still Friday morning in the USA (A regular workday).

After work,  I headed down to Central and picked up the tickets to Space
Cadet 4.   As usual,  being an Optus costomer,  I don't have access to
0055 numbers,   but Make Dagn got the venue information for me.   It was
down where "Happiest people" was held,  in a really cool venue
origionally used for go-cart racing.   It was huge, cavernious,  and
very cool inside.   Chillout opportunities were more than adequate,  and
about the only thing that I didn't like was the lack of soft pillows or
mats to flop own on while chilling.    Other than that,  Pheonix,  the
promoter did a bang smashup job,  scarfing up this venue at the last
minute which made for a late start.

The venue was way too big for the amount of people that showed up.   I
would gues somewhere between 1000 - 2000 people made it.

The vibe was incredable.   Lots of happy smiling faces,  and someone
came up to me and handed me an "E" because I was having such a good
time.    WOW!!  My first Aussie E.    It was nowhere near as strong as
what I was used to in the States,   but it certainly widened my smile.

Dispite my usual sleepless weekends,  this 2nd all nighter didn't fade
my energy level in the least.   Super dupper HARD music,  mixed in with
the slower hard house,  certainly kept me dancing for very long times.
And I was COOL (temperature wise that is).

WOW!!  SO much variaty here....

Lots of people I met just come up and say "I saw you at....",   and want
to know how long I've been raving.   Most are surprised to learn that I
haven't raving that long.

Upstairs was the hard-core room,   but enough hard-core on the main
floor kept me there all night.

After about 4 am,  the music got turned way down,  and zapped the
ambient energy level big-time.    I just migrated next to the speaker
which had NO bass at all,  and continued dancing.   About an hour later,
the music crept up on volume and the party continued well into the
morning until 10 am.   At about daybreak,  most people were sitting on
the side,  totally hosed,   dispite my urging to get them up to dance.

As morning progressed, my energy level was still full on and increasing
gradually until the vary last song was played.

Whaat really made this rave was the lazers.   Multi-coloured lazers that
were just out of this world.   What spectacular light show...   My
breain is still reeling from such wonderful "Eye candy" ..   The lazers
were blasting right out there into veryones eyes,  but dispite the
intensity being very low,  it wasn't that annoying.   In the USA,  this
would have been highly illegal.   One time,  the lights fanned out into
an amazing pattern that gave me the impression that I ws riding down a
swerling tunnel or being swished into a black hole.   Almost forgetting
I was dancing,   I was chasing the beams all over the dance floor,
wildly Zigging and Zagging like a raving lunatic,   with a big shit
eating smile on my face....  :-)

Man,  this has to be the very best rave I've been to since I've been in
Australia.    Good work Pheonix.   Thanx to Pheonix for Guest listing
me,   I sold my ticket for $35 to one lucky dude...   I'm not into
scamming anyone,  dipite the fact that I could have sold the ticket for
much more.

After it was over,  I went with some friends,  and eventually sent over
to Recovery,  and stayed until 1 am...   After that,  back to the
Underground Cafe beore arriving home at 3 am.    WOW!!  nice bit of
raving I did this weekend.   All though the weekend,   I stayed awake
from Friday morning until Monday morning with NO sleep.   But for me,
thats normal.   Now that it's Monday,   I feel Great!!

Till MDMA-2 next weekend,  and my LAST Australian BIG rave,   over and
out...


Crunchman

	Ahh sunset!  Vibe so strong you could cut it with a knife :)
	Galen and crew is quickly showing everyone that you can put
	on a good free outdoor party, work with the local authorities
	and generate tons of vibe at the same time.   I wasn't there
	from the beginning but when I got there around 6:30 the party
	was in full effect.  A peace officer came around 7:00 to check
	it out but didn't interrupt the fun.  They weren't seen again
	until 9:00 (the time the park closes) when a single officer
	can down the hill with a flash light and came up to Galen who
	had put on the last record (really :).  They had a brief, friendly
	exchange lasting about 30 seconds and the cop goes away. (WOW!)
	Galen finishes and thanks everyone for coming.  This is how 
	it's suppose to be folks, because Galen kept his work this cop
	knows that he can trust him in such matters, it makes his job
	easier and he is more willing to let there be "a next time".
	I also saw a real good mixture of "old timers" right along
	with some "second generation" ravers.  As long as there are
	parties like Sunset the true San Francisco Scene is not dead!



						geoffw

Subject: rave heart
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The rave heart has a beat that dances in harmony with the beats of life.  
the beat runs through us all and everything.  As we move, we dance to the 
beat, when we express ourselves, we feel the beat.  When I express the 
beat to you, I experience the beat in me and in you.  Together we feel 
the rave heart thumping to beat of life, full of energy and filled with love.
The love in the rave heart vibrates and nurishes our soul.  With our 
bodies dancing and our souls hugging the love of the rave heart is 
shared.  When the music stops, we're still dancing.  For as we interact, 
whether it be sutle or more direct, we perform a rythmic and patterned 
succession of steps.  We as individuals get to dance together, moving 
toward and with the shared beat of the rave heart.  Sharing the energy 
with the enviroment around, the shared love of life fills the air.  I 
sure do love that rave heart, for it gives me so much love in return.  
I love you all for sharing that rave heart.  With that it feels much 
better feeling the beat, knowing that deep down we all share the beat of 
the rave heart.   


peter

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon May 29 14:07:35 1995

To: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Sunset brings "rave" back into "Rave"
Date: Mon, 29 May 95 14:06:40 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Wow... it's only the day after and I'm already jonesin for more.... In
fact, I need another fix rightaway! And I'm not talking about drugs
here. Sunset was an incredible party and a beautiful day. Massive
dancing-crowd positive feedback energy got the dancing vibe going just
like "the good old days".  Watching/participating with crazed dancin'
people completely going off in broad daylight is a wonderous thing.
These parties are just getting better and better.

Proof of a good party is when you don't do any psychedelics and you
still feel like you're tripping/trancing. It's all about friendly
dancin' people, and warm sunlight and a refreshing breeze and a
gorgeous view ... I also liked the dust-cloud funk-o-meter effect --
the funkier the toonz got, the higher the dust cloud rose; when the
DJ's chilled things out a bit, the dust settled. I'd say it topped out
at a 20-30 foot high cloud at one point. Wonder what song that was?

Now that summer is here, I'm hoping Sunset and other going-off outdoor
parties become a weekly thing!

'Twas Good to finally meet a few more SFravers, and Brian McGonicle
really does give a powerful hug, it is true!

PS: Can someone post the approximate DJ lineup and times they were
playing? In particular, I'd like to know when Donald Glaude was
playing...

==     Niels Mayer -- http://cyborganic.com/~niels -- mayer@netcom.com     ==

From: Daniel Alexander Robinson <drobinso@harp.aix.calpoly.edu>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: energy distribution
Message-Id: <Pine.A32.3.91.950530011606.32498A-100000@harp.aix.calpoly.edu>

hey all,


	I attended Funky Techno Tribe this weekend and IMO it turned out 
to be a pretty cool larger venue party.  I got in the door(after waiting 
in line for an hour) at about 2:00 am.  I danced pretty much all night 
till 7:00 with breaks for socialization and rest. 
	I also went all night sober even though I had 3 little goodies in 
my backpack.  Everything I did that night was a real reflection of 
my feelings personality etc.(as they always should be).
	*But here is the most intense thing that I have experienced 
probably since I started raving, and I was wondering if anyone else can 
relate, maybe has felt the same way, or has heard of this happening to 
other people.
	My style of dance was taken to a new energy level.  But not in 
the normal frame of context.  I don't mean it was taken to the next level 
with more complex movements, more vigor, faster, or freakier.  My dancing 
was at times more intense than others ,but that is a usual cycle it seems 
for everyone.
	What I mean is that I really gave when I danced Saturday night.
Its kind of like when a good massage therapists utilizes his positve energy 
to "heal" his client.  I now understand about what they mean about 
keeping energy in a group of dancers and sometimes if a venue is too big 
it gets spread out to much.
	I feel on some metaphysical level perhaps I was *distributing 
"my personnal" positive energy to other people.  But what I mean was that 
it was all real and that I truly beleive that my psychic energy, space, 
plane, or what ever it is that sustains our life force, was healing, 
giving energy, reassurance, positivity, to others at a high level.
	I remember looking around at others giving smiles and recieving 
them back and also feeling the rush of my spinal cord when the music was 
especially uplifting.  
	*I was too tired to go to the organic after party that 
they had lined up that *started at 10am* when the party ended at 7am.
I drove home and stopped once in the early morning during the drive to rest.

	I got home and slept for a while waking about 5pm or so.
*But what I noticed different this time was that I felt okay physically 
after my sleep but emotionally something was different.  I can't really 
say depressed, bitter or, tired were the right words.  I just felt like I 
had given so much positivity to the dance that I was almost in a sort of 
debt for disrtubting such positvity at what I believe a higher level.

Can anyone relate?
It was almost like paying to have given so much of 
the vibe that night.

	I am not devoutly religious to any particular denomination but I 
once heard that "Jesus had to take time by himself and ask for power from 
god  or whatever to help him after he had healed people(gave out positive 
energy.)
	Please don't cringe if you believe that I am being too religious by 
making such a reference to christianity.  Its just that that is how I felt.

Has anyone else felt metaphysically drained in a sense?

	
I guess sometimes we give energy heavily(like I felt) and sometimes we 
recieve heavily(like when a party keeps you feeling good for days).

 peace

dan

ps this may explain some of the comedown effects e?
who knows?

Geoff:
> Ahh sunset!  Vibe so strong you could cut it with a knife :)

Oh yeah, what a day.  This was one of the better Sunsets, not that
there's ever been a bad one.  Totally Beautiful...

Things got going around 2ish with Darkhouse who started off with some nice
ambient dub.  He soon picked up the pace and more people started to
dance as Donald Glaude took over. Gluade pushed the energy level higher 
with a great funcky/techno set.  He did a little bit of the MC thing which
didn't bother me too much.  Hard to argue with stuff like "Isn't it great 
to be outdoors!"  Solar took over  before 5 with a really nice
varied set, shifting between mellow melodic stuff and more upbeat house -
perfect for the middle of a warm sunny day.  Mark Farina came on around 6,
and delivered a typically boring, but not unpleasant set.  At parties like 
this, it's actually OK when the energy level drops and allows me to do some 
socializing.

My only wish was that the day could have lasted a little bit longer, like
forever maybe.  Tons of familiar faces, lot's of SFRavers.  Met a couple
of new ones, (sorry, forgot yer names), and got to say hi and chat with 
Lydia, Geoff, Brian McG, PeterF, Niels, Gil, Ronan & others.  

Galen took over at around 7:30 and really got things going again.  People
were going nuts as the sun set, and were still screaming at the end.  

Other notes: The've been having some trouble with the sound system lately;
dusty outdoor parties take a toll -  Let's hope our donations can continue
to cover their costs.  And it seems that we still have to work on the
garbage problem a bit. 

peterf:
>Thinking about it I may be somewhat deluded by this rave heart

I don't think feeling really wonderful about stuff is a delusion.  There 
is no shortage of angry pissed off people in the world to remind us of all 
the crap going on.  We also need to be able to focus on the things that 
can unite us.  Spreading positive energy to others, helping each other 
feel good and strong, teaching and reminding the world what it is that 
we're living *for* - this is also real.  There's no point in tearing down 
the status quo without something viable to replace it with. 

Lee

lxfogel@pacbell.com   (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )   lee@hyperreal.com

When I can wake up early enough,I like to watch it because there are many 
cool references to geek talk, like the little kid wanting to increase his 
clock speed but instead turning the rest of the world into 8-bit.  
Everything was rendered in low resolution with 16 colors and the 
characters were all dumb.

Or whenever someone seeks the sage advice of the old man Fong, they have 
to first beat him at a game of life-sized Pong.  And he quotes scriptures 
from "Old readme files".

I dunno if they still show after it Bump in the Night - 30 minutes of 
claymation and a way cool blue-bathroom-scrubber-guy named squishington, 
or squishy for short.  Yes!
