Precedence: bulk


>(are you 'punkers' getting a clue yet?)

I attended a fireside chat with Malcolm McLaren at the Prescott Hotel,
 the day after his record release party at Rococo.  
About 10-15 people were there, and several of the younger hip types
repeately asked him pointed questions about the current ideological
state of 'punk'.  They seemed very dissatisfied when he refused to 
show any signs of being perturbed at the current high visibility and 
commercial success of some punk-inspired bands.  He added:

"Looking back, I see the Sex Pistols as more of a style statement; 
I have never tried to separate Pop music and fashion... with punk,
there was really not a lot of focus on the product itself.  What I 
created with the Sex Pistols was really an existential exercise, 
but of course at the time I wasn't totally aware of this; I was 
working as I always do, by instinct.  And, to be honest, it was 
also somewhat out of necessity-- I had these kids coming into my 
boutique, trying to steal trousers, and nauseating in the store...I 
had to find something for them to do..."

This was followed by a discussion of commercial music in general, 
centering around the perennial efforts of English musicians to break
into the American market.  I diverted the conversation and asked him
what he thought of the 'rave' phenomenon.  He had some general things
to say ... "repetetive beats ... kids needing escape ... lagerheads 
on E ... criminial justice act .. etc etc " and then the really pithy
question,
"the problem is, how do you make it carry over?  What happens in the morning
when the beats stop?"

  there are hundreds of ways to answer that question...

But we went on with a lively discussion of how raves can satisfy a 
*basic* human need, one which has been identified by anthropologists
but that is all but ignored in adult western society; this is the 
need to feel a belonging to and be surrounded by a larger social 
group, outside of one's immediate circle of family and friends.  A
'tribe', if you will...

*-:) -barnoc

>after my sleep but emotionally something was different.  I can't really

>ps this may explain some of the comedown effects e?

        I can relate.  This often happens to me if i put a lot of energy
into things and don't get much back...at least not immediately.  Doesn't
matter what it is, relationships, work, school (thankfully i'm finished
with that though =) ) but especially when i go out.  I remember feeling
very similar to how you've discribed your state after for about a week last
sept.  All i wanted to do was sleep.  I really do believe that there is a
lot more going on in the world than is perceptible and i think that the
flow of 'energy' is a big part of it.  If it's a synergistic thing you can
end up elated, if you give until it hurts you can be drained.  The good
part of this story is that last sept, after this big blowout party i went
for a week feeling like crap, then had _a lot_ of people approach me at
other parties or at clubs and say "hey i remeber i met you at pure, you
helped me out with this" or "you did this and it was so nice" or other
things like that so it all comes back to you...:)
        brad

On Tue, 30 May 1995, Daniel Alexander Robinson wrote:


> 	I feel on some metaphysical level perhaps I was *distributing 
> "my personnal" positive energy to other people.  But what I mean was that 
> it was all real and that I truly beleive that my psychic energy, space, 
> plane, or what ever it is that sustains our life force, was healing, 
> giving energy, reassurance, positivity, to others at a high level.

I've come to a similar realization, Daniel. It seems that at first when you 
relax and are open to it, one feels the  vibe/energy/love. Then, as we 
become more familiar with it, we can *become* the energy/love/vibe. Once 
we've learned to integrate this energy into our being, we can then 
learn to project it onto others.    


> 	I remember looking around at others giving smiles and recieving 
> them back and also feeling the rush of my spinal cord when the music was 
> especially uplifting.

Looks like you found yourself a set of Luv Phasers (Ver. '95) 
   
> 	*I was too tired to go to the organic after party that 
> they had lined up that *started at 10am* when the party ended at 7am.
> I drove home and stopped once in the early morning during the drive to rest.
> 
> 	I got home and slept for a while waking about 5pm or so.
> *But what I noticed different this time was that I felt okay physically 
> after my sleep but emotionally something was different.  I can't really 
> say depressed, bitter or, tired were the right words.  I just felt like I 
> had given so much positivity to the dance that I was almost in a sort of 
> debt for disrtubting such positvity at what I believe a higher level.

Though this energy is incredibly beautiful and strong, it takes a while 
to fully understand it, then integrate it to a point where you can give 
to others and not be so drained. I'm still working with it myself. 


> Can anyone relate?
> It was almost like paying to have given so much of 
> the vibe that night.

Not a debt, Daniel. Just unfamiliarity. I recall giving  so much one 
night that I almost passed out! I still get drained, but I'm getting 
better at controlling this energy so I don't get so worn out. Always nice 
to save a little for the afterparty.  |)

> I guess sometimes we give energy heavily(like I felt) and sometimes we 
> recieve heavily(like when a party keeps you feeling good for days).

And then, sometimes both! That's the key I think, getting to a point 
where we can all *share* this energy unconditionally, without becoming 
emotionally drained.

I've found it difficult share this energy for a few reasons:

	-	My personal energy level is low. Sunset was very nice. 
		Wonderful people, wonderful energy, beautiful views, but 
		I felt really emotionally worn (I checked my biorythyms, and 
		I'm at -8. Yikes!), So I couldn't give like I wanted to. 
		I just sat and soaked up the energy around me. Yum!

	-	There are those who are greedy/needy for this energy. Some 
		don't fully understand what is happening at these events, 
		and when the feel/experience this energy, the want to cling 
		to it because they don't know how to create it themselves.
		Sometimes, these people DEMAND it (a friend calls them 
		rapists). At first I got really uncomfortable when these 
		people were around, but I now feel I can smother them in so 
		much energy, that their presence no longer upsets me.

 
	-	Then there are times when I feel It just won't do any 
		good. I feel that others have to be receptive to this energy 
		in order for you to be able to project it and affect 
		them. For me, this happened at a basement Wicked at DV8. 
		I was all ready to give, but it just didn't FEEL right with 
		the crowd (fancy that).

Sometimes, I think I'm crazy for believing this projection of energy 
actually happens. But as we all know, there are things outside our conditioned 
certainty which can very easily be real.

This projection of energy/vibe-I believe this is what Geoff is talking about 
when he posts the challenge of taking responsibility for creating the energy 
at a party that has no vibe.

Then again, I could be thinking too much. I tend to do that.  ;)

Jonas  



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue May 30 17:19:26 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id RAA15465; Tue, 30 May 1995 17:19:26 -0700

Date: Tue, 30 May 95 16:27:08 PDT
Subject: Brothers & Sisters Line Up
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
X-Mailer: Chameleon - TCP/IP for Windows by NetManage, Inc.
Message-ID: <Chameleon.4.01.1.950530172315.ameba@ameba.ameba.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Thanks to all who came down to Brothers and Sisters last week.

This week's line-up is:  Tracy
                                       Spun
                                       Jan Cooley
As usual anyone from SF Raves gets in free on our guest list.
Just tell the girl at the door that you are from SF Raves and it will be all good.
Thanks for all the support, hope to see you all this Friday at 1015.
And to all of those that are worried about the vibe for one reason or another.
The club always gets better when the bar closes because shortly after that the 
gold room closes, since that seems to be the one that apalls certain 
individuals.  

I think that we all need to drop out pre-conceived notions that because 
someone is wearing a suit or dressed nice means that there is something 
wrong with them.  I have been the resident dj for Brothers and Sisters, 
formally Soundsystem for six months now.  I must admit, at first I thought 
they were dorks but after meeting a few of them I discovered that alot of them 
are cool people that have never experienced a good groove.  There are several
so called "suits" that come to Brothers and Sisters regularly that are really 
good people just trying to unwind with their friends.  I think that it is about 
time that we drop the negitive stereotypes and start communicating.  That way 
rather than judging people based on what they look like, take the time to find 
out what they are about, you may be surprised, there are a lot of subversive 
individuals out there you just have to get past fear and introduce yourself.
If we want our scene to grow and maintain diversisty we need to start being 
less closed-minded and judgemental of people that we have never met.  There 
are good people and bad people.  Anyway, what were you like before you 
discovered the House Movement?  Sometimes we all seem to forget our past.

Just a few kind words.

dj Tracy, Brothers and Sisters

and what they wear, their color or whatever really is unimportant
-------------------------------------
E-mail: ameba@netcom.com           !   boredom makes
Date: 05/30/95                                   !   you do crazy   
Time: 16:27:08                                 !    things

salutations
-------------------------------------

hey everyone,

  here are some reviews  of the Wicked possee's gig in DC on Sat. night.
it was called Big Top and was held out back of this club in DC called
Tracks.

doug ) ( doug@squishy.com 
---------- Forwarded message ----------

Reply-To: Scott C Sattler <kimmel@gwis2.circ.gwu.edu>
Sender: "Washington D.C. Rave List" <DCRAVES@american.edu>
From: Scott C Sattler <kimmel@gwis2.circ.gwu.edu>
Subject:      BIG TOP
To: Multiple recipients of list DCRAVES
              <DCRAVES@LISTSERV.AMERICAN.EDU>

hello everyone.
would some one please write a review of BIG TOP because i did not/could
not/would not get out of my miserable hovel and go. the real reason is
because i'm studying for boards and i need to sleep in order to function
the next day. anyway, my existance, at present, sucks, but i'm sure the
life-quality quotient of anyone that went last night has escalated into
the cosmos. or am i horribly mistaken? whatever the case, how was jeno's
set? just how much cotton candy can a single human consume? does cotton
candy remedy cramps induced by dancing/sweating? is there any adverse
reaction between amphetamine and any of the 6 billion compounds that
compose cotton candy? just how was that wooden dance floor, and did you
ever stop to think how many cute, elderly couples had done the waltz
across it in the past? so many questions.
thanks.
scott
stuck in the damn library till june 14th.

From: Shawn Wills <swills@RWD.GOUCHER.EDU>
Subject:      big top
Comments: To: NE-RAVES@UMDD.UMD.EDU, DCRAVES@american.edu
To: Multiple recipients of list DCRAVES
              <DCRAVES@LISTSERV.AMERICAN.EDU>

i feel the only successful elements of big top were the attendance of the
wonderful people i call my friends...this party didn't do much to inspire
my respect of dc parties.
 
though a minor element...i think the first thing that really bothered me
about big top was the $3 price tag for little bottles of water...granted,
security didn't seem to be denying people the privilege of bringing their
own water..but, i didn't bring a bottle of water to be potentially not
allowed to bring.  i mananged to survive getting drinks from my
friends..but i eventually broke down and shelled out three the $3.
 
the overall feel of the party was club with a capital 'club.'   there
were some musical highlights of the evening...i heard some great acid and
some really nice house...but in all the sets but one ( there was one dj's
set that i liked in it's entirety ( i think he spun two people after
scott henry )), every time i started to ride a groove, the dj would
interupt it with a really cheesy, clubby house tune...i think the musical
low of the evening was 'i am ready' being spun three times i think... the
crowd didn't seemed to like this quite a bit, which is my point...it was
definitely club music, and a club crowd
 
i spent a lot of time sitting talking to people...which was really
wonderful, because, as i mentioned before, there were a lot of wonderful
people there...i seemed to get a consensus that i wasn't the only person
that desired more than i was being delivered in the music...there just
weren't that many songs that really made us want to dance...  the people
that i had an opportunity to spend an evening with are the only reason
i'm not completely pissed off for spending $15 on an evening underneath a
tent erected in a parking lot behind tracks.
 
based on this party..i don't think i'll be in attendance at any other
buzz crew productions

From: danFREELove <anarchy@GLUE.UMD.EDU>
Subject:      Big big big big TOP!
X-To:         DC Raves Mail List <DCRAVES@AMERICAN.EDU>,
              NE Raves - CyberTribe <ne-raves@umdd.umd.edu>
To: Multiple recipients of list NE-RAVES <NE-RAVES@UMDD.UMD.EDU>

Well, it was, pardon the pun, Wicked!  Okay.  Here's the chronology..  I
am sitting around doing my thing when MikeD gives me a page and wants to
hook up for the party, he's down from Connecticut for the Lacrosse games
at UMD.  Anyhow, he pops on by and we jet on down to commercial club
central (The Edge, Tracks, etc..).  Parking is hell, but that was expected.

It's about 11 when we show up and there is a huge line at the Edge across
the street, a long line at Big Top and very few people inside the fenced
off area.  The space is the back parking lot of Tracks, fenced off from
the rest of the world and huge tent (without walls) is set up.  Under the
tent is a portable wooden dance floor set up over the asphalt, all the
sound equipment and DJ stuff is set up at the back corner, up against the
Tracks back wall.  There are concessions on either side of the dance
floor and some sitting pyramids set up for, well, sitting.  :)

The fun started in the line as a man with the biggest platforms I have
ever seen (either that or stilts) walks up and down the line making
balloon hats for everyone.  That just set the tone for the party for me.
Anyhow we get up to the front of the line and are joined by Jenn and
Mike/Inhuman.  They check ID's and send us back into the pat down area
(which consisted of a tap on the pockets and being sent to the ticket
lady, very nice).  First people I see are Scott Henry and Duncan
(Charlottesville) and they are just all up and on life, great vibe
spreading out around them.  I start walking around and seeing and talking
to people.  That was great to experience because everyone seemed so really
into the vibe.

First things first and I go pay homage to the
little-beat-god-who-lives-in-big-black-boxes-and-has-long-tail.  Dance
floor is smooth and easy to dance on, really nice setup.  Lieven is
spinning and he has this hardish trance set going on and I just start
going in and warming myself up.  Okay, achieve the muscle relaxing, body
high feeling and go to let my clothes dry out (I do sweat a bit, don't I).
And that is pretty much how the rest of the night went for me.  I would
dance hard for a half hour, then dance softly and talk and drink and
(occasionally, very occasionally) sit and rest.  It was alot of fun.
People I didn't know would walk up at random and just strike up
conversations, people I knew did the same.  There was this happy feely
vibe all over the place.  Alot of diversity in the crowd with all sorts of
subcultures (punks, club kids, bondage kids, queers, rastafarians, SF folk
and a whole lotta DC scenesters).

The music was incredible of course.  Lieven livened the space, but the
crowd didn't even arrive until after his set.  Scott Henry fucking THREW
ME INTO THE SKY!  Incredible set, just incredible, I cramped but I
couldn't stop dancing to it!  Then came Marky Mark (really nice guy, if
not quite as net-connected as I thought) with well, I can't describe it
but to say "Wow..".  Garth and then Jeno (I finally completed my quest to
make him smile) were (again the pun) WIKKED!  *sigh*  I just wish I had
more adjectives and adverbs to devote to them.  But I think you get my
meaning.

Okay, with all good things, there are of course drawbacks.  First, water.
OUTRAGEOUS!  Okay, $3 for the TINY bottles of water, $1.50 sodas, $.75 for
blowpops.  They were also serving alcohol (but no one seemed to be
drinking, thank goodness).  Now I know why that cotton candy was free, so
you would get thirsty from it and buy water.  And then no spout to refill
the water bottles (made me think of how Rise was giving out water the
entire night before).  That was a jyp.  Second, the sound system wasn't as
clear and crisp as I associate with Scott.  Not that it wasn't good, just
that it got muddy at the low bass ranges.  It didn't make much of a
difference most of the time, but on certain tracks I just went
"Whadefuq?".

Drug use actually seemed really cool.  There were alot of people E'ing and
smiling and touching and grooving.  Thankfully the bar didn't get much
business and actually looked to have closed at some point.  But then
again, most of the people who drank left early.  I saw almost no powder
drugs and crystal kids running around.  I did see one person snorting that
poison.  He didn't dance, he couldn't talk, he couldn't make simple
decisions, he was fucked to the point of stupidity.  But I guess that's
what is associated.  When I talked to him it was like there was a rip in
the vibe at the party that just split and went around him, it was almost
tangible.  Very sad.  But there was just that one appearance of the 'raves
as drug purchase point' crew as far as I saw.

Anyhow, the party was very well attended by Net folks..  I was glad to
see:  Omar (nice to finally meet you), Paul (raver in the White House,
raver in the White House), Wendy Converse (so that's who you are!), Shawn
Willis, Karin, Mark Pflaging, MikeD, Jenn Ladd, Mike/Inhuman, Derrick
(send the tshirt to Marky Mark! :) ), Derrick (congrats on taking over the
SE Raves web site), Peekay (better luck next time), Ron, the woman with
Ron that I just can't recall the name of, Karin v2, Jenka, Sean/Kodak (and
little Bro), Baggadonuts, Dana and the multitude of people my poor memory
isn't grasping just now.  And of course Scott Henry and Marky Mark, nice
to have you folks on the net.

Dan

,._-_  < \, \\/\  _-_        _____ anarchy@eng.umd.edu  ~~~~~---____  Peace
 ||    /-|| || | || \\  _+--=         __                              Love
 ||   (( || || | ||/   _             _            ~~       =          Unity
 \\,   \/\\ \\/  \\,/  ~~~~~          |            danFREELove        Respect

From: "[[[DAMAGE]]]" <fill@DEEP13.SLIP.UMD.EDU>
Subject:      big top
Comments: To: dcraves@american.edu
To: Multiple recipients of list DCRAVES
              <DCRAVES@LISTSERV.AMERICAN.EDU>

the music sucked.  but it's cool talking to people who were like "the music is
SO good!"  it got better towards the end (the last song was BOMB!) when the dj
started to drop a breakbeat and really good house.  by then i could hardly stand
i was so tired.  on the whole the party was phat.  i had a great time, everyone
i talked to was like "it's much better than i thought it would be."
 
it seems to me the frisco sound is as wack as baltimore.  oh well, it's
danceable, sort of.  4-5 times throughout the night i would hear a phat beat and
would think "finally i'm going to lose it" then just i went to groove the beat
drop out or change.  maybe it was coincidence, but it pissed me off.
 
a DC party at tracks (more or less) that was serving alcohol and charging 3
bones for h2o and was still phat... is a might phat party!
 
props
philip aka Mr. Typo

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: "Albert G. Boulanger" <aboulanger@LDGO.COLUMBIA.EDU>
Subject:      Purple Party People (read this!)
X-To:         UrbnGROOVE@aol.com, ne-raves@umdd.umd.edu, nyc-raves@netcom.com
To: Multiple recipients of list NE-RAVES <NE-RAVES@UMDD.UMD.EDU>
In-Reply-To:  UrbnGROOVE@aol.com's message of Mon,
              29 May 1995 09:58:54 -0400 <950529095850_15674072@aol.com>

      However since I do enjoy elaborating; I'd like to start off my shpiel by
   saying as a promotor, I have many dreams and aspirations for the New York
   scene and urban dance culture. All that I ever hoped for, every ambition I
   ever laid forth, was realized on Sunday May 28th by Primary productions.

I wish I had more energy last night -- I was skating at the Skaters
Reunion in Central Park earlier so i was a bit drained, but WOW! I
think the magic was the nexus of past positive vibes of 15 years or
more of dance skaters who made the Roxy their home and the past
positive vibes of Primary productions. Since I did not have my regular
dance energy, I soaked in the scene a little more than usual and
seeing the floor in action was amazing.

      Forget the fact that it was held at a night club. Forget the number of
   people under that roof. This party was at times unrivaled. It was
   Indescribable. Time after time last year I went to Sound Factory and said to
   myself 'this is what rave should be'. Thanks to Primary I was able to see
   that. Finally the rave scene had its Sound Factory.

Not being very mystical I must say however there must be someting to
persistance of past vibes and the catching of ones offered by other
folks. There were many elements present that could of made this a bad
rave, but it seems that people for the most part TRANSCENDED these
elements to achieve the common vibe present -- rallied on by the
music. Why folks trascended last night is an interesting question.


Creating the Vibe,
Albert Boulanger








   =)

boston (one of whom had never been to a party before), and phat times were
had by all. i danced with so many people (thank you all, you all vibed me

From: Kenny Eng <ke0w+@ANDREW.CMU.EDU>

i didn't enjoy purple as much as i expected too. but it was just way too
crowded at the roxy. seems like they were selling tickets even though
more than 2000 people were packed in there.

even when i left at 7am, there were people sprawled all over the place,
on the dancefloor, behidn the bars, in the jungle room, by the
coatcheck. it was just too crowded to dance continuously for more than
5minutes without being bumped into.

but the jungle room was the place to be if you go tired of the wicked
crew. btw, does anyone know who was spinning when on the main floor?
they played i am ready at least twice.  overload and odi just turned the
jungle room upside down with mc panik on the mic.

kenny

From: "herae@inch.com" <Terminata_Ed@INCH.COM>
Subject:      PURPLE: What a BLAST!
X-To:         NE-RAVES@UMDD.UMD.EDU
To: Multiple recipients of list NE-RAVES <NE-RAVES@UMDD.UMD.EDU>

To start, I just want to thank all the NE-Ravers that I met and absolutely
enjoyed the company of all afternoon and night. More than I've ever felt
before, last night made it clear to me that we are truly a tribe. You guys
have PLUR oozing out of your pores, and I *love* being part of this. ***Out of
Control!***

I didn't think that many people would show up at Tompkins Sq Park in the
afternoon, because of all the confusion over where/whether/when it would
happen. But a good 25-30 people showed up- NE-Ravers, vRavers, and others.
Lotsa socializin' and watching this yoga guy do all sorts of contortions and
balance tricks. With the inclement weather (like that word?), we split up to
various people's apartments- some to Cyberslut's (Hi honey!), and a bunch of
others to Jon Speakman's. That was a trip: a friend of jon's came over and
spun for a while. So there were 13 men in his apartment DANCING!!! When the
hell does that ever happen?

PURPLE was terrific. The dancefloor was huge, and **all night** it was
completely covered with people dancing. Lotsa other stuff going on, I guess,
but that doesn't matter, 'cuz there was so much dancing. I didn't find the
music in the beginning too exciting, very inconsistent. But from about 1am
'til the end, intense House music blasted all nite long from the kick-ass
likes of Tiga, Garth, and Gano. Acid house, deep house, tribal house, all
sorts of house, but that was the order of the day. And the NE-Raves corner was
absolutely the epicenter of the vibe. Smiles to: John, a couple of Matts, Mike
Gee, Taj, Dylan, Terrence, Zoinks, Cyberslut, Amber, Heather, Andrew, June,
Junglist DBF, and Nicole(you'll kick me another time if I didn't mention
everyone). By the way, folks, I think we'll have a good handful of new
additions to the list pretty soon.

Bless you all for a terrific vibe. How was the afterhours, by the way?

Peace, and much PLUR,

     *********************************************
     **    "Like Ma Bell,            **    Terminata Ed, NYC
     **        I got the ill communication"    **    herae@inch.com
     **            -Beastie Boys, 1994    **
     *********************************************

From: mike gee <mg162@COLUMBIA.EDU>
Subject:      Re: PURPLE: What a BLAST!
To: Multiple recipients of list NE-RAVES <NE-RAVES@UMDD.UMD.EDU>
In-Reply-To:  <199505291957.AA14556@mailhub.cc.columbia.edu>

Damn....my ears are still ringing and my brain is a little bit frazzled
from all the excitement of the last 24 hours...
but never before in my short career of raving life have I had more fun
than I did last night at Purple,yesterday afternoon at the picnic and
hanging out with all the Net-Ravers that descended on NYC for the day.  I
won't embarass myself and try to remember all the names of the people I
met- but you are all wonderful.  Nobody kicks it like Ne-ravers: hands
down :)
But on to Purple...I got there at 10:30 and managed to get inside
instantly (I hate sneaking in lines, but my friend Liz knew someone right
up in front.) And getting in early made a world of difference...I got to
see the Roxy all clean and empty, a huge dancefloor to run around on and
get siked up for. And I didn't sit there and stew on the line...it
totally killed Voyager II for me and I wasn't going to let this party be
a dissapointment.
But there was no possible way this would be dissapointing- not with the
amazing music being artfully mixed and played all night long. Tiga was
tearing it up when I got in with some really wicked acid.  I didn't
really like Joeski's slowy house, but the vibe was just beginning to pick
up inside. And then at 1 am....Garth came on. I will never forget the
first record he played- that beautiful kick-snare-hgih hat drum track
that seems to go with every record the Wicked crew played, with a
ridiculous bongo/percussion solo on top of it. Garth slowed it down for
about a half hour, bookending the slow parts with 'I am Ready'. When he
played the second part of I am ready, the one where it builds and builds
and builds, I thought the roof was going to come off...amazing energy and
feeling.
Garth gave way to Jeno around 2:30, who was definitely the highlight of
the Wicked crew for me. He was much more trancey and electro-funk, and
from 2:30 to 4 shit was just blowing up continuously. I was having the
best time...runniung around dancing with the ne-ravers, my friends from
school, and even a bunch of old high school friends who were there. ANd
not a dissapointed face in the entire Roxy..
sure it was crowded, but I couldn't focus on that at all. It was crowded
but everyone was dancing, none of that fucked-up wandering around that
goes on.
Markie Mark spun from about 4 until 6ish...and he just pushed everyone
onto another level.  I couldn't believe how amazing the music was...and
so much of it depended on the DJ.  June is right- it's all in the mixing.
The way these DJs manipulated the crowd, slowly brought them up and up
and up the whole night, you just don't see that with East Coast DJs.
Perhaps we need longer sets in the east...so the DJs have more time to
work a vibe, instead of just throwing on their best records in a hurry.
But the Wicked crew are just true craftsmen...incredible mixing. And I
love those records...so much more natural than the sometimes mechanical
trance and acid that everyone loves in the east. These records had great
percussion, shjimmering hgih hats and snares, floating ethereal
keyboards, crazy vocal samples and chanting...
Thomas finished the night with great morning music...even more
progressive, but a little more contemplative maybe. EVeryone was
realizing what a great night they had had.  Finally, at 7:30 the lights
came on, and everyone cheered. It was a totally great night.

Props to Primary- they really delivered on the promise of the flyer for a
'vibe-oriented' party. This was really pretty no-frills: here are 6 fat
DJs, here is the dance floor, let's all get busy and have a great time.
Scotto's lights were great...really in synch with the vibe of the DJs.
I'm sorry that we don't hear music like this more on the East coast...for
all those who thought that Purple would be 'too mellow' or put them to
sleep: I'm sorry that you missed out.  It's SO MUCH MORE than just the
tempo or the style of the music...these DJs know what the spirit of
raving is all about.  I can't wait to goto San Francisco for the
summer...not only for the Wicked crew, but for all the other wonderful
DJs who have yet to get recognized over here. I'm sure their music is
just as soulful as Wicked.

I hope the afterparty was great. I would have loved to hear DJ Spun, but
Alan told me it was on Ludlow street. and I was facing a subway ride back
to the bronx....I feel like I could still be vibing and grooving right now.
__________________________________________________________________________
| mg162 @ columbia . edu  _______   a knife, a fork, a bottle and a cork: |
| michael  d  gwertzman   _______   that's the way we spell New York.     |

From: Dylan Drazen <ddrazen@LIII.COM>
Subject:      PURPLE/review (bigred anti-review)
X-To:         ne-raves@umdd.umd.edu
To: Multiple recipients of list NE-RAVES <NE-RAVES@UMDD.UMD.EDU>

We first decided to go to big red.. We were just more into the lineup..
Yep, I love house, I spin house, but when I go to a party I wanna lose it
to TECHNO.  But none to be heard..  As TWR man said, fire marshall bob
payed us a visit, said wassup, shut the shit down..  I'm really glad I
didn't fork over the 18 bux for presales, and I think I'm going to start
showing up at parties later and later in fear of paying the cover and two
hours later the party gets busted..I see the trend of presale tickets
going away if shit keeps up like this.  Fortunately, we didn't pay jack..
We got in the car and reluctantly headed over to the Roxy...

    Purple.  We got online at about midnight and waited nearly 1.5
hours in the rain to get in...  We got in, payed some cash, and I went
into a club.. Whoever said that rave finally got its soundfactory is
right.. To me, this felt like just another night at the roxy with a
different crowd.  BUT, I still had fun.  I was hearing mostly hard house
(green velvet's new one sounded solid on that system), but then heard
some progressive slow breaks start to seep in my head, so we decided to
chill in the jungle room.. It was waaay to crowded to dance in the
"lounge", so people just stood around and kinda watched.. some danced.
Overload finished his set and next it was Odi's turn.. What can I say?
He blew shit up in there.. never before have I seen such skilful
manipulation of jungle records.. He cut, scratched, transformed, phased,
you name it..it was just a trip to watch him..and when he got on the
mic..heh let's just say he's the frankie bones of jungle..  Ok, so I got
bored again..  Off to the main room once again (it's now like 5:30 or
something).
    So we're in there at 5.30ish, there's some pretty non-melodic
vocal stuff being played..I'm not too into it.. All of a sudden, (whoever
was spinning) someone dropped the 24 hr experience track, and I got extremely
happy.. FINALLY, some deep melodic house for these ravers to hear.. hehe san
fran djs bring NY house to, well, NY.. kinda funny.

>From 5:30 until about 7:30 the djs kicked my fucking ass all over (to
coin a jerky boys phrase).. WHO was spinning then?  I'm pretty sure at
around 7ish it was joeski.. his slow dark tribal stuff always moves me..
So, after the deep house (loved that barry white track..it WAS barry
white right?) I heard some electro-funky-acidhouse.. this just sent me in
a tizzy.. to anyone who might have seen me, I was the skinny white kid in
the freeze shirt towards the back finally letting lose at 6:45am..  Does
anyone realize that a Jodeci song was played?  I was just so happy, but I
was not at a r*ve, I was at a club having a good time.  Really, I'm from
NY, I've been to NY house clubs before and this just felt the same way..

So it was a tad overcrowded, but the main floor was so huge I always
found a spot to dance.. i mostly hung around the back area.. The vibe was
nice and positive.. no crack babies..while I was on line some dick asked
me if I needed any e or krystal..

I'm glad I made it to the picnic beforehand as well.. like one of my ol'
skool bbs user meets, but you guys were cooler.. Peace 2 phated, zoinks,
stefan, jill(unrest), wendyk, grant (thanks for the water), nicole, deknow,
taj(phatvibes), dori(cyberslut), matt, matt, that guy at the park twisting his
body up, alan s, terence, liquid todd, benny, ana, kj, tallpaul, osheen,
mikegee, john speakman for so kindly letting many of us hang at your pad,
musicboy for the music, the whole boston crew (those whom I haven't
mentioned), and to so many others I'm sure I've forgotten.

Taj, thanks for playin yer boombox w/ that cool english acid leaking into
the ears of the peons walking down the streen in the village.  That was
probably the best feeling I got all day.  This mass tribe just headin
down to Speakmans with strangers staring at us like we were crazy, and
what the fuck was coming out of Taj's radio.

I was really lookig forward to big red, but Purple (for me) was a good
second choice and I'm glad I went and finally let off some STEAM!!

Thanks, Primary.. you delivered that trademark primary vibe once again,
and it was a solid party.

-Dylan.

                                           \__/

To: Vladimir Katz <vekatz@ucdavis.edu>, "John S. Lee" <jsl@netcom.com>
Subject: Re: Bay Area record stores...
Cc: Fred Heutte <phred@well.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I *don't* touch the record surface with my fingers after I buy mine,
except right at the outer edge maybe, and in the run-out area in the
center to push or drag.  Actually, I probably push on the label more
than anything.  Records collect a lot of dust and crud anyway, so
why make it worse, right?  But actually, it's as much an esthetic thing
as anything.  Fingerprints on vinyl just look bad.  

The exception comes with scratching.  Good scratch DJs are all over their
vinyl, and they tell me they can do hundreds of plays off the same discs
without too much noticeable degradation.  OK, that makes sense.  

So, it may not be all that crucial, but I just prefer to keep the recording
surfaces clean and clear of fingerprints.

phred

Subject: Lollapalooza: Nocturnal Adventure "ENIT"

Hello, folks.  I am writing to all of you today about an interesting project
that will come to almost every major city in America this summer.

Lollapalooza will be featuring a special rave festival that will take place
after the actual event.

This event will usually be off-site in a more suitable location and last all
night (well, at least past 4).

My questions to you are as follows:

1. If you are interested in helping out please continue reading.

2. We would love to hear suggestions about:
      - What would be the best talent line up? (pick your top three)
      - Where would be the best location in your city? (It has to be legal
and close to the Lolla site; the Lolla sites will be posted tomorrow)
      - Who are the most dependable promoters in your cities to help out with
the local promotion and/or production?

3.  Please e-mail any of your thoughts to: KingFishPB@aol.com


Thanks and Peace to all.

Subject: Funky Tekno Tribe

hey everyone,

  last week in my speech class i tried to describe to the other students
how dancing made me feel, and how it can release make me feel like im
at a "higher state of consciousness" =)  but on most of the reviews of 
the speech, students thought i was talking about dancing being a good
stress releaver.  

  oh well... :P

  on saturday night i once again accended to that "higher state of
consciousness". thanks to dj dan and tony and mark farina
  the party got off to a slow start.  we got there around 12 and had
to wait in line for about an hour.  They were taking away people's
candy at the door so i gave away my blow pops in the line but kept
a few in a bag which i was able to sneak into the arena.
  When we got inside we missed dj marcus, the jungle dj.  from what
i heard not a lot of people danced anyways to it.  that sucks.
  barry weaver was on next.  his music was brain dead and boring.
this simple four/four hard beats with a tinge of acid and electro
thrown in every once in awhile.  it didnt really go anywhere.
  but then dj dan came on. 
  he immediately built up the vibe.  i started dancing from his first
song, and then i kept going on and on and on.  i couldnt stop.  the
vibe was SOOOOO THICK!!!  people bugging out grooving and moving and
dancing and absorbing it.  
  when dan finished up,  tony came on.  i was skeptical that he could
keep the groove going on. but he kicked it on!!  i just spent most
of tony's set bugging out in front of the bass bins groovin and bobbin'
and feeling the bass move my body.  it was intense.  
  finally after dancing for about three hours, i took a break cause
i needed it :) but caught the last half hour of mark farina's set which
was nice to hear house after the techno trancy acid stuff all night. 

  so it was a nice night :)  and i got lost in the dancing and the friendly
vibe of the party.  

  although the music and vibe and location was nice, there were 
some bad items also.
  the lights wern;t the most incredible, the sound was a bit 
distorted, there wasnt a chill out room and not able to bring in
water or bottles or candy.  

  but cause of the music ill over look it this time

sfravers in the house:  john, and dan from cal poly.  who else was there?

peace

doug ) ( doug@squishy.com

Well here is the progress report boys and girls.  I just got back from an 
extremely enlightening trip.  I have some bad news.  July 4th is not a 
doable date for this event.  Due to large amounts of snowfall there is 
still 5-6' snow everywhere.  We couldn't even get into the site.  Since 
we could not guarantee a July 4 open road date it has been decided to 
move it back.  Ugghhh...I can hear the groans now.  DO NOT WORRY I WILL 
DO EVERYTHING IN MY POWER TO SEE THAT THIS THING DOES GO OFF IN A BIG 
WAY.  I met somebody this weekend in LA (actually Bix met someone too 
but...ughhmmm....that is another story) who is really in touch with the 
socal scene.  She has really helped me out and I think we could get some 
money backing (he would donate it hopefully) and stuff.  I am also may 
have contact to several big name DJs in the San Diego and LA area.  This 
along with the hopeful help of some wonderful (Adder and Mike I really 
must thank you guys for missing Sunset just to check out an essentiall 
dead site and thanks Mike for letting us crash at your place) people from 
San Fran could make for a terrific show.  Plus I cannot leaver out  the 
helpful people from Davis who have show me support as well (hopefully we 
can include a bunch of people from your scene too).  I would like to 
includ Santa Barb. (espec. Justice if at all possible) but this will take 
a lot of work.  Anyway we are still working on some new dates we have 2 
main ideas...last weekend of July or the weekend of Sept 23 (Autumn 
Solstice...cool possibilities).   Which do you guys like better?   Is 
there a conflict with another MAJOR rave that you know about?  If so 
please tell me and it will effect my decision.  Well I haven't had but 
about 5 hours sleep since Sat. morning so I will start to rap it up.  
Hmmm, I would like to say thanks to all the people who helped out the 
"Glade-runners" (AirGregor thanks for both of the things you provided one 
was extremely essential (talk to me later about the trick I worked on it) 
and the other (a camping stove) was unfortunately useless.  Thanks to bix 
for keeping this tired boy awake.  Thanks Chuen for letting us semi-crash 
at your place b4 reactor...and of course BlackAdder and Mike Clay to kind 
souls who need no praise for actions speak louder then words).  Well I 
gotta really be going now because I am seemingly levitating out of my 
seat and flying through the air....btw no I am not really on much of 
anything.  The cool thing about hallucinations due to lack of sleep is 
supposedly much more intense and different then any other bcause it is 
natural and more powerful.  happy journeys to all....talk to y'all later 
when I am "myself" (whatever that is..hehehehehehe) again!

One last thing, the name has been changed to MILE HIGH.  Howdya guys like it?

*** I SINCERELY APOLOGIZE FOR ALL THE HEADER CRAP ***
*** I AM GONNA SET UP A LISTSERV SOON SO BEAR WITH***
*** ME!  IF SOMEONE COULD HELP WITH THAT, IT WOULD***
*** BE GREAT!***


	-Christian

From: Crossjam <xjam@bdt.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: A Plug for Primal
Reply-To: xjam@bdt.com
Date: Wed, 31 May 1995 00:27:42 +0000
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

They don't really need it that much but Rob and Barry at Primal have been
hooking me up for the last 2 years or so. I was on record buying hiatus for
the past five months. Rob still pulled records for me, let me get on
the front decks, and treated me just like name brand DJs. They play stuff
over the phone for out of town DJs. I can't say for sure they don't pull
shit out of peoples bags but I can't imagine Rob and Barry doing
that. You can get the cheesiest diva house, the burliest acid tracks and
just about everything in between.

They don't keep a huge backstock, so don't show up expecting them to have
every cut you ever wanted plus some new phat tracks thrown in. But if you
put in a few appearances and get to know them I'm sure you'll get the same
service.

A satisfied customer.

Strictly Rhythm			xjam@bdt.com

>for it).  I took the whole package (just to be safe), and drank a lot of 
>water (which was recommended).  I definately felt it, but it certainly 
>didn't feel anything like the genuine artifact. It made me feel very 
>awake and energetic, and it seemed to heighten tactile sensation a

I took that shit one time. I took two to be exact. It felt like
"Mini-thins", kinda speedy for a while.  The feeling was never that great,
then I had to go pee and......brace yourself......I pee'd then as I was
pushing the last drops out I ejaculated.......no feeling, no woody just a
bunch of white stuff in the toilet.....I wouldn't recommend it to
anyone.....and I certainly won't be trying it again.

Rick

Received: from qmmac by virgil (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA02564; Wed, 31 May 95 10:30:26 PDT
Message-Id: <n1410206265.49748@qmmac>
Date: 31 May 1995 10:25:03 -0800
From: "Mark Camp" <mark_camp@qmmac.emu.com>
Subject: Jamiroquai at Bimbo's
To: "sfraves" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
X-Mailer: Mail*Link SMTP/QM 3.0.0
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Subject:Jamiroquai at Bimbo's

If you didnt go to Jamiroquai at Bimbo's last night, have someone kick you
really hard in the butt.   This was with out a doubt, the best show I've been
to, ever! These guys were great.  We showed up right before they started, I
think it was around 9:30 or so and managed to make our way up to the front. 
They started off with Revolution from their first album.  They had 11 guys on
stage; singer, bass, guitar, keys, 3 guys playing horns, drums, percussion, a
DJ, and a guy playing a digereedoo (SP?) on a few songs.  We were standing
right under this guy!   The highlight of the show, well, the whole show was a
highlight, but one part that really sticks out in my mind was after they took
a short break, they came back on and did this very trancey digereedoo (jeez,
how do you spell that anyway?!) jam.  The DJ was doing these strange scratchs
that were running through a delay that made it sound really ghostly.  The
band as a whole were very tight and man could they groove.  They played for
about 2 hours which was way too short.  Everyone was waiting for more.  

This was also my first visit to Bimbo's.  Its a very 'Posh' club.  Chandelier
on the ceiling, plush red carpet, statues everywhere.  Didnt get to see the
girl in the fish tank though.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed May 31 13:09:31 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id NAA05964; Wed, 31 May 1995 13:09:31 -0700
Received: from is2.NYU.EDU by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with SMTP id NAA05954; Wed, 31 May 1995 13:09:27 -0700

	id AA22006; Wed, 31 May 1995 16:09:26 -0400
Date: Wed, 31 May 1995 16:09:25 -0400 (EDT)
From: "June K. Eaton" <jke2880@is2.NYU.EDU>
To: Doug Zimmerman <doug@hyperreal.com>
Cc: sfraves@squishy.com
Subject: Wicked in NYC
In-Reply-To: <Pine.BSI.3.91.950530195800.27975B-100000@taz.hyperreal.com>
Message-Id: <Pine.OSF.3.91.950531151459.23762A-100000@is2.NYU.EDU>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


WOW!!!!!
A dream of mine became a reality on Sunday night at the Roxy
here in New York City.  San Francisco came to New York.
All of my new friends here, all these months looking at
me with a cynical eye for the last six months since I moved here...
what's this psychedelic freaker princess from san francisco TALKING about.

Well they found out.  People dancing harder than they ever
had before, the joy of watching...it was indescribable...
these friends of mine...all net-ravers and vravers...
cradle their heads in their hands saying...
OH MY GOD I HAVE *NEVER* HEARD THIS KIND OF MUSIC IN MY LIFE!!!!

I am sure I was the only raver from San Francisco in attendance
and it was UNBELIEVABLE....I mean so incredibly WONDERFUL to
have for *one night* my two worlds--New York and San Francisco
fuse into one beautiful magical union.  Garth, Jeno, Markie
and Thomas tore open a porthole into another dimension that
New York City had NEVER seen until Sunday night.

For my own reasons I am so incredibly thankful that Mello asked
Wicked to come to NYC.....finally for some UNDERSTANDING.  
It may be selfish, but in one night about fifty people instantly
and finally understood who I am and where I come from....
and I was never in my whole life so happy to lead my friends
right into what I knew they always wanted and never knew it
until the last.  

Another miracle that has been created, or is beginning to be
created, is a new vision for the scene in New York City. 
I don't know if Garth when he was dancing in the crowd during
Markie's set was aware of the miracle that was happening all
around him...that he was witnessing, taking part in, and who
knows maybe even partly responsible for the vibiest party
that has ever happened in this city.  All he said to me
was "Yeah..I always wanted to play in New York".  I had to
laugh.  I felt like the singular witness....and I could
barely grok all that was happening....the music I have
missed for so long taking me back to that *place*...plus
watching all my friends completely lose their heads.

IT'S MIND CONTROL!!!  IT'S MIND CONTROL!!!!
Those were the words most often coming out of everyone's
mouths when Markie went on and managed to rip apart the
fabric of reality and take these people to levels they
had never even considered could exist.

I could go on for days to try to navigate and describe the
journey that the Wicked boys took us on...but I see that
someone has already posted to sfraves some reviews from
my fellow ne-ravers...a good cross-section.  Though it's
only Tuesday and people are still recovering...I think
people are STILL trying to make sense of what happened to
them that night.

It was beautiful.  It was a dream come true for me.  It
was a DAMN good excuse to hang out for two weeks after
finals before coming home for the summer (though I heard
Sunset went OFF - yay!).  But most of all, I think it was
the greatest gift that could have been given to the New
York scene, to really see that the vibe exists within
and its there...it can happen and it did!!!  I think it
has refueled so much energy and vibe and excitement of
possibilities back into the New York scene.  And I feel
very priveleged to have been a witness to it.

I know this post is very long....I'm coming back to San
Francisco on Thursday for the whole summer....Sunset
here I come and I get my fix every sunday all summer
long!!! (P.S. June 18th is Galen's b-day and after
that sunsets will be weekly again!!)   
I'm so excited and happy I don't know what
to do with myself.  Except prepare for a TON of east
coast people about to pour into my house to check out
the San Francisco vibe that has infected them to the core
through my pictures (of sunsets all last summer) and finally
with this party, Wicked at the Roxy.

See you all soon,

HOUSE NATION UNITE!!!!!

LOVE LOVE LOVE LOVE LOVE!!!!!   WOW    MIRACLES!!!!!

June
jke2880@is2.nyu.edu
junie e - vrave

			    NOW.
		  This is our secret weapon.
		    This is how to do it.
		       And its groovy.

sfravers are the best.  I just want all of you to know that the 20+
responses to my distress signal have me flying high as a kite.  Things
started to change with my first message (Thanks again and again Lee).  This
just goes to show that the positive energy of the rave scene and any energy
for that matter can be transmitted regardless of time or space.  I can't see
any of you, and I don't know where any of you are, but I can feel your love.
I think it also goes to show that it's sometimes a good thing to ask for
help.  You don't always have to be alone.  Tons-o-people are out there to
give you a helping hand.  I love all you wonderful boys and grrls, men and
womyn.  Thanks soooo much for all your support.  I'm going to go home now
and write some music. PLUR.

Rick

> In cases of typical raver jaw-clenching, the other kind is probably
> safer.  And more fun, too!

	You've actually made a very important point and thanks for 
bringing to my attention. Mercory based thermometers as far as ravers on 
E are concerned are definately contraindicated, meaning don't usem. If 
you break one in you mouth, not only to you have the heat related injury, 
but mercory posioning as well, its real deadly stuff. Use Semiconductor 
Digital based thermometer, much safer and more acturate, and easier to 
read,especially in low light conditions. Thanks Lee.
